"The culinary offerings were of exceptional quality, particularly during the warmest season of the year when the establishment boasted a meager clientele comprising six individuals, including two habitual patrons who appeared to be inebriated. The proprietress engaged in vociferous conversations with all present within the confines of the edifice, leaving an indelible impression that these individuals frequented the premises on a daily basis, deriving a sense of existential satisfaction from their nocturnal sojourns. Personally, I shall refrain from revisiting the venue until the advent of avian creatures heralds a more cacophonous ambiance, rendering the aural experience less oppressive. As for the proprietor, it remains unclear what measures could be undertaken to address the issue, aside from the cessation of alcoholic beverages to such imbibing enthusiasts."

"I must confess that drafting this update has proven to be an arduous task for me, as I had previously harbored a profound affection for Apple Spice; however, the recent sequence of events has unfortunately led me to reassess my stance. Specifically, the last three instances in which we opted to procure lunch from their establishment have been marred by an unfortunate succession of errors. It is my conviction that for an enterprise that offers catering services, the successful execution of merely ten luncheons should not be an excessively formidable endeavor.

In today's instance, two individuals opted for bread bowls, only to receive a minuscule container of soup accompanied by a solitary slice of bread, which falls short of meeting the definition of a bread bowl. Furthermore, both myself and one of my vegan colleagues placed orders for the southwestern salad, expressly specifying that cheese should be excluded from the dish. Nonetheless, the salads were delivered with chicken, and the menu explicitly indicates that an additional fee of $1 is required for this protein component. This blatant oversight necessitated the replacement of the incorrect items, including the southwestern salads and bread bowls, as well as the provision of an extra plate of cookies.

While Apple Spice did exhibit a commendable level of accommodation in rectifying the mistakes, the recurrence of such errors has rendered me utterly exasperated. The prices charged by this establishment are, in my opinion, somewhat prohibitive, and the subpar quality of the southwestern salad only serves to compound my disappointment. Moreover, the prolonged delay incurred due to the erroneous preparation of orders has a tendency to hinder my culinary indulgence for an extended period of time, which, in turn, engenders an added layer of frustration.

In light of these circumstances, I feel compelled to express my regret for Apple Spice, as their performance has fallen short of my expectations. Despite their laudable efforts to address the issues, the persistent nature of these mistakes leaves me no choice but to seek alternative dining options."

I was so excited when I found out Yalla was opening near my house- we were in need of a good Med Cuisine place there, and also, it is owned by Khoury's- my FAVORITE place to eat.  
We ordered a few things, the roasted chicken sandwich, Fatoush salad with Chicken, and the beef kabobs. 
The rice was out of this world! It has a little crispy thin noodles and a light oil.  The hummus was great and the Fatoush was so tasty.  My husband had no complaints about the sandwich..but we did have a couple downsides.  
The order was billed incorrectly.  And the cashier was very apologetic, but ended up billing me more, so that he didn't have to call his manager to fix it.  I felt that he should have just billed me the price he told me over the phone and comped his mistake.  Also, their Pita bread was not as good as i had hoped, tasted kind of old.  
I'll be back though.

UPDATE: 
I did come back, only to wait in line behind another customer for 10 minutes (at a counter btw) without so much as a "hello", or "sorry" from the cashier. The wait was so long becuase this woman could not get her order together and we were ignored so we just left. AWFUL SERVICE. Cashier should have acknowledged us, or offered to start our order while the customer ran out to her car, but no. Nothing. AWFUL! 
We went to Osaka across the street.

"In the company of a Chinese acquaintance, I embarked upon a culinary excursion to a local Chinese eatery, whereupon my companion, utilizing her native tongue, vociferously expressed her dissatisfaction with the appearance of one of the dishes that was presented to our table. Following this animated exchange, the quality of the cuisine was elevated to an exceptional level, surpassing my previous experiences with Chinese fare in Central Illinois. However, despite my ardent efforts to replicate this encounter, I have been unable to recapture the essence of that singular occasion. In light of this, I solicited the assistance of my Chinese associate, who graciously composed a written directive in her native language, specifying the precise dishes we had previously enjoyed. Unfortunately, even with this note in hand, the culinary offerings have consistently fallen short of their former excellence, leading me to surmise that the key factor in the superior quality of the food lay not in the menu items themselves, but rather in the spirited manner in which they were procured. With my friend now residing elsewhere, I fear that the gastronomic prowess of this establishment shall forever remain unrealized."

"Pros: 
* Rapid and accommodating provision of requested items, facilitating an optimal guest experience
* Beds characterized by exceptional comfort, contributing to a restful slumber
* Aesthetically pleasing soaking tub, albeit with limited capacity

Cons: 
* Lackluster demeanor exhibited by check-in staff, detracting from the overall welcome sentiment
* Absence of convenient power outlets near sleeping areas, necessitating the utilization of extension cords for medical equipment
* Misinformation regarding the availability of a freezer, leading to disappointment and inconvenience
* Limited options for purchasing beverages, resulting in reliance on overpriced in-room refrigeration
* Byzantine nature of room switches and illumination controls, hindering effortless navigation
* Bathroom sink design, seemingly intentionally engineered to maximize moisture dispersal and compromise the integrity of personal belongings

Comparative analysis: While both hotels offer palatable attributes, The Hotel enjoys a slight advantage in terms of overall quality and guest satisfaction, eclipsing Aria's drawbacks."

I had the pleasure of visiting a Brazilian steakhouse previously, in Dallas, and it was utterly sublime. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met at Braza's, as the quality of the food did not live up to its predecessor. While some of the meats were satisfactory, such as the flank steak and chicken, others like the sirloin were unimpressive and lacked flavor. Additionally, the ambiance of the restaurant was underwhelming, resembling more of a casual buffet than the upscale dining experience depicted on their website. Furthermore, the strong scent of Indian cuisine permeated the air, detracting from the authentic Brazilian taste we were anticipating. Notwithstanding, the customer service was quite commendable, as the staff exhibited warmth and enthusiasm towards ensuring our enjoyment. At approximately $40-45 per person, the cost seemed somewhat excessive for the caliber of the establishment, leaving me with the impression that there were superior options available for the price.

"The staff manager's demeanor and assistance are subpar, and their inventory rarely aligns with my expectations. Despite its proximity to my domicile, I shall resort to visiting a rival establishment to procure the items I require, as my previous attempts at this location have yielded unsatisfactory results."

"Well, I had held high anticipations for the culinary offerings at this establishment, subsequent to perusing the laudatory critiques. 
We were accommodated with remarkable celerity, yet our server, from the onset, comported himself in a manner suggestive of our presence being an imposition upon him. 
I opted for the scampi, which, alas, was somewhat overcooked, resulting in a regrettable incineration of the tails; however, the pasta and sauce accompanying it were quite palatable; my acquaintance, on the other hand, requested the cod, which, unfortunately, was excessively overcooked, prompting her to seek a fresh portion. 
As we approached the conclusion of our repast, we became cognizant of his lamentations, addressed to his colleagues (this was a decidedly vociferous conversation, as the staff members were situated behind the preparation area, en route to the kitchen), wherein he attributed our dissatisfaction with the fare to our own capricious nature. 
I, as well as my companion, shall not be returning, and we shall endeavor to dissuade our associates from patronizing this establishment, owing to the unremarkable cuisine and unprofessional demeanor of the staff."

I was compelled to dine at this establishment due to the temporary closure of Island Style, a restaurant I frequently visit, for renovations. Upon entering, I was struck by the unassuming ambiance, which did not augur well for an exemplary culinary experience. However, I chose to reserve judgment, focusing instead on the quality of the fare and hospitality. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the service was merely adequate, and the cuisine left much to be desired. Specifically, my spouse and I had to request the midday menu, which was not readily available. My primary grievance concerned the food, which lacked the robust flavors and vibrant hues characteristic of Sino-Asian delicacies. The pork and tofu hot pot was unremarkable, with an abundance of pork and a conspicuous absence of dynamic vegetation. Similarly, the shrimp pan-fried noodles were insipid and failed to impress. As a culinary expert myself, I can only surmise that the chefs at this venue have become complacent in their craft, resulting in an uninspired and unappetizing offering. In conclusion, my experience at this restaurant was thoroughly underwhelming, with nothing exceptional about the service and little to commend the food. It is unlikely that I shall return.

"The gastronomical offerings at this establishment are of satisfactory quality, however, our dining experiences have been marred by the evident lack of knowledge exhibited by the servers regarding the menu items and their constituents. Specifically, upon inquiring about the nature of Kenyan cuisine, our server was unable to provide a coherent response, offering instead an awkward and unhelpful comparison to American fare. Furthermore, when queried about the composition of Menudo, our server displayed a marked dearth of understanding, leading one of us to speculate that it might contain stomach, thereby underscoring the need for more effective staff training in order to enhance the overall dining experience and foster a truly informed and welcoming ambiance."

"When encountering an establishment promoting an 'All You Can Eat Sushi' option for a mere $19.95, one cannot help but harbor certain presuppositions regarding the quality of the culinary offerings. Specifically, the expectation is that the fare will be inferior and unremarkable. Unfortunately, this proved to be the case during my recent visit, as the sushi presented itself as lackluster and characterized by an excessive proportion of rice relative to the actual fish content within each roll. Therefore, it is advisable to avoid this particular promotion if gastronomical satisfaction is a priority. 

Conversely, my companion elected to sample the miso soup, which, at a cost of $4.50, delivered an unexpectedly generous portion. This was indeed a pleasant surprise. However, my own decision to eschew the sushi due to reservations about its quality led me to opt for the Ah Sin Fried Rice instead. Unfortunately, this alternative failed to impress, as it lacked discernible flavor. An order of Har Gow (shrimp dumplings) followed, which, while not exceptional, managed to surpass expectations. Notably, a pot of hot tea, intended to serve five individuals, carried an exorbitant price tag of $8.  

In conclusion, while certain menu items may prove satisfying, the overall experience falls short of expectations due to the underwhelming nature of the sushi and excessive pricing of complementary beverages."

La Condesa, I relinquish my expectations of satisfactory dining experiences at your establishment. Despite our persistent attempts to justify and overlook the shortcomings in the quality of service, it has become patently evident that such indulgence is no longer feasible. The sluggish pace and inattention to detail exhibited by your staff, coupled with an apparent lack of concern for the satisfaction of your clientele, have rendered the dining experience at your restaurant unworthy of further financial investment on my part. In light of these factors, I elect to redirect my resources elsewhere.

On this particular visit, we were disenchanted with the culinary offerings as well. We requested the return of our horchata due to its deficiency in both flavor and viscosity, only to be presented with new glasses after the completion of our meal. Furthermore, the aesthetically pleasing crema that you graciously bestowed upon my torta (or, as some might refer to it, lonche) posed a practical challenge in terms of its consumption, as it was impossible to discern a suitable method of lifting and consuming the dish without compromising its structural integrity.

While it is true that your cochinita pibil once brought us immense gastronomical delight, it unfortunately does not compensate for the multitude of shortcomings that have come to characterize the dining experience at your establishment. Indeed, the ambiance and cleanliness of your restaurant have been problematic in the past, yet we were willing to overlook such issues given the exceptional quality of certain menu items. However, the subpar service we have consistently encountered has reached a point where our tolerance can no longer be stretched.

"It is indeed a fortuitous circumstance that this establishment offers exceptional promotions on their protein-based products, as it serves as an inducement for me to frequent their premises, despite my reservations regarding the quality of their produce. The dairy products, in particular, appear to be consistently available at a reduced price point, which is a significant factor in my decision to procure them from this location. Furthermore, the meat and seafood departments often feature buy-one-get-one-free or buy-one-get-two-free deals, which present an opportunity too advantageous to ignore. However, I must express my dissatisfaction with the level of customer service provided by the staff, who often display a lack of cordiality and an apathetic attitude towards acknowledging patrons' presence. Moreover, the checkout process is unacceptably sluggish, consuming thrice the duration required at alternative retailers I visit. Notwithstanding these grievances, I shall persist in perusing their advertisements and taking advantage of their occasional bargains, while simultaneously maintaining my preference for alternate sources of grocery supplies."

Not my \"cup of tea\" -- too Yuppie for me!  Atmosphere way too \"sanitized\", and servers have little or no personality.  The food is fair but not worth the price IMHO!  What ever happened to pasta or pizza with RED sauce?  Seems they have every color and concoction known to man except red (well maybe one or two)- being of Italian descent I need red!!  I ordered from  the \"Small Bits Menu\" because I wanted a light lunch - believe me - it definitely was \"Small Bits\",  good thing they gave out bread because I needed a second helping of that just to let me know that I ate something!  My suggestion is to order from the dinner menu if you want a full meal - of course most folks are much more sophisticated than this old country boy and can figure out what most of the fancy California stuff is on the menu - sorry!

My morning repast and my paramour's culinary experience was utterly insipid. We had procured the waffles and the blueberry lemon pancakes, but unfortunately, the pancakes failed to exhibit even a hint of lemony flavor, while the waffles were merely average in quality. Despite the aesthetically pleasing presentation, I shall not be returning to this establishment.

The modified text is: Individuals afflicted with asthma or respiratory issues tend to avoid this establishment with an unwavering fervor, much like one would avoid a virulent contagion during an epidemic. The pervasive odor of inexpensive adolescent cologne permeates the atmosphere, creating an unpleasant ambiance that is reminiscent of a noxious miasma. Furthermore, the prices of the goods offered are exorbitant and the staff exhibits a remarkable lack of cognitive acuity, rendering them somewhat akin to a collection of inanimate objects. However, it is worth noting that this location does offer a commendable selection of reasonably priced men's sweatpants. To ensure an optimal shopping experience, it is advisable to purchase these items at a discounted price, and to subject them to a thorough cleansing process upon arrival at one's domicile, lest the lingering scent of the aforementioned cologne prove to be an enduring and unwelcome presence.

"Are you cognizant of the exasperation that arises from attempting to section a premium ribeye steak with a blade that lacks the requisite sharpness? My sole recollection of this culinary establishment revolves around the laborious process of manually sawing through my steak, an experience that left much to be desired."

"My visit to this establishment was predicated upon my desire to sample their signature tamales, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the culinary offerings were subpar and lacking in both flavor and temperature, with the additional disappointment of perfunctory and unengaged service."

Every time I play here something makes me angry. Today was slowness. Usually it's service and miserable people but today all staff I encountered were very nice. We played 13 holes in 3 hours and waited at least 5 minutes if not more per hole. Don't go here if you want to play a quick round and don't use the vending machine on the 4th hole. Wasted half my day waiting so we just left. I will say the greens were in excellent shape which is why I gave 2 stars not 1! I am a self proclaimed golf snob so I may be a little bit dramatic but when I pay $30 and barely get through half a round, this is what I have a problem with.

"Satisfactory service was proffered, albeit with some culinary inconsistencies, specifically pertaining to the doneness of the steaks, wherein two were requested to be prepared medium rare, yet one was received in a state between medium and medium well, while the other was barely cooked to an acceptable temperature, thus rendering it essentially raw; meanwhile, the ambiance was characterized by a high level of noise and activity, although our server demonstrated commendable dedication to her duties, and it is likely that, given more time, she would have endeavored to rectify the issues with our meals."
Why is it that no matter what time you come in it is always at least a 20 min wait? They need to hire more people.

I couldn't agree more with some of the reviews I've seen on here. This is not the Wahoo's you grew up with in Cali. The fish is very dry and the green sauce stuff they serve is like some gross watery sour cream and herb combo. 

I've been here a few times for drinks and there is a particular bartender that's horrible. (Sorry, I don't remember her name!) When watching a fight in a mostly empty bar she came on shift and turned down the volume on the television and then changed the channel to some reality show. I asked for it back on and was ignored.  

I've also been here on at least two other nights where her service was lacking because she was too busy chatting up a customer to serve us or even bring us the bill to get paid. I finally had to tell her we were walking out without paying to get her to do her job.

Avoid this location unless you want a mediocre fish taco with crappy service.

This supermarket, a Best of Las Vegas recipient since its inception, serves breakfast on weekends, thereby constituting our destination on a recent morning. I found the market to be comparable to Whole Foods, albeit with more moderate pricing. We placed our order at the counter and subsequently retired to a table in the piano room, whereupon the food was delivered. Our easy over eggs were accompanied by bacon, wheat toast, and home fries. While the quality of the ingredients was satisfactory, the pricing was somewhat prohibitive, and the execution left ample room for improvement. Specifically, the toast lacked the desired crispiness, the bacon was unacceptably limp, the potatoes appeared tired, and the egg whites were unpleasantly watery.

"Upon entering this establishment, I experienced an eerie sensation of familiarity, which was subsequently revealed to be a result of my previous visit to the identical buffet during its tenure at the Aladdin. The ambiance and layout of the restaurant were unremarkable, with a standard array of culinary stations offering a variety of international dishes. However, the absence of a considerable wait time, which I initially perceived as a positive aspect, ultimately proved to be an ominous portent. The cost of the buffet was exorbitant, the cuisine was merely passable, and the service we received from our server was abysmal, as she failed to attend to our needs subsequent to her hasty delivery of our orange juice. My experience at this buffet served as a stark reminder of the importance of conducting thorough research prior to selecting a dining establishment, as well as the potential consequences of neglecting to do so. In conclusion, I cannot in good conscience recommend this buffet to anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience."

"As customary, the rolled tacos failed to meet the standards of my initial experience, possessing a spongy texture in the center and displaying signs of inconsistent frying techniques, with certain areas seemingly untouched by the oil. Furthermore, the guacamole lacked the anticipated richness and creaminess, while the cheese on the rolled tacos remained unmelted, leading to an unpleasant dining experience. Additionally, the price point of $6.50, inclusive of tax, raised concerns regarding value for money, especially considering the availability of comparable options at more reasonable prices elsewhere. Even the consumption of alcohol could not salvage the meal's shortcomings."

Ah Aureole.  Lovely to look at, food divine.  Service?  Ridiculously bad.  Reservations at 930.  Get in, get seated.  Waiter disappears after leaving us with their malfunctioning tablet wine list.  Returns nearly twenty minutes later & is a bit annoyed that we haven't chosen our wine.   Because its clearly our fault the tablet isn't working.  Then he begins warning us (four times total) that \"we'll be closing soon.\"  \nAgain.  Food, magnificent.  So so so good.  But feeling directly pressured to hurry the heck up and get out after being abandoned by the waiter...um no.  We won't go back.

This particular establishment, known as Terrible's, happens to be situated in close proximity to my humble abode. Consequently, I have opted to visit this location on multiple occasions, primarily for the purpose of acquiring beverages of an alcoholic nature, specifically beer, upon my return home.

On a singular occasion, I availed myself of their car washing services, only to be left with an unsettling sensation that the cost incurred was disproportionate to the quality of the service rendered. Moreover, I have refrained from utilizing their fuel pumps due to the prices being somewhat elevated in comparison to those of neighboring gas stations.

Notwithstanding the aforementioned reservations, I must concede that the convenience store within the premises boasts an impressive array of merchandise, available at a reasonable tariff. Furthermore, the beer cellar, renowned for its exceptionally low temperature, is indeed a remarkable feature of this establishment.

Unfortunately, the parking facilities provided do not exactly qualify as expansive or straightforward, rendering ingress and egress somewhat arduous, particularly when the lot is congested and parking spaces are scarce. It is worth mentioning, however, that the staff members at this establishment, though remunerated at a rate commensurate with the minimum wage, generally exhibit a level of professionalism and dedication to their duties that is, at the very least, adequate.

Despite certain drawbacks, I shall continue to frequent this establishment, provided that the prices remain competitive.

Always have had good experience here but not tonight, dinner with group of friends had abysmal service. First waiter forgot our table and second waitress had a poor attitude when asked about very late food. Food was OK but definitely not as good as in the past.

This place serves Werner Enterprises truck drivers. I know cause I'm one of them. It's just the basics for what we need. I've stayed in worse places. So if you like a 5 star hotel, go somewhere else. It's a 2 star maybe a soft 3 star hotel. But there are plenty of food places within walking distance.

"There is nothing particularly distinctive or exceptional about this establishment, as it offers a culinary experience that is merely satisfactory and unremarkable in terms of quality, while the pace of service is leisurely and unhurried, which may be perceived as sluggish or tardy by some patrons, and the physical layout of the seating arrangements is such that there is an absence of sufficient spatial separation between tables, thereby creating an atmosphere that is reminiscent of sharing a meal with adjacent tables, which may engender a sense of discomfort or inconvenience for certain individuals."

The gastronomical experience was merely adequate, with the victuals being passable but by no means exceptional. My last visit to this establishment occurred approximately one year ago, and upon settling the financial obligation for the repast, I was reminded of the reason behind my prolonged absenceâthe exorbitant cost of a single glass of orange juice, which exceeds two dollars and forty cents, and the lack of complimentary refills. While the comestibles were satisfactory, there are undoubtedly superior options available.

"I was experiencing an intense desire for chicken wings, which compelled me to embark on a somewhat lengthy excursion to acquire them. Upon arriving at the establishment, I sampled two varieties of their offerings, specifically the Louisiana and Parmesan Garlic options. While the former was palatable, I found the seasoning of the latter to be excessively saline, bordering on unpalatability. Notwithstanding, I opted to consume only the former variety, eschewing the latter due to its unpleasant aroma, which closely resembled that of a soiled dishrag, a scent that is likely familiar to most individuals. Subsequently, the pungent odor permeated the interior of my vehicle throughout the duration of my return journey, prompting me to discard the remnants of the meal in the nearest waste receptacle. In light of this experience, I must express my skepticism regarding the staff's ability to perceive and distinguish between diverse olfactory stimuli."

This was my first buffet experience since my departure from Las Vegas several years ago, and unfortunately, it proved to be a regrettable choice. My sons and I were eager to indulge in a buffet meal prior to our evening excursion in the city of sin, and this particular establishment appeared to be the most convenient option, boasting a relatively short queue. However, upon arriving at the cashier, I was taken aback by the exorbitant cost associated with an individual buffet dinner. In fact, for the price we paid, we could have acquired a 24-hour buffet pass, granting us access to multiple hotel buffets.  

Following payment, we waited briefly for our table to be prepared. Once seated, our server took our beverage orders, and after ensuring that everything was in order, we set out to explore the array of dishes available. Unfortunately, the selection was quite limited, with certain stations remaining unrestocked. Given the circumstances, I made a concerted effort to derive maximum value from my $47 dinner by opting for grilled meats such as kobe beef and prime rib, short rib tacos, various sushi and sashimi options, and beef Wellington. For dessert, I selected mini churros and vending machine-dispensed ice cream.  

A summary of the experience would include the following advantages and disadvantages:  

Advantages:  

* Short rib tacos  
* Sushi and sashimi  

Disadvantages:  

* Grilled meats were excessively dry, including beef Wellington  
* Mini churros were overcooked and stale  
* Vending machine-dispensed ice cream possessed an unremarkable flavor reminiscent of that found at typical buffet establishments  

While our server displayed helpfulness, they unfortunately misinterpreted our beverage requests. Ultimately, I departed feeling satisfied but disappointed.

I was told to check out this buffet while in Vegas, and I kind of regret I did.  I think there are two types of people: those who like buffets and those who don't.  I'm of the latter sort, and buffets remind me of eating in college mess halls more than enjoying the food.  But still, we went here for a Saturday brunch.  \n\nThe variety seemed pretty good - asian, italian, seafood, pizza, breakfast, etc.  I had an omelet which was probably the highlight of the meal.  Everything else that I tried was fine, but I was definitely limited by not being able to have the meat here.  The desserts looked nice but I didn't really like any of the ones I tried.  My fiance was more experimental, but he thought that most of the food was kind of pedestrian or mediocre.  Ultimately, both of us would have preferred eating less at a better restaurant in Vegas, but then again, I guess we're not buffet people.

"Having been apprised of an abundance of laudatory assessments, in conjunction with the perpetual throngs of patronage, I deemed it appropriate to subject this establishment to my own meticulous scrutiny. Alas, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as certain aspects of the culinary offerings proved to be somewhat disappointing. Specifically, the pork dishes were not adequately cooked, the enchiladas featured a questionable cheese substitute, and the marshmallows possessed a decidedly unpleasant flavor reminiscent of those from a bygone era (specifically, 1987, which appears to have been an inauspicious year for marshmallow production). Furthermore, I couldn't help but notice an unusually high concentration of severely overweight individuals within the premises, which only served to further diminish my overall satisfaction. Notwithstanding these criticisms, I must admit that the prices were quite reasonable, thereby providing a modicum of solace in an otherwise underwhelming experience."

In person, the staff members appear to be amicable and accommodating; however, their behavior drastically alters when communicating via telephone. They have displayed a blatant disregard for punctuality by summoning me to arrive prematurely, only to arbitrarily assign a different physician. Furthermore, the office environment is noticeably unkempt. Despite my fervent hopes to avoid revisiting the facility, I was compelled to do so in order to resolve an issue regarding my prescription refills, as the staff failed to respond to my requests in a timely manner. Initially, they stipulated that I would need to present myself for an examination every three months in order to obtain my medication; however, upon being queried about this policy, they promptly relented and provided me with my prescription. It appears that their primary objective is to coerce patients into undergoing unnecessary treatments and procedures, thereby augmenting their financial gain through the exploitation of insurance providers. Consequently, I find myself once again wishing to avoid returning to this establishment.

I experimented with this culinary establishment's offerings for the first time during the previous week, specifically on a Monday. My order consisted of their Kung Po chicken dish; however, I must admit that I did not derive satisfaction from consuming it, primarily due to the fact that the poultry was battered, which seemed incongruous with my preconceived notion of an authentic Chinese culinary experience. Furthermore, the accompanying sauce possessed an overly saccharine quality reminiscent of a sweet and sour variety, which only served to further dissuade me from expressing enthusiasm regarding this particular dish. Moreover, the cost of procuring this item proved to be greater than I had initially anticipated. Therefore, I would advise potential patrons to consider visiting alternative establishments specializing in Chinese cuisine, such as those situated along Leith Walk, in search of a more genuine and satisfying gastronomical encounter.

"Although Pancho Villa's has been in operation for an extended period, it appears to garner sufficient patronage to remain in business, albeit I am uncertain about the precise factors contributing to its enduring success...I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior chili at various establishments and Illegal Jack's, which were not only more flavorful but also more economical. The enchiladas and fajitas, unfortunately, failed to impress my palate, lacking that extra je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to a truly satisfying culinary experience. A acquaintance did mention that the restaurant excels in crafting exceptional margaritas, yet if the sole means of enjoying the cuisine is through alcohol-induced impairment, then I struggle to comprehend the rationale behind paying premium prices for a dining establishment. In light of the description provided by Yelp, my sentiments regarding Pancho Villa's can be succinctly summarized as'meh', as I have undoubtedly encountered superior dining experiences."

"Although the pizza did not epitomize culinary disaster, the associated transaction proved to be utterly lamentable. Dominos's pricing paradigm is egregiously exorbitant, with their medium-sized offering, featuring a paltry two toppings, representing a particularly flagrant instance of fiscal malfeasance. A rating of low is thus assigned, commensurate with the establishment's dubious distinction of proffering an experience antithetical to the axiomatic correlation between quality, value, and patron satisfaction."

"The recreational aquatic facility boasts pristine cleanliness and aesthetically pleasing architecture, yet, it perplexes me as to why the management would opt to cement the pool decking during sweltering summer days in Arizona, rendering the surface hazardously slippery and uncomfortably hot underfoot. Witnessing a visitor slip and sustain a head injury, resulting in an ambulance being summoned to transport them to the hospital for treatment of a concussion, only serves to amplify my incredulity. Furthermore, the ratio of pool-goers to lifeguards appears to be disproportionately skewed, with approximately three guests to every one lifeguard, leading me to question the efficacy of such a safety protocol. Additionally, the standard operating procedure in the event of an injury, which involves the whistle-blowing mobilization of all fifty guards to expel every single patron from both the pool and surrounding area, strikes me as excessively zealous and unnecessary, especially considering the inconvenience and discomfort it causes for those simply seeking to retrieve their children or personal belongings. While I acknowledge the importance of addressing emergencies promptly, I believe it is unreasonable to cordon off the entire pool area, thereby precluding patrons from accessing their belongings or even hydrating beverages. In light of these concerns, I have decided against returning to this particular recreational establishment."

"My sentiment regarding this eatery is that it is egregiously overvalued relative to the financial investment required to partake in its offerings. While the server was indeed courteous and professional in their demeanor, and the culinary fare was of satisfactory quality, albeit not extraordinary, the exorbitant cost of the meals, coupled with the dearth of exceptional service and the underwhelming temperature at which the dishes were presented, unfortunately precludes me from endorsing this establishment wholeheartedly. Furthermore, the absence of dedicated male and female restrooms, compounded by an extended waiting period to access the sole available facilities, prompted numerous patrons to seek alternative venues for their personal hygiene needs, thus detracting from the overall dining experience. Aesthetically, the presentation of the food was indeed impressive, yet, regrettably, this attribute proved to be the sole distinguishing feature of this restaurant, rendering it merely average in my assessment."
Register service was not pleasant. I'm not sure if the girl who rang me up just didn't like me, but she was nice to everyone else until I got up to her.

We placed an order for a supplementary dish of Macaroni and cheese, which we intended to consume prior to our primary courses, in observance of the tradition associated with the fifth day of the week. Both of us opted for seafood dishes, specifically fish, and accompaniments of leafy greens. Additionally, we requested a bowl of the broth du jour, specifically clam chowder, to initiate our culinary experience. Our salads were presented initially, followed by a brief interval during which we partook of a few bites, and then the soup arrived. Shortly after, the Macaroni and cheese was delivered to our table. We couldn't help but remark that the term "appetizer" appeared to be problematic for the majority of servers. Subsequently, our main courses were served, much to our incredulity. The sheer volume of crockery on our table prompted a humorous observation from our server, to which we responded with a perplexed expression. Throughout the meal, we encountered multiple servers and food runners, necessitating repeated requests for water replenishment. Moreover, we had to seek assistance from a staff member to obtain condiments and settle our financial obligations. Despite the cordial demeanor of the staff, it became apparent that there was a lack of managerial guidance and coordination among the team members. The ambiance and cuisine were satisfactory, however, we shall endeavor to patronize the establishment once more, granting them an additional opportunity to address the glaring deficiencies in their service protocols. A point-of-sale system with advanced features should enable servers to track the timing of food delivery, thereby mitigating misunderstandings between servers and cooks, ultimately attributable to inadequate management.

We were formerly enamored with this establishment as an optimal initiatory halt in Las Vegas; however, it has unfortunately deteriorated significantly - almost entirely downhill, in fact.

It required a staggering 27 minutes - indeed, 27! - for our server to extend a cursory greeting and merely accept our beverage orders. Subsequently, we hastened to request our entire meal and checkout simultaneously, thereby ensuring we wouldn't miss his fleeting presence once more.

The menu has been considerably truncated, offering fewer options and omitting certain items I previously relished. My dinner companion and I opted for the barbecue chicken flatbread, which regrettably featured an abundance of unpalatable, fatty chicken parts, rendering half of it inedible. While their burgers may still be passable, this particular dish fell short of expectations.

Evidently, this venue suffers from managerial issues, leading to staffing difficulties and ultimately resulting in subpar customer service and interminable waiting periods. We shall not return, but we sincerely hope that improvements are implemented for the benefit of future patrons. Nonetheless, we extends a solitary star in recognition of their commendable beer selection.

I asked for delivery. Ok, they did it with no problems and quick enough (30-40 mins). 
I chose just rolls. 
The salmon one was pretty flat, no taste. Californias were ok-ish.

When I gave money to the woman who delivered she took them and left without saying a goodbye or thank you

Meh

Doesn't even taste like pho, nor smell like it.

I had asked for extra veggies in my vermicelli, and it looked like they put in less than most places normally would if i had not asked for extra. This plate was ok.

My seat had a bunch of rips in it, and when you sit on ripped leather it kinda hurts if you wear a dress/shorts.

This eatery, which appears to be a run-of-the-mill Mexican cuisine establishment, is unfortunately rather unimpressive in its culinary offerings. Upon entering the premises, my companion and I were immediately struck by the dearth of patrons, despite the fact that it was a Friday afternoon. The ambiance was lackluster, with nary a soul in sight, save for a few staff members and a small child who was frolicking about the rear of the dining area. The menu options were uninspired and failed to excite our palates, with the enchiladas, in particular, being rather unremarkable. The chicken and beef variants, respectively, were unexceptional and lacked any semblance of flavor that might have elevated them above the mundane. Furthermore, the dark brown sauce accompanying the dish was unappetizing in both appearance and taste, resembling a beef-based gravy of sorts. Our server, though friendly, seemed somewhat disinterested in our experience, and the overall atmosphere was eerily hushed, almost to the point of being unsettling. Suffice it to say, we shall not be revisiting this establishment in the future.

We've been here a couple of times and the poor service does not disappoint.  I'm not sure if they're understaffed or the staff has tables inside and out that causes them to be so slow but both times the service has been painful.  The food is average at best, bar food and not good enough for us to come back.\nThe bar itself seems like it could be great.  They need a lot of improvement to beat the competition that's right next door!

"Culinary artisans who harmoniously blend their vocal talents with their gastronomical prowess invariably ensure an unparalleled epicurean experience, as the hospitable service staff fosters an ambiance reminiscent of a convivial family gathering. While the interior design may appear somewhat lackluster, this establishment possesses inherent potential. 

--The made-to-order Pico de Gallo boasts freshness and a piquant flavor, although its sodium content tends to overpower the palate, particularly when paired with corn chips. 
--The melodious strains emanating from the culinary domain serve as a harbinger of excellence, signaling that a delectable feast is forthcoming. 
--Although delivered, the flour tortillas feature only six ingredients, which is suboptimal. 
--Guacamole should never contain additives such as milk, which would compromise its authenticity and texture. 
--The rice, regrettably, is too minute, resulting in rapid desiccation and disappointment. 
--The cheese crisp, unfortunately, lacks crunch, while the green chili strips display freshness. 

DECOR REQUIRES REFURBISHMENT 
--The presence of extended beer flags suspended from the ceiling does not automatically create a festive atmosphere, especially when they fail to flutter in the breeze. 
--Mounted mariachi hats and diagonally positioned multicolored throw rugs do not contribute significantly to the overall aesthetic appeal. 
--While caballeros and damas are certainly commendable, the juxtaposition of McDonald's-style Men and Women signs beneath them seems incongruous. 
--Mirrored walls, reminiscent of the 1980s, are aesthetically displeasing. 

It is crucial to preface my assessment by acknowledging my corn intolerance, which limits my capacity to sample a significant portion of the menu. 
--This venue exudes a genuine local ambiance, which could benefit from a revitalizing transformation."

It is utterly preposterous to expect consumers to pay such an exorbitant price for a paltry double shot of espresso, truly it is. My recent visit to the Handsome Roasters Cafe, where I was served a double pulled by one of the proprietors themselves, only solidified my conviction that the prices at JPH are unreasonable, as the cost was significantly lower. Furthermore, my experiences at other esteemed establishments, such as Barista in Portland Oregon, where I was served by an award-winning barista, and at Coava, Stumptown, and The Refinery, all renowned for their high-end offerings, only further reinforced my belief that JPH's prices are unjustifiably steep. While I do appreciate the occasional indulgence in a premium coffee experience, I cannot help but feel that JPH's pricing strategy is pretentious and unreasonable, particularly given the plethora of more affordable options available. Perhaps the exorbitant rent or the prevalence of affluent clientele who are either trust fund beneficiaries or burdened with substantial student loans might explain the coffee shop's seemingly inflated prices. In any case, a dose of rationality would greatly benefit JPH's pricing model, in my humble opinion. As an aside, I must express my delight at the fact that LADRO is served at JPH, a pleasant surprise indeed.

I think Phoenix reviewers inflate the ranking of restaurants here to make it seem like there are a lot more real good restaurants (and there are, but Blue Wasabi isn't one of them) or they are simply very generous, or they have no idea what good cuisine is, or they give an extra star for creativity by having "blue" wasabi. I've learned to avoid listening to reviewers who give high ratings for average, at best, restaurants. 

What I like about Blue Wasabi - good service, decent drinks, different decor and look. 

What I don't like - For what you pay, this is average sushi. The sushi isn't cheap, so I had been expecting real fresh sushi. But, I was let down by the quality of the sushi and sashimi. The sashimi was actually better (but not saying much). But, the food here  was not as good as Sushi on Shea or Kyoto, both of which are considerably cheaper than Blue Wasabi. It's more of a scene place, somewhat trendy. But, I am not paying my money for the scene. I want good  food. And, frankly, Blue Wasabi falls short of that.

I was there on Friday night about 9:00.  Not very many people and it seems that this place is short staffed.  No hostess, and only 2 servers for this large place.  My server was very good - he gets high marks!  The food was another story.

I ordered the lemon sole, a side salad and that's all.  With tax and tip the meal came to $20.00.  The salad was nice and fresh and crisp.  The lemon caper sauce was tasty, the sole was not very good.  I did mention this to the server and he offered to replace it, but I didn't want to wait.  It was supposed to be "sautéed", the chef does not know how to cook fish!  It was fried and was crispy and tough.  Sole is a tender fish and doesn't need much cooking.  I was very disappointed in this dish and would not recommend it.  

As always, Mimi's does have good bread, but the rest of the food is not so hot.  This was what I thought a rather expensive meal (well not a lot, but more than $5 or 10!) and way not worth it.  Go elsewhere!

"It is truly perplexing to comprehend the rationale behind the ostensibly favorable evaluations bestowed upon this establishment, as my personal experience has led me to conclude that it is, in fact, quite unsanitary and antiquated. The ambiance is hectic, the service is excruciatingly sluggish, and the culinary offerings are merely lubricous and unpalatable. 

The prevailing sentiment among patrons appears to be that of a superlative dining experience, with particular emphasis on the purported affordability and quality of the Mexican cuisine served herein. However, I must respectfully disagree with such assertions, as my own taste buds have failed to detect even a modicum of gastronomical excellence. 

The salsa presented was conspicuously lacking in freshness, while the guacamole was devoid of any discernible flavor profile. Furthermore, the practice of placing packaged shredded cheese atop tortilla chips and salsa, rather than allowing it to melt, struck me as decidedly incongruous. 

My attempt to consume a taco salad was, regrettably, abortive, as I found the ingredients to be utterly unappetizing. 

In conclusion, if one's culinary preferences lean towards hastily prepared and inferior Mexican-American fare, then, perhaps, this venue may prove satisfactory. Nevertheless, I would strongly advise against entrusting one's dining experience to this establishment, as the likelihood of disappointment is, in my opinion, unacceptably high."

When I overheard my immediate supervisor express his intention to indulge in a personal treat by dining at Blueberry Hill, I nearly collapsed from surprise. Had he perused my previous critique of the establishment on Flamingo Avenue? Appalling! Miserable! Such an experience would be more suitable for a used automobile salesperson or perhaps even Lucifer himself. 
  Nonetheless, my manager maintained that a visit to the location on Green Valley Parkway was imperative, boasting that it was vastly superior - allegedly 10,000 times better, to be exact. My response was a half-hearted "meh," and I promptly returned to my duties. 
  Today, however, I found myself in need of some inspiration to stimulate my creativity. Thus, I decided to put my manager's claims to the test. Upon arriving at the Blueberry Hill on Green Valley Parkway, I was promptly greeted and seated. To ensure a fair assessment, I placed an order for the identical dish I had tried at the previous Blueberry Hill: Mexican-style chilaquiles accompanied by a Diet Pepsi. Unfortunately, the culinary experience was identical to the previous establishment - an unremarkable plate of mediocrity. It baffles me how such establishments garner widespread acclaim when my experiences have consistently yielded unimpressive results. 
  On a positive note, the service was marginally expedited. While the staff remained relatively stoic, I didn't have to wait an eternity for a replenishment of my beverage. 
  Regrettably, my reservations regarding these eateries persist. If I require comfort food in a timely manner, my allegiance lies with Denny's.

"The multiplicity of sauces available at this establishment is rather unremarkable, and the diminutive size of the ribs, even in the case of baby back ribs, is certainly noteworthy. Furthermore, the other meaty accoutrements, including brisket (which, regrettably, exhibited an excessive degree of desiccation for my taste), pulled chicken, pulled pork, and smoked sausage, did not particularly impress. Notably, the sausage, which our server asserted was fabricated in-house, possessed a flavor profile strikingly reminiscent of a generic, mass-produced product, such as those obtainable from a Hillshire Farms packet purchased at Costco. The sole side dish that I consumed, the steak fries, while ostensibly possessing some semblance of skin, unfortunately, failed to deliver a palatable experience. In conclusion, there exist numerous superior options for barbecue enthusiasts in the Northwest Phoenix region."

Located on Fremont Street, and relatively proximate to the illustrious Golden Nugget, this establishment appears to have experienced more favorable days in the past. The sole motivation behind my visits to this venue is the affordable deep-fried Twinkies, which are available at an economical price point of 99 cents. Despite being cognizant of the fact that such culinary indulgences are not particularly beneficial for my health, I cannot resist the allure of deep-fried Twinkies. However, the cleanliness of the deep fry station and the quality of customer service could be improved. Specifically, the comment made by a staff member, "Don't forget my tip," struck me as somewhat brusque and unwarranted, thereby diminishing the likelihood of receiving a generous gratuity from me. In fact, the tip I left was a paltry 10% of the total bill.  

The ambiance of the establishment itself leaves much to be desired, with outdated slot machines that frequently malfunction and an overall atmosphere that seems to be in disrepair. Were it not for the antiquated gaming devices and the less-than-friendly demeanor of the staff, this venue might have garnered a more positive appraisal from me. As it stands, I would advise individuals who are interested in gambling or utilizing slot machines to avoid this location, as the wait times for assistance can extend up to 30-60 minutes. Nonetheless, the slushy drinks and deep-fried delights available at the rear of the establishment remain a redeeming feature.

"The coffee concoction is fabricated according to prescribed protocols, yet the associates manifest a conspicuous lack of enthusiasm and warmth in their interactions with patrons. As a regular patron over an extensive period, I have visited this establishment on numerous occasions throughout the day, endeavoring to initiate dialogue with the barista. However, their responses are typically terse and cursory, precluding any meaningful exchange. Notwithstanding, the beverages and comestibles available conform to the standards one would anticipate from a Starbucks franchise."

"We had the opportunity to indulge in the seafood buffet this evening, and our expectations were not entirely met. Despite the extensive variety of dishes available, the quality was inconsistent. The steamed crab legs were somewhat disappointing, lacking the succulent texture we had anticipated. However, the crab legs roasted in a sweet chili sauce were a notable exception, showcasing a delightful balance of flavors. Unfortunately, the cold crab legs situated near the cold seafood section had an unpleasant saltiness. The lobster tails, though visually appealing, were regrettably small and exhibited a slight rubberiness in texture. Nonetheless, the application of garlic butter enhanced the flavor of these dishes. 

The genuine highlight of the meal was undoubtedly the assortment of desserts. The green tea cheesecake demonstrated a pleasing lightness, while the creme brulee struck the perfect balance between sweetness and richness. The bread pudding, accompanied by a vanilla spice sauce, was truly exceptional. Unfortunately, the red velvet cupcakes failed to impress, as they were unpleasantly dry and lacking in flavor. 

Based on our experience, we would advise against selecting this establishment for a buffet. While the service we received was indeed commendable, the overall quality did not live up to the reputation preceding it. We award one star for the abundance of options and a second for the excellent service, but the remaining aspects fell short of our expectations."

"Underwhelmed experience. We entered the establishment at approximately 4 pm and found only a single table occupied. The exterior's unique charm was inviting; however, upon entering, I felt as though I had intruded upon a tattoo artist's personal space. 

It took between five to ten minutes for a staff member to emerge from the kitchen and greet us, which left an unfavorable initial impression. The salsa bar presented an assorted selection, yet its presentation was subpar. The miniature containers designated for 'to-go' salsa were insufficient, rendering it impossible to accommodate a single tortilla chip. Consequently, we were compelled to utilize a plastic spoon to transfer salsa onto our chips due to the absence of metal utensils on the table. Additionally, we did not receive small plates, resulting in a cluttered table setting before we began placing orders. 

Upon the arrival of our tacos, conspicuous cracks were visible on both my husband's and my plates. The similarity to flea market crockery was unavoidable. My selection was the smoked marlin taco, which possessed the texture of canned tuna complemented by a minestrone-like vegetable mixture above, while the shrimp tacos were passable. Unfortunately, the corn tortillas lacked substance, resembling store-bought El Paso brand products. 

The service was unsatisfactory, as our queries regarding the tacos were met with gestures toward the menu and vacant expressions, indicating a lack of familiarity with achiote rojo. 

In conclusion, the sentiment that we would have fared better at Chipotle encapsulates our disappointing experience."

When I first started frequenting this place's Sunday night happy hour, I loved it.  I would go with a group of friends, and it was always a great time.  Over the last few months, I have seen a decline in the quality of food, service, and an increase in prices.  Happy hour is still pretty decent prices, and the food hasn't been bad, it just isn't as good as it used to be, unfortunate really.

"Individual, verily, consider the expedited procurement of consumable comestibles, if you comprehend my inference.  I surmise that this establishment might be somewhat sensationalized and the culinary offerings are merely mediocre."

"The ambiance of this establishment did not possess any remarkably memorable qualities. Admittedly, my level of hunger was not as pronounced as it ideally should have been, and I was in the process of recuperating from an alcohol-induced blackout the previous evening...therefore, one should perhaps take my appraisal with a slight grain of salt.^_^.  

I opted for the breakfast buffet, which cost approximately $15, a price point that appears to be customary for Las Vegas. While nothing particularly extraordinary about the buffet stands out in my memory, they did offer pizza, which elicited considerable excitement on my part during the morning hours. The remaining items were fairly standard fare, including eggs, slightly stale bacon and sausage, hash browns, et cetera. I managed to consume roughly three-quarters of a plate before feeling utterly satiated and failing to obtain adequate value for my money.  

However, the quality of service was quite impressive! My server presented me with two large glasses of orange juice, thereby eliminating the need for me to request additional servings later on. Her thoughtfulness was much appreciated.  

In conclusion, if you are lodging at Planet Hollywood, it does not harm to enjoy breakfast at this venue. Nonetheless, I would personally advocate for breakfast at Le Village Buffet, located within the Paris hotel, instead. *wink wink*."

Cockroach crawled out of sprout plate... Killed it, hesitated to stay but did. They apologized, replaced food, charged me every cent for my food n to-go dinner. Used to come here every week, my fav pho diner, but I think I'll drive a little farther to Chinatown from now on...

"It was patently evident that the comedic endeavors of the male exotic dancers were the source of immense hilarity, albeit their attempts at seduction were futile, as we were not remotely interested in engaging in any form of terpsichorean interaction with them. Moreover, it was abundantly clear that one particular individual, whose moniker was Chili, was persistently offering discounts in a vain attempt to coerce us into accepting a performance from him, which we categorically refused. However, certain male dancers did display a modicum of affability, such as the gentleman hailing from San Jose, California, who regaled us with amusing anecdotes. Nonetheless, the absence of seating arrangements in the primary chamber for female performers was nothing short of perplexing, prompting us to decline the invitation to join the gentlemen celebrating their friend's last night of bachelorhood. Furthermore, we were witness to a rather unseemly spectacle involving a patron receiving a manual stimulation from a decidedly unattractive stripper, which elicited a response of mirthful incredulity from us."

"The pinnacle of culinary excellence at Pasqual's unquestionably lies within the realm of their delectable salsa, available in an array of piquant flavors ranging from mild to hot, all of which evoke an unparalleled gastronomic experience that transcends mere taste and borders on the spiritual. It is no surprise that at one point in the annals of history, Pasqual's boldly proclaimed itself a'salsaria,' for the sheer quality and depth of its salsa offerings are nothing short of sublime. The salsa is so exceptional, in fact, that it has been known to inspire an uncontainable urge to engage in impromptu bouts of salsa dancing, despite the fact that neither the author nor the majority of patrons possess any discernible aptitude for the art form. Alas, such is the profound impact of Pasqual's salsa on the senses. Regrettably, however, this once-illustrious establishment appears to have fallen victim to a precipitous decline in standards, as evidenced by the paltry serving of salsa accompanying the nachos, measuring a scant tablespoon or thereabouts in a miniature cup. A travesty compounded by the fact that repeated requests for additional salsa have yielded identical, meager portions. While the chicken, beef, nachos, and tacos at Pasqual's may be of respectable quality, it is indubitable that the salsa remains the veritable cornerstone of the dining experience, rendering the recent parsimony displayed in its distribution nothing short of calamitous. In conclusion, an imploration is hereby issued for Pasqual's to rectify this grievous oversight and restore the salsa to its rightful place as the crowning glory of the menu, lest the reputation of this erstwhile culinary haven suffer irreparable damage."

Went this evening with a family member and ordered the $20 dinner for two.   Ordered the guacamole appetizer which was their tortilla chips (yum) and guacamole with corn, according to the waitress, no jalapeno's and not spicy.  First bite into the guac....whoa....5 alarm fire in my mouth.  It was full of jalapenos!!! and other spicy things. Then we got the 6 oz. sirloin, mine was well done as i requested but really burnt on one side.  It came with loaded mashed potatoes, which were great, and broccoli with god knows what they put on it, tasted very foul and rancid.  Service is always poor there and I don't know why I went back.  Today was my last visit there.
Horrible Service. Extremely slow to seat us... and feed us... and water us... and bill us... slooooow.\nWe won't be going back.

"Deplorable. With an uppercase 'B'. 

Based on the pizza we obtained, I find it challenging to believe that the individual responsible for its preparation has ever stepped foot in a pizza establishment within the NY/NJ region, let alone possess any familiarity with the culinary traditions of New York-style pizza. 

We placed an order for a half meatball, half pepperoni pizza, anticipating a product that at least vaguely resembled the depiction on the menu. However, what we received was a pizza that barely qualified as a distant cousin of the iconic Domino's franchise, albeit at a significantly higher price point. The crust was thick and doughy, the sauce more akin to a concentrated tomato paste than an actual sauce, and the cheese was overcooked to an unpleasant degree. Furthermore, the'meatball' topping consisted of ground beef haphazardly scattered across the cheese, rather than sliced meatballs as advertised. 

In short, a truly regrettable experience. My expectations were high, hoping to discover another authentic NY-style pizzeria in our town. Unfortunately, this particular establishment falls woefully short of meeting such standards. We shall continue to patronize our established favorites, leaving this disappointing venture to those who are less discerning in their culinary pursuits."

"Determined to procure sustenance via the drive-thru, I embarked upon an ill-fated culinary excursion. The inexperienced employee manning the window exhibited a profound lack of familiarity with the menu, leading to an interminable delay before I was able to place my order. Upon being instructed to advance to the pickup area, I endured an additional prolonged wait, during which time I could detect the pungent aroma of onion rings emanating from my vehicle. Upon arriving home, I discovered that the putrid scent had permeated not only the exterior of my food items but also the taste, rendering the ice cream unpalatably saccharine. Following a brief and futile attempt to consume the tainted dessert, I was compelled to desist, lest I succumb to a diabetic seizure, and instead opted to quench my thirst with water."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment can be somewhat unpredictable, as I have experienced inconsistent quality during my visits. Specifically, I typically order the piccatta, but on one occasion, the veal was remarkably tough. Furthermore, the prices of the dishes are excessive, and the ambiance is the primary redeeming feature of this restaurant. The staff would benefit from enhancements in various aspects, including their interpersonal skills, service efficiency, and product knowledge. For instance, when I visited the bar and requested a mojito, the bartender claimed she was unable to prepare it, which prompted me to bring it to the attention of the manager. Upon questioning, he assured me that they possess fresh mint and the necessary tools to craft such a beverage. Subsequently, I received my'mojito,' which raised doubts about the bartender's proficiency or willingness to create the cocktail. Previously, in June, I arranged a celebration for my spouse's birthday, involving a group of 16 individuals, and secured a reservation well in advance. Unfortunately, the service proved subpar, as the server and busser demonstrated a lack of attentiveness, evidenced by their practice of hastily delivering the bread and promptly disappearing. We were forced to entreat them for refills. Notably, we have encountered just one exceptional waiter throughout our three-year patronage, and that was solely due to my personal efforts in expressing my dissatisfaction and securing a guarantee of superior service from the manager."

"Regarding the customer service aspect of our visit, I must say that upon entering the establishment, I did not receive a warm welcome from the staff. In fact, despite being acknowledged by one of the employees with a fleeting glance, no verbal greeting was extended in my direction. Furthermore, the other staff member merely uttered a cursory 'hello' after I had been perusing the menu for an appreciable amount of time, and then promptly departed without offering any assistance or recommendations. It is worth mentioning that this lackluster service was in stark contrast to the pleasant ambiance that the restaurant exuded. Moving on to the culinary aspects of our excursion, I opted for the second option on the lunch special menu, which comprised of a slice of cheese pizza, a garden salad, and a fountain beverage, all for the reasonable sum of six dollars. While the pizza's sauce was unfortunately too saccharine for my taste buds, the dough was regrettably over-saturated with moisture. However, the salad proved to be a refreshing delight, consisting of a simple yet satisfying medley of fresh lettuce, succulent cherry tomatoes, and crunchy carrots, all dressed with a tangy balsamic vinaigrette."

"A respectable establishment, boasting an array of amenities such as televisions, al fresco seating, and a roll of paper towels suspended from each table, has captured my approval. As an ardent devotee of pizza and beer, I must confess that while their draft beer is palatable, the absence of a takeout option precludes the possibility of savoring this delightful combination away from the premises. Additionally, they offer an assortment of wines to complement their menu. Although their appetizers appear delectable, my culinary exploration was limited to their pizza, adorned with an assortment of vegetables, which regrettably fell short of exceptional. The ambiance, however, is pleasant, and the location, convenient."

I originate from the San Gabriel Valley, thereby, my expectations for dim sum are considerably elevated beyond those of an average individual. In light of this, the culinary offerings presented by this establishment were utterly disappointing. Upon observation, it became apparent that certain dishes were of the microwaveable variety, and none of them exhibited any semblance of robust flavor or freshness. The texture of the Har Gow and Shau Mai was unpleasantly soft and prone to disintegration, while the white rice cake dessert I hold in high regard was similarly afflicted with an unfortunate lack of cohesion. The taste was overpoweringly bland and devoid of any discernible flavor, leading me to surmise that an excessive amount of steam or cooking time was responsible. For individuals residing in Las Vegas and seeking dim sum, this restaurant may serve as a viable option. However, I do not intend to return.

Regrettably, my domicile was ravaged by an unforeseen conflagration, compelling me to seek temporary refuge in this establishment. Accompanying me were my offspring, myself, and a pair of feline companions. In light of my recent knee affliction, I requested a chamber designated as "handicap-accessible," which, to my relief, was accommodated by the proprietors. Despite the less-than-ideal environs and the occasional cacophony generated by the nearby railway, I was particularly taken by the thoughtful installation of grab bars throughout the bathing facilities, as they greatly facilitated my ambulation. In conclusion, if faced with a similar predicament, I would, without hesitation, opt to return to the Scottsdale venue.

"The establishment boasts an alluring exterior and interior ambiance, which we had the pleasure of experiencing firsthand on a Friday evening, albeit with a moderate level of noise that prompted us to opt for the comparatively tranquil outdoor seating area. Our culinary excursion commenced auspiciously, with a satisfying bread basket and crisp salads that set the tone for a promising start. However, the subsequent dishes failed to maintain the initial quality, leading us to conclude that scaling down portion sizes while elevating the caliber of the fare would be a judicious strategy.

We initiated our gastronomic journey by sharing a spanakopita appetizer, which arrived in the form of three generous pieces, thereby rendering it suitable for two individuals. Although visually reminiscent of a pocket pizza, the dish was marred by an excess of cream cheese, detracting from the authentic flavor profile associated with feta. Moreover, the absence of delicate phyllo crust layers was conspicuous.

Our primary courses consisted of a customary beef gyro and its poultry counterpart, accompanied by potatoes and rice. Unfortunately, the potatoes were prepared in a manner akin to french fries, which rendered them unappealing to my taste buds due to their high fat content. Consequently, I merely sampled a few pieces, feeling somewhat let down. The accompanying rice was unremarkable, and the chicken gyro proved underwhelming as well. My spouse, however, seemed to appreciate the meal relatively more, possibly due to his exposure to prior reviews that tempered his expectations. The service we received was quite satisfactory, and the meal's tempo was well-maintained. Notwithstanding, my underwhelming experience precludes the likelihood of my return visit."

They are somewhat covertly positioned within the confines of Scottsdale Quarters, specifically situated on the upper level adjacent to the esteemed establishments of Tanzy and iPic, thus it is imperative that one does not relinquish their pursuit of discovering them.

I was disappointed with this place not because of the massage; which was good but this establishment has no staff. The masseuse is the receptionist, manager, and janitor. Every time a new customer comes in my masseuse leaves and arranges the massages for the customer. What was a hour massage took 90 min. We actually found this place after having AYCE Sushi at the end of the strip center, but I will not be back.

Peanut butter jelly time?  I think not!  Not sure why the PB&J is only part of the lunch menu, but if you want one for your child before 11 am, don't count on it.  The two employees were unwilling to convey anything to management (which we believe was utilizing the nearby couches for leisure activities) that it is more practical to prepare a PB&J rather than a smoothie.  The employees only knew to state that it was against company policy to create a PB&J before 11 am.  Anyway, I requested an egg sandwich with tomato and turkey and it was a rather unremarkable sandwich in that I could have easily prepared the same dish at home, but with superior quality due to the availability of Tobasco.  I inquired about Tobasco but was instead offered their homemade "chili" sauce, which possessed a flavor profile akin to pureed sundried tomatoes combined with chili powder.  While it was not unpalatable, I do enjoy the piquant sensation of Tobasco when consumed in conjunction with eggs.  Anywhoo, if that was indeed management relaxing on the couches, then shame on them for not defending their stringent PB&J policy and investing in a bottle of Tobasco!

I genuinely aspired to relish this establishment, given its favorable evaluations and reasonable happy hour prices...nonetheless, I simply did not.

The embellishment of the interior appeared somewhat deficient, and the booths were not particularly comfortable. The hospitality was adequate, yet not exceptional.

We opted for the Gyoza, which proved to be moderately satisfying. However, it was pan-fried instead of being deeply fried, thereby diminishing its crunchiness. Additionally, we requested a volcano roll and a rainbow roll; regrettably, the latter failed to impress, as the shrimp was somewhat rubbery, while the avocado exhibited a faintly aged flavor. Notably, they served us a thunder roll by mistake, rather than the volcano roll we had actually ordered. Although I had deliberated between the two options, I presumed it was my error and chose not to contest it. Nonetheless, upon inspecting the receipt, it became apparent that we had, in fact, ordered the correct item. The thunder roll was merely average. The tea and miso soup were, however, quite palatable.

In conclusion, our dining experience was merely mediocre, leaving us unimpressed and disinclined to revisit the restaurant.

Only reason why this is even a 2 is because I have eaten here before and the food is great. 

I have never had service like this before here... 
Started off normally. Greeted at the door, seated... The restaurant was a little busy at a little before 10. We got drinks within a couple minutes of being seated... French press was delicious... and then the waiting... 5 minutes... 10 minutes... 15... I'm about done watching others get seated and orders taken... I watch the waitress put in orders... talk to the other staff... not even a look over to out table... Got up and left... Not what I expect from Postinos... I won't be returning to the central location again...

I am an ardent devotee of Cirque du Soleil, having had the privilege of witnessing no less than six of their extraordinary productions, including the captivating O, the enthralling Ovo, the mystifying Mystere, the enchanting Quidam, the spellbinding Zarkana, and the mesmerizing Dralion. My curiosity was piqued by the notion of Zumanity, as the prospect of experiencing the sensual aspect of Cirque du Soleil resonated with the adult-themed ambiance of Las Vegas, which I was encountering for the first time since attaining the age of majority. Admittedly, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as I did not find the acrobatic feats to be as awe-inspiring as those showcased in many of the other Cirque shows. Furthermore, the choreography and musical accompaniment did not strike me as particularly memorable. Nonetheless, I must acknowledge that the comedic talents of the "clown" hosts of Zumanity did succeed in eliciting laughter from the audience, especially through their engagement with the crowd. The experience afforded by Zumanity diverges significantly from that of its Cirque counterparts, boasting a far more intimate atmosphere. For instance, the theater's diminutive size and the performers' warm greetings upon entry serve to create a sense of proximity and familiarity. It is worth noting that premium seating in the front row can ensure a heightened level of interaction during the performance, making it a factor to consider when booking tickets for Zumanity.

I liked the bar tops and the fact that it was nicely lit at this pub...that's about it.  Wait, the fries were pretty good...

My bf's brother got the fish sandwich with a side of wilted salad.  Yes, wilted because they had put the salad on the same plate as the fish sandwich, and the plate must have been placed under the heat lamp for quite some time prior to making it to our table.

I had the fish and chips, and again, I must admit that the garlic fries were pretty good.  The fish however, was not as good as I had hoped it to be.  The batter did not hold to the fish.  It was not fluffy and airy with the crisp to it.   

My boyfriend had the Bangers, bean and mash.  All three of us came to the agreement that the bangers tasted like breakfast sausage.  Very underwhelmed.

Will I be coming back to this Firkin place (which is a chained pub btw), highly doubted.

The food was excellent but it was very expensive for the portion sizes. For three of us at lunch, the bill before tip was $105 & we didn't even have drinks. Service was good too but again I can't justify the price.

"Peruse the critiques and it was a close call, albeit an unsuccessful endeavor, as we opted for the New York steak and veal scaloppini, in addition to a few mixed drinks...The steak, priced at thirty dollars per plate, was replete with excess fat and gristle, while my veal, which was cooked in a manner that did not resemble the traditional preparation of scallopini, was similarly marred by an unpalatable sauce that was overly reminiscent of gravy and brown in color...My martini, recommended by our server, possessed a saccharine quality, yet lacked the depth of flavor one would expect from such a beverage...Although the service was commendable, it is unlikely that we would revisit this establishment, given the plethora of alternative dining options available."

Sat at the bar for a quick glass of wine and to order some food to go. I ordered A glass of red wine. It was good, i don't know if it was worth 9$ a glass though. The bartender seemed a little mad I wanted half spinach, half romain on my Cesar salad. I'm picky, but I am nice about it. We ordered the spinach pear Gorgonzola pizza. It came out cold, and wasn't that amazing. Probably wouldn't come back.
