I had been lodging at the Hilton Grand Vacations, situated across the thoroughfare and at a slight remove from the main road, and it so transpired that I found myself frequenting the Riviera on a daily basis, indulging in games of chance; the majority of the mixologists stationed at the poker bar were quite affable and accommodating, while a considerable number of the croupiers exhibited a demeanor that could be described as unpleasant or even surly, with James and Bruce standing out as particularly exceptional in their cordiality and proficiency; after suffering significant financial losses at the hands of Tang, an individual who remained impassive and unsmiling throughout the ordeal, I couldn't help but ponder why anyone would persist in patronizing the establishment for purposes of engaging in 3 card poker, and if I weren't in the company of my kin, I would have been highly unlikely to participate in such activities within these premises.

"I am utterly dumbfounded by my decision to expend in excess of thirteen dollars for a duo of frothy beverages, which, while palatable, did not possess any extraordinary qualities that would have justified such an exorbitant price tag, particularly in light of the fact that similar products are readily available at a fraction of the cost in other establishments within the vicinity of Gilbert."

I had the privilege of visiting this establishment in the recent past, accompanied by a group of four associates, subsequent to attending a performance at the Overture Center.  While the culinary offerings were generally satisfactory, albeit a tad overpriced, there were certain aspects of our dining experience that left much to be desired.  Specifically, on multiple occasions, our server removed plates containing unfinished food, which we found rather perplexing.  However, the true nadir of our encounter was our server himself, whose demeanor and communication skills left much to be desired.  A member of our party, who happens to be in the advanced stages of pregnancy, placed an order for a non-alcoholic mojito, only to be met with a quizzical expression and a query regarding her desire for vodka from our server.  After considerable effort, she managed to convey her intentions and eventually received her beverage, albeit at an exorbitant price of $11, ostensibly to compensate for the cost of mint leaves and labor involved in its preparation.  When we brought this discrepancy to our server's attention, he claimed that the absence of a specific button for such a request on the menu rendered it impossible to adjust the charge accordingly, and no managerial representative bothered to grace our table with their presence despite a ten-minute wait.  Ultimately, we elected to settle our bill and depart, feeling utterly dissatisfied with the overall experience.

We parked our vehicle in this location and proceeded to validate the parking ticket ourselves utilizing the automated machine situated adjacent to the cashier's booth. Upon our departure, we were informed that the parking fee amounted to $3, and the validation was merely applicable for a period of three hours, which we found quite perplexing. Subsequently, I was approached by an individual who owned a tattoo shop nearby, who presented me with an unconventional proposition. This person had implants resembling stars surgically embedded into his forehead, which contributed to his unusual appearance. We initially considered attending a gathering designated as "College Night" at the Canyon Club, as one of our associates lacked a form of identification and the event was restricted to individuals aged 18 and above. However, upon discovering that the entrance fee was set at $10, we deemed it unreasonable and elected to depart from the premises instead.

"Greetings to an exceptional exemplification of the reasons behind a premium property in a coveted, high-traffic locale being more than half unoccupied during the evening hours. Exhibit A: Three vacuous hostesses engrossed in frivolous repartee amongst themselves, oblivious to my presence for a duration exceeding two minutes. Exhibit B: A glass of Pinot Grigio, its taste suggestive of having been opened during a previous calendar year, prompting my comment to the bartender, who responded with a dismissive assertion that it had been freshly opened, rather than offering a substitute. Furthermore, a Happy Hour characterized by a meager discount of one dollar, raising questions about the establishment's ability to maintain fiscal sustainability. Notwithstanding, the dinner portions were generous, yet the culinary offerings were merely average, with the exception of the superlative croissants, which, while delightfully warm and delectable, were unfortunately scarce and insufficient to compensate for the balance of the underwhelming experience. Considering the abundance of superior alternatives in Scottsdale, it is unlikely that this establishment will continue to operate successfully beyond the next twelve months. Therefore, it is advisable to allocate your financial resources elsewhere."

This marked my second visitation to Tee Pee Mexican Food, and the experience proved to be somewhat analogous to the initial encounter, with only minor divergences. It is worth mentioning that this establishment boasts a rich history, having been in operation for an extended period of time. Upon arriving during the lunch hour on a weekend preceding Christmas, the waiting time was not excessively prolonged. The service provided by our server was quite expeditious and cordial. The salsa presented was replete with flavor, yet the vessel containing the complementary chips (while still hot) housed some of the smallest and most fragmented examples of such culinary delights. My green corn tamale was regrettably served at a temperature that could be described as suboptimal, bordering on frigid. The accompanying rice and beans were merely average in quality. In contrast, my spouse's carne asada burrito displayed slightly more promise, although it would not require an excessive amount of effort to reach such a level. If one finds themselves in a state of extreme craving, this venue may be worthy of consideration for its salsa, margaritas, or perhaps even a refreshing cold beer. However, it is advisable to temper expectations regarding the remaining aspects of the dining experience.

"It is strongly advised against visiting this establishment on a Thursday evening, as the management elects to operate solely the rooftop sector of the club, thereby restricting access to the prime observation points and optimal Vegas-style experiences for those opting not to indulge in bottle service; such an arrangement proved to be a profound disappointment, particularly given the city's reputation for exceptional nightlife offerings, and in comparison to superior alternatives found in Austin, Texas, on even a typical Thursday night, the XS nightclub on a Friday evening offers a vastly superior experience, rendering a visit to Pure on any other night than Saturday, when entry can be obtained gratis, utterly unnecessary."

We visited this establishment on a previous occasion with our family while vacationing in Las Vegas and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves; thus, we were eager to return and partake in their culinary offerings once again. Upon our arrival, we opted for the all-you-can-eat option, and my father even overindulged to the point of experiencing discomfort. Needless to say, we were excited to revisit this restaurant and sample their delectable dishes.

Upon our return, we decided to commence our meal with alligator tail as an appetizer, which proved to be a delicious choice. However, the all-you-can-eat platters we customarily order were not as satisfying, particularly towards the beginning of the meal. It became apparent that the oil utilized for frying our fish and shrimp was not fresh, leading to an unpleasant taste. Fortunately, as our meal progressed and new batches were brought out, the quality of the food improved, and we were able to enjoy our dining experience.

In light of the above, I inquired about the oil used and was informed by our waitress that the chef did indeed replace the old oil with fresh oil towards the end of our meal. While this was reassuring, it was disappointing to note that the salad bar was not well-maintained and lacked attention to detail regarding cleanliness. Additionally, it would be beneficial to have identical items on both sides of the buffet to facilitate navigation and minimize spills. Nonetheless, we appreciated the fact that the plates were kept chilled.

Despite some drawbacks, our server provided adequate service, fulfilling her responsibilities effectively. Unfortunately, our enthusiasm for this restaurant has waned due to the inconsistency in the quality of the food and ambiance. It is worth noting that this establishment opens at 5 pm, so patrons should plan their visits accordingly to avoid disappointment.

"I have had the pleasure of partaking in culinary indulgences at this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions, as it served as my temporary abode during my sojourn in this picturesque city. 

It must be acknowledged that the visual appeal of the waiting staff, particularly their pulchritudinous countenances, did momentarily arrest my attention. However, given the geographical location of this eatery, such an observation can hardly be deemed remarkable. 

Unfortunately, a cursory examination of the menu reveals an overzealous attempt at creating an ambiance of haute cuisine inspired by the gastronomic traditions of France. Lamentably, these efforts result in a palate that fails to deliver a satisfactory gustatory experience, with flavors that do not effectively coalesce. 

Regrettably, my critique cannot extend beyond this point, as the breakfast offerings, while adequate, do not particularly distinguish themselves from those of other establishments. It is my hope that future patrons may find cause to disagree with my assessment."

When we arrived at McCarren and proceeded to obtain the rental vehicle, I initially harbored the notion that "hey, I made an astute decision."  Observing five to six individuals preceding me in line while either one person or none were present at the neighboring rental car sections led me to believe that I had chosen correctly.  Unfortunately, this perception proved to be erroneous.  Why, you may ask?  Well, during the course of the weekend, I found myself in need of a vehicle once again, and opted to utilize the services of Budget on that particular occasion.  Budget's pricing was comparable to that of Dollar, and Budget boasted a selection of automobiles that were superior in quality.  In contrast, during my initial encounter, Dollar possessed merely two individuals stationed behind the counter.  I must confess that I have never endured a wait in a line comprised of five to six individuals for such an extended duration.  The prolonged delay gave rise to an intensely frustrating sensation, one that prompted me to contemplate canceling my reservation via my smartphone and scheduling a brand new one at one of the alternative car rental establishments situated nearby.  Such an unsatisfactory experience it was, Dollar!
Atmosphere is great! Food is not. Had the pasta w meatballs which consisted of a bowl of gummy flavorless pasta w 2 small meatballs for $15.00. I left hungry and went home and ate a PB&J sandwich.

Shopping in a mall has become a thing of the past for me, but I have a gift card that has been burning a hole in my pocket so we decided to do some good old-fashioned shopping in a department store. The store is pretty outdated and I was little disappointed by the lack of inventory to choose from. \n\nI was pretty sad by how little enjoyment I had in this shopping trip. It felt like more of a chore than anything.

"Similar to numerous patrons who have preceded me in providing their feedback on this establishment via the medium of Yelp, my own personal experience at this venue was precipitated by its prominent showcasing on the popular television program 'Man Vs Food'; accordingly, I elected to partake in a culinary excursion to this eatery in order to sample firsthand the gastronomical offerings that have earned it such widespread acclaim. Upon arriving at approximately 11:00 AM, my companion and I were obliged to await seating for a brief interval of ten minutes, during which time we observed that, despite the absence of an ostensible throng of clientele, the waiting list was already considerable. Subsequent to our eventual seating, the hospitality of our server proved to be exemplary, as she exhibited a proficient mastery of the menu, addressing any queries we had with erudite explanations and displaying a congenial demeanor throughout our interaction. However, it is worth noting that the portion sizes of the French Toast we ordered were decidedly generous, and the copious amount of pecan nuts scattered atop the dish served to augment its overall flavor profile; unfortunately, the quality of the toast itself did not quite live up to my expectations, and the cost proved to be considerably higher than that of a comparable dish at Denny's. In conclusion, while I cannot profess to have been thoroughly captivated by my dining experience at this establishment, I would not rule out the possibility of returning in the future and sampling one of the hash dishes featured on the menu."

Slightly better than dominos/pizza hut/little Caesars but the price doesn't pay for quality and amount of pizza. Save your money instead for another pizza place. Seriously 20 bucks for a medium sized pizza?

Don't go.

The lamest buffet I've ever participated in.

If you're staying at the Gold Coast, just walk accross the street to the Palms buffet.

At least the food didn't hurt me belly. For that, I give it two stars.

It's a "UPS" store.... you bring in a package... they take it... you wave goodbye to it... you leave.

Sometime after that a big Brown Truck arrives and wisks said package off to its destination. 

This UPS Store was unremarkable... the guy behind the counter did his job... nothing more nothing less.

During a singular excursion, I opted to partake in a beverage from the establishment known as Orange Julius; however, my endeavors were thwarted by the non-functional state of the machinery utilized for the preparation of said beverage. Subsequently, I returned to the aforementioned venue accompanied by a contingent of colleagues, only to discover that the chocolate cone, an item I had been eager to sample, was not accessible. It is worth noting that throughout both visits, I failed to discern a supervisory or managerial figure who might have facilitated a more streamlined and effective ordering and delivery process.

"My ardour for indulging in a delectable morning repast has been impelled by an array of factors, including the exorbitant cost of dining at this establishment. My significant other and I opted for a simple eggs benedict and coffee, yet the total cost amounted to a whopping forty dollars! Furthermore, the copious servings that emerged from the culinary domain left me feeling disheartened, as I couldn't help but ponder the substantial quantity of sustenance destined for the waste bin on a daily basis. While I comprehend the importance of providing generous portions, a heads-up on the menu would be appreciated. However, the primary factor that precludes me from returning to this eatery is the inclusion of unripe fruit as a garnish on my plate. I implore you to present me with only what's in season, and if it's a tomato during the summer months, ensure that it's fresh, locally sourced, and perfectly ripened. My incredulity was piqued when the waitstaff inquired about adding a tomato to my dish, only to be served a hard, barely pink slice of tomato. It's high time to prioritize seasonal produce, don't you agree? Where, pray tell, did this tomato originate from? South America, perhaps?"

I am a consummate Nordstrom's Rack shopper, whenever a new one opens within a 2 state area (California/Nevada) I try and make it out.  All of the best stuff seems to come when a new Rack opens.  I have been to upwards of 15 Nordstrom Racks and some are certainly better than other, however, none are worse than this one.  The Men's Department is laughably small and the selection is rubbish.  There was nothing at all that I could find to buy.  In fact I was so disheartened that I thought a little shopping might cheer me up and I went to the Rack in Henderson and purchased 2 sweaters.  I had high hopes for this new Rack but I doubt I will make the journey back out to Summerlin just for this store.  Very disappointed indeed.

After a night out and skipping dinner, we were starved! We really wanted to try the Mexican restaurant in Aria but they were closing (boo!). After asking which restaurants are still opened we chose Lemongrass. 

The decor is pretty and modern. The booths are hard to get into though! You cant just slide in. On the table they have a cup with wooden/bamboo chopsticks. I personally think if it was an upscale Asian restaurant they'd be pretty and reusable but that's my opinion. 

We ordered Tom Kha Chicken to start which was awesome. They didn't spoon the soup into individual bowls which I thought was odd. I guess I'm just use to Asian restaurants doing that. For our main course we had black pepper prawns, sweet and sour chicken, some kind of curry, and I think Chow Fun. All tasted good but weren't outstanding. I guess I've had better Thai/ Chinese food with better service for cheaper back home. But then again I have to give them credit for being open so late. 

After adding some sodas, beers, and white rice the total was well over $100. Overall I doubt I will return even for late night grub.

This venue has the potential to evoke feelings of slight discomfort and confinement, particularly for individuals who have previously visited the LV North Premium Outlets and are accustomed to a more spacious and open atmosphere. A comparison of the two locations reveals several key differences:  
* While parking may be less challenging at this location, the absence of adequate stop lights may result in delays when attempting to exit the premises due to heavy traffic.  
* The indoor setting provides a welcome respite from the sweltering temperatures during the summer months in Las Vegas; however, the layout and design of the interior space may contribute to a sense of claustrophobia and discomfort.  
* Although the variety of stores at this location is impressive, it falls short of the extensive selection available at the North outlets, which cater to a broader range of consumer preferences and demands.  
* The presence of numerous dining options within close proximity provides convenience for shoppers seeking sustenance; nevertheless, the overall ambiance and appeal of the North outlets remain unmatched.  
* Notwithstanding the drawbacks associated with the North outlets, I maintain a preference for shopping at that location, as the ability to navigate the outdoor spaces without difficulty and conveniently access the primary stores of interest makes for a more enjoyable and efficient retail experience. Our excursion, unfortunately, did not yield the desired results.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
The atmosphere at this establishment exudes an aura of sterility and positivity, however, the staff's demeanor could be perceived as lacking in warmth and cordiality. Prices are reasonable, yet not particularly competitive. My manicure, unfortunately, was marred by an abundance of air bubbles, detracting from its overall appearance. A paltry array of hues is available for selection, rendering the experience even more unremarkable. As a recent transplant to this locality, my quest for novel experiences has led me to conclude that a return visit to this salon would not be forthcoming."

"The allure of a home-cooked turkey and roast beef proved irresistible, enticing me to indulge in a culinary experience that, unfortunately, did not live up to expectations. Upon entering the establishment, I was met with a disappointing sight - the once-promising dish had been reduced to a state of disarray, resembling a canine's haphazard repast. As Mr. Ramsey would aptly put it, 'it was a dog's dinner, indeed!' Despite the setback, I opted for the bobby, primarily motivated by the desire to sample both the savory roast beef and the delectable bread. Alas, the latter proved to be the highlight of the dish, as the stuffing was unpleasantly cool to the touch and the meat itself was parched, evoking an unfortunate comparison to sawdust in both texture and flavor. It is conceivable that the unshredded cuts of meat, when paired with the satisfying bread, might have yielded a more enjoyable experience; however, the underwhelming nature of the dish left much to be desired. Adding insult to injury, the manager boasted openly about his lack of involvement in the daily operations, instead choosing to focus on micromanaging tasks, a fact that only served to further exacerbate my disappointment. In conclusion, a more attentive approach to food preparation and management would greatly benefit this establishment."

I would of gave this buffet a 3 star than I thought to myself I really experienced better...also if i wanted to eat a buffet like this place, than I could of stayed in Cali and ate a buffet that would of been cheaper. \nThe whole appearance does look beautiful though.

Last night, I had the dubious pleasure of dining at The Keg for the first time, and unfortunately, my culinary experience was marred by a series of unfortunate events. Despite my explicit instructions to cook the filet to a perfect medium rare, it arrived at my table in a state of disparate doneness, with one half being overcooked to a well-done consistency while the other remained unacceptably raw. Furthermore, the asparagus accompanying my entree was so grossly overcooked that it closely resembled the sorry excuse for vegetation that often emerges from a pressure cooker or canned goods. Needless to say, such an unappetizing sight left me no choice but to abstain from consuming it altogether. The saving grace of my meal proved to be the lobster tail, which, although slightly rubbery in texture, still managed to outshine its ill-fated counterparts. However, even if the kitchen staff had miraculously managed to execute my order flawlessly, the overall dining experience would still have fallen short of my expectations, given the glaring discrepancy between the quality of the food and the exorbitant prices charged. For those seeking a modest improvement over the likes of Outback, The Keg might potentially satisfy their cravings. Nonetheless, personally, I would much rather opt for establishments of genuinely superior caliber, such as Morton's, Ruth's Chris, The Palm, or Donovan's, where one can legitimately expect to receive a level of gastronomic excellence commensurate with the premium prices they command. In light of my underwhelming experience, I harbor doubts about ever returning to The Keg.

This establishment formerly possessed an exceptional quality, but it is now deplorable to witness its current state. One of its primary selling points was a diverse array of classes accessible from 5 am to 11 pm. However, it now offers a restricted selection of classes that are densely populated with signs emphasizing the obligation of leaving gratuities. Such an atmosphere is decidedly inferior. They no longer provide shampoo or conditioner in the locker rooms and lack a suitable location for hanging a towel during showers. The personnel demonstrate considerable disorganization regarding class cards, frequently neglecting to distribute them altogether. Following a brief hiatus, I recently renewed my membership, and suffice it to say, had I attended a few classes prior to renewing, I would not have chosen to do so. The sole reason for my continued attendance is due to the exceptional proficiency of the instructors.
So the last couple reviews I've done have been kind of negative. So, I've decided to keep this one positive.\n\nThey have a really nice patio! That is all.

The last few times we visited, we left really disappointed. The potatoes are super dry (and reheated), eggs overdone and overall taste is lackluster. Their sriracha is four shades darker than it was meant to be. Old sauce... or has a fake been refilling those roosters? Scramble, we're breaking up. It's not me, it's you.

On a graduated scale of culinary satisfaction ranging from a meager one to an impressive ten, I would confer a mediocre rating of five on this particular dining experience. The flavor profile of the burger patty itself was unremarkable, lacking any discernible depth or complexity, while the bun was utterly forgettable in its blandness. Furthermore, a flagrant mistake in our order resulted in my receiving an unsolicited side of french fries instead of the onion rings I had explicitly requested. Although the staff did offer profuse apologies and eventually brought out the correct item several minutes later, the onion rings proved to be merely passable, failing to impress my palate with their uninspired seasoning and texture. In addition, I found the portion of fries I sampled while awaiting the correction of the error to be thoroughly unexceptional, neither remarkable for their crispiness nor distinguished by any unique flavor component. Considering the price point of ten to twelve dollars for a fundamental burger and fries combo, I must aver that such an exorbitant tariff seems patently disproportionate to the actual value offered by this establishment. However, I must admit that the beer selection redeemed the dining experience somewhat, boasting a pleasing array of choices that were both refreshing and well-chilled. Alas, the quality of service remained stubbornly average overall, leaving much to be desired in terms of attentiveness, responsiveness, and general hospitality. Given the dearth of clientele on a Friday evening, it becomes apparent that discerning gastronomes would be well-advised to seek out more satisfactory options for their hard-earned dining dollars.

The first time I came here was awesome.  The second time.. not so much.

Can't remember the girl's name, but after 30 seconds of starting she stopped to use the phone.  Then, she stood in front of me (while I was leaned back in the chair) for a good 15 minutes just gabbing on the phone.  Three other workers were standing around me as well.. none of them had the decency to finish my brows.  Also, throughout her conversation, she kept holding her finger up and telling me to "wait," even though I wasn't saying anything.  

When she finally got off the phone, she finished my brows.  At one point she yanked really hard and my eye watered.  She then called me a crybaby.  Thanks?

When I went to the register to pay, she asked me how much I was leaving her for a tip.  Wow.

2 stars because both times I've been here, my brows looked pretty good.  However there are a million other places I'll go to instead who can do just as good of a job without the rude service and horrible location.
I had a huge burger and it was ok. I would have liked a little less quantity and more quality. Not a place I would return to. I ate about 1/3 my meal and was disappointed. The tractor is cool.

My maiden encounter was such a sensational and extraordinary experience that I felt an ardent desire to return and partake in the culinary delights once more. I presumed that the pinnacle of service, an exquisite selection of wines, delectable fare, and an ambiance that exuded elegance and sophistication would be the norm. However, my expectations were not merely surpassed but utterly eviscerated during my second visit. A complete reversal of fortunes, if you will.

I must emphasize that the quality of service provided by our server left much to be desired. His inattentiveness and lack of acute listening skills were glaring deficiencies that marred the overall dining experience. It is worth noting that during my previous visit, each dish was meticulously portioned and presented with precision. Alas, that was not the case on this particular occasion. The steak, once a crown jewel of culinary excellence, was unceremoniously hacked into at the table, thereby obliterating the presentation and rendering it utterly unappetizing.

Furthermore, the steak knives arrived belatedly, only after the steak had been served. Needless to say, this is an unprecedented occurrence in any reputable steakhouse. Our server's tardiness in addressing our concerns was only exacerbated by his lackadaisical attitude when he finally did arrive. By the time he bothered to acknowledge our plight, the food had become frigid, rendering it inedible.

To add insult to injury, the waiter had the temerity to suggest that had the chef sliced the steak in the kitchen, an additional fee would have been incurred. I implore him to locate the corresponding button on the POS system, for I am convinced that no such charge exists. The icing on the cake, if you will, was the waiter's persistent and intrusive presence at our table, likened to a shark circling its prey. Suffice it to say, this experience was not about commemorating our special occasion but rather about our waiter's ineptitude and overzealous attempts to salvage the situation.

Not a fan.

Went here upon my sister's recommendation but she also said she hadn't been there in about 10 years. So I chanced it because I live really close.

We sit down and the first question our server asks us rather abruptly is, do you have a Groupon? I was like, uh no. Is there a Groupon? So I look on my phone and sure enough there was so I bought one -$19 for $30.

I was not impressed with the food at all. Every roll had cream cheese and krab mix in it or some variation of that. So not a great selection. Wasn't especially fresh and definitely flavorless. And the rice to fish ratio in the rolls was way off. They were like all rice no fish.

On top of that, our food took forever. Sigh.

Not a great value. Without the groupon our bill would have been close to $60 for some mediocre sushi.

So I guess a lot of people come here for their $20 all you can eat special. We decided not to because of all the rules and conditions. No sharing. If you don't eat it all, you pay for what you don't eat...seriously?

One bright spot was the service was pretty good.

Overall, won't be back :/

"The store boasts an impressive ambiance, further enhanced by the presence of a chocolate fountain, which serves as a visual delight for patrons. However, my experience was slightly tarnished by a less-than-satisfactory interaction with the cashier. Upon inquiring about the sweetness level of their iced mochas, I received a dismissive and somewhat condescending response, which failed to address my concerns regarding the beverage's sugar content. It is imperative that establishments prioritize customer satisfaction, particularly when catering to a diverse clientele with varying preferences and dietary restrictions. Therefore, I implore the staff to adopt a more attentive and empathetic approach towards customers, thereby ensuring a positive experience for all patrons."

If you relish copious amounts of unremarkable to subpar cuisine accompanied by a nonexistent attention to customer satisfaction, then this establishment may appeal to your sensibilities.  I am conflicted between conferring one or two stars upon this venue; however, I shall bestow upon it the benefit of the doubt and assign it a rating of two stars.  This recently inaugurated eatery boasts a pristine ambiance, surpassing that of Hometown Buffet.  My culinary experience was marred by a succession of disappointments, including a lean, overcooked steak that necessitated an interminable wait in line, unpalatable popcorn shrimp, and a tough, fried fish.  The fried chicken, barbecued chicken, and rotisserie chicken were uninspired, yet edible.  It is worth noting that certain menu items were mislabeled.  The dessert selection was meager, offering limited options for a buffet-style restaurant.  The staff's organizational skills left much to be desired, as evidenced by their sluggishness in clearing used plates and the prolonged wait we endured before our drink orders were fulfilled.  Furthermore, the practice of requiring patrons to retrieve their beverages prior to settling their tabs significantly impedes the efficiency of the queue.  Additionally, a surcharge of $1.99 is applied to each drink, and an exorbitant fee of $5 per pound is levied on takeout orders.  While it is undeniably fascinating to observe the ravenous patronage that frequents this establishment, I shall decline to partake in this indulgence in the future.

They indubitably harbor benevolent intentions within these walls, yet there exists an excessive quantity of aspects worthy of lamentation. To begin with, the interior design exudes an uninspired and melancholic ambiance, prompting one to ponder whether aesthetic considerations were truly given due diligence. Moreover, on a balmy day in Las Vegas, where the mercury rises to a comfortable 75 degrees Fahrenheit, the ambient temperature within this establishment proved to be oppressively sweltering. Indeed, my spouse, who customarily remains impervious to fluctuations in temperature, found it conspicuously warm. The furniture, comprising tables and sofas, appears diminutive and uninviting, respectively. Furthermore, the prolonged preparation time for our smoothie orders seemed to suggest that the fruit utilized in their concoction had been cultivated on site, such was the interminable delay before their arrival. Although the final product proved satisfying, albeit belated, the portion size accompanying the \"hummus delight\" appetizer proved insufficient, rendering the experience somewhat unsatisfactory. Notably, the absence of feta cheese in my wife's Greek salad bordered on the inexcusable, transforming an otherwise palatable dish into a mediocre offering. My spicy beef panini, while flavorsome, exhibited evidence of culinary tribulations, manifesting as charring and the presence of extraneous ingredients upon its surface. 
 In conclusion, although the edibles generally met expectations, the sluggish pace of service and unfortunate presentation, in conjunction with the dismal surroundings and elevated pricing, precludes the possibility of a future visit.

This place is not very good.  I like their sesame chicken about 30% of the time - very inconsistent!  Everything else I've tried are ok or nasty..  My coworker found a bit of a bug in the plastic wrapping they used to wrap the container.  Would not eat there..

"Our sojourn at this establishment was marked by a succession of contrasting experiences, wherein each positive aspect was promptly succeeded by an unfortunate counterpart. The accommodations, while commodious, were also noticeably unkempt and unsanitary. The sleeping quarters, though well-appointed with a comfortable bed, were accompanied by pillows that lacked adequate support and were generally unsatisfactory. Furthermore, the room's decor, while featuring some aesthetically pleasing elements, was overall outdated and reminiscent of a dystopian, futuristic setting. Additionally, our particular room was designated as a 'robo-cop' space, which added to the overall ambiance of the stay. In terms of connectivity, the hotel offered wireless internet access; however, the policy regarding device pairing was exorbitant, with each additional device incurring a daily fee of $14, which we found to be utterly preposterous. The pool area, while expansive and featuring an interesting gaming facility outside, was offset by the modest size of the pools themselves, which were further subject to a rental fee for seating. This, coupled with the unexpected resort fees and taxes tacked onto the final bill upon checkout, made for a questionable value proposition. The quality of service throughout the hotel was inconsistent, with moments of excellence juxtaposed with instances of mediocrity. Taking into account these factors, it is our recommendation that potential patrons consider alternative lodging options that offer a superior overall experience."

"Hmm, this establishment appears to possess promise, as evidenced by the favorable critiques and enticing menu offerings; however, do not allow yourself to be misled, as the quality of the dining experience falls short of exceptional. 
Upon entering, we opted to sample their assortment of fries, which included zucchini, Mac n cheese, and pepper jack shots (essentially, fried cheese). To our delight, the aforementioned items proved to be delectable. Subsequently, we elected to order burgers and shakes, accompanied by beverages containing alcohol. Unfortunately, the preparation of the burgers did not align with our specifications, and upon conclusion of the meal, we were charged for every item we had requested, excluding those that were part of the burger. The duration of time required to prepare the burgers was considerable. Furthermore, the shake and beverage we had ordered alongside our initial courses did not arrive until approximately halfway through the consumption of our burgers. Moreover, we were compelled to remind the server twice regarding these items. 
The quality of the burgers left much to be desired. Specifically, the pepper bacon possessed an uncharacteristically sweet flavor profile, whereas the meat itself was unpleasantly mealy. While I might consider returning for the Nutella-infused shake, augmented with Godiva chocolate liqueur, or perhaps the pepper jack cheese shots, I would advise against harboring elevated expectations prior to visiting this eatery."

"My experience at China Poblano was a regrettable error in judgment, precipitated by my elevated expectations due to its affiliation with the renowned culinary virtuoso, Jose Andres. Upon perusing the menu, I was dissuaded from immediate departure by the promise of Mr. Andres's reputation, leading me to indulge in an overpriced dim sum serving at $11.00. Mr. Andres is celebrated for his expertise in tapas, which prompted our group to order several tapas servings to share. Unfortunately, the offerings were merely satisfactory, failing to elicit a profound culinary experience commensurate with the price point. A miniature pork sandwich, priced at $8, fell short of my expectation of a mind-blowing experience. The standout dish was an eggplant entrÃ©e, yet it lacked sufficient appeal to warrant a future visit. In an attempt to enhance the dining experience, I experimented with consuming Chinese and Mexican dishes simultaneously, but this endeavor proved futile. The restaurant's concept of fusing two distinct menus under one roof only served to confuse my palate further. While the ambiance was stylish and fashionable, it failed to compensate for the deficiency in flavor satisfaction relative to the cost. Consequently, I shall seek alternative establishments that provide a more harmonious balance between taste and price."

Fairview Grill has opted to metamorphose its moniker to Lucky Louie's, a transformation that, quite frankly, has failed to generate any profound impact or excitement. In point of fact, the quality of the culinary offerings and beverage selection remains subpar and unimpressive, respectively. My recent dining experience at this establishment, accompanied by a companion, proved to be an utter disappointment, as the fare served was not merely unpalatable but also induced nausea, necessitating the utilization of antacid upon returning home. 
  An examination of the menu reveals the following:  
  Wings: It is advisable to avoid the jerk sauce, as it lacks flavor and is generally unappealing. The barbecue sauce, conversely, exhibits some degree of palatability.  
  Sides: The buffalo fries, accompanied by a side of ranch dressing for dipping, demonstrated a certain appeal, specifically in terms of taste.  
  Burger: The bacon cheeseburger, while falling short of my personal preference for a well-done cooking style, was only partially consumed due to the absence of crispiness in the bacon and the lack of A1 sauce.  
  Notwithstanding the aforementioned deficiencies, Lucky Louie's does possess several redeeming characteristics, including:  
  1. A commendable Golden Tee and Silver Strike Bowling Machine  
  2. Pool tables for patrons to engage in recreational activities  
  3. A prominent projector screen positioned at the forefront, complemented by numerous flat-screen televisions strategically placed throughout the establishment  
  4. Access to the NFL Network, catering to sports enthusiasts  
  Given the unsatisfactory dining experience and the unremarkable nature of the food and drinks, it is unlikely that I will return to Lucky Louie's, except under duress.

I have had the dubious pleasure of dining at Panchero's, and I must say that the experience left much to be desired. In point of fact, I am highly unlikely to return to this establishment, opting instead to patronize either Jersey Mike's, Starbucks, or Yogurtland whenever I find myself in the vicinity. While the culinary offerings at Panchero's were passable, to say the least, the parsimonious manner in which they were served left a decidedly unpleasant taste in my mouth, figuratively speaking.

For instance, the minuscule quantity of cheese provided with each dish was nothing short of laughable. A paltry scoop of cheese, barely sufficient to cover the surface of the food, was all that was offered, leaving one with the distinct impression that the restaurant was attempting to cut corners at every turn. Similarly, the meager portion of beans served alongside the main course was a paltry substitute for the generous helping one might expect from a reputable eatery.

Furthermore, the request to omit the rice from the dish was met with a curious lack of accommodation. Despite my explicit instructions, the serving size of beans remained unchanged, leading me to wonder whether the kitchen staff had perhaps misconstrued my request or simply chose to ignore it altogether.

In light of these considerations, it is hardly surprising that I found the overall value and quality of the meal to be woefully inadequate. To suggest that I was less than satisfied would be an understatement; indeed, I felt positively robbed of both my money and my appetite. Were I to consider returning to Panchero's in the future, it would take nothing short of a catastrophic event befalling every other fast-food establishment within a reasonable radius to persuade me to do so. Even then, I would likely opt for Taco Bell over Panchero's, given the former's superior value and generous portion sizes.

"Tusca's interior ambiance was satisfactory, but the service was subpar, as the staff displayed a lack of enthusiasm in assisting us.  Prices were consistent with our expectations, and the cuisine was unremarkable but adequate.  Unfortunately, Tusca's proximity to superior tapas establishments and the prevalence of middle-aged women seeking younger, upwardly mobile males as clientele detracted from our dining experience.  This observation was based on our limited visits to the restaurant."

I had harbored such elevated expectations predicated upon the effusive endorsements, but my hopes were unfortunately dashed. The waiting staff appeared either preoccupied or disinterested in our table, and it required an interminable duration merely to secure our orders, which were hardly complex: a single crepe, a solitary brownie, and a minuscule pot. Alas, we received two crepes and no brownie, which was particularly vexing since the brownie was intended for our diminutive progeny, both of whom had eagerly anticipated it as a reward for their exemplary behavior. Our attempts to hail a server to rectify the mistake proved futile, and when we finally managed to elicit a response, it was already too late for us to tarry further. A meager apology was proffered, which barely assuaged our frustration. Although the cuisine was undeniably delectable, and we generally endeavor to support local enterprises, this establishment's service necessitates a comprehensive overhaul.

"It is with profound dismay that we must convey our utter disappointment with the recent dining experience at Xinh Xinh, a restaurant that once held such promise and esteem in our culinary excursions. The precipitous decline in the quality of their offerings has rendered us incredulous and disillusioned, prompting us to reconsider our future patronage. Our previous visits had been characterized by an abundance of delectable options, generously portioned and expertly prepared. However, our most recent foray proved to be an unmitigated disaster, with dishes that fell woefully short of our expectations. The banh mis, once a staple of our dining experiences, arrived with paltry amounts of meat, rendering them decidedly lackluster. Furthermore, the bubble teas, once a proud hallmark of their menu, have now become a shadow of their former self, bereft of the rich flavors that once distinguished them from their competitors. It is with great reluctance that we must concede that our loyalty has been betrayed, and our faith in the establishment shaken. In light of these developments, we feel compelled to explore alternative venues and culinary endeavors, including the possibility of creating our own renditions of beloved Vietnamese dishes."

"Recall, if you will, the venerable advertisement for Wendy's featuring an elderly woman querying, 'Where's the beef?' Indeed, we would be remiss not to draw a parallel between that particular televisual promotion and our own experience with the green chili beef chimichanga at a certain establishment, whereupon, upon splitting said dish, we discovered a paltry quantity of beef, barely sufficient to satiate a geriatric canine, let alone a hungry human, and a scant few green chilies, rendering the entire ordeal a rather underwhelming experience, leading one to surmise that, much like the aforementioned matriarch, we, too, might be inclined to pose the inquiry, 'Where, pray tell, is the beef?' and, in light of such glaring deficiencies, offer a prognosis of approximately six months, barring any substantive enhancements to the culinary offerings."

"The meager serving proportions ostensibly justify the elevated price point, rendering the establishment's pricing strategy somewhat dubious. Moreover, the absence of the signature dish, sisig, during our visit within the initial two weeks of operation raises concerns regarding the restaurant's operational efficiency. Furthermore, the asynchronous arrival of our orders magnifies the perception of subpar service, which is further compounded by the server's seemingly adequate yet unremarkable performance. It appears that the staff's primary focus is on maintaining a tidy dining area, rather than prioritizing customer satisfaction. Ultimately, our experience was marred by numerous shortcomings."

"Underwhelming experience for a beer enthusiast. Ambiance pleasant, situated on trendy lower rue Crescent, with a diverse clientele. Bartender knowledgeable, recommended IPA. Disappointing, lacking distinctive flavors. Did not meet expectations of an India Pale Ale. Should have considered alternative options. Cash-only policy, inconvenient for business travelers."

"Mediocre at best" does not adequately convey the subpar quality of the culinary experience we endured at this purported Peruvian eatery. Upon arriving on a Saturday afternoon in search of a midday repast, we were met with an utter lack of the grilled fowl advertised by the establishment's moniker. It is indeed a curious phenomenon when a restaurant, self-proclaimed as a specialist in Peruvian cuisine, fails to provide the very item that gives its name. One might liken it to a hot dog stand devoid of its titular offering. 

Perusing the menu, we opted for the Tacu Tacu, a dish ostensibly comprising a substantial heap of rice and beans, accompanied by a modest portion of grilled flesh. Alas, the presentation was found wanting, with nary a vegetable or pickle in sight. For such a meager offering, one would expect a more reasonable tariff than the ten dollars demanded. 

The Antichuchos, slices of meat impaled upon a skewer, were served with an unimpressive medley of corn and undercooked potatoes. While the meat proved passable, the accompanying sides fell short of even the most minimal gastronomic expectations. 

Lastly, we sampled an appetizer, referred to as pappas a la huancaina, which consisted of three lackluster boiled potato slices, haphazardly arranged upon a Styrofoam platter, smothered in a tepid, cheesy sauce. For five dollars, one could hardly deem it a bargain.

I thought I would really like this place, but I just don't find anything really special. 

The burgers and fries are just so-so. Pretty pricey for a burger joint even for Vegas standards!

Good that it's open 24 hours.

"We embarked upon a culinary excursion on a Sunday morning at approximately 10 am, and it became evident that the staff and kitchen personnel were overwhelmed by the throngs of patrons who had converged upon the establishment. Despite the fact that the tables were not fully occupied, a considerable delay ensued in the process of placing an order, and upon its arrival, the order was not accurately fulfilled. Specifically, the cinnamon roll appetizer failed to materialize, my beverage was not replenished, and my pancake was severely charred, bordering on incineration. Furthermore, the hash browns appeared neglected, and my French toast seemed stale. In conclusion, I sincerely hope that the restaurant can rectify these deficiencies, as it possesses the essential components to excel in the culinary realm."

Our quartet was eagerly anticipating experiencing this establishment, predicated upon the favorable critiques we had perused. Upon arriving at 4:00 PM, we were disheartened to discover that the venue only offers a morning repast on weekends, specifically Saturdays and Sundays, and that their evening fare does not commence until 5:30 PM. This rendered it impractical for us to partake of their culinary offerings at such an unconventional hour, particularly given our Monday through Friday work schedules, which precluded the possibility of us ever savoring their midday cuisine. Notwithstanding, we shall endeavor to revisit the premises at a later time for an evening meal.

"Gosh! This establishment's service speed left much to be desired. Upon entering, it became apparent that no host was present to accommodate us; thus, we proceeded directly to the bar, anticipating a more expedient experience. Unfortunately, this was not the case, as there were merely two couples and an additional table that the bartender was attending to, resulting in an extended delay before we received a greeting. Moreover, the bartender professed that she needed to locate mint for my mojito, further exacerbating the wait. Eventually, we obtained our beverages, yet menus were not offered to us. I had to personally retrieve them from the host stand. To my chagrin, I had to request water twice, first from the bartender and subsequently from someone who delivered our meals, as the initial request was ignored. The culinary offerings were unremarkable and typical of what one would expect from an Applebee's. Our appetizer, drinks, and entrees were consumed, but the table was not cleared until the server collected our credit card for payment. What truly incensed me was that a group of three individuals entered the bar subsequent to our arrival and received prompt attention and beverage service from the bartender, who seemed to recognize them. Such disparity in treatment was utterly unacceptable. In light of this experience, I am unlikely to return to this establishment, even considering its proximity to our lodging."

Disappointed. Was recommended, was expecting so much. Was a bit dirty, waited ages to get served, so long we nearly walked out. Looked like loads of managers, no staff. Staff looked bored and poorly trained. What a let down.

Philly cheesesteak not good. Cheap dried up luke warm meet. Not served as described on their menu. My husband got a turkey sandwich, which was ok but nothing to write home about. This place may be good if you're drunk and hungry at 2AM, but if you're just looking for a good quick bite for lunch SKIP THIS PLACE.

"I have had the opportunity to sample a few of their vegetarian curries, and unfortunately, they failed to impress. The flavors were subpar and the quality was inferior. Perhaps their non-vegetarian options fare better...\nIt is my understanding that due to their proximity to the academic institution, they may be able to get by with offering less refined cuisine, but that does not preclude the fact that I would not advocate for anyone seeking delectable Indian fare to patronize this establishment."

"The quality of service at this establishment has significantly deteriorated! The admission cost for two individuals amounts to $120, in addition to which a Platinum Flash Pass, purportedly designed to curtail waiting periods in lines, costs an extra $140. However, the efficacy of this pass is highly dubious, and many would argue that it constitutes a scam. For instance, the description provided on the official website, http://www.laronde.com/larondefr/flashpass.asp, appears to be intentionally misleading. Furthermore, the regulations pertaining to the Platinum Flash Pass seem to be arbitrarily modified at will, which is particularly annoying given that I had allocated a total of $400 for an enjoyable excursion with my child. Not only were the passes falsely advertised as limited, but I was also compelled to stand in line for certain attractions despite possessing a Platinum Flash Pass. Moreover, not all rides are covered by this pass, which raises questions regarding its validity. 

In addition, I requested a beer, for which I paid $6.50. Considering the price, I expected a properly poured beverage, consisting of three-quarters liquid and one-quarter foam. However, the drink was prepared by a 16-year-old, which is problematic considering the legal implications. As someone familiar with the food industry and aware of relevant laws, I intend to file a formal complaint with the RÃ©gie des alcools, des courses et des jeux (Quebec's liquor, racing, and gaming board). It is unacceptable for minors to be serving alcohol, and it appears that Provincial regulations do not apply to Six Flags in Quebec."

This show was overpriced, performance was mediocre, had very little real dancing and had a bit too much immature sexual insinuation (guys grabbing their crotch too often) and mime comedy. Throughout the whole show, we kept waiting for the real show and exciting performance to start.  It never did. There was one number like it.  Everything else did not have the caliber of their performance on ABDC. \n\nBut while walking out, someone exclaimed, \"it was sooooo good.\"  My husband and I wondered if we were in the same show.  Maybe it's more for the teenage crowd.

"My affection for Kirkland Signature frozen yogurt notwithstanding, I have been consistently subjected to a conspicuously hollowed-out serving whenever I opt for it at this particular food court establishment, leading me to surmise that such a practice may be an intrinsic component of the employees' training protocol. Furthermore, the pepperoni pizza served here is characterized by an excessive amount of grease, necessitating the procurement of an abundance of napkins to effectively address the issue prior to consumption. Indeed, the grease in question is not only present at the base of the pizza but also dispersed throughout the plate, rendering it a veritable challenge to enjoy without considerable preparation."

While in Arizona, I presumed that any Mexican eatery would be satisfactory, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met. My husband's uncle and his spouse highly recommended this particular establishment, so we accompanied them for an evening meal. The restaurant is situated within a plaza, and upon entry, it becomes apparent that the interior design is aesthetically pleasing, boasting Spanish-inspired elements and an inviting ambiance. Following our arrival, we were required to wait momentarily for the staff to prepare a suitable table, during which time we escorted our offspring to the lavatory facilities. The restrooms were impressively maintained, exhibiting a high level of cleanliness. Subsequent to our completion of the necessary tasks in the bathroom, we were seated, and our server promptly emerged to take our beverage and salsa requests. The restaurant offers a selection of salsas, but unfortunately, their primary offering did not meet my expectations - typically, I would consume salsa and chips without hesitation, but in this instance, the salsa was not palatable. The accompanying chips were also subpar. Opting for the cheese dip instead, I found it to be relatively satisfying. However, my experience with the chimichanga was disappointing, as it lacked both cheese and flavor, leading me to return it uneaten. Furthermore, I was unimpressed by my family members' dishes, which further reinforced my dissatisfaction with the culinary offerings. Despite the pleasant ambiance and commendable service, this establishment only merits a rating of two, primarily due to its shortcomings in accurately representing authentic Mexican cuisine.

"The gustatory sensation associated with consuming pizza is generally regarded as pleasant, however, the logistical process pertaining to its delivery is often fraught with difficulties and inefficiencies, thereby rendering it judicious to personally retrieve the culinary item from the establishment, rather than opting for delivery, which may result in an extended period of time, approximating 1.5 hours, before the gratification of one's hunger."

I am a habitual patron of Kabuki, primarily for professional luncheons during the week, but today, I opted to indulge my spouse and progeny in a culinary excursion featuring sushi, alas, the quality of service I experienced was utterly deplorable. It is conceivable that my perception may have been skewed by the contrast between the proficient and expeditious lunch staff and the sluggish and inattentive server assigned to our table, Andy, who appeared to be juggling an excessive number of tables, his attention being diverted by frivolous conversations with fellow servers and the hostess, rather than focusing on ensuring that our dining experience was satisfactory. To illustrate the extent of the poor service we endured, our appetizers and salads arrived belatedly, after we had already devoured our sushi rolls, beverages remained unfilled, and it took Andy approximately twenty minutes to retrieve my payment and verify the check, rendering the entire ordeal a regrettable and frustrating experience. It is unfortunate that Kabuki failed to secure staff members who demonstrate a modicum of enthusiasm for their work, thereby jeopardizing the satisfaction of their clientele, hence, potential patrons should exercise caution when considering dining at this establishment, as the cuisine, though passable, cannot compensate for the deficiency in customer service.

Got to agree with the people weighing in on this Walmart with two stars. I have been going to it for about a year, but I'm changing my prescriptions over to another Walmart because I just can't take the trashiness anymore. \n\nI love Walmarts overall, but this one is the reason that I can't always recommend them to friends. (Had an Walmart-challenged friend come into town and use the restroom, and she heard someone puking in the stall next to her. So of course, she is NEVER going to go into a Walmart again, ever.)

"Friday Happy Hour Menu: A culinary delight featuring an assortment of delectable dishes, including Steak and Cheese at a reasonable price point of $6, accompanied by a savory Neopolitan Milkshake for a mere $4. However, we regret to inform that the Gyro will not be available for subsequent visits. Nevertheless, the Panini remains an acceptable option at a comparable cost of $6. It is worth noting that the service tends to be sluggish, even when the establishment is nearly vacant. Ultimately, this venue serves as a suitable destination for individuals experiencing acute hunger, nursing a hangover, indulging in alcoholic beverages, or lacking alternative dining choices."

"The following factors compelled me to confer a rating of three stars upon this establishment: the blueberry scone exhibited an unfortunate lack of culinary prowess, possessing an unpleasant, almost savory flavor profile that deviated substantially from the conventional sweetness associated with such pastries, and its texture was disagreeably coarse and grainy; however, my espresso con panna was characterized by an intense bitterness that surpassed my expectations, rivalling the bitterness of Starbucks' offerings, yet ultimately proving less satisfying due to its markedly acidic quality; nevertheless, certain items on the menu proved to be redeeming features, specifically the lemon olive oil cornmeal cake, whose subtle tanginess and delightful texture rendered it truly exceptional, and the mocha, which boasted a rich, velvety consistency and an impressive depth of flavor; additionally, the counter worker displayed a commendable level of friendliness and knowledge, contributing to an overall positive experience despite the aforementioned shortcomings."

Ehh. Nothing to write home about. Good service. Food just average. Unless you are a veggie loving hipster, this place is not worth the 2+ hr wait. Save yourself the trouble and disappointment and cross Butler St to Franktuary.

I will be forthright in my assessment; this establishment does not possess an exceptional quality. I found myself with several hours to kill prior to my late-night flight, and my craving for Mexican cuisine led me to this location. In retrospect, it would have been more judicious to dine elsewhere.

Pros:

* The staff exhibited amicable demeanors.
* The guacamole presented a satisfactory taste experience.

Cons:

* The tortilla chips lacked the flavor and crunch associated with freshness.
* The absence of burritos on the menu, with the exception of Monday through Thursday, was perplexing.
* The chicken quesadilla failed to impress, bearing a resemblance to something easily preparable in one's own domicile. The texture was also subpar, featuring an unpleasant sogginess and an abundance of unfilled space along the periphery, resulting in an overall sensation of mediocrity.

In light of these factors, it may be wise to consider alternative dining options.

"Our experiences at this establishment have been numerous, and upon perusing their menu, we have consistently observed that the serving sizes of their dishes, particularly when ordering takeout, are often diminished while maintaining an equivalent price point. Specifically, during our most recent visit, we opted for the Mahi Mahi entrÃ©e accompanied by a variety of vegetables, and the portion size of both the fish and vegetables was satisfactory. However, upon placing a subsequent to-go order on Sunday, July 29th, we were dismayed to discover that the fish portion had been reduced by approximately half, while the quantity of hummus provided was also diminished. This phenomenon has transpired on multiple occasions, thus advising prospective patrons to carefully inspect their orders prior to departure, lest they receive less than what they paid for."

"My affection for frozen yogurt is palpable, yet my rationale dictates that if one is opting for FroYo, a revitalizing and fruity flavor is desired. Conversely, if a richer, creamier texture is preferred, ice cream would be the superior choice. Unfortunately, during my previous visits to this establishment, their fruit-flavored offerings have been limited and often coincided with my allergies or personal distastes. Notably, they lacked the quintessential original tart flavor, which I had presumed to be a ubiquitous staple across all frozen yogurt purveyors. However, their assortment of toppings is quite impressive. The premises are well-maintained, the staff's demeanor is adequate, and the pricing, calculated per ounce, is comparable to that of other frozen yogurt vendors."

"On this occasion, which constitutes my second visit and, regrettably, my final foray into this culinary establishment, I must confess that my expectations were not merely unfulfilled but, indeed, utterly decimated by the paltry quality of the fare and the lackadaisical demeanor of the staff. Specifically, my companion and I opted for the table d'hote, anticipating a savory and satisfying repast, only to be confronted with an unfortunate excuse for a burnt steak, served after an interminable wait and bereft of even a modicum of culinary finesse. Furthermore, our server, rather than demonstrating a scintilla of concern or interest in our dining experience, displayed a flagrant nonchalance, bordering on disdain, which only served to exacerbate our profound disappointment. As an ardent proponent of the belief that a server is the embodiment of both the cuisine and the establishment, I must aver that the absence of any semblance of ownership or accountability for the experience leaves me with no alternative but to seek sustenance elsewhere."

"This establishment presented a rather dichotomous dining experience, with the quality of the fare oscillating between palatable and inedible. Of the trio of specialty pizzas we sampled, one was delectable, another was mediocre, and the third was utterly disappointing. The salad course was satisfying, yet unremarkable, while the ranch dressing proved to be a highlight, in stark contrast to the subpar bleu cheese dressing. Unfortunately, the chicken tenders were severely overcooked, emitting an acrid aroma reminiscent of a kitchen inferno upon opening the container, rendering them inedible. Notwithstanding, the buffalo sauce accompanying the chicken tenders was quite tasty, albeit futile given the unpalatability of the main component. The baked potato fries, though conceptually intriguing, suffered from an unfortunate lack of crispiness, potentially attributable to the delivery process. Thus, it may be argued that the overall quality ratio at this venue fell short of the 50/50 mark, particularly considering the substantial expenditure of over $100 for a meal that failed to meet expectations."

Didn't go in with high expectations as I wasn't impressed with Bottles & Burgers at Tivoli Village, but a friend wanted to try this place out. I am willing to give any place a try at least once, especially if they offer patio seating. The only bad part about their patio is it's located in between the two escalators that lead up to the second floor, so there was a lot of traffic, it was noisy and distracting. I didn't try the food, but I had their cucumber martini, wasn't bad but I've had better, and then the sangria, hands down the worst I've ever tasted. It came with a sugared rim which was strange, and it tasted like prune juice, I'm not joking. The only drink that was good was my honey jack on the rocks, can't mess that up. If you're looking for a nice outside patio, go to Brio, comfy chairs and fire pits, plenty of room and great people watching.

"Underwhelming", "disappointing", "excessively seasoned", and "overpriced" are adjectives that come to mind when reflecting on our culinary experience at Imadake. Previous reviews led us to believe that certain dishes were worth trying; specifically, the octopus balls, okonomiyaki, fried chicken with wasabi mayo, jellyfish salad, and black cod. However, none of these items lived up to our expectations. The black cod was overcooked and lacked the tender texture found at other establishments, such as Azuma on St-Laurent. The octopus balls were unpleasantly chewy, with an uncooked tempura batter in the center, and were excessively salted. The okonomiyaki was completely smothered in sauce, making it difficult to discern any other flavors, and its texture was unusual, almost resembling cornmeal. Our meal consisted of five small dishes, plus one order of mochi, totaling $67 before the tip. Unfortunately, due to our underwhelming experience, we will not be returning to Imadake. It appears that this restaurant prioritizes ambiance over the quality of its food, creating a trendy atmosphere with an abundance of oyster sauce."

"While it would be inaccurate to categorize this establishment as a premier resort, it does offer certain amenities that may appeal to families with young children. However, the accommodations themselves leave much to be desired in terms of both size and modernity, with outdated technology such as tube televisions being only one of several areas in need of updating. Furthermore, the bathrooms, particularly in one of the rooms we occupied, lacked fundamental essentials such as toilet paper and functional locks, issues which were further compounded by the minuscule nature of these spaces. The exterior areas, too, appeared in dire need of a comprehensive makeover, with peeling paint and overgrown vegetation contributing to an overall sense of neglect. Despite these shortcomings, the panoramic views afforded by our lodgings did, admittedly, provide a pleasant surprise, although the proximity to the adjacent highway rendered them somewhat less enjoyable due to the persistent hum of traffic. On a more positive note, the waterpark did prove popular among our offspring, even though the lazy river and slides were periodically inaccessible, leading to frustration among our daughters. Confusion regarding the operating hours on Saturday also marred our stay, detracting from what could have been an otherwise satisfactory experience. In conclusion, if your primary focus is on a water-based theme park and merely adequate accommodations, then this resort might suffice. Nevertheless, those seeking a more well-rounded and luxurious resort experience would be better advised to consider alternative options, such as the Fairmont Princess."

A sans-culotte eatery in the proximate vicinity of the Olympic Stadium, offering an unremarkable culinary experience, replete with an abundance of security personnel idly loitering about the premises and a smattering of habitual patrons partaking in the establishment's offerings, notably lacking in feminine clientele, save for the singular presence of this writer, who, in point of fact, constituted the sole distaff devotee of the venue on the occasion in question.

The best thing to say is that the waitstaff is polite.  Mediocre food.  Overpriced for menu options.  If you have to eat here, buy a beer.  It will make the food better.  I ordered a quesadilla (steak) with a side of guacamole and a Coca Cola.  My soda was so anemic looking I thought it was weak tea.  I was never offered a refill.  The quesadilla looked great, despite the nearly two dollar guacamole only containing a tablespoon of guacamole.  The dried and shriveled green onion garnish was unneeded.  After attempting to eat the quesadilla, I discovered that despite the attractive appearance, the filling to cheese ratio was horrible and the entire thing fell apart and had to be eaten by fork.  The steak filling was overdone to the point of being inedible and the corn and black bean relish they put in it just made the small bit of cheese coagulate in a grainy mess.  Save yourself the money and just pick up food at Burger King.

Decent for the price, but by no means exceptional. Wings were overcooked and lacked succulence. The western bacon cheeseburger showed promise, but ultimately fell short of expectations due to the bread's inability to maintain its structural integrity.

Expected to be satiated for a paltry sum of $50 to $60, a veritable bargain considering the quality of the fresh fish in Las Vegas, yet ironically, I left a greater amount of currency at the establishment than at the craps table, a phenomenon that can only be attributed to the capricious nature of Lady Luck herself.

The culinary offerings were indeed satisfactory, boasting an impressive freshness and meticulous preparation, but alas, the portions were regrettably diminutive, a characteristic that belied the exorbitant price point, which bordered on usury, even by the standards of the nation's capital, where prices are already egregiously inflated.

However, it must be noted that the libations were surprisingly reasonable, with my Manhattan martini being both copious and affordable, a welcome respite from the fiscal hemorrhage that threatened to deplete my bankroll.

The ambiance of the sushi bar was quite pleasant, enhanced as it was by an imposing and captivating animated display that loomed large behind the sushi chefs, casting an ethereal glow over the proceedings. The service, too, was commendable, characterized by a friendly and attentive demeanor that bespoke a commitment to excellence on the part of the wait staff.

Lastly, I must confess that the recommendations proffered by the waiter were indeed tantalizing, their flavors a true delight to my palate, and thus, I departed the premises feeling suitably sated, if still somewhat financially drained, yet determined to recoup my losses at another venue, for as the saying goes, "fortune favors the bold," and I, for one, am nothing if not intrepid in my pursuit of a favorable outcome.

"On my second visit to a Twin Peaks establishment, following an initial experience at a location in Austin, Texas, I encountered an unfortunate dearth of hospitable service from the wait staff, who were conspicuously scarce and preoccupied, even when we required our check, opting instead to congregate in secluded areas beyond visible range, thereby rendering the overall dining experience decidedly subpar and lacking in comparison to my previous encounter at the aforementioned Austin venue, whereupon I savored a delectable burger accompanied by a portion of fries, both of which were executed to satisfaction according to the menu's description, yet failed to proffer sufficient impetus for a repeat visit to this particular Scottsdale outpost, given the availability of superior burgers at alternative establishments such as Whataburger, which, regrettably, did not feature prominently among the culinary offerings available at this specific locale."

"The culinary offerings were merely satisfactory, failing to elicit any profound enthusiasm on my part. Upon closer inspection, certain aspects of the dining experience struck me as peculiar. Firstly, the practice of charging for refills seemed somewhat dubious, given the negligible cost associated with such a service. Furthermore, while enjoying my meal, an influx of new patrons entered the establishment, including a sizable group of nine individuals. To my surprise, the woman operating the register informed them that a gratuity of 15% would be added to their bill, despite the fact that no table service was provided, and thus, neither food nor drink refills were brought to their table. This raised questions regarding the equity of such a policy. However, it is worth noting that the staff members were indeed quite cordial."

"The dearth of succulent meat options and sluggish service, despite an absence of patrons, precipitated a profound disappointment. The sirloin, in particular, exemplified the unfortunate quality of the available cuts. Furthermore, the salad bar lacked variety and failed to elicit enthusiasm. My previous visit, approximately one year prior, had yielded a significantly more satisfactory experience."

"Following the submission of my response via electronic mail, as requested by the Customer Service Representative (CSR) below, I received a prompt and considerate reply from the CSR, who demonstrated genuine concern for my grievances. Subsequently, I engaged in a series of written correspondences, totaling two emails, with the initial CSR, as well as a second corporate representative, who augmented their colleague's efforts with an additional missive, infusing a touch of levity into our interaction. Following these exchanges, I was informed that the local district manager would initiate contact with me within the ensuing week. Unfortunately, this communication has yet to materialize, despite the lapse of several weeks since the initial exchange. My dissatisfaction with the overall customer experience remains palpable, particularly in light of the glaring disparities in service quality between the local and corporate levels of the organization. Notwithstanding my desire for no further interaction with DSW, I deemed it appropriate to provide an updated assessment of my experience, in order to ensure a comprehensive understanding of the situation."

"The eatery's location is spotless, and the staff's deportment is courteous and efficient. I appreciate their utilization of blue film covers over the fluorescent overhead lighting, which creates an almost lounge-like ambiance within the dining area by mitigating the harshness of the illumination. However, the culinary offerings leave much to be desired. The salt and pepper calamari, priced at $7 for 14 pieces, lacked any discernible seasoning and was swimming in grease, accompanied by insipid cups of sweet and sour sauce. The random inclusion of fried carrot fragments as a garnish was the sole redeeming feature of the dish. Furthermore, the'special combination' banh mi, touted with a smiley face on the menu, proved to be a considerable letdown. The meat was stacked haphazardly at one end of the sandwich, necessitating my intervention to redistribute it evenly. Upon doing so, I discovered numerous blackened pieces of meat, suggestive of spoilage rather than intentional cooking methods. Additionally, the presence of a potent spicy sauce or seasoning caused my eyes to water, and I could only identify jalapenos as the source of this intense flavor. Considering the proximity of this establishment to my fitness center and the acclaim surrounding its pho, I shall not be returning due to concerns regarding the consistent quality of the cooked meat used in their dishes."

Took a business group to Harvest last night.  I realize their committment to locally sourced ingredients means a variable supply, but our experience was extreme.  They did not have one fish dish listed on their menue.  They had only two of their steak special, and so could not accomodate orders from our group.  They had only three of their dessert special, so similar issue.  They could not provide one request for a diet Coke.  They ran out of straws for one person's drink.  This was not a big group.  The place wasnt overly busy.  They were just apparently not prepared to be open last night.  Disappointing.  Will not take clients there again.

Although our visit transpired on a Saturday evening, we arrived punctually at six o'clock; however, we were seated within a mere ten minutes due to the eatery's lack of patronage. Subsequently, we were escorted to a table that had yet to be sanitized. Following an extended period of waiting for a server to take our beverage order, the manager ultimately assumed the responsibility. A nearby server noticed that we had been sitting idly for an extensive duration without beverages or a server, and thus, our waiter materialized shortly thereafter, taking our order in the process.
