Unfortunately, our mozzarella garlic bread, which we would have otherwise savored during the interval preceding our entrees, arrived simultaneously with the main courses. The culinary offerings, with the exception of the aforementioned bread, were merely tepid at best. Throughout our dining experience, several tables in our vicinity vacated, yet I failed to observe a busboy clearing the tables. Consequently, we were disheartened by the disorganized and haphazard nature of the staff's performance, leading me to harbor doubts about returning to this establishment in the future.

Last night, while in town for business, I opted to return to Roland's, despite my previous underwhelming experience, and sample their offerings once again. Upon arriving, I was met with a substantial wait time of over 30 minutes, which led me to surmise that the restaurant's popularity had not waned since my last visit. However, upon entering the establishment, I was struck by the conspicuous absence of patrons, which seemed to be at odds with the crowded ambiance pervasive in neighboring eateries. Furthermore, I noticed that the dining area was plagued by an inadequate air conditioning system, which only served to exacerbate the already sweltering temperature and humidity levels outside.  
Despite these drawbacks, I elected to partake in a grilled vegetable sandwich and a bowl of clam chowder, both of which were merely satisfactory, mirroring my previous experience. Nevertheless, I did notice a marked improvement in the quality of service during this visit. In conclusion, my culinary excursion to Roland's left me unimpressed, and I would advise potential patrons to explore alternative dining options. Notably, the restaurant boasts an extensive selection of beers from diverse regions across the globe, which may appeal to those with a penchant for international brews.

"On February 17th, my significant other and I opted to dine at Pin Kaow 3, a locally renowned eatery in close proximity to my humble abode, prior to engaging in an evening of merriment in the city's central district...a decision that would ultimately prove to be a regrettable miscalculation! The service we received was excruciatingly sluggish, with a prolonged waiting period of 20 minutes merely to receive our beverage order, and a subsequent 20-minute delay in the arrival of our Thai yellow curry. Furthermore, our server failed to exhibit the slightest concern for our well-being, leaving us utterly ignored and disregarded throughout the duration of our meal. A resounding 'Boo' is certainly in order for such an underwhelming experience! \n\nIn light of my recent bout with influenza, which necessitated a convenient and nourishing meal option, I opted to contact Pin Kaow 3 for their acclaimed tom ka kai, accompanied by a side of sticky rice. Unfortunately, the broth arrived in a minuscule quantity, its flavor profile characterized by an excessive salt content and viscosity, prompting me to dilute it with water in order to render it palatable. This unanticipated inconvenience, coupled with the unreasonable price point of $12 for a single serving of soup and a modest side dish, left me feeling utterly dissatisfied. However, I must admit that the sticky rice, although meager in portion, possessed a pleasant warmth and texture. A silver lining, albeit a faint one, amidst an otherwise disappointing culinary escapade."

Good hotel if you just want a place to stay when you are in Vegas. Its location on the end of the Strip is convenient if you are into walking a bit. If not - take a bus, it stops right in front of the hotel. \nYou can get cheap and ok drinks at the hotel bar & the room was clean!

"An extensive array of beverages, featuring an emphasis on craft brews, graces the menu at this establishment, which, in conjunction with its ambiance reminiscent of a public house, creates a setting conducive to relaxation and socialization. However, it appears that the quality of the service does not quite live up to the standards implied by the sophisticated nature of the venue's decor and offerings, as certain patrons have expressed disappointment regarding the attentiveness and responsiveness of the staff. Furthermore, while the culinary selections available may not necessarily be deserving of unbridled enthusiasm, it is reasonable to surmise that the proprietors have made a considerable financial investment in the venture, thereby necessitating a greater attention to detail in regard to the presentation and quality of the fare provided."

"This dining establishment bears a resemblance to a more costly, less delectable iteration of Macayos, offering an experience that falls short of expectations. Upon arriving with a group of nine individuals, we were not accommodated until all members of our party were present, which seemed unnecessary given the lack of patrons on a tranquil Monday evening. Our server, however, demonstrated exceptional proficiency and attention to detail, ensuring that our beverages remained consistently replenished. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings failed to impress, with my carne asada taco plate and accompanying side of guacamole suffering from a glaring absence of seasoning. While I acknowledge the prevalence of Americanized Mexican cuisine and did not anticipate an excess of flavor, I did expect a modicum of taste and depth. Ultimately, I would not opt to return to this establishment."

"Bonus points are awarded for the meticulous selection of specialty coffee beans, specifically those sourced from Verve and Forty-Ninth Parallel, however, deductions are made for the overwhelming ambiance that permeates the space, which can be perceived as pretentious or trendy. The layout presents challenges in navigating from the beverage counter to a seating area, as well as accessing the restrooms from said seating area. Although the chocolate chip cookie offered was observed to have an excessive amount of oil, it is acknowledged that certain patrons may prefer this attribute. No criticisms are expressed regarding the quality of the coffee beverages themselves; nonetheless, if one seeks a straightforward, expertly crafted espresso drink to go and does not mind enduring a delay in line, this establishment suits that purpose adequately."

DONT BELIEVE THE HYPE

OK so the reason I came here was because of all the reviews and honestly this place is not all that. First of all you have to wait for an 40 minutes or more to be seated and the service is very slow.

Only thing I liked about this place is the hurricane roll (The extra star is for this roll). The fresh was not as fresh as some reviewers said.

OH and because we were sitting thing there and talking with friends with have not seen for awhile, mind you this is shortly after we paid the bill, they asked us if there was anything else we needed kinda their way of telling us to get the eff out because there were people waiting. I am sorry but if we were at any other place, they wouldnt make us feel that way. 

They are never getting my business again. Get a bigger spot!

"My culinary excursion to Las Vegas for the annual SHOT show led me to an unanticipated extended stay at the luxurious Venetian resort. In search of an authentic Mexican dining experience, I ventured to Taqueria Canonita, a seemingly promising establishment in close proximity to the California border and catering to a diverse clientele. Upon the recommendation of the attentive wait staff, I opted for the Santa Rosa Pork Barbacoa, eagerly anticipating a savory and tender slow-cooked pork dish. Unfortunately, my gastronomic expectations were not met, as the pork was underwhelming in both flavor and texture, lacking the richness and moisture I had hoped for. In retrospect, Chipotle's barbacoa would have been a superior choice. Furthermore, the empanadas we ordered as a table failed to meet our expectations, lacking the desired crispiness, while the guacamole accompanying the tortilla chips was inadequately mashed. Such inconsistencies proved detrimental to the restaurant's reputation, rendering it unsuitable for discerning patrons. However, the tequila offered a welcome respite from the disappointing cuisine."

"A sobriquet that accurately encapsulates the current state of an establishment that was once the epicenter of culinary delight, but has since experienced a precipitous decline in quality and patronage. Suffice it to say, any future visits to this eatery would be an exercise in futility and serve only to perpetuate a cycle of disappointment. Rating Scale: 1 Star - Avoid the municipality in which this restaurant resides, lest one risk encountering a similar dearth of gastronomical prowess; 2 Star - With numerous exceptional alternatives available, it is imprudent to chance a visit to this particular venue; 3 Star - I shall endeavour to partake of their offerings once more, either out of necessity or convenience; 4 Star - I frequent this establishment with regularity, provided it is financially and/or calorically feasible to do so; 5 Star - I eagerly anticipate indulging in their culinary creations with my significant other or associates."

This fitness facility is merely adequate; I have mixed feelings about its overall quality. Specifically, I find it annoying that the sanitation personnel consistently obstruct my path, despite their ostensible efforts, the environment remains unkempt. The ladies' changing area is particularly reprehensible, with an ambiance that can only be described as grimy. Furthermore, I find the gym's dimensions to be somewhat restrictive and its atmosphere stifling due to an excess of machinery and equipment that appears haphazardly arranged. Additionally, the reception staff exhibits a lack of competence and their demeanor could be construed as sullen, with the exception of a sole individual, whose name escapes me, but I believe it commences with 'C'.

This establishment earns a paltry two stars due to its notable amenities; specifically, the pool area, which significantly surpasses the cost of our therapeutic massages. We indulged in a fifty-minute couple's massage, priced at three hundred dollars, inclusive of a twenty percent gratuity, which we were not afforded the opportunity to decline, given the automatic addition to the total cost. Although the spa exuded an atmosphere of elegance, it lacked a designated area for us to encounter one another before the massage, leading to separate areas for men and women, thereby creating a sense of disconnection. Moreover, the experience felt hurried, and the masseuses failed to deliver the requested deep tissue massage, leaving us feeling underwhelmed and frustrated. My shoulder region harbors severe knots, which remained unaddressed throughout the massage, rendering the entire experience futile, as I did not obtain any semblance of relaxation or relief. Consequently, I would not consider returning to this spa, even if we opt to utilize our timeshare for future excursions. Instead, I intend to seek out alternative spas in Scottsdale, ideally affiliated with the JW Marriott resort, to ensure a more satisfactory experience.

"A further aggravating Scottsdale eatery. 

I awarded it two stars, as the cuisine, while not extraordinary, was palatable. However, the hospitality was woefully inadequate. The dining area was uncomfortably chilly! Upon requesting that the rear entrance be closed to prevent the influx of frigid air, our appeal was met with indifference. It was the luncheon hour on a Monday, and we comprised merely the second table to be seated; thus, the reason behind our request being disregarded remained unclear. 

Soon after taking our beverage order, our server disappeared for nearly a quarter of an hour. Subsequently, she failed to provide any of us with hydration. Following that, we submitted our second, third, and fourth requests for water, ultimately receiving it simultaneously with our main courses. Would you desire additional salsa? Unfortunately, such a query was futile, as the waitstaff was nowhere to be found until my companion rose and approached the bar to have her carbonated beverage replenished. At that point, it dawned on her that we were vexed. The culinary offerings could have been the most magnificent experience conceivable, but owing to the dearth of adequate service, I shall never return."

You will discover here a plethora of gastronomical options, including but not limited to:

1) Subpar, frostbitten sashimi that lacks the freshness and quality one would expect from a reputable establishment serving raw fish.

2) Scallops that have the potential to induce adverse gastrointestinal effects due to questionable handling and storage practices.

3) A dining area reminiscent of a witches' coven, creating an unsettling ambiance that may or may not enhance your culinary experience, depending on personal preferences.

A detailed explanation of the third point follows:

The cuisine offered can be classified as average Americanized sushi, garnering a rating of three stars at best. The ambiance, while unconventional, has the potential to elevate the overall experience to a respectable 3.5 stars. However, the exceptional quality of the service unfortunately warrants a reduction in rating to a mere two stars.

The wait staff, comprised of Chinese individuals, engage in surreptitious and unethical practices, such as covertly peddling inferior alcoholic beverages to unsuspecting patrons, including myself and my colleagues. This reprehensible behavior necessitates a decrease in rating.

In conclusion, Hiro offers superior dining options for those seeking a truly satisfying culinary experience.

"The patrons' ardent affection for the establishment's coffee beverages is palpable, as they throng the premises during peak hours, creating an extended queue that reaches the entrance. Notwithstanding the prolonged delay, I opt to procure my caffeinated beverage elsewhere, as the waiting time proves prohibitive. However, I habitually purchase coffee beans at this location for home brewing. The management could consider implementing a separate station for expedited service, dedicated solely to accommodating straightforward coffee orders, thereby augmenting efficiency and potentially enhancing customer satisfaction, thereby increasing revenue."

I genuinely yearned to relish this establishment; its outward appearance conveyed an air of enjoyment and merriment.  Alas, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as we visited during a lull in patronage.  The barkeep downstairs proved to be affable and hospitable, engaging us in cordial conversation.  Upon the arrival of our associates, we ascended to the upper level of the edifice.  Unfortunately, the pace of the service was sluggish, and the culinary offerings, while diverse in nature, lacked the zest and vitality that would have elevated them to true gastronomic excellence.  Despite these shortcomings, I remain convinced that this venue possesses the potential for greatness, contingent upon the implementation of improvements in both the gustatory and server aspects of its operations.

"The lodging facility in question does not conform to the traditional definition of a resort, as it is, in fact, an apartment complex that has been adapted for use as a motel. Furthermore, during our stay, we did not have access to air conditioning, which rendered the interior of our room uncomfortably warm, particularly given the external temperature of approximately 60 degrees Fahrenheit in February. When I inquired about this issue, I was informed that the establishment did not possess any air conditioning units and that the thermostat was merely a cosmetic feature that produced a modicum of warm air upon activation. Although the staff members were amicable, the oppressive ambient temperature significantly detracted from our overall comfort level."

"This aerodrome is tainted with an aura of squalor and ineptitude, rendering it unaccommodating to patrons who seek a seamless and convenient experience. Specifically, the absence of sufficient power outlets throughout the terminal hinders the ability of business travelers to recharge their electronic devices, thereby creating an unnecessary obstacle for those seeking to maintain productivity during transit. Furthermore, the physical distance between gates poses an additional challenge for passengers facing layovers, as they must traverse an excessive distance on foot, thereby augmenting the already heightened levels of anxiety associated with air travel. Moreover, the proliferation of slot machines within the airport serves only to exacerbate the financial burden inherent in modern-day travel, thus further undermining the overall quality of the facility."

It has been about 6 years since we dined at streets of New York. This time we ordered a thin and crispy pizza, a Caesar salad and bread knots. From my memory the pizza was better than I remember but not great.   However, the salad was not edible in fact we took it back.  The romain was brown and at least 4 or five days past it's prime.   They took it back without any Question and comped us a piece cheesecake in good faith.  Who ever prepared our meal should be totally embarrassed....        I don't think we will go back..

slow to leave the airport. waited about 20-30 minutes for the shuttle to fill up before we left.

calling for a pick-up wasnt very helpful. they say the shuttle can arrive within a 15 minute window and then take up to an HOUR to get you to the airport. i sucked it up and just had a taxi take me. well worth it the money.

don't recommend this company unless they improve their efficiency.

they do get 2 starts because of their cheap rates. cant beat it if you don't mind waiting

My spouse, progeny, and I have been patronizing Casey Jones for an extended period, yet our most recent visit presented a precipitous decline in culinary excellence. In the company of acquaintances, we sampled their newly introduced burger, the "Juicy Lucy," and were dismayed by its lackluster quality. Upon ordering the burgers at a medium level of doneness, we were served two patties that appeared to be hemorrhaging, with an overflow of cheese reminiscent of a gruesome cinematic scene where a character suffers a mortal wound. Following our return of the burgers to the kitchen and receiving assurance of their rectification, the subsequent dishes were cooked to an extreme degree, bordering on incineration, and were devoid of any semblance of dairy products, thereby negating the essence of the "Juicy" moniker. As a result, my previous endorsement of this establishment has been rescinded, and further visits will be forestalled until a more competent culinary artisan assumes responsibilities in the kitchen, as the likelihood of such an unfortunate series of events had previously been considered improbable.

"Subsequent to receiving a $20 discount voucher via postal delivery, my companion and I opted to sample the culinary offerings of this establishment. Suffice it to say that several months have transpired since our inaugural visit, and the sole instance in which this venue has resurfaced in my consciousness was during a conversation with a colleague who shared a comparable account of an unremarkable dining experience. \n\nWhile the hospitality we received was adequate, the fare served proved to be underwhelming. Specifically, I requested cheese enchiladas, while my partner opted for chicken enchiladas. However, upon presentation, I discovered that the tortillas were conspicuously absent from my dish, compelling me to embark on a quest to locate them. My significant other expressed equal disappointment with her entree. Notwithstanding, the sangria I ordered exhibited a modicum of palatability, although it failed to suffice as a sufficient reason to warrant a future visit."

Good food and decent service, but way too expensive for galbi and meat! They also have menus, new and old, that say certain dishes include dessert, but at the end when we asked for them they said that it wasn't being offered anymore. Um, okay, can you let us know before we order and/or update the menus please? I hate surprises like that when eating out when it's been spelled out. That alone knocks off a star or two. \n\nThis place would also be better to eat at alone or with two people for better value, because they give you the same amount of side dishes and seafood pancake no matter how many are at your table.

"It has been an appreciable duration since my last visit to Dos Gringos, or perhaps this particular establishment is inferior in terms of cleanliness compared to the Tempe location, but my recent experience at this venue was utterly disappointing. The lavatory facilities were emitting an unpleasant odor, and the overall ambiance seemed grimy and unkempt. I would not consider partaking in culinary indulgences from this establishment, given that the state of their bar area raises concerns about the cleanliness of their kitchen. Frankly, I am perplexed by the preference of some individuals to frequent such an uninviting atmosphere when there are numerous alternative destinations in Scottsdale that offer a more enjoyable and sanitary experience."

"On multiple occasions, I have visited this Jasons Deli and experienced satisfaction with their offerings. Specifically, their delivery services have consistently met my expectations in terms of quality and taste. However, my most recent encounter with their delivery was rather unremarkable, as the butter croissant that housed my turkey sandwich was excessively desiccated, leading to an unpleasant dining experience. Furthermore, the brownies that have previously been a highlight of their menu, failed to meet my expectations due to being overcooked, resulting in an unpleasantly dry texture and burnt flavor. Overall, this particular meal was a disappointment, prompting me to reconsider my future patronage."

Outrageously priced. I get they have state of the art equipment but we couldn't afford to use any of it. While the staff is super friendly we did have one of the doctors say, after we couldn't pay to have anymore tests done, that it wouldn't be bad if we choose to put our dog down. I have no idea how a person can be so cold. Do no harm, right? Our dog only stayed 24 hours at the place and it ran us around $2000. We took our dog somewhere else that was much more affordable and they saved his life. He stayed at the other place for about a week. Same treatment and it cost us less than the one day at VCA.

"Upon entering the establishment, I noticed that they possessed an array of cosmetic lines; however, the abundance of products available for purchase was unfortunately meager during my visit. Specifically, the selection of items from MAC, the brand I was seeking, was quite limited and many of the products were either already opened, damaged, or appeared to have been heavily utilized. Furthermore, the quality of customer service I received was subpar. The trio of employees stationed at the cash register failed to acknowledge my presence or offer any assistance, leaving me feeling ignored and disheartened. Consequently, I will be venturing to the interior location in the future, hoping to find a more extensive range of options."

"Satisfactory victuals at a reasonable cost. We visited this establishment in the early hours of a Friday morning, following our arrival in Las Vegas. Despite the lateness of the hour, the venue was bustling with activity; however, we were promptly accommodated. I opted to partake in the 7 oz. steak, accompanied by hash browns, eggs, and toast, which I shared with my companion due to my limited appetite. The steak presented a dichotomy of doneness, with one half being well done and the other half falling somewhere between medium and medium-well; we had requested the latter, but such minor inconsistencies were inconsequential given the affordable price point of less than $4. The hash browns lacked the desired crispiness, while the toast was satisfactory, and the eggs fell within the realm of mediocrity. A cursory examination of the culinary offerings revealed an absence of sodium, a characteristic seemingly tailored to the preferences of the mature clientele that frequent this establishment. In summary, this restaurant serves as a suitable option for those seeking sustenance following a night of revelry or for individuals who prefer a more relaxed dining experience, but it does not qualify as a premier gastronomic destination."

"We partook in a culinary excursion at this esteemed eatery last week, during which the comestibles were merely adequate, while the tariff was somewhat prohibitive. Specifically, supplementary dishes incurred an additional fee of $11.00 or more. 

However, the hospitality we received was quite another tale. Our trio of servers, with the primary one being conspicuously discourteous and haughty, bordering on impolite, and her countenance betrayed no hint of joviality. Such behavior, though unfortunate, might have been tolerable had not the supporting staff member committed the egregious faux pas of extending his arm across my spouse to retrieve my plate, leaving me utterly flabbergasted. I forthrightly admonished him, stressing the importance of proper decorum. Subsequently, the manager appeared and, upon being apprised of the situation, expressed contrition and effected a transformation in our attendants, resulting in a marked improvement in the quality of our service. 

My indignation stems from the fact that, at an establishment of such lofty stature and cost, one should never be compelled to lodge a complaint to receive satisfactory service. The Las Vegas Strip boasts a plethora of exceptional restaurants, rendering it unnecessary to squander one's resources and time at a venue incapable of maintaining top-notch service consistently. My recommendation: seek an alternative dining destination!"

I had dinner at Leroy Fox tonight.  This site used to house the old Hotel Charlotte.

The rennovation was very impressive.  The restaurant was very nice and it was good to see that they had incorporated parts of the old restaurant into the decor of the new restaurant.

The restaurant was packed solid.  The noise level was probably the most negative aspect of the experience.  In addition to the already deafening noise level, live music started up and it soon became impossible to hear the conversation at our table.

I had the "north" chicken which consisted of a breast and a wing.  It was fried and was quite good.  The chicken comes with a choice of a side item.

The menu looked quite good.  The service was also good, but I believe the kitchen got backed up with orders since the restaurant was full.

I wouldn't recommend going to this restaurant, if you have hopes of having normal conversation with the people at your table.

This lodging establishment proved to be a profound disappointment, failing to meet our expectations of a luxurious four-star hotel experience in Las Vegas. Despite its unremarkable appearance, we opted to spend a single night at this venue, only to discover that for an identical tariff, we could have secured accommodations that were markedly superior in both quality and amenities.

"My experience at this particular BJ's establishment has been rather inconsistent, as the culinary offerings have demonstrated a propensity for variability in terms of adhering to the specified parameters of my orders. Specifically, on seven separate occasions, I have visited this restaurant with a group of colleagues, and on six of those instances, the kitchen has failed to accurately prepare my meal according to the details provided in the faxed order. Notably, the kitchen has consistently struggled with the seemingly straightforward concept of a vegetarian pizza sans cheese, as evidenced by the fact that I have received deliveries with cheese included, as well as others with sausage substituted for the requested cheese. While the waitstaff has displayed commendable contrition in response to these errors, the persistent incompetence exhibited by the kitchen staff raises concerns regarding their capacity to effectively fulfill patrons' dining requirements."

I was eager to relish the culinary offerings of this eatery and had high expectations, however, upon entering the premises, my enthusiasm was dampened by the cramped layout, which appeared to prioritize maximizing seating capacity over patron comfort. Although I comprehend the economic rationale behind this decision, it created an unpleasant ambiance, particularly during peak hours. Moreover, the menu options were limited, which made it challenging to find a suitable dish that catered to my taste preferences. My spouse opted for the turkey sandwich, while I selected the grilled cheese BLT. The total cost for these two items and a single fountain beverage was almost $20.00, which seemed excessive given the quality of the fare. Furthermore, the service was sluggish, with a prolonged delay between placing our order and its fulfillment. When the food finally arrived, it was merely satisfactory, with the bacon in my sandwich displaying an unpleasant texture and appearance, suggestive of having been stored for an extended period. Additionally, my spouse's meal lacked the specified vegetables and condiments, but due to the prolonged wait, he chose not to request a replacement. In conclusion, this establishment failed to meet my expectations, offering a noise-filled atmosphere and unimpressive cuisine at an exorbitant price point, leading me to concur with my spouse's sentiment that alternative dining options, such as Capriotti's, would provide better value for the money.

"The entire assortment of pre-owned vinyls showcased within this establishment's confines are, for all intents and purposes, dilapidated and worn items, with price tags ranging from a meager $5 to an exorbitant amount beyond that threshold, and it is utterly deplorable to note that the quality of clientele interaction is not merely subpar but thoroughly unacceptable, thus impelling me to formulate the unequivocal decision of abstaining from future visits to this purported hub of musical indulgence."

As a denizen of the San Francisco Bay Area, I felt compelled to sample the Asian gastronomic offerings within Montreal's Chinatown precinct, and Beijing emerged as a highly acclaimed establishment according to the aggregated opinions on Yelp. Thus, we opted to partake in their culinary experience.

The dining area was characterized by a cavernous interior with an excessive number of tables and chairs, creating an environment that was boisterous and lacking in intimacy. Our order consisted of the Chicken Soo Guy, which our server defined as being imbued with a distinctive Asian sauce, the specificity of which was left undefined. It became apparent upon sampling that this purportedly special sauce was, in reality, a rather conventional sweet and sour variety, which did not particularly impress me.

In contrast, the spicy beef dish displayed a modicum of flavor, albeit only after we requested that it be prepared with an extraordinary degree of piquancy. This led me to ponder about the nature of the dish when served in its standard form.

Taking everything into account, my expectations were not met by this eatery, and I would not consider returning.

I have availed myself of OnTrac delivery services for an assortment of packages originating from Amazon Prime shipping, however, on a few occasions, they have failed to meet their obligations in a timely manner. Specifically, on the first occasion, they were unable to effectuate delivery subsequent to my payment of an additional fee of 3.99 for expedited delivery, and on the second instance, their tracking information indicated "out for delivery" followed by "UNDELIVERABLE - OTHER REASONS" and then "REDELIVER ON NEXT BUSINESS DAY". 
  The delivery individual could not furnish a reasonable explanation for the non-delivery of my package, leading me to surmise that he was running behind schedule and elected to postpone its delivery until the following business day. Moreover, the initial delivery person who began delivering packages to me displayed a consistent lack of friendliness, failing to return my smile and express gratitude when I received the package, responding only with a grumpy demeanor and hastily departing. 
  It is imperative that OnTrac invests in the proper training of their delivery staff in the realm of customer service skills. Although they generally perform their duties effectively, their shortcomings in comparison to the likes of UPS or FedEx preclude me from assigning them a rating exceeding two stars.

When I visited the recently established Panera on a Friday evening, I was cognizant that we were encountering difficulties when my youthful companion requested the poultry noodle soup in a bread bowl. The staff member tasked with taking orders curtly replied, "We've exhausted our bread bowl supply," upon which my acquaintance, who had been craving such a dish since becoming aware of its existence, decided on a conventional salad featuring avian components instead. Subsequently, I placed an order for a Thai-style poultry flatbread sandwich. We navigated through a narrow passageway leading to the dining area, whereupon observing the unimpressive decor illuminated by subpar lighting, it became apparent that none of the vacant tables had been adequately sanitized. During the interval preceding the arrival of our cuisine, I ventured to the lavatory, which regrettably had not undergone recent cleansing and featured a substantial cylindrical container of toilet tissue positioned atop an empty dispenser. Ultimately, our culinary selections were brought to our table, and it was evident that the individual responsible for the kitchen shared a familiar relationship with the decorator, as the presentation was uninspired. Although the prices at this establishment were more reasonable than those of Paradise and the exceptional Wildflower, we opted to visit Frys en route home and acquired a La Brea Olive Oil and Rosemary round loaf along with a can of Progresso chicken noodle soup. Indeed, that meal proved to be delectable.

"Our culinary experiences at this establishment have been largely satisfactory, with the exception of our most recent visit on a Thursday, which happened to coincide with their burger night promotion. Unfortunately, the preparation of my hamburger was executed prematurely, resulting in a dining experience that was diametrically opposed to our expectations, as the meat was desiccated, lukewarm, and somewhat challenging to ingest. Similarly, the poultry dish we ordered was also afflicted by an unfortunate dearth of moisture and tenderness, making it arduous to consume. In contrast, our previous encounters with their hamburgers have been characterized by their freshness, juiciness, and satisfying temperature. It is worth noting that the cooking method employed by this restaurant, which involves precooking the meat and allowing it to sit in a pan, is not optimal for creating an enjoyable dining experience. In fact, this practice is reminiscent of the methods employed by certain fast-food chains, such as McDonald's. Therefore, we must express our disappointment with the quality of the food and service we received during our most recent visit, which warrants a rating of two stars."

It's really nothing special if you ask me. Unless you're a tourist who doesn't know much about the great local spots available it maybe satisfying. But asides from the decor I think the sweets are just too sweet to do anyone any good and especially not worth the price. It's just really hyped out I mean would you really buy a lollipop holder that Katy perry designed for $25? Seriously! Where do they come up with this stuff! 1 star for the fun decor and another for having a little cafe sitting eatery station.

I was thoroughly disillusioned with my maiden (and presumably singular) encounter at Hepatica, as a result of which I am now reluctant to patronize the establishment again. My visit was marred by an unacceptable delay in procuring a mere half dozen roses, which took an exorbitant amount of time, nearly thirty minutes, despite the fact that I was the sole customer present within the premises. Furthermore, the florist included an assortment of foliage with conspicuous insect bites, without bringing the supplementary expense to my attention prior to charging me for the floral arrangement. To further compound the issue, the staff member responsible for processing the transaction proceeded to charge my payment method twice, which contributed significantly to the prolonged duration of the transaction.

Last evening represented the second attempt at consuming this particular culinary creation, yet unfortunately yielded analogous gustatory consequences. Specifically, the dough exhibited an unpleasantly raw flavor, while the exclusive availability of a crimson sauce for the pizza resulted in an excessive influx of acidity within my digestive system. Consequently, I shall persist in preparing my own pizzas or opt for establishments such as Domino's, which incorporate authentic spinach rather than relying on canned alternatives. The thought of consuming such processed produce is utterly repugnant.

While it was gratifying to behold vegan alternatives, they were profoundly restricted and the presumption appeared to be that vegans intensely yearn for meat and dairy.  The culinary offerings were satisfactory, but by no means exceptional.  The beverages were mediocre at best, and a single drink would cost more than the entire meal.  The servers were brusque and discourteous; the host who attempted to emulate a secret service operative with his earpiece and inappropriate attire was boorish and impolite.  It did not merit the expense, and I would unlikely return.  The din and fumes from the gambling establishment significantly diminished the pleasure of consuming food.

"A contingent of discerning gastronomes, including yours truly, opted to partake of a midday repast at this establishment on a Friday, and although the culinary offerings were undoubtedly of superior quality, the pace of service was somewhat lacking in celerity and attention to detail. Furthermore, I personally sampled their Blue Petit Mignon, and I must say that the quantity provided was perfectly suited to satiate my hunger without feeling excessively indulgent."

The food is excellent, of that there is no doubt, but the service recently has completely gone down the drain.

When we ordered from them we were told thirty minute delivery time - it took an hour. We ordered three gyros and more and only half the order was delivered. When we called to make this matter known we were met with a rude manager that could barely be bothered to fix the service issue. 

It's been an hour and a half since the original order was placed and we are STILL waiting for our food. Food that was paid for in full.

Absolutely terrible customer service.

I was dying for some drunken noodles, saw this place close and gave it a go.  They open at 11, I tried 1058, no one there realized how early and killed time at the dollar store, came back at 1114, still not open, started to leave and someone ran to the door to unlock it, still had her purse on so I know she just walked in the door.  I ordered takeout drunken noodles and asked how long it might be since I know they just walked in, 5 min.  I didn't know whether to be happy or scared.  How could that be ready in 5 min? It was obvious they took old stuff and just re fried it, pretty greasy and nothing tasted fresh.  I am not one to know authenticity, but I had some drunken noodles in San Diego that I am trying to find something similar here.  This is my 3rd round with the noodles and just a few other times eating Thai apart from that, but this was my worst for sure out of all of them.  I don't know Thai food real well, but I know fresh, and I didn't get anything fresh here.  Also, smelled like old lady moth balls

"Appalling clientele assistance. My sibling and I visited this establishment subsequent to failing to procure an appropriate bridesmaid gown from David's Bridal. No personnel acknowledged our presence, compelling me to seek out an employee to aid us after a ten-minute interval. Upon conveying our requirements to said individual, she dismissively responded, precipitating a thoroughly unpleasant encounter. This incident alone was sufficient to preclude us from conducting future transactions with them. Notwithstanding, they obtained two stars due to the aesthetic appeal of their garments and the adequate variety of accoutrements available for selection."

"Although my experience at this establishment was merely adequate, I must admit that the server's attention appeared to be diverted towards fulfilling call-in orders, which, given the limited number of tables available, seemed to be a recurring trend. However, this did not excuse the fact that it took an inordinate amount of time - well over five minutes, to be precise - for me to successfully place my order. Upon finally being seated, I noticed that the ambiance was rather lackluster, with nary a soul in sight. Nonetheless, I opted to retrieve my meal, albeit with some trepidation, and, upon consuming it, was left feeling underwhelmed, as the dish was excessively oily and the rice and egg roll accompanying it were severely overcooked. Suffice it to say, I shall not be inclined to revisit this eatery in the near future."

Dropped $300 for my spouse and I to get in, it was entertaining but altogether not necessarily worth the price.  Then I discovered that we were among the handful of people who actually had to pay to get in, which was kind of a gut punch as cocktails are tremendously expensive.

A very interesting stage show, some of the players interact with the audience, but the price point is very out of proportion to the actual performances.

If you're amongst the lucky majority that received a complimentary admission, go take a peek but I heavily suggest avoiding this place unless you smoke $90 cigars lit with $20 bills.

The performance art was entertaining and the interaction with the audience brought out a "third dimension" to the show.  Think of well-dressed street performers, a little bit of "Tap Dogs", a little "Blue Man Group"-ish.

I don't want to say it's a rip, but it's certainly priced for the Romanovs and not exactly worth the tremendous entry fee, especially when most of the club seemed as if they were there on comps.

Feeling a little jaded and, well, financially leeched.

It's a stage show and then a standard night club. If you morphed the marquee with a sprinkle of cabaret and a very light touch of Cirque du Soleil, drop $300 for a couple, there you have rose rabbit lie.

"My affinity for the atmospheric charm and sensory appeal of Grassroots remains unwavering; however, my recent dining experience was marred by a perceptible display of culinary condescension on the part of the chef. Upon expressing my disappointment at the unavailability of the menu items I had previously attempted to order, the chef responded with a dismissive air, citing the establishment's commitment to utilizing only the freshest ingredients as a rationale for their depleted inventory. While I can certainly appreciate the emphasis placed on quality, I cannot help but wonder how a staple such as a baked potato could be in short supply. The chef's subsequent remark, which seemed to imply that the restaurant's success was somehow contingent upon my personal satisfaction, struck me as both irrelevant and insincere. Suffice it to say, the cuisine was unremarkable and failed to surpass my expectations; consequently, I would recommend Grassroots primarily for its beverages, rather than its culinary offerings."

We ceased frequenting the Sunset road venue of this establishment in Las Vegas approximately a year ago due to a decline in culinary quality. Upon the opening of a novel branch on Stephanie St In Henderson, we decided to accord it an additional opportunity, misguided as it turned out. Gigantic blunder! The steaks were not prepared in accordance with our instructions, even after being cooked for a second time. The assistance was also subpar. The sole redeeming features were the bread and salmon. Disillusionment of substantial proportions, Outback...

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
On a recent Friday evening, my spouse and I visited this establishment with high hopes of enjoying an excellent dinner; regrettably, our expectations were not met. The food was merely passable and overpriced, which was particularly disheartening given the high standards we had set for our dining experience.

The mixed drinks were reasonably priced at ten dollars apiece, but their flavor profiles failed to impress us. They lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that we have come to expect from establishments of this caliber.

Our servers appeared to be inexperienced, which detracted from the overall quality of our meal. Their service was less than polished, giving the impression that they were recently hired staff still finding their footing in the industry.

Moving on to the main event, the cuisine left much to be desired. Our New York strip steak arrived in a meager portion, which was problematic for my robust appetite. Although its flavor was satisfactory, it fell short of our expectations regarding quantity. My wife's sandwich, cooked to a medium temperature, was also underwhelming. Unfortunately, it was served rare, necessitating its return after a protracted wait of ten minutes.

In conclusion, our dining experience was subpar, with each dish costing approximately forty dollars. Considering the high prices and lackluster quality, we were left feeling disappointed and underwhelmed.

I visited this establishment on a singular occasion, as a particular club affiliated with the University of Pittsburgh was hosting a fundraising event at this venue, and my expectations were not entirely met, specifically regarding the quality of the food items offered.

I opted for a pumpernickel bagel accompanied by a plain cream cheese spread, which, unfortunately, failed to impress me owing to its lackluster taste and unremarkable texture. The bagel itself was rather thin and unsubstantial, and the cream cheese application was sparse and haphazardly distributed, thereby detracting from the overall experience.

While the site's accessibility is a definite advantage, gastronomic aficionados would be better served by venturing to alternative establishments specializing in superior quality bagels, such as Einstein's Bagels or perhaps even Panera Bread's offerings, instead of settling for the comparatively mediocre fare provided by this particular business.

"Acknowledged, we are all cognizant of the merchandise; it has an appearance of being costly, and its expensiveness seems to be appealing to everyone...\nHowever, my recent experience with the customer service was problematic. I must confess, I have visited this store previously, and the encounter was satisfactory, but this particular instance was not. Upon entering the establishment, I noticed a sign positioned at the entrance, indicating a discount of forty percent on a single item for men, without any further specifications. (It was intended for Father's Day.) Consequently, I selected a shirt and proceeded to the checkout line. After waiting patiently, I approached the cashier, only to be informed that the item I had chosen was not part of the promotion, as it was recently introduced. I then expressed my desire to return the item. The cashier uttered some words, which I could not decipher whether they were addressed to me or to her headset. She eventually stated that they would still honor the discount. Throughout the entire transaction, the cashier did not make any eye contact, nor did she extend a greeting or express gratitude. In fact, it was I who offered a 'thank you.' The interaction gave the impression that I was imposing upon them by purchasing the shirt! The level of friendliness and courtesy displayed by TSA agents far surpasses that of the cashier's behavior."

While there are, indubitably, fewer sightseers at this end of the regal thoroughfare, it remains patently evident that the World's End public house is an establishment tailored to capitalize on its diverse and frequently macabre history, catering predominantly to transient visitors who are eager to immerse themselves in the rich cultural heritage of this storied metropolis. Fundamentally, this drinking establishment exudes an aura of inflated prices, seemingly oblivious to the needs and preferences of local patrons, instead choosing to prioritize the interests of those who are merely passing through, fostering an ambiance that is somewhat alienating for residents. My associates and I were rather disenchanted by the bar staff's inquiry regarding our touristic status, which seemed to imply that our response would determine the extent of their attentiveness and hospitality, leading us to feel marginalized and inconsequential. However, upon being served, we did enjoy a pleasant interval, although my inclination is to avoid revisiting this establishment in the future.

"It is comprehensible that individuals possess an affinity towards this establishment, as the restaurant offers copious amounts of food, and the presentation of the dishes on the plates is aesthetically pleasing. However, it is unfortunate that the extensive waiting period detracts from the quality of the service, and the culinary offerings are often characterized by an excessive amount of oil and lack a fresh, vibrant taste. Furthermore, the menu does not provide a wide range of health-conscious options, which may be a drawback for some patrons. Nonetheless, it is apparent that the majority of individuals who dine out in Las Vegas are not seeking healthful meals, and thus, the popularity of this location can be understood."

"This establishment represents a binary paradigm, wherein the culinary experience is either satisfactory or disappointing, with no middle ground. Hailing from Chicago, I was intrigued to compare the quality of Asian cuisine herein. Upon entering, Satay's interior exuded a sense of cleanliness and coziness, fostering an inviting ambiance. Regrettably, my visit was marred by the unfortunate circumstance of dining with a large group, which significantly impacted my overall impression. Our endeavors to await the arrival of every individual's dishes proved futile, as a considerable lapse of timeâapproximately 50 minutesâelapsed before the final dish was served, rendering our meals frigid. Ultimately, we relinquished our initial plan, but those who opted to wait were confronted with lukewarm dishes. \n\nMy order, chicken pad thai, a ubiquitous and uncomplicated dish, failed to impress, as its flavors were unremarkable and lackluster. In light of this underwhelming experience, I find it unlikely that I shall return to this establishment in the future, barring the possibility of a happy hour visit or similar circumstances."

Ok. The two stars are because the floors had many sticky diseases on it. WTF? Don't they clean the floors? But the bartenders did make me forget about the nastiness with the strong and cheap drinks. That was the only reason it didn't get one star. I'd go back if I'm in Champaign again.

Update - we finally had the opportunity to visit the recently established Lincoln Square Mall venue. The aesthetic ambiance of the interior space left much to be desired, which was particularly disheartening given our fond memories of the previous location's more refined and inviting atmosphere. The seating arrangements appeared cramped and claustrophobic, while the utilitarian lighting fixtures overhead contributed to an overall feeling of melancholy within the space. Furthermore, an eccentric art installation positioned directly behind several of the tables resulted in numerous accidental collisions, adding to the general sense of discomfort. Unfortunately, our culinary experience did not fare much better, as we encountered difficulties with both the availability and temperature of certain menu items. Specifically, two of the dishes we ordered, one being a special promotion and the other a staple bread-based option, were unavailable at the time of our visit. Moreover, the pasta dish took an inordinate amount of time to arrive, and when it finally did, the accompanying cream sauce had solidified due to the prolonged wait, leaving our dining companion understandably disappointed.

During Restaurant Week, we reserved a table for six individuals through OpenTable and indulged in a culinary excursion encompassing a variety of dishes. Our party opted for the appetizer sampler, which featured an assortment of delectable delights such as fish tacos, bacon-wrapped bacon and eggs, and chicken pot pie nuggets. Although the chicken pot pie nuggets lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of flavor, perhaps a pinch of salt would have sufficed, the remaining dishes within the sampler platter proved satisfying. For our entrees, we selected the crispy fried game hen and shrimp and grits, while the other half of our party chose the Niman skirt steak. Unfortunately, these dishes failed to leave a lasting impression on our palates, with the exception of the bacon-wrapped bacon and egg appetizer, which demonstrated a remarkable balance of savory and rich flavors.

Midway through our meal, we finally received our sides, specifically zucchini and mac and cheese, upon request. The dessert menu presented a duo of tantalizing options: freshly baked cookies accompanied by milk or a trio of refreshing sorbets. While the cookies boasted an undeniable charm, their quality seemed unremarkable, mirroring something one could easily concoct in the comfort of their own kitchen.

Upon receipt of our check, we were taken aback by the various supplementary fees we had not previously been cognizant of, including a charitable donation in conjunction with Restaurant Week and an upcharge for the appetizer sampler. My extensive investigation of the restaurant's online menu failed to reveal any mention of such an upcharge fee, nor were we apprised of it during the ordering process. Moreover, the restaurant increased the price from $40 to $50, rendering our dining experience even more disappointing. In retrospect, we would have benefited from selecting a different establishment for Restaurant Week or opting for individual dishes from the standard menu. Despite the underwhelming experience, the Jameson mule cocktail proved quite satisfying.

"Our culinary excursion to Rustic Cafe this morning was motivated by its ostensibly impressive 4-star rating, which we believed would be an accurate reflection of the eatery's quality, given the generally reliable nature of Yelp reviews. Unfortunately, our expectations were not entirely met, as the dining experience fell somewhat short of our standards. Both my spouse and I opted for omelets, which, while filled with various ingredients, were regrettably saturated with oil. Moreover, the hash browns accompanying my husband's dish were unpleasantly cold. Our overall satisfaction with the restaurant was limited, to say the least, and we were left feeling somewhat underwhelmed. Notwithstanding, the prices charged were reasonable. However, I must admit that my uncompromising stance on the quality of orange juice served at establishments of this kind led me to deduct a star from my overall rating, as the OJ provided was unmistakably derived from concentrate, a fact that I find difficult to reconcile, particularly when considering the $3 price tag."

"Underwhelming experience at Terzetto Steakhouse Las Vegas. 

The M Resort Spa Casino boasts an upscale eatery, Terzetto Steakhouse, exuding sophistication and elegance in its ambiance and interior design, reminiscent of high-end restaurants found further north on the renowned Las Vegas Strip. Despite its visually stunning appearance, the menu lacks innovation and creativity, offering only traditional steakhouse dishes. 

A group of seven guests were impressed by the exceptional service provided by their server, who demonstrated punctuality, attentiveness, and helpfulness, despite the restaurant not being fully booked. However, the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, with steaks lacking rich beef flavor and a satisfying char. Although priced lower than premium steakhouses, the quality did not match the value. The sides were satisfactory but unremarkable. 

In conclusion, Terzetto Steakhouse presented an underwhelming dining experience, with disappointing food quality and unimpressive sides, despite its attractive atmosphere and excellent service."

"I crave an enhancement in the quality of Tom's eatery, but alas, it fails to meet my expectations. Despite its ambiance reminiscent of a beloved television show and commendable customer service, the culinary offerings leave much to be desired. Specifically, my grilled cheese sandwich, a seemingly straightforward dish, falls short in terms of both flavor and presentation. A dearth of butter on the bread and a solitary slice of American cheese hardly constitutes a satisfying meal, especially given the nomenclature of the dish itself. Furthermore, the exorbitant price point of $12 for a mediocre grilled cheese, fries, and iced tea only serves to augment my disappointment. Notwithstanding, I must acknowledge the attentive nature of the servers. In conclusion, while Tom's may possess an extensive menu boasting numerous options for non-carnivores, my hurried demeanor precluded me from exploring said choices and warranted a more streamlined approach. Moreover, I lament the lack of vegetarian-friendly establishments and implore restaurateurs to broaden their menus to accommodate the dietary preferences of all patrons."

"My sentiments regarding the eatery in question are utterly unfavorable. In conjunction with a colleague visiting from another location, I opted to partake of a midday repast at this establishment, primarily due to its proximity to our place of employment. Unfortunately, my expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but thoroughly disappointed by the unsanitary ambiance and lackluster hospitality. Furthermore, my culinary selection, specifically a chicken salad, failed to leave an enduring impression on my palate."

I've been here a few times because it's close to my job.  The lady that works in the front is really nice but the food is just alright.  I've never had a major complaint but today my food was not good.  I ordered shrimp fried rice for lunch and it's different, maybe a new cook or they change the oil.  It smells really good but has no taste whatsover.  Even after adding soy sauce and pepper it's unedible.  I'm so surprised because I love fried rice and who can mess that up.  Now I have to find something else to eat for lunch.

Having been told just yesterday about Batch and the fact that they make different types of fougasse breads, I raced over today to try them out.  I am a sucker for great fougasse, and try them out whenever I see them at a bakery.  The trouble is, they are not always so good!  Alas, the Madison fougasse lived up to my fears. Having created something more like a pizza crust in the shape of a pretzel, the Batch Bakehouse would be better advised to stick with less ambitious treats, like the sinful \"Hello Dolly\" 7-layer bar...  Though, of course, I DID manage to consume this  roasted garlic/sundried tomato/rosemary pretzel in disguise, it was heavy and way too chewy, not achieving the standard of firm exterior but soft interior.

"Fuel Pizza situated in the epicenter of Charlotte's upscale district merits a solitary star for its geographical location and an additional stellar accolade for the hospitable demeanor displayed by its staff. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings themselves are rather uninspired and lacking in depth of flavor, with the accompanying side salad boasting a vibrant palette yet lamentably devoid of an adequate dressing to elevate it to a truly satisfactory level. It is utterly perplexing that such unremarkable fare is offered at a premium price point, especially when juxtaposed with the establishment's tantalizing combo meals which, regrettably, fail to deliver on their promised gustatory satisfaction. A veritable gastronomical travesty! For a mere $6.50, one can indulge in a colossal, mouthwatering slice of pizza that rivals even the most exquisite culinary masterpieces. Conversely, at Fuel Pizza, the cost of a single serving surpasses $8.00, inclusive of a beverage and a paltry portion of pizza that fails to satiate one's hunger. It is my conviction that Sabarro's, a nearby eatery, offers a superior dining experience for only a marginally higher tariff. The ambiance of Fuel Pizza, while intriguing, appears unfinished and somewhat disjointed. Furthermore, the facilities designated for personal hygiene are spotless yet aesthetically displeasing, marred by unsightly graffiti and haphazardly positioned sanitary fixtures. In light of its prime location within Charlotte's bustling business district, one would expect a theme restaurant such as Fuel Pizza to maintain a more polished and refined appearance. Alas, the overall atmosphere is chaotic and visually unappealing, eliciting feelings of chagrin and disappointment in those who have the misfortune of partaking in its offerings."

"The accommodations were adequate, but lacked any distinguishing features that would have elevated them beyond the realm of mediocrity. The personnel, however, exhibited a commendable level of cordiality and hospitality. Unfortunately, the parking facility adjacent to the establishment exuded an unsettling ambiance, which was further accentuated by its eerie illumination. The aquatic recreational areas, while ostensibly designed to provide a relaxing respite for guests, failed to impress this particular patron. Moreover, the presence of an adult boutique situated directly across the street from the hotel served to enhance the overall sense of unease and discomfort that permeated the surrounding environment. Despite its proximity to various points of interest, I would not consider returning to this lodging establishment in the future."

"Initially, the service was satisfactory, albeit somewhat sluggish. The wait staff member exhibited remarkable cordiality, whereas the culinary specialist in charge of managing the kitchen operations opted to offer a pecuniary reduction on our entire bill due to the prolonged waiting period surpassing three quarters of an hour for our midday repast selections. However, the carbonated beverage and citrus-flavored liquid refreshment did not meet my expectations in terms of flavor, prompting me to return them thrice. The complementary tortilla chips and tangy dip were relatively palatable. I opted for the mixed grill consisting of both bovine and avian components. Unfortunately, the beef exuded an intense sweetness akin to teriyaki sauce, while the poultry was overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant dining experience. Therefore, it is unlikely that I shall revisit this establishment in the future."

"This culinary excursion is not intended for tourists; rather, it caters to individuals possessing a domestic kitchen setup. While meandering throughout the premises, I observed a dearth of vendors proffering complimentary tastings, and there was a conspicuous absence of readily consumable fare, such as one might encounter at numerous other mercantile centers. Perhaps my expectations were skewed due to my familiarity with Pike Place Market. Additionally, the venue itself was unexpectedly diminutive in scale, which was surprising given the region's temperate climate and the resulting abundance of fresh produce available for cultivation throughout the year."

After an abundance of initial acclaim on Yelp, I opted to partake in a culinary excursion to Nourish, eager to sample the fare that this purportedly health-conscious eatery had to offer. As an individual who does not adhere to a vegetarian, vegan, glucose-free, or lactose-free dietary regimen, yet still maintains a penchant for delectable and nutritious cuisine, Nourish appeared to cater to a specific niche that was previously unfulfilled in the local dining scene, with True Food being the sole comparable establishment that came to mind. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, as certain aspects of the dining experience fell short of my standards. Specifically, the unremarkable taste of their plain water prompted me to appreciate the variety of flavored waters available, while the salads, though undoubtedly flavorful, were minuscule in portion and priced unreasonably high. In contrast, the sandwiches presented a relatively better value, although superior options are readily available at numerous other establishments. Furthermore, the "air-fried" sweet potato fries, while satisfactory, failed to surpass their conventional counterparts in terms of quality, raising questions about the necessity of specifying such a detail. Notwithstanding, the accompanying dipping sauce deserves commendation for its delectability. The ambiance of the restaurant exuded a sense of comfort and relaxation, and the service was indeed impressive. However, the crux of a successful dining venture lies in the quality of the food, which, unfortunately, did not inspire me to consider a future visit.

My spouse had the novel 5-cheese Mac and Cheese with poultry. It appeared visually appealing, and he expressed that it possessed an enjoyable flavor profile. In contrast, I opted for the traditional baby back ribs, which unfortunately did not meet my expectations. The meat was excessively desiccated, resulting in an unpleasant texture, and the edges were overcooked to the extent of being charred. The dish lacked any semblance of moisture, and the absence of copious amounts of barbecue sauce, often used as a makeshift solution, was conspicuous. The overall experience was utterly disappointing and unpalatable. Consequently, I strongly advise against ordering the ribs at this establishment and would caution others against doing so as well.

I genuinely yearned to relish this eatery since I possess a predilection for diners and dives, albeit not drive-ins, per se; and this establishment boasts the quintessential diner layout within an area of town, specifically Melrose, that I am fervently hoping will metamorphose into something exceptional, as it already harbors an inherent coolness. However, my culinary experience proved underwhelming. I opted for the breakfast sandwich, comprising eggs, sausage, and cheese nestled between a croissant. While the croissant itself was merely passable, the eggs, sausage, and cheese combination exuded an unpleasant oiliness and lacked any remarkable flavor profile. Furthermore, it was accompanied by a side of potatoes that failed to elicit even a modicum of enthusiasm. Despite my initial disappointment, I shall grant this venue another opportunity at a later time.

Wait staff and service was good.  My steak was excellent (Tabasco peppered Kobe flank). My friends duck was mediocre and the fat was not rendered. We didn't have time to wait for a fix so she just ate it.  The sides with it were good. The worst part of the experience was the fact that they charged $5 for hot water. 35 for mediocre duck and 40 for a steak.  I find charging for hot water ridiculous.

This store is like a Mega store. Maybe they are a little bit over they head because sadly the meats are not the best. They have meat on sale for 3 and 4 bucks and its coloring is brown to black. Meat should be Red. I will shop here but I will stay away from the meat. If you can get pass that the store is really ok.

Just had the worst experience ever at Picture People in Henderson Nevada. The white background of my photos show the scuff marks of the backdrop, they did a shoddy job of cropping, only allowed me a certain number of photos to go on my disk (nowhere in writing does it say I only get \"x\" number of photos), refused to give me a price sheet because \"we just know the price of and tell customers the price\", and above all refused to accept my coupon for $20 off a $100 purchase because they said it excluded the CD...umm... once again nowhere in writing does it say \"excludes the photo CD\"! The best part is the manager was the individual I was dealing with!! If it werent for the fact that my husband very nicely asked me to just woosah the situation I would have flipped out....Now I am just looking at the photos crying. I am definitely going to tell everyone I know not to waste their money.... 100% satisfaction guarantee my butt!   \n\nI gave them 2 stars because Portia was an amazing photographer and was very interactive and animated with my 3 month old to get her to smile

Once again the Mexican restaurant in Stations casinos has changed hands. No longer Guadalajara, but Cabo now.

My fiance and I decided to stop in here late on Friday night after I got off work. I really wanted a margarita to celebrate the completion of my training. 

We waited... A lot. We waited for the hostess to show up. We waited for chips. We waited for drinks... Lots of waiting.... I waited for a water I ordered that never came. So I drank my fiance's. We were never asked if we wanted a refill of our chip basket.

The poor girl serving us seemed frazzled. The busboy was of very little help.

The food was mediocre. My margarita was the star of the night. It was very good and blended well. They did honor the check-in policy and we got sopapillas, which we took to go.

I don't know why Stations Casinos keep changing their restaurants... But this change was not for the better. The only thing I'd come back for is another raspberry margarita.

Service is great, drinks are good, food is only ok. Stuffed peppers and dates are the best thing there. However, the entire restaurant smells like an old dish rag. It makes me wonder how clean things are...

"Beer: Satisfactory. 

Culinary offerings: Subpar. 

It is my conviction, formed after indulging in an excessive number of culinary establishment rescue programs, that eateries boasting menus of considerable volume invariably serve fare that is, at best, unremarkable. BJs falls squarely within this category. 

Their menu, replete with pizza-esque items, led me to deduce that opting for a flatbread would be the wisest choice. Alas, the execution fell short of expectations. While the dish did contain tomatoes and cheese, the sausage component was conspicuous by its absence. A paltry few pieces of sausage-like matter graced the flatbread, rendering the claim that it featured sausage dubious at best. 

The bread itself presented a dichotomy of texture, with certain areas exhibiting a satisfying crispness while others descended into sogginess. This inconsistency rendered the overall experience less than satisfactory. 

Given that the primary item on their menu (i.e., pizza-like products) failed to impress, it is reasonable to surmise that the remaining menu items, sprawled across a whopping 12 pages (an exaggeration, perhaps, but not by much), are likely to be forgettable, at best."

We dined the last night of restaurant week(which we didn't know until we arrived). The menu was very limited, the appetizer of pork bellies(my husband's) was so greasy he couldn't eat it, his entree was cod and very bland. My entree, sea bass was overcooked and tasted bland and not very fresh.  The only part of the meal that we liked was the dessert.\n\nThis was our first time here for my birthday and was very disappointed considering all the great reviews.  Was this any off night, maybe but will probably not go back. One positive was our waiter-very knowledgable and friendly.

I spent a good three hours studying. Besides having a great facility for wifi, seating, and noise level, the service could use a lot of work. If you're in the service industry, people who apply for this jobs should be mindful that they will be working with people. In other words, they can be more friendly and cheerful no matter how difficult it may be. Other than that, I did enjoy my peach green tea lemonade.

The food is good, but how hard it is to make good Italian food - after all, even the O Garden can get that right. But this place believes itself to be "exceptional Italian food" (which is obvious from the exorbitant prices they charge) and it is not even close. No originality, just another offering of the same tired old foods that every other place is making. 

This is a prime example of what has become a scourge in Vegas eateries of late - high cost, low atmosphere, mediocre cuisine offerings - where people with more money that taste go because they know nothing more about food except the belief that "the more it costs, the better it must be".

Oh and then there was the WORST greeting any bartender could EVER utter:   "I'll be with you in a minute!"   Could I mean any less to them? If I wasn't meeting somebody, I would have walked out.

During my most recent visit, I had a subpar experience, which was unfortunately marred by several unpleasant discoveries. Specifically, upon consuming my chicken curry, I noticed an unsettling presence of errant strands of hair, which I promptly captured in a photograph for evidentiary purposes. Furthermore, the naan bread served alongside the curry was remarkably flat and dry, lacking the customary fluffiness and texture that one would reasonably expect from such an item. Additionally, the chicken in the curry was not particularly abundant, which only contributed to my overall disappointment. However, it is worth mentioning that the establishment offered a diverse array of dishes, some of which were admittedly quite palatable. Unfortunately, the prices charged for this culinary experience were somewhat prohibitive in comparison to similar buffet-style restaurants in the area, leaving me uncertain about the likelihood of my future patronage.

This eatery proved to be a modest letdown. Indeed, it boasts a quaint setting within St. Mark's Square at the Venetian, with an ambient atmosphere that is quite pleasant; however, the overall encounter was not particularly satisfactory.  

The service was sluggish and unreliable. Upon being seated, the waitstaff informed us that she would promptly deliver water; regrettably, said water did not arrive until we had already received our meals and beverages, and only subsequent to our repeated queries directed towards our server. When we were presented with the opportunity to add parmesan to our dishes, the gentleman who inquired about it simply disappeared without a trace, leaving us to solicit the attention of our waitress, who was conspicuously absent for the majority of the evening. Subsequently, she carelessly dropped a sizable piece of cheese onto the table, which remained there throughout the duration of our repast.  

The culinary offerings were adequate, albeit their rapid arrival seemed almost too expedient, as if they had been previously prepared prior to our placing our orders.  

In light of this underwhelming experience, I would unlikely return. Given the abundance of alternative dining establishments in close proximity (it is Las Vegas, after all), it is reasonable to explore other options.

Arrowheads Applebee's is much more enjoyable! Went to karaoke last night an it was so horrible. The dj and his crew sang most of the songs :/ there were some families after 11... I thought there had to be an age limit to be in the bar after 10? There were some annoying high school girls screaming spice girls... Help me!!!!

This establishment undoubtedly offers exceptional yogurt, particularly the oatmeal cookie variant, which stands out as the most superior option among their extensive array of flavors. However, their customer service approach significantly hinders the overall experience, as they opt for distributing samples by hand rather than maintaining easily accessible sample cups. I endured an agonizing wait of over five minutes to receive a solitary sample from the indifferent employee, who barely acknowledged my presence with a cursory greeting. Upon presenting the price, he concluded the transaction with a brusque demeanor, omitting even the most basic expressions of gratitude or well wishes. Needless to say, I won't be revisiting this location, considering the underwhelming encounter I had.

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and my experiences have been overwhelmingly positive. However, my most recent visit was not up to par, primarily due to the absence of the sole English-speaking staff member. As a result, communication proved to be a significant challenge. In the past, I have consistently requested the services of Andy, as his proficiency in massage therapy has been exceptional. Unfortunately, he was preoccupied during my visit, and I was attended to by one of the female therapists instead. It is worth noting that the therapists present appeared to be engaged in conversation amongst themselves, which created a distracting environment. Furthermore, the lady who administered my massage seemed hurried and irritable. This combination of factors resulted in a less than satisfactory experience. Following my massage, I made my way back to the restroom, whereupon I observed a male individual being escorted into a secluded back room with a door. This sight piqued my curiosity and raised concerns regarding potentially illicit activities. I must emphasize that I do not condone such behavior and am currently undecided about whether I shall return to this establishment in the future.

Not impressed. I was with a large group, so that might have been that. I was late and everyone else had already ordered. The server acknowledged me as the straggler or so I thought. I asked for a drink menu and a regular menu and he gave me the drink menu and he came back to the other end of the table a couple times leaving me still drink-less. After that he didn't ask about food and one of the guys in my party went up to him to tell him I was still looking to order. Everyone else received their food before I even ordered. I should have just given up right there, but I was starving. I ordered the apocalypse sow with salad. Not as good as I expected. I felt it was dry and lacking flavor. The aoli was just plopped in the middle. The meat was crumbling and I had to just eat it with a knife and fork. Should have just got the soup.

"Two stars for the frozen hot chocolate, a culinary indulgence that elicited a profound sense of satisfaction, albeit accompanied by an unfortunate concatenation of events that transpired during the dining experience, specifically pertaining to the temporal duration between our arrival and the moment we were seated, which exceeded thirty minutes; the interval between requesting hydration and its actual delivery at our table, which amounted to fifteen minutes; and the additional quarter hour spent awaiting the taking of our orders, resulting in a cumulative delay of forty-one minutes before the consumption of sustenance, which, regrettably, did not meet expectations, falling short of excellence while failing to justify mediocrity, thus prompting the decision to circumvent the conventional dining protocol by opting to place future orders at the window, thereby eliminating the need for a reserved table and streamlining the process, all in pursuit of that delectable frozen hot chocolate."
