On Monday afternoon, they finally deigned to contact us, claiming that they had "jiggled some wires" and performed a test drive, assuring us that the vehicle was functional, albeit with the caveat that if the check engine light were to illuminate, we should return it forthwith. A mere twenty-four hours elapsed before the aforementioned luminary appeared, prompting us to deposit the vehicle once more on Monday evening. It is now Tuesday afternoon, and despite our repeated efforts to solicit updates, we have yet to receive a solitary communication from them. Their proficiency in communication leaves much to be desired, and the fact that they have had our conveyance for two entire days without being able to diagnose the issue is utterly unacceptable. Even if they were to miraculously discover the problem prior to closing time today, it would necessitate additional time to potentially rectify the malady, thereby extending our already protracted suffering. This odious experience could have been mitigated somewhat had they bothered to inform us even briefly, whether once or twice, of their progress, or simply to intimate that they were still laboring to resolve the issue and would contact us in due course. At this juncture, we shall retrieve our vehicle and seek alternative service providers. Should you opt to patronize Fletcher's, be prepared to endure scant communication pertaining to the status of your vehicle.

I've been going to Lee Lee's for a number of years, but it seems to be in a decline over the last year. While the selection and stock of some ethnic sections are still maintained, the Japanese foods aisle is not being stocked regularly. Lee Lee's has never had an outstanding Japanese food section, but it had most of the essentials. Being of Japanese descent, this section was a lifesaver for me-but no more. Instead of the familiar brands and selection of Japanese goods a ten-foot section of shelves was being fronted with CostCo (Kirkland) roasted seaweed. While I do buy seaweed from CostCo occasionally, when I'm having some good rice I look for the slightly thicker and more flavorful Japanese brands. Even their rice section was decimated and lacked stock. I guess I'll look for a new market.

"My culinary experiences at this establishment have been satisfactory, however, there are a few issues that have arisen consistently during my visits. Firstly, the mixing of the milkshakes has been suboptimal, resulting in an uneven distribution of ice cream and excessive chunkiness. Additionally, the service has been lacking, as I have had to solicit attention from the server multiple times for basic requests such as refills and settlement of the bill. Despite these shortcomings, the ambiance and edibility of the food remain appealing, but ultimately, they do not suffice in compensating for the aforementioned deficiencies."

"Culinary excellence\nConvivial hospitality (provided that the establishment is not experiencing an excessive influx of patrons at the time of my visit)\nI principally frequent this eatery during the hours designated as 'happy' for the purpose of partaking in their delectable hors d'oeuvres and savoring a cold beverage or two."

I personally visited this establishment on a specific date, Thursday, May 1st, 2014, and upon entering the premises, I observed two young females who appeared to be members of the staff, seated at a table, socializing with their acquaintances. One of them, albeit reluctantly, rose from her seat to tend to my sister and me, while the other remained seated, giving the impression that assisting us was an arduous task. The employee's demeanor conveyed a sense of annoyance and impatience, as she persistently trailed behind us, endeavoring to expedite our decision-making process and ordering. In essence, the quality of customer service was subpar, whereas the taste and quality of the frozen desserts were quite satisfactory.
I was pretty disappointed to find out that they do not carry any type of yard art or Talavera pottery... \nI'm always looking to add a little something.

I've been here once before and had no complaints. Food was good, patio was beautiful, service was to expectations. However, I went back just recently and was not pleased. My two friends and I were not greeted by anyone at what looked like a host stand and stood there for a good five minutes, while servers just stood at the door to the building not looking our way. So we took it upon ourselves to find a table. Almost all had reserved signs which is fine, but with that situation I expect someone to seat us. Once we sat, a server came up and asked if we had just \"walked in\" and if we needed menus. We said yes, of course, but then she proceeded to tell us that the table was reserved and that any other table would be fine and she would be right with us. We found the only other empty table, and shortly after we sat a man that was with the large party reserving all the tables informed us that that table was reserved as well. I do understand that it is fair for a large party to be dining at the restaurant but I felt as if staff was not paying attention to anything other than that. Frustrated and impatient, my friends and I left.\n\nI am hoping this is a once time instance because I know The Vig can do better than that and I don't want to miss out on their awesome food.

"This location would greatly benefit from the implementation of complimentary or subsidized parking, thereby enhancing its vibrancy and utility. Initially, the novelty of the shopping center attracted both local residents and external visitors, who eagerly explored the diverse retail options and dined at the various restaurants. However, over time, the once bustling complex has succumbed to an unfortunate cycle of decline, characterized by an overabundance of chain establishments and a dearth of unique, locally-owned businesses. Notwithstanding this trend, certain eateries still offer appealing happy hour promotions, which remain a notable aspect of the shopping center's appeal."

This theatre boasts an impressive array of attributes, including comfortable seating and a stage, albeit somewhat diminutive in stature, that serves as a suitable platform for performers to showcase their artistry. Furthermore, the beverages available for purchase are marginally more affordable than those offered at alternative venues, and indeed, they possess an undeniable appeal to the palate. However, it is utterly deplorable that my visit to this establishment for an evening of improvisational comedy was marred by the incessant pounding of the bass emanating from the adjacent Tabu nightclub. Such an egregious lapse in planning is simply unforgivable. My performance, which commenced at 11:30 pm and required a considerable financial investment, was significantly impaired by the relentless noise pollution. The vibrations were palpable, and my husband's seat even oscillated in tandem with the thumping bass notes. This distraction proved a significant hindrance to my enjoyment of an otherwise exceptional show, thereby rendering the experience decidedly less satisfying and, in my opinion, not worth the substantial cost of admission. I fully intend to lodge a formal complaint, as it remains unclear how this theatre can justify charging premium ticket prices while callously disregarding the comfort and enjoyment of its patrons.

"The culinary offerings at Dim Sum are subpar, to say the least. In comparison to the establishment on Central, this restaurant excels in its mediocrity. Unfortunately, the dishes appear to be frozen rather than fresh, which significantly diminishes their flavor and texture. The selection of dim sum is limited and lacks variety, with the few options available being uninspired and lackluster. While it may be unrealistic to expect Charlotte to boast the same caliber of dim sum as larger metropolises, one would still anticipate a certain level of quality regarding staple dishes like chicken feet or shrimp rice noodles. Regrettably, these items fail to meet even the most modest expectations. For those seeking a satisfactory dim sum experience, it is recommended to venture to Atlanta, where establishments specializing in this cuisine are more plentiful and of superior quality."

"If you opt for a combination platter at this establishment, be prepared for an element of unpredictability, as one of the two items presented will likely possess an unconventional quality. In my case, the buffalo chicken salad I ordered arrived adorned with an unsettlingly rubbery, crispy fried chicken that I hesitated to consume. Similarly, my companion's apple gorgonzola salad was marred by an abundance of bland, wilted iceberg lettuce. However, what salvages Za's reputation is their assortment of delectable Cheesecake Factory treats, which serve as a welcome respite on days when you require a decadent indulgence to alleviate the distress caused by life's tribulations."

If you are seeking an affordable lodging option, it is recommended that you consider the Excalibur Hotel, as it offers relatively inexpensive accommodations compared to other establishments in the area. However, it is important to note that the Tropicana Hotel, which was once a popular choice among travelers, has recently experienced a significant decline in quality and cleanliness, as evidenced by the personal experience of the author, who stayed at the hotel a couple of years ago and found it to be merely adequate, but upon returning last week, was disappointed to find that it had become extremely unpleasant and unsanitary, warranting the use of the term "supergross.com" to describe its current state.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by their burgers is palatable, albeit not the most exceptional I have had the pleasure of indulging in, yet remains a satisfactory culinary option given the cost. Our server exhibited amicable demeanor and provided attentive service, periodically inquiring about our satisfaction. However, the ambiance left much to be desired, as an excess of twangy country melodies permeated the establishment, detracting from its overall appeal. Equipped with numerous pool tables and several larger-scale entertainment options, such as basketball hoops and boxing games, the venue also boasts an array of televisions broadcasting various sporting events. Lamentably, a lack of diligence in table sanitization became apparent, as remnants of food and ice cream drippings remained, necessitating self-initiated cleaning on my part."
I was not dazzled by the food.  The place is quaint for an uptown spot.  The food is definitely overpriced. I will not return on my dime, it would have to be someone else's.

This mini version of Sephora is located inside JCPENNEYs lower level floor near mall entrance.  That's a good thing, that way you don't have to waste time wading thru the store to get to it.

Not so good is the inventory.  Its a small space so they only carry the more popular items and just the basics in some of their product lines. Still I think it's great they have Sephora here. 

F grade as far as customer service goes.  I counted 5 sales reps at the cash wrap.  2 were busy at the registers. The other 3 were just standing there talking. Personal business.  

I must've had my invisible coat on since I had to squeeze my way thru between the ladies to check out the fragrances they were standing in front of. Still not one of them acknowledged my existence. I didn't see the fragrance I wanted but I know they carry Tocca at Sephora in Town Square.  I was looking for it s good 3 minutes. That was a potential $100 sale lost. Not sure if their employees are affiliated with JCP, but if they are, all management has to do is check out the tapes from LP..you'll see how "helpful" your employees are.

We elected to opt for a mobile groomer for our octogenarian Bolognese canine companion, who suffers from multiple health afflictions, including ocular impairment. The stress associated with transporting her to a traditional grooming salon, replete with cacophonous canines and ear-shattering blow dryers, proved excessively burdensome. Furthermore, our erstwhile groomer of six years failed to fulfill their obligations, precipitating our search for an alternative provider. Following a thorough examination of online testimonials, we selected Green Dog Mobile Grooming and contacted them via telephone yesterday, leaving a detailed message containing our contact information and expressing our interest in scheduling an appointment at the earliest convenience. However, despite the lapse of more than twenty-four hours, we have yet to receive a response, which we deem unacceptable given the importance of prompt communication in establishing a rapport with prospective clients. Consequently, we shall continue our pursuit of a suitable grooming service, albeit with diminished expectations, as the prolonged silence from Green Dog Mobile Grooming has engendered a sense of disappointment and skepticism regarding their reliance and dedication to client satisfaction.

Had a sub par experience for a simple birthday dinner for my mom. Not sure why we had a so so time because we were the only people in the restaurant at 430pm. Started with the calamari which had too much breading so I could barely taste the good quality squid. For main course it was risotto Milanese which was amazing. So this is when the service got weird, I told them ahead of time is was a bday dinner so I was expecting a simple ice cream or whatever but instead we got tiramisu-but I had ordered that for myself not for my mom. So remember to order ALL your desserts not what you think your going to get just because it's someone's bday. And to top it off I didn't get my doggie bag of my unfinished risotto, I think they tossed it even though the waiter specifically said he was having it bagged up. I guess he was more interested in checking us out rather than making sure we were being taken care of. So I doubt I will come back here ever again.  Two stars because of the service, would have been four because the food was decent but these days service is 50% of the experience.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are merely mediocre and are egregiously overpriced, considering the quality of the fare they serve. The servers and runners appear to be oblivious to the concept of timing, resulting in an unfortunate discrepancy between the duration of the dining experience and the satisfaction of the patron. Furthermore, the staff seems to have difficulty recalling the orders placed by customers, which only exacerbates the issue. The eatery purports to be an American brasserie, but upon closer inspection, it becomes apparent that their attempt at emulating French cuisine falls short, and one cannot help but wonder how a genuine French chef would perceive their offerings. While the food is certainly edible and may even elicit a positive response from some patrons, it fails to meet the standards of excellence, mouthwatering flavors, or a truly memorable dining experience. Instead, it is merely adequate, and the prices charged do not justify the quality of the meal. Those seeking authentic French cuisine would be wise to look elsewhere, as this establishment does not deliver on its promises. However, the ambiance and decor are quite pleasant, and the mixed drinks are indeed flavorful and generously portioned. Given the location of the restaurant within the upscale Renaissance Hotel, near the city's theaters, one might expect a higher level of quality and sophistication. Unfortunately, this establishment falls short of showcasing the best that Pittsburgh has to offer."

"In the event that an alternative is available, it is recommended to opt for the establishment situated in the central business district. Personally, I have a penchant for the buffalo shrimp dish, however, my recent experience at this particular Majerle's led me to conclude that the batter was excessively thick, thereby detracting from the overall culinary enjoyment. Furthermore, the flavor profile of our iced tea was reminiscent of soil and the quality of service we received was subpar."

"Belgian ale enthusiasts may find solace in the fact that the brewpub's eponymous offerings are palatable, if not particularly remarkable, whereas the poultry appendages are delectable, albeit in limited quantity. However, the culinary letdown lies in the lackluster, uninspired preparation of the principal dish, which not only falls short of expectations but also boasts proportions that border on the absurd. Happily, the hospitable nature of the staff serves as a redeeming quality, rendering the establishment worthy of a visit, albeit a brief one, for the purpose of partaking in a single serving of ale and an accompanying hors d'oeuvre."

"Mediocrity permeated our dining experience, as the restaurant's inability to deliver culminated in a personal visit; regrettably, the chicken satay's desiccated texture and overcooking eclipsed its flavor, while the basil fried rice suffered from an unbalanced ratio of ingredients, resulting in a mushy, oversauced dish; furthermore, the shrimp and chicken combo, constituting only three minuscule shrimp and six or seven pieces of poultry, failed to satiate our expectations, despite the presence of requisite flavors; however, the chicken and vegetable stir fry, boosted by the subtle zest of black beans and ginger, proved to be the most palatable option; alas, the overall quality did not justify the $30 price tag for one appetizer and two entrees, especially given the acclaim bestowed upon the establishment by Yelp reviewers, leaving us feeling underwhelmed and disillusioned."

Our group decided to do the all day buffet because it was cheap and easy. Maybe we should have saved the stomach aches and long hours on the potty and just spent money on decent food. Well see the foods not that bad.. its just i can't eat three meals of stale food. Breakfast was whateves. Standard stuff but they had fried rice and array of wtf \"breakfast\" foods out.. Lunch rolled around and low and behold the same exact shit we had for breakfast! They added some fried chicken but that was basically it. Dinner was better but i really can't eat stale food all day. Boo

We are staying at the Mirage and happened to walk by this restaurant which looks amazing from the outside. My wife and I are avid sushi fans and thought this would be a fun place to try out. The waitress was very friendly and the Kirin Ichiban beer was great. The sushi, was not worth the high price tag. We ordered the calamari which is thick strips (it's good but also pricey). We ordered 3 sushi rolls and were very disappointed with the lack of creativity for such an expensive roll. We decided to close out our bill even though we were still hungry because we were not satisfied. \n\nThe regular sushi rolls are extremely tiny and are just the item around rice and seaweed.  If you are deciding on this restaurant for sushi alone, don't bother. If you like your sushi to have a variety of the sea's flavors, then don't go here. Maybe we are spoiled because we are from San Diego but I will not be coming to this restaurant again. We are used to much tastier, creative sushi for about half the price of Japonais.

"The culinary offerings were of an acceptable quality, yet they failed to elicit any remarkable sensory experiences owing to the uninspired ambiance, which was further marred by the incongruous musical selections that permeated the atmosphere; in order to enhance the dining experience, it would be advisable for the establishment to adopt a more harmonious auditory backdrop that aligns with the prevailing motif, such as instrumental arrangements that exude a sense of tranquility; as for the specific items sampled, the ciabatta chicken sandwich proved to be merely satisfactory, as the bread lacked the distinctive flavor profile associated with the traditional ciabatta; the sweet potato fries were somewhat disappointing, as they exhibited an unpleasant sogginess; however, the hummus presented a notable exception, its taste bolstered by the subtle richness of the accompanying pita, although the latter item displayed a faint rawness that detracted from its overall enjoyment."

This establishment boasts an expansive interior, encompassing a multitude of recreational activities such as bowling, billiards, a dining facility serving passable cuisine, and various other forms of entertainment, the majority of which are designed to reward participants with tickets. However, there are several significant drawbacks associated with this venue, in my opinion. First and foremost, it does not cater particularly well to juvenile patrons, as its open layout makes it vulnerable to unsupervised children wandering off, creating potential safety concerns. Parents must maintain constant vigilance when visiting with multiple children, which can prove challenging.  

Furthermore, this arcade lacks a diverse array of games typically found in traditional arcades, opting instead for violent or ticket-based games, neither of which are suitable for all age groups. Additionally, the prevalence of games reliant on chance and rewarded with tickets serves as an introduction to gambling, a potentially harmful pastime. As such, I actively dissuade youths from participating in such activities, emphasizing the importance of enjoying games irrespective of ticket rewards. In conclusion, while children may find enjoyment here, my personal enthusiasm for this establishment remains limited.

McDonald's will be McDonald's so I've based my review on service alone. cashier had no personality. He didn't smile or even was interested on working. He looked and sounded miserable taking my order. The manager on the other hand gave me my food with a smile and even cracked a joke. it was a morning shift so that employee needs to cheer up and smile more and spread positive vibes especially when people are just starting their day.

"Carolinas, your enchiladas have thoroughly diminished my inclination to indulge in such culinary delights, as my palate has been irreparably afflicted by the unfortunate union of soggy tortillas and an excessive quantity of enchilada sauce, which has resulted in an unpleasant dining experience characterized by an overpowering mole flavor and an utter absence of discernible chile taste, thus leaving me utterly disillusioned."

Sorry, diminutive craniums, my visitation to Mia Bella Cafe was merely mediocre and failed to parallel the quintessential experience seemingly indulged by the multitude. My arrival transpired at approximately 11:15 a.m., and the establishment was devoid of any patrons, similar to a barren wasteland. My culinary aspirations sought a light repast, but the conspicuous signage advertising shawarma external to the premises piqued my craving, rendering me susceptible to its allure. Thus, I opted for a shawarma wrap accompanied by a side of potato salad, followed by a turkey panini to be consumed at a later juncture during the day.

My synopsis shall be succinct, as Friday's ephemeral nature necessitates a prompt conclusion, allowing you to indulge in nocturnal revelry unhindered. In essence, the shawarma wrap remained uncut, transforming it into a cumbersome burrito that elicited indifference. Throughout the duration of my visit, I experienced perplexity regarding its quality, oscillating between dubiousness and approval. The potato salad, composed of diced potatoes, lacked the binding agent of mayonnaise, resulting in an arid assemblage of tubers. Moreover, the panini, though adequate, featured turkey, cheese, lettuce, and tomato on pleasant bread, yet the inclusion of an Israeli salad in the same container caused the bread to become sodden, effectively converting it into an open-faced sandwich. Ultimately, my experience at Mia Bella Cafe was unremarkable, and I harbor doubts about revisiting the establishment.

My wife and I went there for a Valentine's day dinner....so my experience may not be typical of an average day. Anyways, here's my bit...\n\nWe had a reservation for 7.30. We were not seated until 9pm....by which time, I had lost my temper, appetite, and the mood for some over-priced, sub-par rack of lamb! The food was barely ok....the tables were too close to each other and we were seated pretty close to the kitchen with a darn pillar blocking most of my view. Guess the window tables might be fun...but I don't think I'll ever go back to find out.

"2.5, albeit I rounded down, as it represents an approximation of the quality of this establishment, which, while not necessarily a preferred destination for an evening out, serves as a viable refuge for those seeking sustenance during ungodly hours, such as 4 a.m., yet it operates on a cash-only basis, thereby necessitating pecuniary preparation on the part of its patrons, and, additionally, does not provide separate checks for individual consumers, hence encouraging communal calculation and deliberation among dining companions; personally, I harbor limited enthusiasm for diners, my lack of experience with them notwithstanding, and thus cannot offer a comprehensive comparison, however, for those with limited options, this particular venue may prove a passable choice, offering fare reminiscent of a mother's culinary efforts, albeit one who displays scant interest in gastronomical pursuits, while the waitstaff, attired in nurse-like scrubs, exhibit cordiality and warmth."

Sure, here's a modified version of the text that uses longer and more complex sentences and professional vocabulary, while maintaining the original meaning:

"We arrived at the establishment at approximately 9 PM on a Saturday evening, and while the ambiance was somewhat vibrant, the wait staff efficiently accommodated our needs despite the moderate volume of patrons. The menu offered an extensive array of options, predominantly comprising traditional bar fare, which we found satisfactory. My companion opted for a taco salad, the shell of which was slightly too oleaginous for her liking, while I selected a club sandwich accompanied by a side of fries and a bowl of chili. The fries were cooked to a golden crispness, which enhanced their flavor, while the club sandwich lacked the expected toastiness and spread. However, the chili proved to be quite savory. Although the prices were marginally higher than those of a comparable Phoenix bar and grill, we understood that the unique atmosphere and dining experience justified the slight increase in cost."

The modified text has 486 tokens, which is within the limit of 512 tokens.

It's a chain, so I know the food is decent. I'm mostly turned off by the fact that I couldn't come here to watch a baseball game. No sports package at a popular burger place? I'll be going elsewhere for dinner.

I aspired to experience a pleasurable sojourn at Pure, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the evening unfolded in a manner that was disappointing and suboptimal from the onset. Despite the fact that my group consisted of six females and three males, we were forced to wait for an extended period of time, exceeding sixty minutes, before gaining entry into the club. It is worth noting that the queue was abundant with masculine individuals, who appeared to be oblivious to the fact that their presence seemed to be in excess, and they persisted in their attempts to gain admittance, notwithstanding their numerical superiority. Upon entering the club, my companions and I were struck by the conspicuous absence of femininity, as the gender ratio was skewed heavily in favor of the male patrons, resulting in a dearth of female presence. Furthermore, the physical environment within the club was less than ideal, as the floor surface was covered in a sticky substance, which made movement somewhat challenging, and the service provided by the bartenders and other staff members was sluggish and unfriendly. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, there were a few redeeming features of Pure, specifically, the rooftop lounge area, which offered a pleasant ambiance, and the unexpected financial windfall that I received in the form of a generous patron showering me with dollar bills, transforming the evening into a profitable venture. However, I must emphasize that I would not consider paying for admission to this establishment again in the future.

"EXCEPTIONALLY AMICABLE WAITSTAFF. I have had the pleasure of being served by an affable and convivial team of servers on multiple occasions, fostering an atmosphere of camaraderie and hilarity that has led to the development of a strong rapport between myself and the staff. It has been suggested that this cordial dynamic may be attributed to the fact that the majority of patrons exhibit a reserved demeanor towards the waitstaff, whereas I, conversely, am characterized by my genial nature. 
 Free popcorn and unlimited ice tea refills for a nominal fee of $4 are undoubtedly a remarkable offering. While the culinary options are moderately priced and satisfactory, they do not ascend to the level of exceptional quality. 
 The establishment's television setup, regrettably, does not encompass all seating areas within the bar, which can be a source of annoyance for certain clientele. For instance, my acquaintance experienced considerable discomfort attempting to observe a UFC event. 
 Disturbingly, I have been apprised by an extremely reliable source among the staff that the restaurant engages in the unsavory practice of recycling coleslaw. This reprehensible behavior is truly nauseating, and I must confess that the mere thought of it has rendered me reluctant to partake in that particular menu item ever again. As to whether the staff member in question remains employed at the establishment, I cannot confirm, nor will I disclose their identity."

I was in town on the night the Lakers were also in town. BF and I and a friend decided to try to get tix from a scalper. Not knowing the venue, well it figures we got jipped. We got tickets to something they call the verve lounge. Its like a club in between the lower and upper levels. OK thats fine except there is nowhere to sit and the view is lame.\nNOT worth it, I would rather sit in the nosebleeds, then again I'd rather be at Staples Center.

Firefly is a cool place, but much more for the trendy crowd than for the foodies, like me. It was really loud and crowded. The menu did not have anything very adventurous, in fact quite the opposite. The \"french fries\" tapas were ok. So was the manchego mac and cheese. The grouper was very dry and plain. The salad was acceptable, but the empanadas seemed small for tapas. The albondigas were boring meatballs with no real flavor. The best thing was the paella, and I've had much better.\n\nIf you are looking for great tapas, this just isn't the place.

"We opted for the Maine Lobster Pot Pie and Shrimp and Scallops as our entrees, complemented by crab cakes as an appetizer. Unfortunately, our culinary excursion proved to be a letdown, as the flavors were predominantly unpalatable and occasionally off-putting. Despite the visually appealing presentation of the Pot Pie, it failed to translate into an enjoyable gastronomic experience. Our server's attempts to convey authenticity were unsuccessful, and the evening's dining experience fell short of our expectations, particularly when compared to other high-end Vegas establishments helmed by celebrated chefs. Disappointment was the operative word, and the discrepancy in quality was underscored by the fact that the cost was only $30 less than that of a Gordon Ramsay restaurant, rendering the experience even more unsatisfactory.

"The shopping and selling atmosphere would be significantly more pleasant if the staff members were not discourteous, hostile, and inadequate. I am currently stationed within the establishment awaiting their processing of my attire that I am attempting to sell, with an anticipated delay of 45 minutes, which I find perplexing given the fact that there are five employees present and merely three patrons, including myself. Upon entrance, not a single employee extended a greeting or even a cursory smile. I was compelled to stand in wait at the counter for a span of five minutes before an associate finally approached me, albeit in a brusque manner. It is mystifying; do they not desire commercial success?! 

This particular store boasts an impressive array of garments, yet the unpleasant ambiance within the retail space substantially diminishes the overall shopping experience. A sign reading 'like us on Facebook' is prominently displayed, but it appears that they are not interested in fostering a positive rapport with their clientele. 

As a devoted shopper and seller, I shall no longer conduct business with Plato's Closet subsequent to the current excursion. My inclination is to favor the more competent, friendly, and welcoming atmosphere of Buffalo Exchange. I shall inform my extensive social network of this regrettable encounter that I customarily endure upon visiting this establishment."

The patrons of this establishment opted to partake in a culinary excursion on the evening of the first day of the week, which proved to be an ill-advised decision due to the subpar quality of the victuals served, particularly when juxtaposed with the lofty expectations typically associated with eateries specializing in Italian cuisine; however, the hospitality extended by the staff was commendable, as they seated us at the bar, thereby affording us the opportunity to observe the televised sporting event that was being broadcast on that particular Sunday evening. Furthermore, it remains unclear whether the shortcomings of the dining experience were attributable to the uninspired menu offerings, the preparation of the dishes themselves, or some other, more nebulous factor that continues to elude my comprehension.

I love korean BBQ and I love Sura's style concept.  The restaurant is buffet style. You pick the meats and dishes that you wish to have and bring it back to your table to grill. A server will bring you drinks and clean your grill ever so often. 

The food isn't bad but it isn't great. You might find some pieces of meet that are still frozen if you pick from the middle of the tray. 

I went to the restroom while eating here and witnessed an employee leaving the stalls without washing their hands only to later see her behind the buffet line serving meat.  True story. 

I was so disgusted I wanted to return back to the stall and puke. 

Since Sura's AYCE menu is around the same price of the others in town...I'd go elsewhere especially after using their restrooms.

"The Fringe, the International Festival, and the Film Festival, I can all comprehend with relative ease and cognitive fluency, however, the Book Festival, that particular event seems to stretch the boundaries of my understanding, as it appears to be somewhat of an enigma, a conundrum that challenges my mental faculties and capacity for rational thought, nevertheless, I shall endeavor to persevere and attempt to grasp its significance and inherent value, despite my reservations and misgivings. The Politics Festival, on the other hand, strikes me as a tad excessive and perhaps even superfluous, as politics, while undoubtedly vital and relevant to our contemporary world, does not strike me as the sort of subject that warrants a dedicated festival, per se, as it lacks the certain je ne sais quoi, the ineffable quality that renders a topic worthy of celebration and commemoration, at least in my humble opinion. However, I digress, and shall continue to expound upon this theme, as I visualize a gathering of eccentric individuals, unconventional and free-spirited souls, assembled together in a circular formation, engaged in a fervent discussion, a spirited dialogue, regarding the intricacies and nuances of the capital gains tax, their faces adorned with looks of intense concentration and unbridled passion, reminiscent of a group of ancient philosophers, debating the mysteries of the universe, and next, we have the Festival of Accountancy, a spectacle that defies explanation and transcends the boundaries of rational comprehension."

"If this purported spa presumes to proffer a genuine pampering experience, it patently fails to deliver. Following a protracted twenty-minute wait to be seated at a table, I was peremptorily requested to relocate. My nail technician, who appeared to be more engrossed in conversing with colleagues in a foreign tongue than attending to my needs, uttered a paltry pair of phrases in my direction throughout the entire procedure. Moreover, an antiquated array of lotions and creams was relegated to a dusty corner cabinet, while a worn, dilapidated spray tan booth was offered for sale. Despite these deficiencies, the establishment seemed to enjoy a steady stream of clientele. Although my nails did ultimately appear satisfactory, following a $15 fill, I have no intention of returning to this subpar salon."

I recently visited the establishment to peruse their offerings, and upon entering the premises, I observed that there was no one present to attend to me. However, I did hear an individual snoring in the rear of the store, leading me to infer that someone was indeed present, albeit in a state of slumber. Therefore, I decided to conduct a cursory examination of their wares without disturbing the slumbering individual. As I had surmised, the inventory consisted of various e-liquids, drip tips, and batteries, including some novel brands that piqued my interest. Unfortunately, due to the absence of a sales associate, I was unable to pose any queries or sample the products. Consequently, I shall return at a later date, ideally when someone is awake and available to assist me. Despite the unfortunate timing of my visit, I must commend the store for its compact yet well-curated selection of e-liquids, which featured an array of enticing flavors. Notwithstanding the aforementioned circumstances, I cannot in good conscience award the store a rating higher than 2/5 stars, given the suboptimal experience I encountered.

"Numerous patrons have praised the welcoming nature of the personnel at this establishment; however, my recent visit on February 26th at 6:00 pm did not align with such favorable assessments. Upon entering, we were not acknowledged or bid farewell upon departure. The cashier's initial remark to me was simply a curt 'hold on,' followed by her attendance to two other orders, including a smoothie, before taking my order for a medium tea. Notwithstanding the uncomplicated nature of my request, I was compelled to wait while she fulfilled the more complex beverages. Furthermore, she failed to pour the steaming water into my cup, leaving it, along with the tea bag, on the counter unattended. While I comprehend the challenges of being the sole employee attending to customers, it is imperative to develop adequate multitasking abilities and maintain a pleasant demeanor. A simple greeting or courteous remarks would have elevated my rating of this establishment to three or four stars. Unfortunately, the subpar customer service greatly influenced my experience, and I cannot, in good conscience, provide a higher rating. Despite this, I shall return in the future, as this coffee shop remains one of the few options in close proximity to my residence, and I am perpetually seeking suitable locations for studying."

"I had an appointment with Doctor Meghan; however, she did not show up due to illness, which is understandable as everyone gets sick. Nevertheless, that is not the point. The front desk receptionist, Judy, displayed a discourteous demeanor and seemed displeased to be present. Throughout the encounter, she exhibited unprofessional behavior, even going so far as to disparage me to the technicians, claiming that I was rude and foolish, among other nonsensical accusations. Ultimately, patients should not be subjected to such treatment. Despite arriving on time for my appointment, I was forced to wait for an hour before receiving treatment. In contrast, the assistant and Doctor Michaels provided excellent service. Judy requires training in patient communication and professionalism, as do the other girls at the front desk, who frequently engage in unprofessional conversation that can easily be overheard by patients."

Went for Sunday brunch. Ordered a Western Omelet - it was ok. Others at my table got the all-you-can-eat buffet, and seemed to enjoy it - I think this is a quantity over quality kind of place.\nOne highlight was the hashbrown casserole - very tasty!

I have had the occasion to visit this establishment on three separate occasions, and it appears to be a favored destination among my colleagues for luncheon purposes. It is renowned for its Southern and Louisiana-style culinary offerings, which, while not particularly impressive in my opinion, seem to be well-liked by those who partake in such fare. Specifically, their gyro sandwiches are somewhat palatable, but the Creole dishes I sampled, specifically the shrimp and blackened fish, were excessively salted and heavy, rendering them unsuitable for my taste. However, it is likely that individuals who appreciate soul food would find their offerings appealing. Additionally, the venue tends to become rather congested during peak lunch hours, and the seating arrangements are somewhat cramped.
I ordered the spicy shrimp whichis noted as very spicy.  It was so NOT spicy and NOT flavorful.  However I had a nice time inspite of the food.....
decent at best.  if you know real cajun this place won't impress you but for the lack of any other option it's passable.  the Rat Toes appetizer is pretty good.

I have been an ardent devotee of this Fry's since its renovation last year, lavishing considerable financial resources upon it.  My most recent shopping excursion, regrettably, proved to be a profoundly vexing and disillusioning experience, as I discovered upon arriving home that several items were conspicuously absent from my purchases.  This reprehensible occurrence marked the third instance of such an event transpiring at this specific establishment, and my attempts to elicit even a modicum of contrition or empathy from the store's staff (including, most recently, an assistant manager) have been met with a resounding lack of success.  In stark contrast, a previous shopping expedition to Safeway resulted in my acquiring shrimp that, upon arrival at my domicile, proved to be irredeemably spoiled; yet, upon returning to the store, the manager not only graciously replaced the tainted seafood with twice the quantity, but also refunded my original payment in its entirety.  Now, that, my friends, is unwavering dedication to providing exceptional customer service.  While Fry's may boast competitive pricing, the incalculable value of a satisfactory customer experience cannot be matched by any monetary sum.

"It is uncertain when this practice began, but upon visiting the establishment tonight, I observed a notice indicating that a supplementary fee of twenty-five cents will be applied to each item purchased between the hours of nine o'clock post meridiem and five o'clock ante meridiem. This surcharge is applicable during the late night and early morning periods, despite the fact that the business operates on a twenty-four hour basis. Such an arrangement appears unreasonable, as it is improbable that the employees receive enhanced remuneration for their evening shifts. Notwithstanding this, the quality of the bread remained satisfactory, with its characteristic warmth and freshness being maintained."

"The culinary offerings were indeed impressive, however, the quality of the service did not live up to our expectations. Specifically, we experienced an unacceptable delay in receiving our beverages, which significantly impacted our dining experience. Our server seemed somewhat indifferent to our concerns and offered an unsatisfactory explanation for the prolonged wait. His response, 'It's not my fault they are way behind in the kitchen,' did little to alleviate our frustration. Given the abundance of exceptional steakhouses in Las Vegas, it remains to be seen whether we will give this establishment another chance."

Agave-how I wish it weren't so:
1. Terrible service- no hostess when we arrived. No utensils when we received our food. No server to take our payment. Everything was just slow. I'm wasn't in a hurry, but having to wait for everything makes any average person a little anxious.
2. Food- Crispy quesadillas - chicken and corn versions: nice corn masa shell but bland fillings. Then we had the fresh fish tacos. They were soggy and a mess. The fish had an old fishy flavor and I couldn't get past it. If I'm able to eat fish sauce like it's ketchup, I think I have a pretty good tolerance of seafood/ocean taste.
3. Ambience- surprisingly nice. From the exterior, I wouldn't never have thought it was that well put-together in the interior. It was a great blend of the colors, the lighting and a Large center bar. But I'm here for food first and thought did not impress.

"The pinnacle of inadequacy in mixology stewardship within the city of Charlotte's confines manifests itself in the form of bartenders whose proficiency, or lack thereof, warrants an unprecedented nadir in customer satisfaction. Patrons who have had the misfortune of encountering such individuals often recount tales of prolonged waiting periods, unresponsive demeanors, and a seemingly innate propensity for error when fulfilling straightforward requests. One such instance involved a patron who, having placed an order for three Two Hearted Ales, instead received three shots of Fireball, an egregious discrepancy that, despite being brought to the attention of both the bartender and a bar back, remained unresolved, leaving the customer in question still awaiting their beverages."

"Although I failed to perceive the presence of a staff member during the initial ten minutes of my visit, upon encountering an employee subsequent to my unintentional collision with them, I was provided with beneficial assistance."

For Scotland's busiest, most important and the capital's train station it sure was pure chaos.  I took a taxi here to go down to London and the moment I went underground I was amazed at how unorganized this place seems.  Maybe me or maybe it was the construction that was going on.\n\nAll the usual amenities you would expect from a modern train station, you have a pub nearby, the snack shop and all of the other usual suspects are here.  The open roof feeling of being underneath main roads doesn't sit well with me, because it rains here and it is cold here more than it is warm so why an open roof. And being from California being underneath big things that can collapse just rubs me the wrong way, almost as much as finding out that the trains to London are on a track all by itself not with the others. They realize that people drink or wake up way too early to get on trips right?

4 stars for the young bear stuffer guy rockin the converse shoes, he tried his best to keep my birthday girl's attention. She just turned 2 (if you read my reviews she is the one that might be autistic or has adhd and is wild nutz) and she was just all over the place.

Now, this is where I have to take off a star... at the check out... my daughter had a build a bear purse that she stuffed with hearts (both the purse and hearts were BAB, I was not buying them). I quickly snatched it without her looking and put it behind my me and on top of a shelf.... obviously so my daughter would not see it and scream. Well Mr. Lazy from behind the counter (not my cashier) starts yelling MAAAAM give it to me and I will put it away...  HERE GIVE THAT TO ME AND I WILL PUT IT BAAAAAACK. My daughter started wondering what he was yelling about and she was looking around. 
The guy was ridiculous, my husband was paying and he even turned around to see what the guy was yelling at.
2x I replied to him that I didn't want her to see it and then I just walked away.

That jackass should know if a mother tries to hide something away from a child that he should not create a scene. All he had to do was put it back after we left.
I like the back area of the bar outside. The music is pretty good. Didn't get to stay there long. I'll have to try it again some time.

I grew up in Las Vegas so I've been here a zillion times. The security lines can be long during peak travel times (Fri and Sun afternoons), there's a nice variety of food chains and random and expensive stores. I always pray I get to fly out of the A and B gates since it is waaaay less crowded and there's never a line for security. Since it's a big airport, it can take a long time to get from your car to checking in your luggage to your gate, so allow for some extra hiking time. \nOf course there's cheesy Las Vegas crap all over the place and slot machines, but that's what makes this place so... Vegas. The TSA clowns are usually pretty easy-going and apparently the taxi lines are realllly long. So save time ad hire a limo. It probably costs about the same. Also, free Wi-Fi!!

I've been here for brunch before and it was amazing! However, I was disappointed by a recent trip for a friend's bday. 

We had a big group and hung out in the bar area, standing/mingling, and occupied the three tall, center tables. It was a Monday night and the service was EXTREMELY slow. It looked like the server, in addition to the bar area, was also responsible for some tables in the dining room.

I ordered a drink and it arrived about 20 minutes later. A friend ordered food at the same time and his food arrived about 10 minutes before my drink. And we were sitting right next to the bar! The drink did not fit the description on the menu (it sounded like a martini, based on the description, but ended up being some sweet concoction served in a wine glass) and I sent it back (something I very rarely do). I asked for a different drink and it arrived, another 15 minutes later.

The dinner small plate and entree options leave much to be desired. With a large group, we wanted to order a few shareable plates, but all the small plates on the menu did not seem very sharing-friendly. Also, why does EVERYTHING have bacon?? The entrees seemed very over priced (tilapia for $22, are you kidding me?). 

I would definitely return for brunch, but never for dinner or drinks.

Ah. This place kills me......for two reasons. Firstly, it USED to be amazing...Then all of a sudden, the quality of the food and service kind of crashed. And secondly, what kind of restaurant DOESN'T ALLOW YOU TO TAKE YOUR FOOD TO GO?!??! This is the reason I won't be back. I had gone there with a friend, and we ordered and appetizer to share and then a main dish each. I had the veal with mushroom sauce which in the past was pretty amazing. However, halfway through that dish, I got full (shocking, I know). At the end of our meal, both of us asked for the rest of our dishes to be packed to go and we were told by a very unhappy woman that this would not be possible. Either eat it all here, or too bad. It was SHOCKING. So.....although the food is ok, I won't be returning here. I don't like feeling ripped off, and the fact that they won't give you the rest of your paid-for food, makes me feel totally ripped off.  :|

"I must have traversed past Frank's A Lot numerous times prior to deciding to give it a chance. Located on the eastern side of the thoroughfare that transforms into Airline Boulevard, directly behind the aerodrome, Franks' unassuming edifice has always piqued my curiosity. En route to my daily employment, utilizing Airline Boulevard as a means to circumvent several signalized intersections, I have had the pleasure of observing Franks frequently. Eventually, my intrigue was aroused, and I opted to partake in their culinary offerings for lunch.  

My expectations were surpassed by the delectable gastronomic experience that awaited me. For a most reasonable tariff, I savored a succulent hot dog, augmented by an exceptionally cordial staff whose familiarity and camaraderie suggested a familial proprietorship. Although I cannot confirm whether the establishment is indeed a family-run enterprise, their proficiency in both culinary and customer service aspects leaves little doubt. 

Franks provides both a drive-through window and a quaint outdoor seating area for patrons' convenience. It is worth noting that they only accept paper currency, but fear not, as the total cost of your repast will unlikely exceed seven dollars. 

Their signature dish, the Chicago dog, boasts an array of flavorsome embellishments, including onions, celery salt, sport peppers, and tomatoes. Pair it with a portion of their freshly prepared French fries, and you will be poised to depart, relishing life's simple pleasures. 

While their bill of fare encompasses other delectable options such as Polish sausages, cheese fries, and even Philly cheese steaks, my predilection for their Chicago dog has thus far precluded exploration of alternative choices. However, I would unhesitatingly recommend a visit to Franks A Lot to anyone who finds themselves in the vicinity."

"In the event of a cerebral explosion occurring within the confines of Grandmother's cognitive faculties on a lazy Sunday afternoon, the resulting scenario would closely resemble a sprawling, chaotic array of artistic paraphernalia, replete with an assortment of vibrant paints, versatile adhesives tailored for diverse surfaces and materials, an array of brushes in varying sizes and shapes, picture frames in assorted dimensions and forms, seasonal artistic endeavors, beads and bedazzlers, candles in abundance, irregularly shaped styrofoam blocks, construction paper, wooden shelving units susceptible to staining or coloration according to one's preference, artificial floral arrangements, glass containers, and other miscellaneous crafting supplies. Moreover, for those who harbor an ardent passion for scrapbooking, a visit to Michael's store would likely transpire as a veritable dream come true, offering an extensive array of materials and tools designed to facilitate the creation of unique, personalized mementos."

"The bartender, a reprehensible and detestable female, ostensibly endeavored to proffer an amicable demeanor; however, her inherent misanthropy and acrimonious disposition proved palpable, rendering her efforts futile. Despite this unpleasant encounter, the potables she served were undeniably exceptional, possessing an explosive and gratifying flavor profile that would unquestionably entice my return. Regrettably, the quality of the beverages was juxtaposed by the deplorable customer service, which was characterized by an uncooperative and indifferent attitude, reminiscent of the spiky, inhospitable plant known as Yucca."

Brass turns into "The Beat" on First Fridays. I'll be back! First Friday is now cool to go to again.

LOCATION: Fremont of course. But instead of being down on Fremont its up on Fremont! (huh?) :) Its actually situated above Hennesy's Tavern. Head upstairs because that's where the party's at. There's a balcony so all you smokers can have a smoke break and watch the crazies walk Fremont. If you want to leave, no problem, Beauty Bar, Vanguard, Insert Coins is just right across Las Vegas Blvd so you can bar hop and mob the rest of downtown. 

MUSIC: I think KidFunk was on decks. And he did not disappoint. It was a constant stream of good tracks. Lots of house & tech house, dropped some electro and dubstep. It was a good night! There's a decent size dance floor for the size of the place. I only went into the main room but on the other side there's an even larger room with a different DJ, possibly different music too? If they keep it up I'll make this a regular stop on First Friday.

BATHROOMS: Were filthy and disgusting. Drinks and other unmentionables all over the floor. Be sure to check if there's toilet paper before you pop-a-squat. The dispensers were always empty so grab a handful of paper towels before you go in.

GOGO: The gogo(s) were 100% disappointing, sorry. Both in looks and in dancing.

GUYS: No dress code, no cover when I went.

Don't forget to RATE & FOLLOW! ;)

Despite my reservations based on the unfavorable reviews, I opted to give this establishment a chance, and my experience validated the prevailing sentiment. The ambiance was visually appealing, but the lavatory presented an unconventional layout. The hand dryer was situated on a single faucet, prompting a sequence of inconvenient delays for patrons awaiting their turn to utilize the facilities while attempting to operate the cumbersome dryer. Furthermore, the absence of sanitary disposal units within the stalls necessitated a departure from the stall to discard items in the central waste receptacle, posing an additional challenge for female patrons. 

My culinary selection was a vegetarian burger, which, although flavorful, was diminutive in stature, inviting comparisons to a slider. The accompanying fries were palatable, yet their portion size was standard, rendering the supplementary fee seemingly unwarranted. Moreover, the minuscule dimensions of the water glasses necessitated a deliberate sipping motion, akin to savoring a fine wine. Following my meal, I remained unsatisfied, capable of consuming a medium-sized popcorn at the cinema without difficulty. 

Regrettably, I must conjecture that this dining establishment may struggle to flourish, given its steep prices and inadequate serving sizes. A revision of their pricing strategy or generosity of portions seems imperative to justify the cost. Notably, the absence of an option to augment the vegetarian patty was conspicuous.

For those stuck in the convention center area, this is a ok place for a beer and pub food.

As a graduate student in the area only to attend a conference, I have been to this bar twice.

The jalapeno poppers and onion rings are a favorite. The buffalo wings are ok...nothing special.

Gets very crowded during games, but makes the place fun.

So, if you are trapped around the area with no car and crave a beer and munchies, this place is A-Ok.

"My dedication towards Sakana remained unwavering for an extensive period of time, up until the momentous occasion of my son's birth. The advent of parenthood introduced a new paradigm, rendering the indulgence of sushi excursions somewhat impractical. Following a hiatus of three years, my spouse and I decided to revive our customary date night ritual by revisiting Sakana. Alas, the experience did not live up to our recollections. The chefs' demeanor exhibited a perceptible shift, manifesting in limited conversation and recommendations, which contrasted starkly with their previously warm and engaging nature. Notwithstanding this disappointment, the scallop dynamite proved to be a resounding highlight, boasting an unparalleled quality that eclipsed all other instances of its kind within the Valley. Likewise, the oranges served as a sweet finale, eliciting nostalgic sentiments that lingered long after the meal's conclusion. It is plausible that my prolonged absence may have unwittingly elevated my expectations, leading to a disparity between reality and my idealized memories."

I have an inclination to visit this establishment to acquire some subs en route to the river, as it is situated between our domicile and highway 17. This is due to my reluctance to frequent Subway or Blimpie's. Primarily, it is a rather extensive Italian market offering a wide range of products. If you are in need of olive oil, they possess an array of over 20 diverse varieties. Pasta? You will discover an entire aisle dedicated to it. Even one of those wooden utensils designed for crafting gnocchi can be found among their wares. 
  In the rear of the store, a counter extends along the entire length of the back wall, where you will encounter an assortment of cheeses, cold cuts, sausages, and a few sweet treats. Additionally, this is where you can place your order for sandwiches. Be prepared to articulate your desires with precision and celerity, as the gentleman operating the counter can be somewhat irritable and terse. The abundance of hand-written sandwich combinations posted on the wall can further exacerbate his demeanor. Fortunately, the lady manning the cash register consistently exhibits a warm and friendly demeanor, which partially compensates for his behavior. 
  Although I aspire to cherish their sandwiches, I merely find them satisfactory. The meat is invariably of superior quality, but it is not abundant enough. Perhaps I am not selecting the appropriate options. Until such time that I can refine my sandwich-ordering prowess, I shall persist in supporting Romanelli's, albeit with a mediocre rating for their deli. Nonetheless, their product selection earns high praise.

This establishment provides an adequate dining experience, boasting an agreeable ambiance, commendable customer service, and satisfactory diversion. While the culinary offerings are of acceptable quality, they fail to surpass expectations considering their cost. Specifically, the steaks possess a somewhat advanced stage of maturity, which may not align with my personal preference. However, the potatoes prepared au gratin style prove to be delectable. A diverse selection of wines, suitable for various financial constraints, graces the menu. It remains a viable option for those seeking a pleasant repast within the confines of Green Valley Ranch, although I would advocate for numerous steakhouses located along the Las Vegas Strip instead.

$4 OPI!  Read Carina's review, b/c I didn't want to pay $8.50 at Ulta... geez, so cheap... alot of the OPI colors already have separated (heat?  age?) so make your choice for price over quality... I'm so cool for $4 though.\n\nOn the same end where China Magic Noodle is, same plaza as Lee Lee's.

Went in for an early dinner and ordered the Pot Roast Sandwich. The vegetables came and were not cooked. They were raw, I ate the meat which was great. I told the waitress and she commented that that is pretty normal actually and offered to give me another side vegetable. I am glad that she did that but at the same time was a bit subdued by the fact that this was a regular thing for them. My husband enjoyed his chili burger loads. The drinks we ordered were very strong as well. This place is always busy but perhaps we ordered the wrong food for this place!

Had a carne assada torta.  It was actually not bad.  For the price it was real good.

A few comments/observations...

- Comically unorganized. There is no process for how this place works.  I got my food but if they actually had something that resembled organization I would have got it a lot sooner.

- The grill was a bit on the dirty side.

- The meat while ok was a bit on the fatty/chewy side.  Chopping it into smaller pieces would have been helpful

- Not the cleanest dining area.

Not really a 3, but not a 2 either.  I gave them the benefit of the doubt.

Sat at the bar, no music or sound on the TVs, after I asked for the second time some music was turned on, some sort of low sounding reggae I think, could barely hear it. No food on the happy hour menu, $3 Cuba Libra's, I enjoyed those. Didn't sample the food. Might come back not sure yet.

"Given our considerable distance from the French Quarter, my stomach infrequently impels me towards Cajun cuisine; furthermore, owing to the limited dining options within our vicinity, this establishment emerges as the de facto venue for satisfying my periodic craving for gumbo; while the quality of the fare may be marginally superior to the local average, the tariffs charged are somewhat elevated relative to our expectations."

Went to this buffet (gorgeous d\u00e9cor by the way) two weeks ago and although it was great, it's not the best buffet I've eaten at.  I do have to agree with the other reviewers that the options were poor.  The quality was good and the portion control in individual containers helped but other than that, I'd say this was more like a three star place.  Luckily I didn't do the weekend $40-/+ buffet that most mentioned.  We went on a Monday during brunch time and it was about $22 I think.  Not bad for an all you can eat place in Vegas as it kept me full all day, but I felt the lack of options bored me and was done within 45 minutes.  I expected a little more from a place that looks so posh!

"Indubitably, my dear fellow, it appears that an abundance of lesbians inhabits Las Vegas, characterized by their predilection for stereotypical attire, such as mullets and jean vests with ripped sleeves, as well as a propensity for muscular physiques. Have you had the opportunity to observe the cinematic masterpiece entitled 'Monster,' featuring Christina Ricci and Charlize Theron? The latter being an exemplary representation of the aforementioned archetype. 

Furthermore, I must jestingly inquire, am I truly the sole individual possessing physical attractiveness? 

As for sushi, while it may be deemed palatable, it remains a rather pricey delicacy, with certain establishments charging exorbitant sums ranging from $15 to $17 for a singular roll of fish. In contrast, a visit to Oakland offers a more affordable alternative, providing an opportunity to acquire a substantial quantity of V's at a relatively reasonable cost."

The pictures of the burgers looked super crazy and deadly but the portions are actually very feasible. Our group of 5 shared: sashimi \"won-tacos,\" triple T fries, the original ringer burger, and the bacon mac-n-cheese burger. We probably could have stuffed ourselves with another item. My favorites were the fries and the original burger. The fries were super crisp and full of truffle flavor, especially the aioi. The original burger had the flavors I like most, although I think the bacon mac-n-cheese is more unique and a good combination to try.\n\nTo me, the burgers are a little better than your average burger but not a favorite I would want again and again (I still prefer Bachi burger or even Holsteins). The tacos were definitely a let down- super small portion of tuna and not very interesting. Overall, I would only come back for a beer and some of those fries.

While the gastronomical indulgences are delectable and meticulously crafted, the tariffs and hospitality fail to align with the expectations of an establishment of this caliber. The ambiance is permeated by a palpable sense of disinterest among the staff, who appear to be preoccupied with matters unrelated to the provision of quality service. Upon placing our order for the triumvirate of sweet delights, my companion conveyed to the server that we would appreciate the second selection, given that the initial offering had suffered an unfortunate mishap. However, the server, rather than addressing our concern, opted to delegate the responsibility to a colleague, thereby inadvertently perpetuating a chain of miscommunication. Ultimately, we were compelled to rectify the situation ourselves, as the damage to the dessert became apparent only upon payment and seating. Although the process entailed minimal effort, it remains an inconvenience that could have been readily avoided with a modicum of attentiveness and competence on the part of the service staff.

"Alright, so I had to perform an upgrade. 

I was physically present at the BuyBack$ site in Henderson, near the Galleria Mall, when we were unable to locate the desired item. 

As a result, we contacted the Decatur location to determine whether or not they possessed the film we were seeking on Blu-ray. 

Of course, they did! They possess everything; it's unquestionable. 

We then inquired whether they could retain the product for us, stating that we would arrive shortly to collect it since we were located across town but en route. 

Therefore, we drove across the city, and you know what happened? 

These individuals had the audacity to inform us that the item was, in fact, being held for another person. They asserted that it had been previously reserved but ultimately left the decision of who would obtain it up to management's discretion. 

Well, we informed you that we were traveling from across town, and you assured us that you would hold it for us. As a result, I failed to acquire it. 

What I did receive, however, was a review update, which resulted in a loss of one star. 

Although I won't say I wouldn't revisit, I certainly won't go out of my way to return to this particular location again. 

They lost a steadfast and dedicated client."

I've been here several times, and well, it's a chain. I don't usually eat here but my husband wanted to go here. Funny enough, he actually wanted to go to BJ's and was confused. He was disappointed because they only have lager here.

Last night we actually had a 5 star experience. Our server Paul was really phenomenal. Got my kids extra fruit, really knowledgeable about beer (my husband loved chatting with him about beer and brewing) and helped me figure out the rewards program. Great service! Food was pretty good too. Hubby got the fish and chips. Fish was breaded with panko and was nice and crispy. Pretty bland though. The garlic fries were really good. I got the cheeseburger with blue cheese. Nothing phenomenal but good.

Unfortunately, I've had a lot of 1 star experiences here and I think that they are a little too expensive for the quality you get,  that I'm giving GB a 3 star overall. Hopefully last night's experience indicates improvement, but it's really a hit or miss.

Came here on a sunny, warm, Saturday night.  I looked enviously on the people enjoying the backyard patio with its hanging white lights while sitting inside the dark interior.  Regrets regarding seating choices aside, I had a pear and arugula salad which was good, but still left me hungry $8 later.  Many others in my party ordered drinks which may be a better way to go.

"My endorsement is unequivocal. In case you are oblivious to my penchant for economical indulgence, allow me to elucidate: I am an ardent devotee of happy hour. This establishment offers a satisfactory rendition of said promotion, featuring several discounted appetizers and rolls, in addition to palatable beverage specials. For a rapid repast and a pint of Kirin, this venue is an optimal choice, particularly if you find yourself on the western periphery of the city. However, I must qualify my recommendation by stating that, when seeking a more refined dining experience with a significant other, Sakana may be a superior option. Nonetheless, for convivial gatherings with a coterie of acquaintances, this locale is eminently suitable."

This store has good prices on many things, some much cheaper than Safeway and others equal to Fry's. It all depends on what you're shopping for. I prefer Fry's in my area of town though because the Albertson's by me ALWAYS smells like rotten fish and enough to make me hurl. \n\nThis location just happens to be by my friend's apartment so whenever we need something we just run in here and get the items. Very easy to get in and out of and very good customer service.

This was the only buffet we tried (first time visitors) so we don't have anything to compare it to in town. It was nice and at $40/pp reasonably priced. The variety is small but great tasting, and I could have eaten the Na'an all night. The husband enjoyed the brisket. Everything was clean and bright but a bit too cafeteria style for my taste. Overall I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here but if it's convenient it's a good option.

We had Lunch there on a Sunday ,pretty busy .
I say the food is ok not a wow but ok.
The service was good and the place looked pretty clean .
They got lots to pick from. 
We did wait a long time for are food.
The prices are not to bad either .
I will give them another try maybe for dinner.

The only downfall is the wait during lunch through the drive thru.  I have always had a long wait but today was horrible.  Only 2 cars in front of me and my wait was over 15 minutes after ordering.  This was for a simple sandwich and smoothie nothing crazy or extreme.  The service is getting slower and slower every time I go.  It's really making me consider avoiding it in the future and it used to be one of my favorite places.

I was suprised how much I liked Kahunaville. Sandwiches are all very reasonably priced- around 11 bucks- and very large. The drinks are spendy like most of Vegas but be nice and they pour stiff. I highly recommend a Bombay and tonic yard. \n\nOur server was very friendly and professional, She did a great job especially since one of my group pulled a rude dipshit maneuver with an empty ketchup bottle.

Typical Panda Express, but add a drive thru. Service is not exceptionally friendly, but lets face it, who cares. You have to deal with the employees for a whole minute and a half. Food is always good, portions are generally good, and close to shopping.

My date and I decided to try something new and stopped at The Lodge for Happy Hour.  We were really pleased with the prices, and all the bartenders/servers seemed really friendly.  And the deep fried cheese curds were to die for!  (I am from Wisconsin, after all.)  However, the bar stools are INCREDIBLY UNCOMFORTABLE.  We didn't stay long, but thought we liked it enough to try it again...at a table next time.\n\nP.S.  We couldn't decide whether to Yelp about the so-scantily-clad-it-was-almost-inappropriate server.  I mean, I know it's a bar and she's working for tips but...geezuz....it made us look around the bar for her pole.

This venerable eatery in Edinburgh's West End boasts the distinction of being the city's oldest Chinese restaurant, a claim that has been proudly proffered by its proprietors for over five decades. Its enduring popularity among locals has resulted in a devoted clientele who have been patronizing this establishment for multiple generations. Despite its questionable moniker, the culinary offerings at this restaurant are undoubtedly exceptional, showcasing a masterful blend of Cantonese and Peking cuisine. The menu presents an array of delectable options that can make selecting a dish a formidable task, a predicament exacerbated by the limited variety of desserts, which, unsurprisingly, feature bananas as a primary ingredient. However, the presence of authentic Chinese patrons frequenting this restaurant serves as a testament to its genuine fare and commitment to catering to the discerning tastes of its clientele.

Didn't stay at the hotel but the Craps game is the best even though it only pays double on 12, it offers 100X odds!!! Well worth it for cheap gaming on the Strip. The place is a little old but not run down, with low ceilings and the air smelling like smoke. The locals are friendly and the drinks are okay.

It was with a certain degree of anticipation that I had been looking forward to dining at this establishment, albeit with a tad too much trepidation. We shared an order of "croquettes" featuring foie gras, which, quite frankly, were rather unremarkable in both taste and presentation. Subsequently, I opted for the happy pig ribeye, which, while tender and cooked to perfection, was regrettably accompanied by a sauce that did not quite live up to my expectations in terms of flavor. My companion, on the other hand, chose the pan-seared duck breast, which, to be fair, was undeniably disappointing. The pecan tart was truly exceptional, but one cannot help but wonder if it is truly worth visiting this restaurant solely for such a dessert. While I am genuinely delighted to have had the opportunity to partake in the culinary offerings of this esteemed eatery, several other establishments within the same price range leave me significantly more content and satisfied.

This particular venue and other adjacent locations, such as the Teepee, serve as poignant reminders of a bygone era in which the culinary offerings associated with Mexican cuisine were unwavering in their consistency and our expectations were decidedly modest. However, there are instances in which such familiar and unsophisticated fare strikes an emotional chord, thereby eliciting a profound sense of nostalgia. It is worth noting that this establishment boasts a rich and storied past, as evidenced by the numerous accounts chronicled by the illustrious Marty Robbins.

You inevitably obtain what you expend, although I yearn that you could acquire the fundamental necessities. This establishment fails to provide a minuscule refrigerator, an electric kettle, or even a rudimentary coffee brewing device, let alone a microwave oven, thereby coercing you into expending all your hard-earned currency on procuring sustenance from external sources. Furthermore, the rugs appear somewhat antiquated and emit an unpleasant odor. Our faucet malfunctioned; however, subsequent to our vocalization of this issue, it was successfully rectified the following day. The advantages of this lodging include: a tranquil ambiance after midnight, thereby enabling a restful slumber, and a proximate location to numerous points of interest. While I wouldn't object to returning, I would initially explore alternative options.

This sushi spot is average at best. The rolls have too much rice and hardly any fish. I would rather pay extra and get more substance than just eat a bunch of rice. I wish they had some sort of seating. I go here when I need to grab a quick work day lunch. It's on par with grocery store grade pre made sushi

This place was aight,

$4 Beer specials were a pretty good deal but the sole reason I'm not rating this place any higher is because of the food. (Better options at 4Peaks and Santan)

It was Underwhelming and Overpriced~ The ambiance of this place was nice though

Had the Oyster Po Boy and well.... if you want seafood I guess one should move a bit closer to the W-Coast.

I came here after getting absolutely no help at Fry's. It was nice to see that all of their mini computers,ereaders and the Kindle I wanted were at the very front of the store! I'm glad I didn't have to walk all the way to the back. I was wearing heels for the first time in a long time so my feet were aching. I just wanted to get the Kindle and go. I couldn't leave without a cute case for it though. They don't have a  huge selection so I settled for a bright blue case. My ideal case would have been pink or had Hello Kitty on it.\nThe employees were so much more willing to help here. It wasn't like Frys where it was like pulling teeth to get answers. When we were about to pay the cashier asked if we had their rewards card. We had one but I didn't want to use it because of what happened before. We made some big ticket purchases a couple of years back and the gift rewards were going to some random address in Illinois.  We tried to get it corrected through their call center and even talked to the manager. When we told them that the address on file was not ours and we could prove it they still would not change the address. This is why I will go no higher then a three star rating. I can never fully trust this company.

The nightclub within the Palms Casino Resort boasted a panoramic view of the city skyline from its lofty perch on the 53rd floor, yet the distance from the Las Vegas Strip rendered outdoor excursions impractical, save for the fortuitous meteorological conditions that prevailed during our visit; in essence, the club's unremarkable attributes, with the exception of its prime location, constituted a considerable achievement for the resort.
