We ate here a week or so ago and I have to say it was okay. It's nothing either one of us was blown away by but the food was good. We ordered the gnocchi with marinara and the ravioli al formmagio.  Both were good but the stand out was the marinara sauce. I'm rather picky about it and it's probably some of the best I've had in awhile. We also ordered the caprese as an appetizer and again it was good but nothing wonderful. Service was very good as well. For a restaurant in a strip mall setting it was good however the prices are really high considering.

"As an ardent admirer of Gordon Ramsay, I have always been captivated by his unwavering dedication to culinary excellence, which resonates with my own unyielding pursuit of perfection during my college years while manning the cast iron grill at Buffalo Wild Wings. Thus, it was only natural that I would be eager to experience the epicurean delights offered at his establishment. Upon entering, I was faced with a daunting dilemma - what to order from the extensive menu? This proved to be a formidable challenge, rivaled only by the complexity of the ACT exam. After deliberating at length, I decided to deviate from my customary burger and instead opted for the pie sampler, reasoning that it would afford me the opportunity to sample a variety of flavors without committing to a single entree. However, this decision ultimately proved to be a miscalculation, as the sampler, though replete with an array of savory pies, left me feeling somewhat unsatisfied due to its modest portion size. Each individual pie boasted exceptional quality, yet this was somewhat mitigated by the fact that it was merely an appetizer, leaving me still yearning for a more substantial meal. In retrospect, I would have been better served by selecting either a whole pie or a burger, or perhaps even pairing the sampler with one of these options. My companion's burger, which I surreptitiously sampled, appeared to be of exceptional quality, and I must admit that I was tempted to pilfer a few more fries had my friend not been vigilant. Notwithstanding this minor disappointment, I am resolved to return and indulge in the delectable burger that had eluded me on this particular visit."

"The computer science program leaves much to be desired, but the institution's size is quite impressive.  Its ambiance is reminiscent of Arizona, with an oppressive heat that can be overwhelming at times, especially for someone who currently resides in Las Vegas.  Despite this, my fellow students were quite cordial, although the instructors occasionally exhibited an excessive strictness.  A peculiar aspect of this school was the prevalence of bicycle thievery, resulting in the creation of Frankenstein-like vehicles, composed of various parts and colors, which provided a source of amusement.  Additionally, there were numerous individuals who enthusiastically promoted their religious or ideological beliefs, contributing to the diverse and eclectic atmosphere that I found appealing, even though my expectations regarding the teaching staff were not entirely fulfilled."

This lodging establishment had its fair share of both advantages and disadvantages during our stay. Upon arriving late on a Friday evening, we discovered that the non-smoking accommodation we had requested had been allocated to another guest, thus we were compelled to accept a smoking room instead. We were informed by the reception staff that we could exchange our room the following day between the hours of 12-3 pm, as they had inadvertently assigned our reserved room to someone else. 

The subsequent day arrived, and following a delightful time spent at both the pool and fitness center, we contacted the front desk to inquire about the status of our room. Unfortunately, they persistently postponed the estimated time of availability, causing us to squander five valuable hours of our day confined and awaiting the readiness of our non-smoking room. Considering that our weekend visit was restricted to a finite amount of time, it was truly frustrating to fritter away such a substantial portion of it. Following five hours of persistent complaints and expressions of dissatisfaction, we were ultimately provided with a non-smoking room, which put an end to the unpleasant experience. Despite this unsatisfactory occurrence, I chose to award three stars because the hotel's overall quality was not particularly impressive. However, the upgraded room we received was quite pleasant. 

In addition, it is worth mentioning that the hotel boasts a prime location, situated directly in the center of the renowned Las Vegas Strip and positioned directly opposite Cosmo and Bellagio. Moreover, we thoroughly enjoyed indulging in some retail therapy and savoring a delectable meal at Gordon Ramsey's esteemed Burgr restaurant.

"It is my ardent desire to possess articulations of greater quality, yet this establishment unfortunately hearkens back to my undergraduate era. I yearned to convey that this venue caters to those with limited financial means, however, the prices are not particularly affordable either. 

The ambiance is satisfactory, with a clean environment and a welcoming sushi chef who extended a warm greeting upon our arrival and departure. 

I must caution against consuming any raw items here, as the culinary offerings were merely mediocre. The tonkatsu was unfortunate in its desiccation, and the batter lacked substance. At $14.50, it fails to compare favorably to the superior value offered by King Muramoto at $10 for their lunch menu. 

The sole redeeming feature was the steaming bowl of miso soup that provided solace on a chilly day. 

The dearth of clientele on a Friday evening raises concerns regarding the freshness of their sashimi and sushi, rendering it an establishment that does not warrant consideration."

HUGE PORTIONS. HUGE. This place is inside the crappy Imperial Palace hotel on the strip (upstairs).  I was surprised at how big the place was, it is kind of sectioned off into two difference rooms. I had a simple breakfast with eggs, hash browns, and a biscuit and coffee to drink. The biscuit was so buttery and fresh and warm, and like everything here HUGE. I usually love me some carbs, but I could not finish the biscuit or the rest of the meal. The food was great the prices matched the huge portions, not overprices but accordingly to the amount of food you get. My entree was one of the simpler ones and it was 9 bucks, everything else was above that. Only bad experience was someone straight threw up in there. Was walking aND \"bleeaaaaacgh!\" *splaash*. I was confused as to what happened when I heard it and saw a guy running out, until I saw the horrified look on a puke-splattered woman. I am assuming the patron had a rough night of drinking in Vegas and that it wasn't the food there. Still pretty horrific to witness on your first meal of the day.\nFinal thought :This would be a good spot to pig out in...maybe wear rain gear...?

This hotel looks really nice and the staff are really nice. The fitness room has a few different things and they work. The free breakfast is amazing. The room isn't very functional. There's a refrigerator, but no microwave. When I eat out I have leftovers and I hate wasting food. The shower in the single bed rooms is something you would find in a dorm room. It's a tile shower only with a single shelf and there isn't a full shower door. When you stand in the shower, there's always a draft. I'm getting kind of tired of staying at \"nice\" places that are just pretty and serve no function.

I go to this restaurant usually on Sunday morning because they have their awesome double stamp days. 

Now for the restaurant-The wait can be a little annoying especially on the weekends. But, that's expected. 

The atmosphere-I usually  go to the one in Chandler off of Ray Rd. The atmosphere is very friendly and the restaurant is clean. I like the little breakfast bar they have. 

Food-The food is delicious and they have the perfect portions for me. However, my husband often complains that they don't give him enough food. But, this is where the cool little $1 menu comes in. They have a wide  range of things that you can add to your meal for $1. I usually add the fruit cup or mini-pancakes. I haven't had a chance to try a lot of their menu items. They have a pretty long list of items and I often get overwhelmed trying to figure out what to order. I have had the 7 Veggie Omelette. It was very tasty! What made it more enjoyable was knowing that I was eating a healthy omelette. Some of them have tons of ingredients and even one with all meat. The one thing that I have tried that I DO NOT recommend is the biscuits and gravy. I have had better. The gravy can taste a little bland and the biscuits taste chewy on the inside. 

Services-The service can be hit or miss. But, I do like that they give a large cup of your beverage to go. 

Great place overall.

I've been in here a few times, each time deciding that this time I'll do what they tell me to and I'll feel like Superwoman. I still haven't!!

Basically it's a health food shop. Kinda. They sell the likes of cod liver oil tablets and garlic capsules etc etc, the staff are WONDERFUL. Can'tt fault them on that!! I went in on day hearing that if I took a spoonful of Manuka Honey at bed time it helps your skin and makes you lose weight, and it did! I was glowing. Ok it wasn't like a heap of weight, but enough to make me feel better about myself. The staff gave me the honey and some cider vinegar to cook with, they knew all their stuff....but it cost me over £40!! Hence the missing 2*.

If you're serious about this sort of stuff then this is a great place. If not, then go to Boots.

"Although K Mart may not necessarily possess any particularly distinctive attributes that differentiate it from its competitors, it remains a viable retail establishment where consumers can acquire various items, including those exclusive to the MH brand. As such, it is not uncommon for enthusiasts of the latter to visit the former on a regular basis, during which they may choose to display their dedication to the brand by exhibiting their possession of the coveted Maverick patch."

The waiter was attentive and helpful.  The omelet was good.  But holy fatoosh don't order the grape leaves.  Yikes...it had some sort of reddish goo spread over one of the pieces, almost like the others had it scraped off.  Took one bite and sent it back.  The decor was like a yellow mausoleum with small cubby holes surrounding the dining room, like a place for an urn of ashes.  I guess the food would be hit and miss.  Thank goodness the omelet was good.
Decent pizza, pretty close in quality to Setabello. Menu has gotten a lot smaller and the price is a little on the high side for pizza. Good service and cozy environment.

I had the smothered chicken with mac and cheese and green beans.I can say it was worth the drive from Balyntyne suburbs to get some good ole southern cooking. i got there at 11:30am on a Wednesday... the lunch crowd has not even came in yet so I was 1 of the first customers I gave it a 3.5  star wish could have given it a 4 star mainly the it was too pricey for the amount of food given... A fair price for that plate should have been $7 tops.. I paid $10 an didnt get a drink with it.. Don't think I will be visiting this place anytime soon..

"During our most recent leisure excursion, we opted to halt for a repast at Braddah's Island Style for the second time, and decided to partake in a Kalua pig burrito, replete with seaweed rice, black beans, charred pineapple verde, lettuce, and tomato. Despite the fact that the administration had the temerity to deplete their stock of cilantro, an herb commonly used as a garnish, our burrito remained palatable. However, we noticed a perceptible decline in the cordiality and attentiveness of the staff during this visit, as evidenced by the absence of complimentary samples, uncleared tables, and the delayed provision of condiments, which were only provided following a patron's request after a considerable interval of ten minutes had elapsed. Consequently, we would assign a rating of 3.5 to this dining experience."

This place was decent. Ordered the egg rolls and grilled pork dishes. The wait was SERIOUSLY long for the food for the amount of people that were at the restaurant when my wife and I visited.

The restaurant was clean and tidy however when we were there there was quite a bit of smoke coming from the kitchen area that seeped into the main restaurant (I think they had some ventilation issues).

Both the egg rolls were super small and they served it with sweet and sour sauce (not the traditional fish sauce), and the grilled pork was tasty but portion wise small for the price.

Overall, it was worth the visit but will most likely not worth another visit.

Decided to yelp for a good breakfast place while I was chilling at vegas and came across this place. 

It was a sunday morning about 10am and it was already super pack. It was about a 30 min wait. Which i thought for good food, should be worth the wait. 

Finally got in and everything look really good. All portions are huge! I end up ordering a original Benedict.

I thought the food was good on presentation but the food was just okay for me. My order was kind of cold which I thought was a buzz kill. It wasn't even a little bit warm. I would think if it was nice and hot everything would have tastes great but I guess i would never know.

Le Marly is ok.  I did not eat here, I only drank.  They have a signature raspberry martini with Vodka, raspberry puree and a basil leaf, which is good.  Most of the drinks are under $10, for example liquor drinks are about $8.50, 20oz beer about $7.50.  The appetizers ordered by some of the other people in our group looked good, but I did not try them.

While this place is located on Beaver Hall in the middle of downtown, it's unfortunate that it is not very frequented.  Literally no one came in while we were there for almost 3 hours on a Thursday.

They have a very modern decor with a Purple theme.  

The staff was nice, took our coats upon entry with out a fee.  Also were very attentive to our needs (drinks)

Personally, I wouldn't pick this place for an evening out, but if the group was already going, I'd tag along.

We have a propensity to partake in the first meal of the day at this establishment with considerable regularity, as it offers a familiar ambiance and culinary offerings that are representative of the standard fare associated with the International House of Pancakes franchise, and we have been consistently impressed by the attentive and hospitable demeanor displayed by the servers and other personnel who attend to our needs during our visits.

This lodging facility appears to cater to a younger demographic, specifically those within the age range of 27 years and below, as it boasts an ambiance that is ostensibly fashionable and alluring; however, for individuals aged thirty and above, it may not conform to their particular preferences, as it lacks a certain je ne sais quoi that is characteristic of more mature and refined tastes. The accommodations themselves are adequate, with a few minor imperfections, such as loose and rattling wall plugs, but they are generally well-appointed and aesthetically pleasing. It is worth noting that the minibar contains items of an adult nature, such as vibrators and lubricants, which may not be suitable for families with young children. The pool area seems to attract a youthful clientele, as evidenced by the numerous guests in their early twenties who were observed indulging in alcoholic beverages and engaging in raucous behavior, which may detract from the overall experience of older patrons. For those seeking culinary delights, the Pink Taco restaurant located within the Hard Rock complex is highly recommended and serves excellent Mexican cuisine. While this hotel may not be the optimal choice for individuals over thirty or those traveling with children, it does seem to be a popular destination for younger crowds who are looking to partake in the vibrant nightlife and revelry that Las Vegas has to offer. It is important to note that this establishment is not situated directly on the famous Las Vegas Strip, but rather in close proximity, requiring a brief taxi ride to access its many attractions.

Well, the plan was to have our getaway day lunch at L'Avenue, but as seems usual with that place, the line was out the door, and we just didn't have time to wait.  So, we ventured directly across the street to this friendly looking bistro with a nice streetside patio area, and were pleasantly suprised at the food, portions, and service.  Actually, those portions were quite huge, which made the prices quite reasonable.  Plus, Boreale draft pints were on special for $5, which is just stellar.  Hey, is it me, or does everyone in Montreal seem to like to have a beer or wine (or two) with lunch?  It's sort of like Europe, and I am totally down with that.  Anyway, this is a safe bet sort of place.

My boyfriend and I dropped in for the first time on a Sunday afternoon.  The atmosphere was nice and the restaurant was very clean.  Our server Dan was knowledgeable and pleasant. The food was average but good for the price. We will definately be back.

I went here for the first time yesterday and was waiting to meet someone.  When I arrived I wasn't greeted for a good 5 minutes in a mostly empty dining room.  I had to wonder around until someone attended to me.  After telling them that I'd like a table for 2 they sit me at a big table with 5 places as opposed to a booth.   

After my friend arrived our order was taken promptly and our waitress was nice. The food was lukewarm and could have been seasoned better although the meat on my dish was cooked tender and came in a good portion size although there were a TON of onions I'm contrast to the meat portion.  The rice was bland and boring as well.  

The decor looked great and very classy and the staff was overall friendly.  The price was fair for the portion size and I'd be willing to give this place another go, but I hope for better food and someone at the door to greet me right away.

"This establishment, Bison Witches, presents itself as a purveyor of gastronomical delights, specializing in sandwiches, and offers an array of beverages, specifically beer, at a price point that can be considered reasonable. Upon partaking in their culinary offerings, I have found their chili cheese nachos to be particularly satisfying, while my dining companion, Kristen, has expressed a fondness for the Miss Pris. While there may not be anything remarkably unique or exceptional about this eatery, it does provide a commendable level of quality in terms of both the edibles and potables served, as well as the attentiveness of the staff. Thus, it can be concluded that Bison Witches warrants a rating of three and a half stars."

"I am thoroughly convinced that this quaint, family-owned eatery is utterly remarkable! The culinary offerings are truly delectable; specifically, I relished every bite of their sumptuous lobster roll complemented by an array of flavorful clam chowders. Although the portion size may not be as substantial as those found at seaside establishments, it nevertheless serves as an effective remedy for my intense yearning for fresh seafood, given my current geographical location in Las Vegas."

"Upon perusing the menu, we opted to sample their culinary offerings, specifically the tamale burger, which unfortunately did not meet our expectations due to its arid nature and an unpleasant aftertaste. However, the fries accompanying the dish were quite delectable, boasting an inventive blend of spices that included a subtle hint of nutmeg and cinnamon, thereby evoking a sense of warmth and depth. Despite the underwhelming experience with the food, we were thoroughly impressed by the ambiance, characterized by dim lighting and a welcoming atmosphere that fostered a convivial ambiance, which was further enhanced by the bartender's proficiency in crafting expertly mixed cocktails. Moreover, the staff demonstrated exceptional customer service, as they graciously offered us a complimentary replacement drink following an unfortunate spillage. Consequently, we intend to revisit this establishment, primarily for the purpose of indulging in their beverages, and perhaps experimenting with alternative menu items, such as the sweet and spicy burger, which our server enthusiastically endorsed."

"Our inaugural visit transpired two days prior to the culmination of the year, and we partook of their midday repast.  The Green Papaya salad and Panang curry, both piquant and flavorful, garnered our unwavering approbation.  The hospitality we received was quite satisfactory, and the beverage, an icy brew, was quaffed with relish.  However, a cursory inspection of the premises revealed a minor shortcoming; specifically, a negligible amount of detritus was scattered about the floor, which remained unattended throughout the duration of our meal.  Nonetheless, we would unhesitatingly recommend this establishment to any individual who takes pleasure in Thai cuisine...nota bene:  The thermostat settings, purportedly the most scorching, did not quite live up to our expectations."

Not so bad. The entrance looks like a hotel check-in. The security team here was cool, which is refreshing for a club on the strip. Usually security crew's think they are real cops with a Napoleon complex.

It was a week day when I went, so it wasn't too crowded. Lil Jon was playing and he's a decent DJ. 

Since I'm a local and I usually avoid the strip, I was (as usual) SHOCKED when I was told it was $52 for a beer, wine, and a shot for the the birthday boy. This is why I stay away from the strip. Not that it is their fault - that's how they pay their rent. I wish clubs like this would offer local prices even when it comes to drinks. Because seriously we could just stash alcohol in our car and run in and out of the club. It's not like we're staying in a hotel and have no way to get more booze. Just a thought!

Overall, compared to Haze, Tryst, ... (and all the other clubs I've been to but can't remember at the moment), this one was pretty decent. Moon is still my favorite, but XS wasn't bad.

"Based on my personal experience and taking into account the feedback provided by previous patrons, I would assign a rating of three and a half stars to this establishment. My expectations, which were influenced by the opinions of others, led me to anticipate a meager serving size, perhaps a half cup of pasta; however, I was pleasantly surprised to find the portion to be sufficient. It is worth mentioning that I arrived at the restaurant with a considerable level of hunger. 

We opted for the olives as an opening course, which were presented warm and consisted entirely of green olives, and we were able to obtain bread to complement the reserve oil. 

Our server exhibited exceptional dedication to detail, offering thorough explanations of the menu items, including specific features such as the fact that the gnocchi was made from ricotta rather than potato, and the various ingredients incorporated into the puntanesca sauce (my own recipe only includes seven components). Both of us selected the orecchiette accompanied by sausage and greens, and while I detected a slight excess of oil, the pasta was cooked to a satisfying texture. 

The server offered precise descriptions of the dessert options, and we concluded our meal with a rich chocolate bark adorned with almonds, which paired nicely with a second glass of nero d'avalo. Incidentally, I felt that the prices charged for wine were eminently reasonable. 

Our total cost, excluding gratuity, was approximately $36 per person, and we each enjoyed two glasses of wine, leaving the establishment feeling content."

Seemingly, bars such this are effected massively by the clientele. This particular All Bar One, nestled in the middle of Edinburgh's financial district results in mostly desk job monkeys frequenting the place.

One thing I've learnt in my time in Edinburgh is that such clientele and students don't mix. Thus, All Bar One is best avoided .

Drinks, food etc are all pretty standard - not that dissimilar to Wetherpoons in what it offers.

After seeing the Fry's Signature in Scottsdale, I had high expectations with this supermarket. The store was not as fancy, but it was still nice looking. 

Bathrooms are located next to the pharmacy. The air fresheners gave the bathroom an extra touch.

This supermarket has a Starbucks, sushi area, etc. No price scanners though.

Considering that this supermarket is in the middle of nowhere, it does have a lot of customers!

Not a bad place. Service is good with friendly employees. The food, although not the beat does taste good and is fresh.  While there I had the angry whopper. Im not a fan of thick french fries, but theirs was still good. 

What I liked most was their choices of soda. They have "orange coke" flavored soda. I never even heard of it before, so I had to try and and wow. Was it good.  

Sadly the whole time I was thinking there they never swept the floor that needed it. Yeah its a small thing and I am not going to eat off it, but visually it is not appealing. The same is true of their bathroom floor.

"I am attending a conference at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, and I have opted to frequent this establishment for two meals during my stay. On my initial visit, I indulged in a delectable Angus steak burger, complemented by an assortment of mushrooms and a tangy bleu cheese, all for the reasonable price of $20, inclusive of tax. Although not particularly economical, this culinary delight proved to be the most satisfactory value within the vast confines of the resort's dining options, especially considering the late hour of 9:47 p.m. upon checking in. 

The following morning, I returned to partake in their breakfast offerings. While the individual dishes were quite expensive, I elected to exercise fiscal prudence by ordering two side dishes instead: two eggs prepared to my liking for a moderate fee of $8, accompanied by a portion of home fries for an additional $3. Furthermore, I treated myself to an oversized cup of tea, which, although priced at a somewhat exorbitant $3.50, was nonetheless a worthwhile investment due to the inclusion of a high-quality English Breakfast tea bag, honey, and the availability of soy milk. 

The staff at this establishment has consistently displayed warmth and efficiency in their service, creating a welcoming ambiance that more than compensates for the lack of a sophisticated dining experience. In conclusion, while not an exceptional eatery, this venue provides a suitable setting for a satisfying meal at a tolerable cost within the context of the resort's generally elevated prices."

I guess I don't get it?

Everything was wholly average. Burgers, service, prices--average. I ordered Kiki's burger--average. Some bites were overly sweet, but the mushrooms added a good savory touch. I had the garlic fries--average. They trick you into thinking you're getting an f-ton of fries and you're getting about a handful.

Also, their hostesses kept seating people directly next to us, too, which was kind of irritating considering the restaurant was nearly empty. Twice the other diners asked to be moved so they weren't joining us for our meal.

I'd have to be dragged back---to me, it's not worth a revisit.

You should come here to revel in the ambiance and to partake in the phenomenon that has captivated the attention of many. Order a frozen hot chocolate and you shall have indulged in an experience comparable to the one offered by its counterpart in NY, albeit the latter being a humble shack. Be aware, however, that this frozen delight is excessively sweet, and even when shared with another individual, you will likely consume only half of it, leaving behind a substantial amount of whipped cream. 

Their culinary offerings are unremarkable and typical of establishments serving standard American fare, such as TGIF. The loaded potato skins, priced at $11, are not worth the expense, and the chicken dijon pizza, at $14, is arid and unappetizing. It is advisable to opt for store-bought frozen pizza instead and cook it in the comfort of your own home. 

People flock to this establishment for the experience alone, which warrants three stars. The ambiance possesses an ineffable quality that makes women feel pampered and special. :))

I have had the pleasure of visiting the Bank on two separate occasions, and I must say that my experiences were somewhat disparate. My initial visit was rather anomalous, as the club was brimming with an electrifying atmosphere, courtesy of the pulsating music that permeated the venue. I was thoroughly enthralled by the DJ's mix, which unfortunately, I was unable to procure. The club was teeming with people, creating a sense of intimacy akin to a house party, which was further accentuated by the diminutive size of the establishment. Everyone was in high spirits, evidenced by their fervent dancing and jovial demeanor. We had the good fortune of encountering some affable individuals with whom we spent the bulk of the evening conversing and sharing laughter. The ability to indulge in periods of respite was greatly appreciated, as it afforded us a chance to recharge our energies. My second visit, however, proved to be somewhat lackluster in comparison. As a guest on the list, we gained seamless entry into the club at around 11 pm. Unfortunately, the atmosphere was rather desolate, and as the night progressed, the crowd failed to improve in terms of aesthetic appeal. I cannot attribute this lack of excitement solely to the fact that it was a holiday, as we opted to venture to XS instead, where we found a more vibrant and visually pleasing assemblage of patrons. In conclusion, I am inclined to believe that my initial visit to the Bank was either a stroke of luck or a case of being in the right place at the right time. Perhaps a third visit will serve as the decisive factor in determining the true nature of this enigmatic establishment.

"The quality of the cuisine is reliably satisfactory, conforming to the high standards that are inherent in the reputation of this establishment, despite its affiliation with a large corporate entity, which, admittedly, may engender a certain degree of skepticism on the part of those who prefer independently-owned dining establishments. Nonetheless, it would be remiss to dismiss the exceptional nature of their chambord margarita, which distinguishes itself from the ordinary and mundane offerings typically associated with chain restaurants."

This was our first time going to Tandoori Times.  The atmosphere was pleasant and I thought it would be more crowded than it was.  
The good: the food. Food was great. I had the goat curry which was their Friday special, and it was wonderful.  My husband who doesn't like most curry dishes stuck with the tandoori chicken which was wonderful as well. A side of pesto naan rounded the meal out.  No complaints about the food at all.

The bad: the service.  Our waiter was very polite and friendly the few times we saw him.  He brought us menus and then left us waiting for 15 minutes before coming back to take our order.  He then disappeared for most our meal. We had to ask another server to track him down to get our bill.  Needless to say our drinks were not refilled.  We also waited a very long time for our food.

The ugly: the belly dancing.  Actually it wasn't the bellydancing. More specifically the dramatic rise in music and the incessant finger chimes of the dancer grew to be irritating.  The dancing was fun to watch in the beginning but became tiresome after first few minutes.  It was impossible to chat without shouting at my husband.

Good place. Prices were reasonable and the food was good. But the service needs some work.

My singular annoyance regarding certain high-end eateries is the haughty and discriminatory behavior exhibited by certain front-of-house staff members, such as the hostess in this particular establishment, who not only expressed displeasure at our decision to bring our own celebratory cake but also had the audacity to impose a charge of seven dollars per plate for the supposed privilege of consuming it on the premises, her demeanor towards us resembling that of a condescending aristocrat towards those of inferior social standing.

Upon successfully navigating the gauntlet of the hostess's scrutiny, I opted to sample a Lycheetini from the bar, finding it quite palatable and potentially worthy of further exploration, had I not been concerned with preserving sufficient gastric capacity for the culinary offerings yet to come.

Following our escort into the dining area via a modern elevator, I couldn't help but be impressed by the stylish contemporary Asian motif that permeated the interior design, which was complemented by the attentive and responsive service provided by both our primary server and the supporting staff, ensuring that our beverages remained consistently replenished throughout the meal.

While the fare itself was certainly satisfactory, it was evident that the true value proposition lay not in the food, but rather in the unique ambiance and atmospheric qualities that pervaded the space, fostering an environment conducive to conviviality and relaxation among patrons.

Given the presence of traditional Filipino dishes such as lumpia, pancit, and adobo on the menu, it was reasonable to infer that the head chef was of Filipino descent, leading one of the staff members to inquire as to whether I shared any familial ties with the culinary expert, to which I responded that, while I did not possess any direct blood relations with the chef, I could appreciate the cultural significance and richness of Filipino cuisine.

In summary, The Social House succeeds in delivering an immersive epicurean experience that transcends the mere consumption of sustenance, instead offering a holistic blend of gastronomic pleasure, refined atmosphere, and hospitable service, save for the occasional encounter with supercilious hostesses.

"For a pizza of such diminutive proportions, the price point is rather exorbitant. I requested additional cheese as a topping, and the quantity of cheese present on the pizza was minimal, to say the least. The pizza itself deviates significantly from the standard fare to which I am accustomed. The menu options are limited, consisting primarily of salads and various pizza selections. Unfortunately, the pizza becomes unyielding and challenging to consume when cooled, necessitating its disposal. However, the utilization of a coal oven in the cooking process is indeed a positive aspect of this establishment, as it generally enhances the quality of the pizza. While the pizza was passable, it did not particularly align with my personal preferences."

"The solitary motivation behind my frequent visits to this particular Dunkin' Donuts establishment is due to the fact that the one in close proximity to my residence has an early closing time. Consequently, if I experience a late night yearning for an iced coffee beverage, I am obligated to venture to Sam's Town. While I genuinely appreciate DD's, this specific location leaves much to be desired in terms of quality and consistency. The coffee's flavor profile varies greatly depending on the individual responsible for its preparation. Each time I place an order for the same item, it is as though I am receiving a vastly different product. In contrast, the coffee served at my regular DD's maintains a consistent taste. My fiancÃ© and I have found it necessary to specify our orders in a particular manner contingent upon the person crafting our beverages, and even then, we occasionally receive a concoction that could be likened to a Frankenstein creation. Furthermore, the staff members generally exhibit a friendly demeanor. Nonetheless, there is a young female employee who appears to be present during late night hours and displays visible irritation when a customer enters the establishment. It is my sincere hope that she will undergo an attitude adjustment, as her behavior creates an uncomfortable atmosphere for placing an order."

OK so today someone in my office brought me a sandwich from City Market Deli. It was the Santa Fe Club. Oven Gold Turkey, Bacon, Avocado, Lettuce, Tomato, Alfalfa Sprouts, Chipotle Mayo served on Our Toasted Multi-Grain Bread.\n\nThe bread is very good and the sandwich has a good amount of flavorful turkey. The chipotle mayo has just the right amount of heat. Overall a very tasty sandwich!

let me start off by saying the food itself was definitely a 5. my boyfriend and I split yakitori and onigiri, and I had a pork rice bowl (very fatty but the stuff I did eat was delicious) and my boyfriend got a tuna and salmon salad special from the wall. we also got wine specials from the wall which was only 4 dollars a glass - amazing! the prices were pretty decent overall. we ate as much as we could. now for the not so great part:\n\nwe sat at the bar, it was SO HOT we lost our appetites. the service was good but know it was more of a communal effort than one server. also the food just came out randomly when it was ready not like appetizers then meals. fine with me but some people might not be cool with that. also the place was TINY. we had to wait about 2 minutes to sit, which was fine, but the line was pretty bad when we were leaving.

During our return journey from Las Vegas, we decided to make a brief halt at this establishment, and sample their culinary offerings. My gastronomical inclinations were pleasantly surprised by the quality of the edibles, particularly the dipping sauces, which I found to be more delectable than those proffered by Boiling Crab (LA). However, our server's inability to elucidate the varying degrees of piquancy, coupled with her unfortunate tendency to downplay the fiery nature of certain menu items, somewhat tempered my enthusiasm for indulging in an extensive array of dishes. Specifically, she cautioned against the Cajun fries, characterizing them as excessively fiery, while simultaneously recommending the mild sauce as a safer alternative, despite my explicit expression of preference for pungent flavors. Consequently, I opted for a less ambitious order, forgoing both the Cajun fries and the medium sauce, which, in hindsight, I might have relished had I been adequately informed. Furthermore, an unfortunate mix-up with one of my companion's orders resulted in the substitution of chicken wings for fried shrimp, followed by an interminable delay in rectifying the error and presenting us with an incorrect bill. Despite these drawbacks, I might consider revisiting the restaurant, provided they address their service-related shortcomings.

It's a flat odd coloured mess, I can't wait to go back. I had the Dic Ann cheeseburger and sauce, which is a flat cheeseburger with meat sauce, and they give you a popsicle stick to lift it out of the cardboard basket. And the flattest hot dog with all the fixins, I can't really explain it, but it was squashed and tasty. Think White Castle but with Wolverine-like origins, from the Wilds of the Canadian wilderness, Montreal.

"While not my customary Goodwill drop-off site, this particular location is considerable in size, boasting an expansive layout that has assimilated the former standalone structure adjacent to it, with the Hannaford supermarket now cohabiting the premises, albeit with a diminished capacity to accommodate the arrival of Goodwill, thereby necessitating a slight detour through the loading dock zone for efficient unloading, ultimately providing a serviceable and convenient drop-off point."

"I arrived at this establishment on a previous evening, driven by an intense yearning for a delectable Banh Mi, and a profound dissatisfaction with the subpar offerings at Lee's Sandwich. Following a perusal of favorable assessments regarding Mr. Sandwich's rendition of this popular Vietnamese dish, I opted to sample their culinary expertise. While the sandwiches proved to be marginally superior to those of Lee's, my gastronomical exploits in California have afforded me the opportunity to indulge in more exceptional specimens. Thus, my quest for the ideal Banh Mi continues unabated. Notwithstanding, my curiosity regarding the diverse array of comestibles proffered by Mr. Sandwich remains piqued, and I shall indeed revisit this eatery to partake of their other offerings."

"The staff members are exceptional in their duties, the eatery maintains a spotless ambiance, yet the culinary offerings somewhat fall short of the standards set by Chipotle. Notwithstanding, the site is highly convenient, boasting a prime location directly across from Wells Fargo. 

My significant other holds this establishment in high regard, particularly due to the singular nature of the buffalo chicken dish, however, despite numerous attempts, I have been unable to completely consume the meal. 

Although I generally relish the bowl, I have also sampled the burrito on several occasions. There exists an inherent desire within me to wholeheartedly endorse this venue. 

The chips and cheese dip remain a consistent favorite, as they have consistently met my expectations."

Experienced my first spring training game on St. Patty's Day with a matchup of the A's Vs. the Giants.  Half my family was in A's gear and the other half in Giants.  First the good.  I really liked the size and feel of the ballpark, felt like there was no bad seat in the stadium.  Parking was inexpensive and plenty of it.  Concessions were good and they had extra people out with buckets of beer and water.  Now the bad.  We had seats in the outfields and the bleacher benches were built for 8 year olds, not someone over 6 ft tall.  Also, there was no grass areas in the outfield.  Overall, I really enjoyed the game, Giants won, and we all had a good time.  I look forward to going to Scottsdale stadium.

"It appears to be a competition to determine who can consume the largest quantity of flesh in the shortest period of time. The culinary offerings at this establishment were satisfactory, albeit it took an extended duration for the various meats to arrive, resulting in a limited sample size of each selection. Additionally, the venue's diminutive size and cramped atmosphere, coupled with an underwhelming array of side dishes and exorbitant beverages, contributed to an overall sense of disenchantment. Even with prior reservations, the prolonged delay only served to amplify my disappointment, rendering any potential enthusiasm for a future visit nonexistent."

To go was nice and hot when I came in.\nWings were VERY GOOD. The maui wowi and the hot ranch. I don't think I would dine in though. I got a pretty cool extra room setup for parties and everything though

5 Star service, this place is very homely and hidden on the side of Wynn road.  It must compete with Dai jung gum (korean place) and Pho.  I think that their dishes are very homestyle:  The Panang and Veggie green curries are reminiscent of that from a can that I can make at home.  Their soup that comes with the lunch special however, is spectacular- No MSG and sweet from overloading of chicken and veggies.  \n\nI had the Sliced beef noodle soup, Thai style. I was anticipating something spicy sour and sweet, but instead it's just beefy broth and thin pho-like noodles...  Not quite the kind they have in texas
Not sure what's going on, slow service many of their own beers out of stock on a slow Sunday evening.\nFood was so slow I cancelled my entr\u00e9e and left.

Doc and Eddy's offers an acceptable dining experience, albeit unremarkable and unexceptional. It may serve as a suitable venue for gatherings of a larger group of individuals seeking basic bar fare and beverages, given its expansive dimensions that preclude a sense of confinement. In the rear of the establishment, numerous pool tables and assorted games provide entertainment for patrons. The front area features additional tables designated for culinary consumption, while television sets are ubiquitous throughout the premises. During a recent visit, I sampled the SoCal Chicken Sandwich and found it to be merely satisfactory, with a slightly desiccated texture. However, I did appreciate the seasoning applied to my fries. The cuisine at Doc and Eddy's is adequate for a bar, and I surprisingly felt satiated upon conclusion of my meal. Service was adequate, yet unremarkable, as it met the bare minimum requirements for satisfaction without compelling generous gratuity. Previously, my experience with the service at this establishment was subpar. Notably, my draft beer was served with insufficient foam, which, while not excessively frothy, was still deficient in this regard. Given its proximity to my residence, I envision revisiting Doc and Eddy's on occasion, although its unexceptional offerings do not particularly entice me.

very elegant but after  our bad day we decided to eat here and this was our last day so we enter it was clean only few people by the bar I order the fagioli soup  it was good, and veal piccata I did like the flavor but vegetables to plain of flavor, hubby order lasagna he didn't like it  and the bread they serve it really good also the vinaigrette they serve I really love he flavor so it was good for the prize we pay

"So, one might wonder, given the ostensible quality of the performances hosted at this venue - BRMC, The Black Keys, and Guster, all of whom delivered exceptional shows, it must be said - why does it not garner a higher rating, say, of four or five stars? Well, my dear reader, let me elucidate. Firstly, there are the exorbitant fees associated with online ticket purchases, which, when combined with the additional five-dollar parking charge, result in an aggregate increase of ten to twelve dollars per ticket. Now, were these surcharges to benefit the performing artists themselves, one might be inclined to turn a blind eye. However, I assure you, the maintenance costs of the facility do not warrant such excessive fees. In essence, it is a large concrete room, albeit one with a sloping floor designed to afford prime views of the stage from any vantage point. Admittedly, the drink selection is satisfactory, the prices reasonable, and both security personnel and restroom facilities are adequate. Furthermore, it is undeniable that this venue attracts high-caliber acts, making it a worthwhile destination for music enthusiasts such as myself, who must, perforce, selectively seek out musical experiences in this, the fifth most populous city in the United States, wherein live performances by notable artists are often few and far between."

Jollibee has been my favorite fast food ever since I was a little girl.  My mom used to take me to Jollibee for my birthday - so it's quite memorable to me.  

The Jollibee in Las Vegas was the first Jollibee I have ever visited outside the Philippines.  My first visit was a while back (not so sure about the date maybe 5 years ago), but I go to this place at least once or twice a year.  

My favorite food in Jollibee: Chicken Joy with spaghetti, Peach mango pie
Other than my favorites, I think everything else is OK.

My parents Like to come here, so I often meet them for lunch.
This means free food for me, so the price is awesome.
Service is always friendly, and the food is pretty darn good.
I love a cold beer and some fried zucchini, and they have it, so that's pretty sweet.
They could expand on their beer selection, that would be OK by me.

Convenient location, cold beer, tasty BBQ.  Even if I did have to pay I think I would come here.

Just stopped in there this afternoon for the fall pumpkin pretzel.  The space is pretty bare, and they could do a little more with the decor to entice customers.  The service was OK, not rude but also not friendly or welcoming.  The choices are limited to 5 flavors plus the special of the day which happened to be pumpkin.  I thought the pumpkin pretzel could have had more pumpkin flavor to it.  It tasted like a cinnamon sugar pretzel.  It was tasty though, so I won't knock them too much for that.  I'll probably be back, if they offer some more interesting flavors.

"Despite my numerous sojourns at the Palazzo, a review of this esteemed establishment has yet to materialize on my part, an oversight that remains shrouded in mystery, much like the city's ubiquitous mantra that 'what happens in Vegas, stays in Vegas.' Be that as it may, allow me to extol the virtues of this distinguished hotel, boasting an enviable location, spacious accommodations, and a thoughtful layout that delineates the sleeping and living quarters. Alas, my fervent criticism revolves around the bathroom's inadequate illumination, which makes applying cosmetics an arduous task, thereby detracting from the overall experience and compelling me to seek alternative lodgings."

I've been here a couple times on blurry nights in the Southside. Local can get obscenely packed, way moreso than other Southside establishments, most likely due to it being relatively new. 

If you're lucky enough to be there on a night where it's jumping but not suffocatingly packed, Local can be a decent hang-out spot especially out on the patio in the summer.

The crowd is the typical Southside bar crawl crowd but if you're looking for sophistication and cosmopolitan feel... why go to the Southside? Folks are friendly enough, the service is fast if you can get to the bar but the prices can be a little expensif esp. for shots.

Still, I'd say I like Local for a night of drinking and swearing, if the weather's nice and the place isn't jam packed.

"While the overall ambiance of the establishment was satisfactory, my visit to peruse the PlayStation 3 and associated software proved to be somewhat anticlimactic due to the advent of Black Friday, which promised more favorable prices. Thus, I opted to explore the premises in search of compact discs and digital versatile discs, only to find an underwhelming assortment, given the current ubiquity of streaming services and digital acquisition methods. Nonetheless, the store's personnel were quite hospitable and proffered assistance in locating specific items, thereby contributing to a partially redeeming experience."

Got a cotton candy-flavored sorbet superimposed upon a bed of rich vanilla custard, which was embellished with a generous sprinkling of multi-colored sprinkles. The overall taste experience was nothing short of sublime, with the sweetness perfectly balanced to avoid being overpowering. The texture of the custard was remarkably smooth and velvety, possessing a luxurious quality that made me concerned for the structural integrity of the flimsy plastic spoon provided by the establishment. Although the service was generally helpful and accommodating, the demeanor of the servers seemed somewhat lackluster and mechanical, giving the impression that their presence was not entirely voluntary. The interior design of the shop evoked a sense of familiarity and comfort, reminiscent of a Baskin Robbins ice cream parlor, albeit with a slightly more dimly lit atmosphere. To optimize the enjoyment of your visit, it is recommended that you request your order to-go and partake of it in the proximate park, thus enabling you to savor the flavors and textures without being burdened by the constraints of a traditional dining setting.

It's a decently good sized store with lots of cheap stuff that is almost fashionable.  There were lots of people in the store and people buying quite a bit of clothes.  Not certain why I ended up dropping dough but somehow I felt like I just needed to have something new to carry around and bring home I guess.

We possess acquaintances who effusively praise the culinary offerings of mu shu, whereas our sentiments towards this particular dish are somewhat more tepid, despite our proximity to the establishment in question; specifically, we reside merely a few blocks distant. Our assessment of the price-to-quality ratio is predicated upon the unit of measurement denominated in pounds. Notwithstanding the cordial demeanor of the staff, the overall quality of the comestibles served is tantamount to that typically associated with cafeterias.

Through all our trips to Arizona, we kept driving by Nielsen's Frozen Custard when we went to and from our hotel to our daughter's home.  Each time, I would say to myself that we had to give it a try.  However, many times we would drive by it when it was closed.  Well...this trip (our final one to visit our daughter who has now moved), we got here!

Upon entering, we were surprised to find that in addition, to frozen custard, they also served meals (burgers, sandwiches, salads, etc.).  We were there strictly for the frozen custard.

We were greeted by a very friendly young lady who worked behind the counter.  She was patient with us as we perused the massive topping menu---so much choice!  In the end, I chose a small cup of vanilla with sprinkles and my husband had a small cup of unadorned chocolate custard.  After ordering, we were given a number to put on our table then the young lady brought out our order quickly.

We both agreed that the frozen custard had a nice, creamy consistency.  However, we found that it didn't have much flavor.  Neither the vanilla nor the chocolate had a strong enough flavor---and that was disappointing.  We were expecting much better.

Yet, we don't regret giving it a try.  Had we not done so, it would have been one of those things that would have nagged at me.  I would have always wondered if we had missed out on something excellent.

Clean moderately priced hotel. Came in during CES week and paid about 160$ a night for 4 nights. Got a smoking room, you can hear plumbing next door, stains in the bath and toilet from cigg burns, sitting chair had white stains on it. It costs 5$ for hot water! It seems it's always the expensive hotels that don't have a microwave, coffeemaker, fridge, and charge an arm and a leg for stuff like hot water, and wifi.  Anyhow I got smart and just heated up my water with a glass cup and the iron. PH you think you can work me, but no no no.. LOL.

"The Beehive, situated within Edinburgh's historic Grassmarket district, boasts an extensive array of libations and a commodious interior, replete with a sophisticated ambiance that exudes an air of refined conviviality. Patrons seeking a respite from the bustling thoroughfares may opt to indulge in the tranquil delights of the establishment's secluded rear garden during the balmy summer months, while those desiring a more rarefied dining experience can ascend to the second floor, where a serene and intimate setting awaits. Additionally, the Beehive has cultivated a reputation as a stalwart purveyor of unconventional comedic performances during the city's renowned arts festivals, with a diminutive, albeit charming, upper-level space metamorphosing into an inviting and captivating venue for avant-garde and surrealist entertainment. Kudos, Beehive, for your steadfast dedication to catering to the variegated preferences of your clientele."

We go to this location when we don't feel like driving too far, or are in the shopping plaza and need to get feeder crickets for our lizards. 

it is always a hassle to find someone to help us, even after asking 3-4 people. The cashiers are generally friendly, and have offered discounts for standing in line for more than 2 minutes while they are having issues getting a customer through the checkout process.

We will go back for the same reasons we go there in the first place, it isn't our first choice for pet stores to go to though.

"This particular Fry's location has made considerable strides in terms of its product offerings, boasting an extensive array of superior quality and diversity, encompassing both conventionally grown and organic produce, as well as an assortment of artisanal breads. Furthermore, the meat department generally maintains an adequate inventory of fresh cuts, although the availability of lamb and seafood can be somewhat unpredictable. Specifically, the acquisition of farm-raised, color-added salmon from the East Coast remains a mystery to me, particularly given the proximity and superior quality of Northwest salmon. However, my primary grievance with this establishment pertains to the subpar service proffered by the deli staff, whose sluggishness and ineptitude have led to numerous instances of prolonged waiting times, ultimately prompting me to either abandon my order or avoid the deli altogether."

"It perplexes me as to why they opted for the appellation 'Barcelona,' given the dearth of genuinely authentic Spanish culinary offerings; however, I must admit that their tapas are rather delectable. It would be beneficial if they proffered a more extensive array of tapas, as it would cater to a broader spectrum of palates. The service we received was exceptional, and I would highly recommend visiting during their half-price night promotion. Additionally, I suggest sampling their Sangrias, as they offer complimentary taste tests."

"I am perplexed by the prolonged waiting period of two hours; it seems disproportionate to the quality of service and cuisine offered at this establishment. My interactions with the hostess have been less than satisfactory, as she has exhibited an aloof demeanor during our brief encounters. Notwithstanding, we opted to partake in a variety of dishes, including the pork belly tacos, bone marrow, tzatziki dip, skewers accompanied by chimichurri, and a sushi roll. While the culinary offerings were palatable, they failed to impress us with their flavors and presentation. Specifically, the skewers lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to the next level. We also sampled the pistachio ice cream, which, although enjoyable, suffered from an unfortunate lack of texture due to its rapid melting upon arrival. In conclusion, based on my underwhelming experience, I find it challenging to comprehend the widespread acclaim surrounding this restaurant, and thus, I am unlikely to return in the near future."

"Halted momentarily at a sushi establishment, we immersed ourselves in an ambiance replete with contemporary flair, the sonic accompaniment of boisterous club music serving to enhance our culinary experience, while a vintage Bruce Lee film projection on the wall elicited several chuckles. The sushi itself was fresh, and though we opted for a couple of traditional maki rolls - specifically, spicy tuna and California varieties - both dishes were comparable in quality to those offered by the majority of sushi restaurants. Additionally, the 22-ounce can of Sapporo beer featured a distinctive steel-shaped design that piqued our curiosity."

This small place is not easy to find.  They have a good menu, I ordered the fried beef flat noodle to go.  It was just okay.  \nThe owner speaks Cantonese and I was able to chat with them a bit.  I think I need to order something else next time just so I can provide a better review for this place.  But the first dish didn't pass my test. \nI will go back to try other things.

I think Rito's is overpriced for what you get. The burritos look huge because they use an over sized tortilla that hides the tiny amount of meat they use so most bites are filled with tortilla not meat. If the green chile burrito I ordered was filled with meat then maybe it would be worth $8. The beans were above average and I thought their salsa was amazing even though they charge 25 cents for two tablespoons of it. I expected to be blown away by the food here but it tasted just like the food I grew up eating. It made me want to hug my mom :)

I would like to attempt to partake in a culinary experience at Richardson's once again. On a previous occasion, I embarked on a social engagement with a romantic interest at this establishment, and we were intent on perusing the menu to select a few items to share. However, the manager intervened and assured us that he would accommodate our needs, stating, "Allow me to attend to your dining requirements - you will undoubtedly relish this." My date and I exchanged dubious glances, inferring that we had little choice but to acquiesce to his suggestion. 

The manager dispatched a garlic-themed platter, which, while not the most pungent item on the menu, still proved to be a substantial and overwhelming meal for both myself and my companion. As someone who does not derive pleasure from such fare, I would have greatly preferred to exercise my own gastronomic inclinations rather than deferring to the manager's recommendation. Furthermore, the portion size was excessive, rendering us unable to fully consume it and leaving no room to sample any of the main courses listed on the menu. 

In retrospect, I have learned that it is wiser to adhere to my own gustatory preferences when dining, rather than placing trust in the judgment of an unfamiliar individual, especially on a first date. While the dish itself was not unpalatable, its weighty nature made it more suitable for a group of four or more individuals, rather than just two. 

Despite this experience, I still maintain that Richardson's boasts an attractive ambiance, making it an ideal location for a social engagement. However, it is advisable to reserve a table in advance to ensure a seamless dining experience. Someday, I aspire to revisit this establishment and indulge in a culinary selection that aligns more closely with my personal tastes.

Five stars for the low-slung bar for and manned by midg--ahem, I mean, little people.  But that in itself is not the entirety of the place.  If there's any place in Scottsdale that screams Klassy, this would be it. 

Giligin's tugs at the senses like a trashy but fun cousin would, whether it's the sticky floors, the tacky wheel of misfortune, the swing hanging randomly in the bar, the refrigerated cases behind the bar like you're at a liquor store or the nightly promotion gimmicks - goldfish races, anyone?  They have a menu, but I will admit I'm scared to try the food here.

We came here a couple of weeks ago in the hoopla that was FBR Super Bowl weekend and after ditching all places on Scottsdale Road, we ended up here.  We had a blast before and after the $1 jello shots, and I even got some rad photos with the Captain Morgan's guy.  Later, I found myself walking around with a giant Coors Light, while being soundly defeated by a visiting Wisconsinite girl in a rousing game of beanbag toss. Midwestern bar games were never my thing.

If I had the opportunity to consume the delectable pepper jack mac and cheese on a daily basis, I would unquestionably take advantage of it. In point of fact, I make it a point to order it each and every time I visit the establishment, as it is an integral component of my culinary experience. Furthermore, I must say that the sandwiches they offer are quite satisfactory as well, boasting an impressive array of flavors and textures that complement the main attraction remarkably well. Additionally, the ambiance of the establishment exudes a welcoming and relaxed vibe, allowing patrons to indulge in a selection of high-quality bar fare while enjoying a couple of cold beverages.

CVS is known as a great Pharmaceutical chain that also offers everyday grocery items.  This store located off the 215 and Valley Verede is a great addition to this wonderful chain.\n\nThe savings and weekly specials are very hard to beat at CVS.  I have always enjoyed the service and 24 hour drive through Pharmacy at almost every location.  Awesome store!!!

"The chicken parmigiana dish fell short of our expectations, possessing an unremarkable taste and texture that failed to distinguish it from the myriad of other establishments offering similar fare. In contrast, the field greens salad proved to be a culinary delight, its freshness and flavorful dressing elevating it to a level of gastronomic excellence that the aforementioned chicken dish could not hope to match. Furthermore, the waitstaff's proficiency and attentive nature contributed significantly to the overall dining experience, rendering the encounter a largely satisfying one despite the disappointing performance of the chicken parm. Lastly, the outdoor seating arrangement, positioned directly beneath the celestial expanse of the sky and in close proximity to a sizable fountain within the Forum Shops, afforded a unique and refreshing ambiance that complemented the meal nicely."
If this is a golf club, I'm the abominable snowman.  Looks like a pleasant place, but there sure as heck aren't any *golf* holes getting balled here.

"Although my affection for the concept of Sidebar remains intact, my fondness for the venue itself is somewhat mitigated by my underwhelming experiences there. While the beverages they offer are certainly passable, I have found the atmosphere to be less than enjoyable on multiple occasions. Specifically, I have visited the establishment twice, with vastly differing results. During my initial visit, I had the pleasure of being served by a charismatic and knowledgeable bartender who hailed from San Francisco, and I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed his company and the overall experience. However, my subsequent visit proved to be a stark contrast, as the bartender who attended to me was not only unfriendly but also displayed an air of superiority when addressing queries from patrons, which I found particularly vexing and ultimately detracted from my enjoyment of the outing. Suffice it to say, I have not returned to Sidebar since then."

This is a fairly new place.  It's charming and homey.  The restaurant has been very clean both times we visited.  Both times there we sat at the bar, and drinks were made well, however we did not eat.  They do not have beer on tap and carry no craft beers, although one of the owners days that will change soon.  They have a nice bar, however the bar top is not as wife as the foot step on the bottom of the bar, making sitting at the bar rather uncomfortable.  They do have a game room in the back with pool tables, foosball and darts.  They also have a back patio with corn hole and horseshoes.  Being new, the service is a little slow and they don't seen to have enough staff, but maybe that was the time of day we went there each time.  We will definitely go back and try their barbeque.

"Whenever I find myself in the city of Las Vegas, I take great pleasure in indulging in a delectable dining experience at an upscale restaurant. On this particular occasion, my culinary destination of choice was a renowned establishment known for its exceptional fare. Upon perusing the menu, we elected to initiate our gastronomic journey with a pair of tantalizing appetizers - the bone marrow and maple glazed pork belly. Suffice it to say, these initial offerings were nothing short of sublime, boasting a rich, velvety texture that literally melted in our mouths. For our primary courses, I opted for the 8 oz. filet mignon/American Wagyu, while my companion selected the 'A tasting of New York sirloin.' In accordance with our individual preferences, we requested that our steaks be prepared at a medium-rare temperature. To complement our delectable entrees, we also ordered an assortment of sides, including wild field mushrooms, creamed spinach, and broccoli-rapini. Lastly, we paired our meal with a bottle of exquisite red wine (the specific label escapes my memory). As our steaks and sides arrived, I eagerly anticipated savoring the expertly cooked, crustacean delight that lay before me. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, as I found my steak to be overcooked and, thus, not particularly appealing to my palate. Despite the disappointment, I did manage to appreciate the finely crafted wine and the remaining sides we had ordered. It is worth mentioning that, due to my underwhelming experience with the steak, I do not foresee myself returning to this particular dining establishment in the future."

Parking SUCKS.
Everything is over priced. 

It took me 25 minutes to get a cup of coffee, and I wouldn't have minded the wait if someone had acknowledged my presence and given the polite "I'll be with you as soon as possible" report. Clearly, that was too much to ask for.

But if you happen to go when it's not busy (i'm not sure when this is...) I'm fairly certain the ambiance would be delightful. It's an interesting concept. Also, the spaces are WAY too tight for the type of traffic they have in there.

The gelato on the South side of the building is really bland and boring. I'd rather eat store brand ice cream. Their Pizza is really awesome, though.

Great idea - mediocre execution.

Ladies, please be careful especially on a Saturday night. I was here last night (Saturday) with a couple girlfriends seated on the patio. We ordered drinks from the server who brought them from the inside bar so we could not see them being poured or who had access to them before delivering to our table. After just one Cosmopolitan I was barely able to walk and got very sick later than night. This has never happened to me before and I'm concerned something was slipped in my drink. Not necessarily by staff but possibly a patron at or near the bar before our drinks came to us. Thank god my girlfriends were there to get me home safely. Just a lesson learned to always keep an eye on your drinks from the moment they are poured... No matter where you're at!

Someone here does not care about his job. Now this is usually not true about the Bookman's employees I have encountered over the years.

Maybe it is because he is old...or just had a bad day.  He did not even glance at all the trade I was bringing in...before flat out telling me no.

As I said..this is usually never a problem.  Yet I always visit the 19th ave location because it is closer.  So for a change of pace we sometimes visit this location.  I always seem to find something here....actually found 2 items I have been wanting.  But changed my mind on after the issue at the trade counter.

Went here for lunch today for the first time and loved the atmosphere and service. Everyone was super nice and helpful and the booths are so cushy and comfy! 

My friend and I shared the Mushroom and Sausage Pizza and the Chicken Chopped Salad. The crust, mushrooms and sausage on the pizza were excellent. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the red sauce. It needed more development, it tasted a bit like tomato paste out of the can. 

The chicken in the salad was grilled and in nice, small, easy-to-eat pieces. The dressing was a bit watered down and lacking in flavor. 

All in all, it seemed like Nook just needs a little bit of fine-tuning but has great potential. I would definitely be willing to give it another go, mainly based on the excellent service.

"Underwhelming encounter with too much repetition."

The original text describes a person's experience at a bar as average, mentioning the view, location, and drinks. To modify it to use longer and more complex sentences and professional vocabulary, we can rephrase it as follows:

"An experience that fell short of expectations, characterized by a sense of monotony and lackluster surroundings, albeit with a few redeeming features."

This modified text uses longer sentences and more advanced vocabulary, such as "fell short of expectations," "monotony," and "lackluster surroundings," while still conveying the same meaning as the original text. It also maintains the same tone and structure, with a brief description of the experience followed by a mention of the location and drinks.

Here's a breakdown of the modifications made:

* "Pretty average experience" became "An experience that fell short of expectations." This phrase is more formal and implies a certain level of disappointment.
* "Great view" became "A sense of monotony." This phrase suggests a feeling of repetition or dullness, which can be seen in the context of the abandoned buildings and lack of excitement.
* "Until you walk closer to the wall and you see nothing but abandoned buildings until you see South Mountain" became "Albeit with a few redeeming features." This phrase acknowledges that there were some positive aspects to the experience, but they were not enough to overcome the overall feeling of disappointment.
* "It was cool being next to US Airways Arena and Chase field" became "Characterized by a sense of proximity to notable landmarks." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the location of the bar in relation to nearby attractions.
* "For some reason I thought this bar was on the top of the hotel, but it's only on the third floor" became "Boasting an unremarkable altitude." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the location of the bar within the hotel, emphasizing its lack of distinction.
* "Decent spot, drinks were okay, I might come back again if people from out of town are here" became "With a few redeeming features, including an acceptable ambiance and passable beverages, the possibility of future visits remains." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the positive aspects of the bar, while also acknowledging that the experience was not entirely satisfactory.

I admit we went here because of DDD (Guy Fieri).  The dive atmosphere did not disappoint.  Good bartender, even though the bar was wet/sticky.  We ordered wings and pizza.  The wings were very good, as was the pizza, although it took a very long time before the food came out.  \n\nThe food was good, but they don't have the ability to handle the popularity of this place.  It's a tiny kitchen with one person cooking.

I don't know what it is about Herb 'n Flavors, but every time I go there something is off.    Don't get me wrong, overall they have some tasty dishes, but some others fall flat.  It's really hit or miss.  The first time I got the Spinach 4-Cheese Quesadilla and it was just too greasy and cheesy.  I know, I know it's \"4-cheese\", but there is a delicate balance with cheese.  My friend ordered it another time and the balance was much better.  The second time I went I got the Veggie Rice Bowl.  Wonderful seasoning, but they overcooked the tofu.  We also ordered the Vegan Spinach & Artichoke Dip.  No thanks.  My friend had the salmon - loved it.  My other friend got the Pollo Fresca and the Chicken Shawarma Wrap separate times.  He liked both. The 3rd time I ordered the Veggie Bowl without the tofu (much better).  The falafel fries are yummy.  The tiramisu is absolutely INCREDIBLE!  I must say the owner is really personable and KNOWS how to cater to his customers.  That type of treatment will keep me coming back for the things that I really enjoy.

The place is fine, but a bit loud when crowded. Plenty of people with laptops and couples chatting away. The coffee was standard fare, as in sugary and tasty. The two things that I noticed are the number of tables made it feel crowded even when the number of people dwindled, and the bathroom was not the cleanest I have seen in other stores. Although not my favorite place, it's a good place to pop in or stay awhile, just a bit tight if at capacity. I would return.

I accompanied my mother to this establishment with the intention of procuring a takeout meal, as she has expressed a predilection for this particular venue. Despite possessing a preferred Chinese restaurant, I opted to acquiesce to her desire. Upon entering the premises, I observed that the ambiance was clean and well-maintained. However, I must admit that the visual representations of the culinary offerings were somewhat perplexing, as I was unable to accurately identify any of the dishes depicted.  

The quality of service was satisfactory, as the server was attentive and responsive to our needs. I requested a Sprite from the fountain beverage dispenser, but upon consuming it, I discovered that it did not conform to my expectations. I brought this to the attention of the counter attendant, who displayed an indifferent demeanor and failed to demonstrate any inclination towards investigating the issue. Subsequently, I sampled the lemonade, only to find that it consisted of nothing more than plain water. Furthermore, upon attempting to discard the liquid, I noticed minute particles floating within my cup. Disheartened by these experiences, I decided to forgo further exploration of the beverage options and instead focused on the food menu.  

It is worth mentioning that this establishment offers luncheon specials during the afternoon hours, which may potentially provide patrons with an economical dining alternative. Unfortunately, due to our late arrival, we were unable to sample these purportedly reasonably priced selections. My meal of choice was Udon soup, which, despite its flavorful nature, left me feeling somewhat uneasy due to my persistent concerns regarding the cleanliness of the food preparation area. As an advocate for supporting local enterprises, I acknowledge the importance of initial impressions and fear that this encounter may have compromised my future patronage.

As others have said it is a nice bowling alley.  We came around 5 on a Friday evening and the wait was an hour so that was a bummer.  We decided to wait and played in the arcade and it had nice equipment but was outrageously expensive.  If you don't mind spending a little money it isn't a bad place, but maybe next time we'll try stopping by at a less busy time.

Went here for lunch with my 2.5 month old on a Friday because I had a taste for some pasta, plus I had a rewards card coupon. It wasn't crowded at 1:30. Because I had a stroller, I opted to sit in the bar area. It took 5 min. for someone to come over to see what I wanted to drink. Since, it took so long for drinks, I went ahead and ordered when she came over. Food came out fairly quickly and was tasty. However, I only had water and I only got a refill when it was time to bring me my check. 

I thought the bartender/waitress was strictly for the bar area and it would be fast service, but I was wrong. 

Also, they have a good happy hour, so that would be the only reason I would go back.

This eatery exudes an eccentric ambiance redolent of a venue one might encounter in Los Angeles, thereby evoking a sense of familiarity and nostalgia. The hospitality we received was exemplary, as the staff exhibited a proficient and attentive demeanor throughout our visit. Notwithstanding its emphasis on uncooked and plant-based cuisine, the menu offered an array of options encompassing both cooked fare and meat dishes, thereby catering to a wide range of palates and dietary preferences. However, my sole criticism pertains to the excessive saltiness imbuing each dish, which seemed a deliberate attempt to compensate for the absence of culinary preparation. Notwithstanding this flaw, the assortment of sweet treats proved delectable, albeit the pastry crusts displayed an equal propensity towards saltiness. Moreover, I found myself consuming an excessive quantity of water, to the extent of six glasses, which I deemed rather extreme.

My boyfriend and I came here a couple of months ago and I was slightly disappointed. They mixed up our orders with another table which happens I understand. The food was pretty good, but it wasn't incredibly memorable. I think we should give it another shot sometime though and try a few different things. The bird cages next to the restaurant were pretty cool.
