Was mostly disappointed here.  Had heard good things, but the pizza was mostly uninspiring.  The crust was bland... and too dense/hard/chewy.  I appreciate light and airy crusts and that was what I was expecting, but really nothing like it came through.  The fig appetizer was delicious, but otherwise not really worth the $$ I spent.

Johnny Rockets holds a special place in my heart with memories of mall trips with my friends in high school. This location wasn't as fantastic as those of my past. There's only bar-seating and everything is definitely rushed. They've done well with they space they have, but I truly miss being able to tuck into a booth, listen to our own jukebox and sip on a beautifully pulled milkshake. \n\nUpon our trip we ordered a Big Apple shake and a Dark Chocolate shake. We received one but not the other and had to fight for the attention of the staff to ask for our second shake, which was definitely not even on the radar of being made. Once we actually received the second shake, everything was delicious - but it's just not the experience we were hoping for :/

I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to this esteemed establishment, accompanied by my esteemed acquaintances, Shelley M. and Arlin B.  Allow me to elucidate the salient points of our dining experience:

*  The gastronomical offerings served within these hallowed walls are indeed delectable! (Indubitably, that is a singular aspect, is it not?) 

HOWEVER:

*  My initial visit to this edifice was characterized by an uncomfortably frigid ambiance, while my second foray into its confines was marked by an oppressively torrid atmosphere; unfortunately, the third time proved to be no charm, as the thermometric conditions within the premises were once again frosty and uninviting.

*  It is worth noting that the hospitable demeanor of the staff during my previous sojourns was, regretfully, not replicated during our most recent visit. Rather than being greeted with warm smiles and effusive welcomes, we were met with a perceptible chilliness and an air of indifference. 

*  Furthermore, the customary practice of presenting each patron with a diminutive platter of expertly prepared allium vegetables, citrus fruits, and other savory accoutrements was, much to our dismay, conspicuously absent. Instead, we were obliged to improvise and surmise which delectable morsels belonged to whom, an exercise that proved both vexing and unnecessary. 

*  In light of the preceding observations, it becomes apparent that certain aspects of the dining experience at this venue require closer attention and refinement. Specifically, the ambient temperature must be regulated with greater precision, while the quality of service should be scrupulously maintained, as it was previously. 

Now, permit me to divulge the particulars of my culinary selections for this specific occasion:

Carne Asada (beef) Taco: $1.25
Al Pastor (pork) Taco: $1.25
Pescado (fish) Taco: $2
Beef Tamale: $2

"I assure you that I shall endeavor to provide an enhanced assessment of this establishment, as I habitually aspire to compose a laudatory critique of any venue. Their sushi was indeed delectable, despite the fact that I opted to consume it off-premises; it may have been even more scrumptious had I consumed it on location. 

It appears that they offer a satisfactory happy hour menu, which I intend to sample in the near future. 

During my wait, I couldn't help but notice that the music was rather boisterous, making conversation somewhat challenging. The prices, however, seem to be aligned with those of other sushi restaurants in the area. 

Thus, I anticipate the opportunity to indulge in a meal within the restaurant's confines, thereby permitting me to enhance my evaluation."

Thirty-five minute wait must mean something's tasty here. Good thing they have free coffee outside while you wait. Nice touch.

I liked the atmosphere, like a southern hospitality cottage-type setting. It went well with the friendly service we were given by all of the servers there, since none are assigned to a specific table. They all work together to cater to all guests.

We came for breakfast, so I wanted the stuffed French toast. Not a fan of pb, so I asked if I could get a Nutella & banana one instead. Wasn't a problem at all. Cool. But then when my food came out, it didn't look like Nutella. It wasn't as dark. I tasted it, and turns out they do a Nutella + cream cheese mix. Disappointment. I tasted more cream cheese than Nutella. Meh.

3 out of 5 at our table ordered the corned beef hash. They picked the right thing. Definitely better than my french toast. Oh well.

Sometimes when I'm at work and I get overloaded, I go into old-people f*#k mode, ie; any way to get the job done.

I suspect that's how the chef functions at AF when the place is packed to the gunwales because my herb roasted chicken sandwich, a long standing favorite of mine became my least favorite...all in the space of one visit.

I've rarely had a bad meal here, but Saturday, the place hosted every old woman's birthday, baby shower, and all-around chick event. I think the kitchen panicked and started throwing shit on plates like monkeys were ruling the kitchen.

Anyway, it wasn't good.
Come here when it's not so packed and you don't have to listen to the gay couple next to you bragging about their trip to Barbados and how they frolicked nude on the beach.
The image of swinging dicks combined with a bad sandwich was over the top.
Glad I have a Xanax prescription.

I see what you're trying to do here and I do like it, I can't just grant a good review for only being.  What I don't understand is the overblown reviews for the place, to me it is not worth five stars.  First of all, it closes at 7pm on a Saturday, no good.

Had 3 pieces of fried chicken, 2 waffles, cornbread and mac and cheese.  While all of this was good, it wasn't great.  The chicken was juicy and well seasoned, but it was lacking for meat.  The mac and cheese seemed to use liquid cheese, instead of taking the time to really create some down-home goodness.  I'm going to stick with Honey Bears for my glutenous indulgences.

I wish Lolo's had some outside perspective on their food and menu.  This type of place can compete where there aren't many options but there are so many restuarants that have better quality, better service and cleaner spaces in the area.  

The Fried Chicken (strips) at Four Peaks beat this place.  Bring on the hate mail.

"Starbucks has evolved into a veritable institution within the United States, and my personal experience with their offerings has been largely positive. As a discerning patron, I typically opt for a Venti Mocha, sans whipped cream, but on rare occasions, I may indulge in a Columbian Roast or a Frappuccino. While their breakfast sandwiches are not necessarily the epitome of culinary excellence, they do surpass those of their fast-food counterparts, McDonald's, in terms of flavor profile. The baked goods available at Starbucks are adequate, given their prepackaged nature, but fail to elicit the same level of enthusiasm as their specialty coffee drinks. Unfortunately, frequenting a Starbucks location often entails braving crowded environments, lengthy queues, and an uncomfortable chill in the air, which can be somewhat off-putting. Nonetheless, despite these drawbacks, my preference still lies with independently owned coffee houses or quaint, hidden gems, rather than this ubiquitous chain, which, by its very name, suggests a certain uniformity and predictability."

I was experiencing an intense yearning for the frozen hot chocolate, which, upon consumption, proved to be of considerable proportions and somewhat formidable in its taste, although it did not entirely align with my previous experiences of the beverage in New York... 

We had also requested a variety of other items such as the nachos, a burger, and a hotdog, all of which were of satisfactory quality, but their prices, in relation to their culinary value, seemed slightly disproportionate, considering the nature of the establishment and the fact that the fare was merely a few notches above what one would typically find at a diner... 
Wishing to save some space for a sweet treat, we opted to forgo dessert on this particular visit, intending to reserve it for a future occasion when we could indulge in it without restraint... 

The service we received was somewhat lacking, as our server's attentiveness waned at times, necessitating our intervention to ensure the timely procurement of certain essentials. Nonetheless, the restaurant did accept Harris' complimentary coupons, which served as a minor redeeming factor.

There are many bigger and better Harris Teeter locations in Charlotte, but if you live in Plaza Midwood or NoDa, this one is your best option. Unfortunately, the produce there isn't great. And the location is pretty small. It's packed and frustrating around 6 pm, when everyone is getting off work and stopping there to buy groceries. I will say, the VIC card rewards are pretty good. You get good deals, and I got free luggage once through the program.

This particular location proved to be quite satisfactory, despite encountering an unfortunate technological glitch during the check-in process, which was resolved by the staff in a timely manner; the complimentary breakfast offered between the hours of six and nine am served as an adequate compensation for the brief delay, thus motivating us to explore other establishments that provide similar amenities in the future.

There's no doubt that XS is a beautiful club.  But, I really didn't have much of a great time here considering it's suppose to be one the best in Sin City. Maybe, it was the music.  Which was more Techno than Hip Hop.  Or maybe it was the crowd, which I wasn't feeling.  There were some nice ones out of the bunch, but most of them were stuck-up. Although, I have to give it up to security though, because they sure did a good job at making that line move.  I was kinda feelin' bad for the guys during Memorial Day Weekend though.  The cover charge to get in for a guy at XS was $100 and later on that night it jumped to $200 just to get in!  

Ridiculously XS-cessive indeed!

But honestly didn't think it was quite worth all the hype.

"The proficiency exhibited by the waiting staff was indeed commendable, as they demonstrated a profound ability to attend to our needs with alacrity and cordiality, thereby enhancing the overall dining experience. However, it was rather unfortunate that the manager did not display a similar level of competence, as their lack of proactive communication and problem-solving skills resulted in an unacceptable delay in the food preparation process. Specifically, the presence of a large party that preceded ours and subsequently monopolized the kitchen's resources for an extended period of time did not warrant a visit from the manager to our table, neither did it elicit any conciliatory measures on their part to mitigate the inconvenience caused. Moreover, the manager's absence during the climax of our meal, when confusion reigned supreme, only served to exacerbate the already tense situation."
Lee's sandwiches are lee's sandwiches iam just excited I don't have to drive all the way to China Town to get my Viet Sandwich fix...Yay!!!
Cafe has new owners that are very nice as well as the staff.  We ordered burgers, fries, salads, and grilled ham and cheese sandwich.  All were delicious!

"The Sunflower store has undergone a transformation following its acquisition by Sprouts, and unfortunately, the changes implemented do not appear to be an improvement. Although this location still offers a limited array of Boar's Head Deli Meats and a few varieties of cheese, the meat and seafood counter has been reduced in size and is now manned by friendly personnel. The majority of the store's floor space is dedicated to showcasing an extensive selection of fresh produce; however, the prices, while not exorbitant, are comparable to or lower than those at Whole Foods. 

It is worth noting that since Sprouts took over, the quality and variety of their supplement selection have diminished. For instance, previously, there were five distinct options for Kava Kava capsules available, but upon my most recent visit, only two remained, and the brands they carried were not ones I would consider purchasing. While this location may serve as a suitable starting point for individuals seeking basic supplements, seasoned supplement users may find the selection to be somewhat disappointing. 

Despite my desire to endorse this store, three stars remain the highest rating I can bestow upon it."

Meh..not particularly memorable.
I've eaten at this location and the one by ASU, though I like this location better. I would probably only eat here if I was walking by and I was starving. 
The cookies ROCK though, I like that you get one with your sandwich. And they have my favorite flavor of Jones Soda (Sugar-free Black Cherry) which kicked ass. 

Warning: The roast beef sandwich (Overture?) comes with horseradish sauce and it is hot as a mother.  I like the spice but it was almost unbearable. My nose pretty much turned into a snotty waterfall. 

Go to Opa Grill next door instead.

Interesting restaurant.  Limited menu.  I assume the menu will grow as this place finds its way.  We had the cheese plate(ok), beets(very good), mussels(very good), iceberg sald(big and good).  Pretty good beer selection.  The music was defintely off.  I am sure this will change as well.  The brunch menu looked very good.  \n\nI'll go back sometime to see what changes have been made.

Last Monday, we visited this establishment for breakfast, and due to its immense popularity, we were forced to endure an approximate waiting period of 20 minutes before being accommodated. Unfortunately, this delay was reflected in the culinary offerings, as they appeared to have been hastily prepared. I opted for the pancake combination, but unfortunately, the turkey bacon was excessively salted, and the pancakes lacked the customary fluffiness, leading my dining companions and myself to conclude that the fare was unremarkable. Consequently, this experience differed significantly from the exceptional dining encounter I have grown accustomed to at the IHOP in Torrance.

"An exceedingly tranquil and understatedly fashionable district, characterized by an unpretentious ambiance that exudes a sense of relaxed refinement. Strategically positioned in close proximity to a stylish hair salon, providing patrons with the opportunity to indulge in a pampering session, followed by a leisurely sojourn on a comfortable bench situated in front of a picturesque window. The overall experience is reminiscent of the carefree and laid-back atmosphere synonymous with San Diego, California."

Food quality disappointing. Not the best steak in Vegas.

Three of us enjoyed two ribeyes ($52) and one filet ($46). Waiter told us their ribeye is the best steak in Vegas, but don't believe it. They were cooked correctly. The rub was rather bland and the crusting on the filet was hard. On a scale of one to ten, my ribeye overall was a 7. I've had 10's before in Vegas, so the competition is tough! But just claiming you have the best steak doesn't make it so.

The sides ($9 each) were disappointing. We ordered four. Creamed spinach, always a favorite of mine and recommended by the waiter, was just odd and bland - didn't taste interesting or flavorful at all. The best side was the asparagus, but honestly, how hard is it to steam asparagus?

Desert, as it often is at these kind of places where desert is an afterthought, was disappointing and ended the overall experience on a "blah" note.

Wine list was excellent.

With so many great places in Vegas, you can do much better. Everything else was top notch, but the food is the core of the experience and Delmonicos is just average, unfortunately.

"Having had this establishment on my culinary radar for an extended period of time, I decided to pay a visit with a companion subsequent to participating in the National Kidney Foundation Walk. Upon perusing their online menu, I was particularly intrigued by the pear omelet and was eager to sample it. To my surprise, we were promptly seated upon arrival, despite my anticipation of a considerable delay due to the lateness of the morning and the likelihood of a sizable crowd. The ambiance of the restaurant was reminiscent of a private residence, exuding a warm and welcoming atmosphere. However, my enthusiasm was somewhat diminished by the unsettling appearance of the thick gray carpeting, which struck me as unsanitary and questionable in terms of cleanliness. 

The pear omelet, while palatable, did not quite meet my expectations, primarily due to the scarcity of pears within. It seemed to me that the dish's namesake ingredient should have been more prominent. My companion and I couldn't help but notice the delectable appearances of the other patrons' meals, specifically the mouthwatering French toast, which piqued my interest and left me contemplating a future visit. 

In conclusion, our experience at this eatery was merely average, lacking any truly exceptional or remarkable aspects."

"A veritable cornucopia of gastronomical delights at an unparalleled price point, this esteemed eatery offers a diverse array of delectable dishes that cater to a wide range of palates, featuring none other than expertly crafted, hand-scooped ice cream, an unmitigated delight for the taste buds and a true embodiment of value for money. While the meat offerings may not necessarily conform to the lofty standards of haute cuisine, they are by no means inferior, with each dish showcasing a distinct flavor profile that is sure to satiate even the most discerning of diners. An ideal venue for a satisfying repast, especially given the reasonable prices, this restaurant is a veritable gem in the culinary landscape."

"Underwhelming gastronomical experiences were unfortunately abundant during my latest excursion to Montreal, specifically pertaining to the quality of their galettes, which fell short of my expectations and left me feeling disenchanted; however, it is worth mentioning that my local acquaintance, upon learning of my disappointment, responded with an air of vindication, stating 'I told you so'; nonetheless, it would be remiss of me not to acknowledge the establishment's proficiency in their dessert offerings, particularly those featuring chocolate, which Juliette et Chocolat executes with a certain degree of competence, thereby making them a viable option for those seeking sweet indulgences, but it is advisable to exercise caution when considering their dinner selections."

This is small quaint place that sells pizza by the slice or the whole pie if you wish. 

This is a 1000 times better than Sabarro's but nothing to write home about either.  If you want something quick and cheap, this is a great place. 

If you are waiting for someone to arrive at the airport this is also a great pit stop.

We enjoy happy hour here. The Tuscan Taster appetizers are very good. The spicy shrimp and eggplant varies from time to time in flavor and preparation ie., crispy vs oily. The burger is always a solid choice.  It would be nice for a healthy appetizer option.\nYou need to stick with the happy hour drinks or else your tab gets sky high quickly.\nAt the San Tan location, the blonde bar manager is efficient but super serious and curt.  We always leave satisfied but not thrilled.
Wow. Can't believe this location is closed. I was not aware that it had and tried to stop by to grab some lunch to take back to the office. What a disappointment.

"Although my dining experience was generally satisfactory, I must express my reservations regarding the pricing policy implemented by this establishment. Specifically, the cost of the menu items appears to be disproportionate to the portion sizes, with the smallest sandwich and two accompanying sides amounting to a total of $11, an exorbitant sum that may deter potential patrons, particularly those with families to support. Furthermore, the additional fee of $1.99 for each drink, albeit a nominal amount, contributes to an overall sense of dissatisfaction with the value received for the price paid. In light of these concerns, it is suggested that management consider adopting a buffet-style format or increasing the quantity of food provided to justify the cost. Notwithstanding the aforementioned criticisms, the culinary quality of the dishes served did meet my expectations."

The food is good....selection is ok.  The service is good. It is WAY loud ALL of the time.  I understand that it is more of a sprots bar kinda feel but not being able to hear the waitress was a little frustrating/\nWe will go back I am sure of it.

I haven't stayed here but I've been inside. Hotel looks really nice. Nice lobby and very well decorated. Its located at a descent location on the Strip. However, their casino isn't the best. If you are a gambler, might wanna hit up some other casinos.

Good place, but i was kind of annoyed how my friends got there orders way before i did , and i ordered it right when we walked in i was starving and they take a while to decide what they would like to order , spicy mayo , is just straight up mayo and spiracha which was weird because i have always ordered it at diffrent locations and its actually there own take on a sauce not a blob of mayo with spiracha on the side -_- , eel sauce was alright , there rainbow roll was delicious and eel roll , my friends were also happy with what they ordered which was arizona roll , crunch roll , and a caifornia shrimp tempura roll , it was good over all , but im a sauce person , and they were clearly lacking in that =]

My sister and I headed over here last week and I have to say, I was a little mixed about our visit.

When we first walked in, there was no one there. Literally. We were eye'ing the ice creams for almost 5 minutes before the server drifted in from the Z Pizza side.

I had the Pink Spot sundae with two ginormous scoops of kona coffee and hot fudge. The ice cream was meh, but the hot fudge was very good and served in generous portion. My sister had the low-fat coffee with ribbons of chocolate and she raved.

The prices weren't outrageous considering the serving size; just one week before I spent three dollars more for the same exact thing at Mary Coyle's.

I wasn't overly impressed with the ice cream, but they get props for always having at least one low fat, sugar free, or sorbet offering.

It probably wouldn't be my first choice for ice cream, but because they are in the neighborhood they get a gold star for convenience!

It required a considerable amount of time for me to deliberate on whether to confer 2 or 3 stars upon Diablo's. Ultimately, I opted for the latter rating, as most establishments of a similar caliber in Las Vegas tend to be quite pricey, and Diablo's offered delectable cuisine in generous portions. However, the service we received was utterly reprehensibleâthe epitome of poor hospitality. Our server, during her brief appearances, exhibited blatant rudeness, seemingly intentionally. She displayed exasperation with my companion simply because they requested fresh cheese on their nachos instead of both fresh and processed cheese. The waitress heaved a heavy sigh and responded in an annoyed tone, âItâs NOT going to taste the same,â?while rolling her eyes. Additionally, she grumbled, âWell, what do you want?â?when taking our order, without so much as a greeting or acknowledging our presence. The entire dining experience was plagued by an array of unacceptable delays; our orders were not taken for at least 30 minutes, despite the restaurant being relatively unoccupied. Furthermore, it took over 90 minutes for our meals to arrive, followed by another 30 minutes to receive the check. A planned quick meal for five individuals turned into an excruciating, three-hour ordeal. One star for the abysmal service; five stars for the scrumptious food; and 2.5 stars for the questionable value.

I have had the privilege of visiting The Joint on three separate occasions, with the first instance being in the original venue and the subsequent two times in its newer, expanded iteration. In my opinion, the current layout of the Joint features a well-designed flow of people in and out, although I am perplexed as to why they opted against installing a reversible escalator, which would have enabled a portion of the crowd to descend via escalator and the remainder by stairs.

During my most recent visit to witness a performance by the legendary rock band KISS, I was seated in the balcony section. To my surprise, I found the balcony seating to be significantly more enjoyable than the floor seating, primarily due to the fact that the latter was characterized by an overwhelming sense of claustrophobia, with attendees packed tightly together like sardines. In contrast, the balcony offered plush, theatre-style seating that afforded me a high degree of comfort throughout the duration of the show.

The Joint's sound and lighting systems are truly exceptional, and KISS's elaborate pyrotechnic effects were accentuated by the superb lighting. One minor drawback was that the catwalk, while providing an excellent vantage point for certain sections of the audience, obstructed the view of the stage for some unfortunate individuals.

While there are only a select few performances that I would deem worthy of attendance at The Joint, I would certainly consider returning, provided that I could secure a table seat situated on one of the side balconies. This, in my estimation, would provide the optimal viewing experience.

As a final note, I highly recommend parking in the Paradise garage, as it offers effortless access to The Joint.

"Neglect the gaming establishment where your financial resources incur significant damage; instead, focus on the venue where your physical form endures substantial discomfort. However, prior to casting blame, direct your gaze towards the reflective surface in front of you, for it is there that you will find the root cause of your current predicament. Indulge in an array of delectable dishes, including leg of lamb, prime rib, wild boar, kalbi ribs, spicy shrimp, macaroni and cheese, gnocchi, assorted cheeses, salads, artisanal breads, and an abundance of other culinary delights that are too numerous to list. Furthermore, be cognizant of the fact that your consumption habits are under constant surveillance by an unseen observer, who is undoubtedly monitoring your every move with great interest. Consequently, it would be wise to pace oneself with a sense of decorum and moderation."

This eatery has experienced fluctuations in quality, possessing an ambiance that exudes a charming, antiquated charm, particularly during the evening hours, rendering it an ideal setting for a romantic escapade. The culinary offerings are merely adequate, with prices that could be considered somewhat steep, and portion sizes that are either generous or suitable for sharing. However, the primary drawback of this establishment lies in its sluggish, unreliable, and unremarkable service, which significantly detracts from the overall dining experience, warranting a rating of two and a half stars. It is advisable to visit this restaurant on a bustling date night when they have an event scheduled, as it may enhance the experience. Nonetheless, it is not recommended to visit solely for a speedy lunch or for the food itself, given its subpar quality and lackluster service. Despite these shortcomings, the venue boasts a unique, vintage Vegas atmosphere and offers alcoholic beverages, making it a feasible choice for those seeking a nostalgic dining experience.

Decent bubble tea, surly service.  Got a ginger milk tea and asked what type of jelly they have (Didn't see any selections on the menu or on the board).  The woman at the register gave me a really dirty and annoyed look, and said \"What type are you looking for???\".... Not sure why that would cause such annoyance?  Anyways, my ginger milk tea with lychee jelly was OK, a bit too mild for me (just a hint of ginger flavor), and a bit too sweet.  Plus, it was WARM in there!  Please put the A/C on!  (Maybe that's why the cashier was so surly, I would be grumpy in such a warm store too if I had to be in there all the time!)
got two chocolate croissants and 1 mini cake..  \n\nIf i'm paying 2-3 dollar for a croissants at least enough chocolate for taste.

Mr. Lucky's does not possess any extraordinary attributes or distinguishing features, with the exception of their covertly offered $7.77 Special, which comprises a triumvirate of savory elements, including a fresh garden salad, succulent steak, and delectable shrimp, all served in conjunction with a generous portion of creamy mashed potatoes, thereby providing a gratifying dining experience at an eminently reasonable cost, particularly when compared to the prices charged by neighboring establishments, and furthermore, its accessibility is augmented by the fact that it remains open on a continuous basis, twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, rendering it an ideal refuge for those seeking a satisfying repast during the late hours of the night or early morning, when the majority of other eateries have ceased operation. The rationale behind patronizing Mr. Lucky's resides primarily in the aforementioned $7.77 Special, as evidenced by the preponderance of positive testimonials from contented clientele who have availed themselves of this culinary gem.

Thai Basil is alright, not great but alright. I ordered the Pad-see-ew and the weirdest thing is that the noodles were tasty and delicious but all the veggies and chicken were pretty well tasteless. Plus, my medium to hot dish was much more mild to no spice. 

However, my iced Thai coffee was delicious and the service was very friendly, they even went to find me when I stepped out to Tops while waiting. Also, the the prices are very reasonable, my whole meal was less than 10 bucks.

So, ok for now, I'll try some more dishes and hopefully be more excited.

"It is with profound dismay that I recently traversed past the erstwhile DD establishment, only to be met with an eerie silence and a conspicuous absence of the customary bustling activity that had once been its hallmark, leading me to infer that it has unfortunately succumbed to the pervasive economic downturn and joined the ranks of the innumerable businesses that have fallen prey to the relentless ravages of fiscal instability; a truly lamentable turn of events, indeed."

"The mere mention of the term 'waterfall' conjures up images of a veritable oasis amidst an ocean of inebriated revelers, rendering Tryst utterly remarkable. Its inherent allure was such that even the most incapacitated patrons were unable to navigate their surroundings with any semblance of coherence, rendering mobility a futile endeavor. My associates and I were extended an invitation to partake in a table replete with bottle service, whereupon we lingered for a brief interval before opting to vacate the premises. However, the male individual responsible for the table in question, motivated by a desire to perpetuate our presence, purloined our purses, thus prompting an arduous quest to retrieve them. Following a protracted duration, a security personnel, cognizant of our plight, restored our belongings, accompanied by a tacit admonition to appreciate their return, sans further scrutiny. Subsequently, a member of the group occupying the table in question, in a purportedly fortuitous turn of events, discovered my companion's camera concealed within his attire. This sequence of events transpired, notwithstanding the club's laudable attributes, which encompassed expedited ingress, complimentary admission for a select number of masculine acquaintances, and an atmosphere conducive to merriment, characterized by the presence of a picturesque waterfall exterior."

"While the cost may be slightly higher than that of other Chinese buffets, the value proposition remains favorable when compared to dining options in New York; thus, I do not have any reservations about patronizing this establishment. The variety of dishes available is satisfactory, and the presence of sushi and Korean cuisine options is a welcome addition. Furthermore, the ability to customize one's own soup is an appealing feature. However, the remaining dishes are rather unremarkable and lack a certain je ne sais quoi. It is unfortunate that the fish dishes tend to be overcooked, but they remain palatable nonetheless. 

Upon observing the behavior of the staff, it became apparent that they were eager for my family and me to vacate our table, perhaps to accommodate other patrons. Nevertheless, I did not perceive any impending scarcity of seating or imminent waitlist, so I chose to take my time and savor the experience without undue haste. 

In conclusion, while not necessarily a standout among its peers, this restaurant holds its own and warrants a revisit, should the opportunity arise."

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the weekend brunch at this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say that the value offered is truly unparalleled. For those who are local and seeking a reasonably priced meal, I highly recommend taking advantage of the special deals available on Mondays and Wednesdays. For a mere $3.99, $4.99, and $6.99, respectively, you can indulge in a delectable breakfast, lunch, or dinner, provided you present your Hilton rewards card and a valid form of local identification.  

The weekend brunch boasts an impressive array of delicacies, including succulent crab legs, savory prime rib, and an assortment of beverages such as beer, wine, and on certain days, champagne. In addition to the standard breakfast fare, there is also a made-to-order omelet station, complemented by expertly prepared grilled meats and sausages. While the cuisine may not be considered exotic or sophisticated, it is undoubtedly hearty and satisfying. 

At a mere $18, the opportunity to relish prime rib, cocktail shrimp, and crab legs represents an offer that is simply too good to pass up, particularly for those seeking a respectable weekend brunch buffet without the hefty price tag associated with establishments like the Wynn or Bellagio. Although the service may not always meet the highest standards, it is essential to remember that we are discussing a buffet, and thus, such minor shortcomings can be readily overlooked.

Kinda like a family Italian joint but too bright inside. Food is good enough for what it is and service is sufficient. Food is a 6 on a scale of 1 to 10. Not great not bad. Cutesy place with an \"almost\" feel. Experience it for yourself. You will understand what I mean.

You don't really have to twist my arm to get to me to try a restaurant where pork prepared in any way is the main attraction.  So, when my husband and I had a chance to get away for a meal, I naturally chose Salty Sow.  I wish that I could talk about the wonderful dishes that I had, but they were all only okay.  I had the candied pork belly.  I guess in my head I pictures something somewhat crispy.  I was very wrong.  It's a braised dish.  It's not a bad dish, just not something I would convince me to come back again.

My husband had the lamb burger and I had to sample.  It was pretty good if you enjoy tapenade. It's not really for me.  

Service was good up until we asked for the check.  It felt like a lifetime before it finally arrived, and then it was wrong.

Overall, it was an okay experience.

Okay but the noodles were over cooked and some of the vegetables were frozen,  not fresh as we would have preferred.  It's worth trying but it wasn't the caliber we were hoping for.  We've gone to a few different build your own wok houses in different areas, and this one was just so-so in comparison.

I've shot my share of guns (see http://www.yelp.com/biz/bullseye-precision-indoor-shooting-range-san-rafael). I came here with a bachelor party. We did the $110 package for 12 guys.

The guys running the shop seemed to be arguing with each other a lot. Maybe that's why they like guns? 

Anyways, I thought the guns looked pretty worn out. The ear protection they gave folks using the range sucked, my ears hurt the entire time. We shot the uzi, thompson, two other automatic weapons, and a dessert eagle hand gun. The bachelor shot the grenade launcher, but don't get your hopes up, they don't give you a real grenade, it's more of a shot gun shell fired from a grenade launcher ($35 bucks a shot).

Best quote from the gun store, there always is one... We were selecting a target for the grenade launcher, and pointed at the Ossama Bin Ladin poster. The guy from the store says, "you mean Obama poster?"

Decent place to bring a group of guys looking to get out of the casinos. I recommend getting a limo for a big group since it's hard to get cabs back from this place.

"The sibling of my spouse and his consort were temporarily residing in our city and expressed a desire to partake of the culinary offerings at RigaTony's, as they had a acquaintance who frequently visits the establishment and speaks highly of it. My spouse and I had not indulged in a meal at this particular venue for an extended period of time, primarily due to the fact that we have been frequenting Olive Garden, largely owing to the fact that I acquire gift cards valued at twenty-five dollars through my professional endeavors. However, upon experiencing the delectable fare provided by RigaTony's, it shall undoubtedly become our preferred dining destination when we are financially independent and seeking a satisfying repast and salad. The marginally elevated cost per menu item is more than justified by the superior quality of the cuisine. Personally, I opted for the poultry dish infused with lemon and artichoke, which I found to be utterly delectable. Their house salad is also quite impressive, and one of my associates from my bunco group customarily orders it when she has the opportunity to act as hostess. My spouse not only appreciated the bread accompanying the salad but also relished the lasagna he selected as his main course...up until a later point in the evening when he experienced a sudden onset of severe acid reflux. Unfortunately, the natural consequences of aging can be rather unpleasant. Despite my persistent efforts to persuade him otherwise, my stubborn companion refused to sample my crystallized ginger remedy, which has proven to be remarkably effective in alleviating such digestive issues. Instead, he elected to forgo this potential solution. Following our satisfying dining experience, we decided to conclude the evening with a visit to Angel Sweet, where we indulged in an assortment of delectable treats."

This place is showing its age. I went to see Avatar in their Imax theater and the seats were pretty banged up and the movie crapped out as it was starting due to some technical difficulties. It took a good 10-15 minutes before they fixed the problem and restarted the movie. I do have to say that as far as movie theater food goes, their hot dog and nachos are decent.

"The sushi exhibited an unexpected level of culinary excellence, surpassing my preconceived notions of its quality. However, the remaining items on the menu failed to impress, with their flavors and presentation falling short of my expectations. Despite this disparity, the establishment's maintenance of cleanliness and proficient service remained commendable. Although it does not compare to a luxurious five-star dining experience, my visit was significantly more enjoyable than that of the previous patrons. Considering the vast array of options available, I would unhesitatingly endorse this venue for large gatherings, particularly those comprising children."

"The visual spectacle was captivating, as the female performers exhibited their proficiency in dance, but it appeared that the screenwriters had indulged in some form of substance when conceptualizing the narrative, while Mickey, among the actors, was the most entertaining."

So-so Mexican food.  I have heard people raving about this place and I don't really get it.  Don't get me wrong, it's better than Manuel's or Filiberto's... but that's about all I can say.

Okay, their Pollo Fundido is good (but not great like you will get at Ajo Al's). But let's talk about the purple and teal accent colors that scream "I was remodeled in the 80's"! Lame.

Good chips and salsa but small-ass bowls! 

Oh, and don't expect to park in their little lot during dinner rush.  Also, the surrounding neighborhood is definatly the ghetto-side of the Moon Valley area.

"Recently, I visited this establishment in conjunction with an acquaintance who possessed a strong desire to consume sustenance from this particular chain, while my own preferences regarding dining locations were decidedly more flexible, as long as nourishment was readily available. 

Upon perusing their revamped menu, I opted for one of their novel, health-oriented selections, specifically the balsamic chicken, while my companion chose a more traditional option, the club sandwich, accompanied by a supplementary green salad and a side of pancakes, the latter of which may seem somewhat incongruous when taken in conjunction with their primary selection. 

Notwithstanding some initial reservations, the culinary offerings proved to be unexpectedly delectable, and the attentiveness of the staff was truly commendable."

Some people will be upset with this review, but when we are asked to write a review, Yelp wants us to be honest right? 
Finally tried out Hash House a go go for lunch yesterday. Had read great reviews and many a celebrity have endorsed it. 
The interior is great and the service is pretty good too. That is why I gave Hash 3 stars, but the food did not appeal that much to me and I consider it forgetable.
I tried the mushroom and goat cheese sandwich and have no complaints about my dish, The potatoes au gratin looked very cheesy, but tasted good as the cheese wasn't not all overpowering as I had expected. My wife tried the chicken and waffles and we both agreed: nothing special! The all white meat chicken and waffles were both too dry and bland and we prefer Roscoe's for sure.  
For the average 'white' person, this food probably tastes great, the presentation looked above par, but for those among us who consider themselves foodies, the wide gamut of Asian food offered in this city is soo much more appealing. And finally their lunch prices are a little high at $38 for two. Again, this is just my honest opinion.

My uncle possesses an eating establishment specializing in barbecued meats that enjoys a certain degree of renown in Memphis, Tennessee; thus, I habitually approach barbecue-related culinary experiences with a heightened sense of skepticism and critical scrutiny. Although my sampling of their offerings has been limited to a pair of sandwiches - specifically, the pulled pork and barbecue chicken breast varieties - I must admit that both exhibited commendable quality, extending even to the bread upon which they were served, which was satisfyingly tasteful without being excessively substantial. However, I did notice the absence of chopped egg in the potato salad accompaniment, a detail that struck me as somewhat conspicuous. Furthermore, my visual perception was tantalized by the delectable appearance of certain dessert items borne by fellow patrons, which unfortunately remained beyond my epicurean reach. Ultimately, the veritable litmus test for any barbecue venue lies in its proficiency in preparing ribs, an item I intend to sample during a future visit, at which point I shall furnish an updated assessment. Until then, I bid you adieu, with the expectation that you will indeed return at some point in the future.

This state-of-the-art edifice, boasting an unparalleled standard of culinary excellence, has been erected by the esteemed Taco Bell franchise, renowned for its expedient and attentive service, thereby ensuring a gratifying dining experience for its clientele, who can indulge in a diverse array of delectable and affordable fare, thus cementing the establishment's reputation as a veritable gastronomic haven.

Really great atmosphere, wines, etc... but I didn't think the food was very good, so I give it only 3 stars.  The bread is very thick and maybe uncooked, no oil.  It was not what I expected.  I was hoping for crunchy bread with creatively delicious toppings.  The toppings are great combinations, just not executed like I expected.  I thought the bruschetta would be warm, but instead it was cold, nothing melded, and the bread was very large.  Great concept, but I don't get all the great reviews.

basic food, nothing special, but all tasted good.  Limited menu, funny wine selection, no multipuciano, or other usual italian wines.  Just the popular basics.  Right next to Goodwill, but better than you'd expect

This only gets three stars cause the food is amazing! Other then great tasting food, place is very confusing. When you walk in there is a line that no one has any idea what line they are in. The first two are for tacos, but if you want a burrito or fish tacos you have to go to another line.  They tell you to go there but then you pass 10 people and I feel like I'm cutting everyone in line.

Everyone stood and looked at each and was  like what line are we in? Once you get to that line your suppose to be in, they don't speak English.  I ordered a carne asade burrito, and they tried to give it to someone else. I told them that's mine and he said ohhhh, and had to open it, but looked at me weird cause he did not speak English!

I would give them a 1 star but the food is amazing! Great prices too! Just really confusing.  We also came on a Tuesday night and damn if there wasent 50 kids running around up and down making a ton of noise!

If you read all my Yelp reviews so far, you will find that the majority of them cover barbecue joints. Yes, we like barbecue. My wife and I each have a sibling living in Austin, Texas, so we think we know the real deal when we taste it. Dickey's isn't quite that, but it's a nice addition to the Madison 'cue scene and I hope it's here to stay. 

The meats have a good smoke flavor and they're tender, if sometimes overcooked. But that's to be expected in a fast-food/fast-casual place where I'm not sure the meats are smoked in-house daily. They might be smoked elsewhere and delivered, but for the price, that's OK. The ribs and brisket are worth ordering. The chicken is a grilled breast you can get anywhere.

The sauces (original, spicy), are served hot, just like in Texas, and they're of that thinner, Texas consistency. I like them. The option to top your meal with jalapenos and onions is also very Texas-like, but the smoked sausage isn't. The slaw and potato salad are decent sides; the others are unremarkable. 

Dickey's offers free soft-serve ice cream where the most clever among us can make a root beer float in our big yellow drink cups. Kids eat free on Sundays with each adult meal purchased. We are always satisfied when we leave. What more can you expect for under $20?

We have been patronizing the Dragon Noodle for an extensive period of time, and our experiences have been rather inconsistent. While the culinary offerings are generally satisfactory, the prices are somewhat elevated and the service is merely adequate. In concurrence with certain fellow Yelpers, we have found that the ambiance in the rear section of the establishment tends to be somewhat melancholy. Prior to the renovation, the atmosphere was more convivial, with kitschy embellishments and souvenir t-shirts available for purchase. 
  Following a prolonged day at a trade exhibition, we seek to unwind and avoid venturing excessively far from our lodgings. The Dragon Noodle is rarely crowded, thereby enabling us to secure a table for any size gathering with minimal difficulty. 
  Our preferences lean towards the Chinese menu, as the sushi options appear overly pricey and our previous experiences with them have been underwhelming. Specifically, we enjoy the Kung Pao Chicken, Mongolian Beef, and Wonton Soup. During a recent visit by a group of six, the total cost was approximately $140.

I dined here on a recent trip to Vegas.

I had the Kobe beef sliders.  They were ok, but not worth the $13 I paid for them.  (Side note:  My friend almost got sick from eating them because they were too rich for her liking.)  I also had their Shichimi fries.  Those were good - nice & spicy.  Also had some Yukon Gold mashers, and those were good too.

They poured decent cocktails.  

I would probably go here again next time I go to Vegas if I am hungry and in the area.

"I recently attended a networking event at this establishment, and while the ambiance was pleasant, the culinary offerings left much to be desired. Despite the happy hour special, the quesadilla my companion ordered was unremarkable, and the menu options, including the flatbread and parmesan, failed to impress. However, the moscow mule I ordered was satisfactory. The outdoor patio area was charming, providing an idyllic setting for enjoying a glass of wine on a balmy evening. To provide a comprehensive assessment, I would need to sample more of the primary dishes, as the appetizers and wings were underwhelming. In conclusion, while Kitchen 56 may not be a standout in terms of cuisine, it could still warrant a visit if one is in the vicinity and seeking a casual dining experience."

"It is not advisable to harbor lofty expectations regarding establishments serving culinary delights along the primary thoroughfare catering to visitors, as these eateries tend to exhibit elevated pricing and subpar hospitality, though this may merely be a personal observation. We initiated our gastronomic excursion by sampling an assortment of artisanal cheeses, featuring four regional varieties whose appellations escape my memory, with the exception of the ubiquitous brie, and I must confess that I derived considerable pleasure from the unfamiliar specimens, particularly the tangy goat cheese iteration. Our party opted for a diverse array of principal courses, including pasta Arrabbiata, which I inexplicably selected, and it conformed to my expectations of mediocrity. The remaining members of our group chose mussels and a quarter chicken, respectively, and while the portion sizes were satisfactory, the fare itself proved unremarkable."

I am a hertz gold member so i always go straight to the gold check in area. This location is hit or miss. Sometimes they are very good and the car i have requested is ready to go and easy to pick up and go. Other times they have given me cars that either had too much mileage, one time a car that looked like it had been driven thru rocks, another a car with stickers on it. Also, they are sticklers about the gas tank being full. Due to this fact i always fill right by the airport now. Always check to make sure the car they give you is acceptable and dont be afraid to ask for another one if there is a problem. And check the tire tread. Otherwise the gold service is useful especially when the regular counter line is long.

Today, my hasty movements propelled me towards various destinations, and my stomach yearned for a quick culinary satisfaction.  Given my lack of enthusiasm for burgers, I opted for the convenience of Panda Express.  Although my expectations were not utterly disillusioned, the meal did not qualify as an epicurean experience.  A single staff member attended both the cash register and food service, resulting in a brief delay (during which said employee appeared somewhat harried by the multitude of tasks they faced).  It is plausible that another worker was on hiatus, as a second individual was present upon my departure.  Despite this, the eatery maintained a commendable level of cleanliness, albeit with a few empty stations for utensils and paper products.  The fare, however, exhibited freshness and an agreeable flavor profile, as I had anticipated.  My selection included a two-item combination featuring fried rice, beef and broccoli, and string bean chicken, supplemented by a chicken egg roll.  Families, solo patrons, and couples also partook in repasts within the establishment, and their contentment with their meals was palpable.

Sep 25 2011 2:10 pm

1 item lunch combo -$5.50
Comes with soup, entree, appetizer 

Red curry- 3/5 little too oily for a Thai dish
Garlic and pepper stir fry -3.5/5

2 Thai iced tea- 4.5/5

Customer service- 4.5/5

Stopped in here for lunch today, joined by Arlin B, Robyn N & Mike C.  Scott's was a bit of a disappointment for me this time.  My expensive bowl of Kreplach Soup was lukewarm & only contained one little Kreplach the size of a Ping Pong ball!  Even the smaller cup sized soup should have two or three of them.  My corned beef sandwich was good but the service was only so-so.  Considering all of this and the prices, it's down to 3 Stars this time for Scott's.\n\nCorned Beef Sandwich $10.95, bowl of Kreplach Soup $7.95 (!)

I was drove past there this weekend, and then read yesterday on azcentral.com that they have closed their doors.  I had never dined there but the building & decor looks awesome, huge outdoor patio with a glass enclosed fireplace, guess it's just another sign of the struggling economy....

Maybe it was my long day of travel that got me disoriented, but I couldn't find my way out of the airport when I arrived! I felt like I was wandering around on the lower levels trying to get to the street and was thrown for a loop when confronted with that super-speedy tram. 

Staff was friendly and the facility was clean.

It's an OK airport. You fly in and fly out. Nothing can touch PDX!

My coworker recommended this place so I decided to give it a try. I had the Gyro lunch with fries. It was pretty good, nothing outrageous and I've definitely had better but given the area and it's limited lunch options I can see myself coming back here in the future.\n\nThe restaurant was small and service was friendly. The \"bar\" was awkward; looked like it didn't really belong but I guess it's always great to have the option of enjoying a drink with your meal. I guess I see this more of a quick service dine and dash kind of joint, that's why.

I'm reviewing my rating. After Mor telling me i had to wait for them to come inspect the table (i'm moving dont have time for this) and i left my review, i ended up getting a call the next day from a manager & they actually delivered a brand new table, said the old one turned out to be from a bad batch- 

So overall i'm NOW happy with the customer service- and i'll take their word that it was a bad batch and not bad quality overall.



Old Review: Bought a dinning room granite countertop table from here, within 6 months the legs are cracking, the marble actually stains real easy from heat. Absolute garbage, $800 wasted

"I requested a spider roll, a lobster roll, and Uni, and upon consuming these delectable dishes, I discovered that the rolls possessed an exquisite flavor, particularly the spider roll, which featured a soft crab that was both fresh and crispy due to the expertise of the culinary artist who prepared it; however, my experience with Uni was somewhat different, as its taste was reminiscent of fish, lacking the expected freshness, leading me to surmise that it may be wise to inquire about the quality of this particular dish before placing an order, thereby ensuring a satisfying culinary experience."

The experience was not utterly dreadful, as the young woman appeared somewhat disinterested and eager to be elsewhere, while the male individual endeavored to captivate her attention with an array of diverse subjects, albeit in a manner that struck this observer as excessively assertive and annoying; nevertheless, his efforts did not particularly impress me, and the quality of their work was merely adequate.

"Although I harbor a certain skepticism towards public car washes as a whole, my recent visit to Classic Car Spa proved to be a refreshing exception to this rule. Not only were there an absence of streaks or droplets on my windows, but also the meticulous attention devoted to buffing the rims of my BMW left me feeling truly satisfied. Opting for the comprehensive package, which encompassed a thorough cleaning of both the vehicle's exterior and interior, I was impressed by the staff's fastidiousness. It is worth mentioning that my modest Z4 happened to be the most economical automobile in the queue, surrounded by an array of luxury SUVs, a Porsche Panamera, and even a Maserati. Such an assemblage of high-end vehicles served as a poignant reminder that, were I able to afford the latter, I likely would have had the means to engage the services of a professional detailer to come to my residence and pamper my car for me."

I am originally from New York City, where the Chinese cuisine is of superior quality and reigns supreme, and when I relocated to this region, it was a challenge to discover anything that could compare to the exceptional culinary standards that I had become accustomed to in the city that never sleeps. While China Red cannot be considered an exact replica of the remarkable Chinese restaurants found in the Big Apple, it undoubtedly comes close to satisfying my cravings for delicious and authentic Sino-American dishes. The generous portions, rich flavors, and delectable egg drop soup are all factors that contribute to making this establishment a top choice among local diners seeking a taste of the Far East. Furthermore, China Red offers reasonable lunch specials, which provide customers with an unbeatable value of two meals' worth of food for approximately six dollars. Additionally, the restaurant provides delivery services, a convenience that is uncommon in the Arizona area, thereby making it a standout among its competitors.

We went this past Sun and overall had a great time. My only issue, and why I'm on Yelp, is the food. Just horrible and way, way, way overpriced.
I would suggest spend the extra $10 for preferred parking and bring a cooler. Don't buy any food in the park. Out of desperation my sons a I had 2 slices with 2 breadsticks. Survey says-I've had MREs that tasted better.
                              Oh yeah, $14 by the way.
Preferred parking is only $10. Bring your own chow and have a great time.

"SSSSSsssssshhhhhhhhhhh.............. DON'T TELL ANYONE. I have an affinity for Hooters. 

Consequently, allow me to elaborate on the narrative: We had reserved a remarkable bargain at the Hilton; however, it was merely for two nights. We required a place to stay for our final night in Las Vegas and desired a cost-effective and proximate location to the airport due to our extremely early departure. Hooters corresponded to our requirements. Positioned at the southernmost point of the strip, the taxi ride to McCarran is relatively brief. Although it lacks luxury, there are affordable rooms available, and the staff member at the registration desk was incredibly cordial. We requested a nonsmoking king room situated on a higher floor, and he accommodated us with an impressive panorama of the Tropicana, Excalibur, and the roller coaster at New York New York. The lodging was fundamental, yet acceptable. 

We traversed the street to the MGM for the majority of the day. 

Later in the evening, we returned to the Hooters Casino, and surprisingly, we experienced immense enjoyment! The minimum wagers are minimal, permitting a genuine sense of recreation. The ambiance is more relaxed compared to the high-stakes casinos, and the clientele is youthful, eliminating the pressure to be a seasoned player. Frankly, I am not a dedicated gambler, nor would I desire to be, so the environment at Hooters aligned perfectly with my preferences."

Bacchanal's culinary offerings are satisfactory, boasting an array of diverse stations that cater to various gastronomic inclinations. However, it is worth mentioning that nothing particularly extraordinary or memorable was encountered during my visit, with the exception of the unique dessert options such as the orange beer sorbet and mango habanero gelato, which exhibited a distinct departure from the norm and possessed a palpable fiery quality. 
The crab leg offerings, both hot and cold, were adequate, benefiting from the convenience of being plated for ease of consumption and limiting the potential for overindulgence by fellow patrons. Unfortunately, the absence of dungeness crab was a notable disappointment. The prime rib and lamb chops, while satisfying, failed to leave a lasting impression, with the latter being slightly saltier than expected. Noteworthy mentions include the flavorsome Chinese chicken wings, though marred by a perceptible excess of sodium, and the unimpressive oysters, whose lack of freshness was readily apparent to seasoned consumers. To avoid prolonged waiting times, it is advisable to visit during off-peak hours, with seating times ranging from 30 to 45 minutes.

"This critique pertains to the Tiffany Showroom and its latest production, 'Yesterday - A Tribute to the Beatles.' The showroom's interior boasts three distinct levels, each offering a unique seating arrangement. The uppermost tier features individual chairs and a smattering of diminutive round tables, while the middle level is appointed with banquettes and chairs. Lastly, the floor level offers an array of seating options, including two rows of banquettes and several minuscule table settings. The stage, of considerable proportions, benefits from exceptional acoustics and illumination, courtesy of the meticulous planning that has gone into this homage. The performance itself is characterized by the vocal prowess and instrumental proficiency of the male cast members, who excel when harmonizing. However, during solo passages, the sound deviates slightly from the iconic Beatles' sonic signature, albeit momentarily. The duration of the show approximates sixty minutes, leaving this reviewer with a desire to assign a rating midway between three and four stars, given the minor inconsistencies in the performance."

"Indulge Burger is an establishment that offers a pleasurable dining experience, where customers can partake in delectable culinary creations and enjoy a convivial ambiance. This eatery boasts a pet-friendly environment, with water receptacles positioned external to the dining area, thereby accommodating canine companions. Our initial visit to this venue was precipitated by the receipt of a promotional document, which we discovered in our postal receptacle. Subsequently, we have returned on multiple occasions, at intervals of several months. The fare served at this establishment is of considerable quality and diversity, featuring an array of options. Particularly noteworthy are the sweet potato fries, onion strings, and garlic chips, which elicit praise from patrons. The burgers, priced between $10 and $14, are substantial, constituting half a pound of savory meat. It is essential to note that coupons may be available, thus it is advisable to seek them out prior to visiting this restaurant. Furthermore, I have recently become aware of a current promotion offered by Yelp, whereby customers can acquire $30 worth of food and drinks at Indulge Burger & More for the sum of $15."

"The Cajun Queen constitutes a veritable epicurean haven for yours truly, boasting an exceptional level of service, particularly within the confines of its convivial bar area. The ambiance, suffused with the melodious strains of live Dixieland jazz, contributes significantly to the establishment's overall appeal. However, a recurring concern has arisen during my numerous visits to this esteemed eatery, pertaining to the kitchen staff's proclivity for imbuing their dishes with an excessive degree of piquancy, seemingly under the assumption that such an approach is intrinsic to the Cajun culinary tradition. Alas, this strategy often results in certain menu items being overwhelmed by an oppressive heat, thereby obfuscating their inherent flavors. A case in point is the crawfish scampi appetizer, which, in its traditional preparation, relies on a subtle infusion of garlic, herbs, and, on occasion, a judicious sprinkling of red pepper flakes to enhance the delicate taste of the shellfish. Unfortunately, the Cajun Queen's interpretation of this dish involves an egregious application of chili, effectively subsuming the crawfish's natural sweetness beneath a fiery blanket of spice. Furthermore, this penchant for extreme seasoning renders the scampi eerily reminiscent of the etouffee, a dish that is intentionally designed to showcase a more pronounced level of heat. Were the culinary artisans at the Cajun Queen to display a modicum of restraint in their utilization of Cajun spices, a greater balance of flavors might be achieved, thereby elevating the gastronomical experience to an even loftier plane of satisfaction."

The food is pretty good for a chain restaurant.  The prices are very reasonable and portions are huge.  I ordered the Chicken Katsu with a side of gravy fries...hit the spot!  Katsu curry had corn in it; guess that's Hawaiian style? Fires were the best, but only mediocre, would be better if gravy had more richness to it.  It's not the best I've ever had but far from the worst.\n\n-I'm still really confused as to why they don't redecorate.  The entire outside and interior resembles a 50's diner...it's been like this since they opened and hasn't changed.  It would be more comfortable if they could change the decor and clean it up a bit; the right side of the restaurant has been under renovations for some time now and looks really shabby.

This place was far from where my friend stayed (West Side), but it was worth a trek out.  The place is clean and the food is made fairly quickly even with the lunch crowd.  On a hot day, you can sit outside under the misters, but I'm from Cali, so this AZ heat it not for me, even under the misters.

Food: Fontina burger with blue cheese was fresh.  The burger was juicy and full of flavor.  The blue cheese definitely enhanced it.  I like the different options for your sides.  The garlic fried were a big too greasy.  The beet salad is a nice refreshing touch.  The strawberry cheesecake from scratch that is not on the menu was just OK.  The fried okra was overly fried.  The BBQ pork sandwich looked tasty and my friend enjoyed it.  

Bottom line: I enjoyed the food and it's worth a try.

This critique pertains to the eatery situated on the upper level:

Upon partaking in the culinary offerings of this establishment, my sentiment can best be described as a profound sense of indifference, verging on utter disappointment, owing to the fact that, despite a few notable exceptions, such as the pork belly, salmon, and beef tartare, which demonstrated a modicum of gastronomical prowess, the majority of the dishes served were, regrettably, forgettable to an alarming degree.

Furthermore, our server, seemingly obsessed with maximizing our expenditure, adopted an overzealous approach, bordering on the impertinent, by insisting we commence our repast with a copious quantity of oysters, twenty-four to be precise, in addition to interpolating several ounces of wagyu beef into the meal, an suggestion that struck me as not only superfluous but also utterly preposterous.

In conclusion, given the plethora of superior dining options available in Las Vegas, it is my conviction that one would be ill-advised to allocate their resources towards experiencing the culinary endeavors of this particular restaurant, upstairs or otherwise.

"This establishment served as a recurrent destination during my formative years in Las Vegas, as it offered an economical and convenient dining experience, allowing me to indulge in their culinary offerings without incurring exorbitant costs. My recent visit proved to be a satisfying encounter, with their rendition of steak and eggs exemplifying the quintessential breakfast staple. However, I must deduct a star from my overall rating due to the price point of $20, which seems somewhat excessive in light of the local standards. Nonetheless, I must commend the attentive service rendered by our server, who graciously provided a bottle of Heinz 57 sauce upon request."

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on three or four separate occasions, and while my initial inclination would have been to bestow upon it a rating of four stars, subsequent visits have led me to reevaluate this assessment. Specifically, I have come to realize that certain aspects of the dining experience do not quite warrant such a lofty rating. Notwithstanding, the selection of beverages available is truly impressive and merits high praise, particularly in light of the presence of Triple Karmeliet, which holds a special place in my heart as my preferred libation. Furthermore, the culinary offerings are also quite satisfactory, with the Hawaiian pizza being a particular highlight and a testament to the kitchen's proficiency. However, it must be noted that the cost of dining at this establishment can become somewhat prohibitive, particularly for an extended duration, and this serves as the sole point of contention in an otherwise pleasant experience. Despite this minor drawback, I remain confident that I will return to this venue in the near future, as the ambiance and musical accompaniment are both thoroughly enjoyable.

Ate with a client here today for the first time. Really enjoyed the yellow curry dish medium and the soup that comes before the meal, but the service was slow. It took 16 minutes for my entree to come, although after it came many employees asked if I wanted a drink refill.\n\nNice decor and decent prices

3 1/2 STARS

This is Marriott's TIME-SHARE complex across from their luxury hotel. We traded a time-share for a week here in May. I must say, the place was packed - it appeared to be fully occupied.

Our room was small but just fine for us. The employees were all friendly and the grounds were kept in good shape.

We found this to be a good place to use as a base for a week's holiday while taking day-trips to the Grand Canyon, Sedona, Prescott, Scottsdale, the Phoenix Botanical Garden, and so on...

I would say this place is pretty much like every other nail salon in Charlotte.  The fumes greet you at the door, they have you pick your color, they point to the chair they want you to sit in, they stare at you and smile, attempting to connect with the few English words they know, they do a decent job and slap you with a bill.  Sound familiar?  That was my experience.  It wasn't bad, it wasn't amazing, it was just....familiar.  They did have a very nice selection of colors which was nice but nothing else stood out to me.  They were friendly enough and priced the same as everyone else.  They did a nice job on my cuticles which other places have not been as detailed.  I would come back.

If Spearmint Rhino and Treasures were to be considered siblings in the realm of adult entertainment, it would be analogous to comparing Charlie Sheen and Emilio Estevez, where Spearmint Rhino embodies the unbridled and riotous spirit of Charlie Sheen, while Treasures assumes the role of Emilio Estevez, lacking the pizzazz and excitement of its counterpart, despite offering a comparatively economical bottle service experience.

My family and I serendipitously encountered this establishment while perusing the retail offerings in Townsquare, and upon entering, we were immediately captivated by the aesthetically pleasing ambiance. Our attention was graciously captured by an exceptional waitress who informed us that the duration of the happy hour was rapidly approaching its culmination, with only twelve minutes remaining until the prices would increase exponentially. In light of this information, we unanimously decided to expedite our order, ensuring that we could partake in the discounted beverages prior to their transformation into double the original cost. However, much to our dismay, the bar manager, Jessica, declined our request, maintaining that the designated time frame for happy hour had already elapsed. Despite this setback, we opted to continue dining at this location, investing $160.00 in delectable cuisine that thoroughly satiated our palates. The impeccable service we received further enhanced our dining experience, yet unfortunately, the actions of Jessica left an indelible impression, precluding us from future visits. As an ardent patron, I habitually demonstrate loyalty towards establishments that cater to my preferences, frequently returning with my acquaintances and loved ones; regrettably, the $18 saved does not justify the relinquishment of our custom.

This minuscule canine recreational area, confined to a singular expanse of land adjacent to a baseball field, presents a rather limited scope for canine exercise and socialization, which, in conjunction with its questionable maintenance, renders it an inferior choice for discerning dog owners seeking a suitable venue for their pets. Despite the occasional visit from myself and my spouse during our tenure in the vicinity, the dearth of upkeep and the recent, albeit ineffectual, "renovation" have rendered this park somewhat disappointing, particularly in light of the presence of more well-appointed facilities in the surrounding area. Notwithstanding, its proximity to my place of employment shall continue to facilitate my patronage, though an inclination towards alternative, superior destinations persists.

I had passed this restaurant dozens of time without knowing what magic was behind the plain building. I was very pleasantly surprised upon walking in at around 9pm on a Friday night to see ducks and turtles swimming around. The tables outside were filled with lovers, adding to the romantic ambiance of El Encanto. There was a older gentleman singing Spanish love songs while playing the guitar. It was like another world from the street that we entered from; it almost felt like a secret club for some reason. And I was happy to have found it.\n\nAnyway, on to the food. I shared the pollo fundido with my other half. I wasn't TOO impressed, because I still think X Tapa Joe's has the best Pollo Fundido in town, but the yellow rice that accompanied the dish was superb. Usually, I am disappointed at the dry and bland Mexican rice that comes with entrees. Not here. It tasted like the yellow rice that I make, which is moist and rich in flavor. The margaritas were a bit too sweet but still okay. Overall, I thought it was a great place for a date night as it seeped with romance. I would love to try another dish sometime to give them a higher rating, but so far, the 3 stars I gave it seems right on point.

Although the culinary offerings, vinous delights, and ambiance are all commendable, regretfully, I must express my disappointment. One of my grievances pertains to the intermittent sluggishness in the service, which has hindered my dining experience on multiple occasions. Furthermore, during a recent celebration of a friend's anniversary, the restaurant unfortunately exhausted their supply of edibles, leaving me with an unpleasant sensation akin to having an angel of darkness hovering over my table, poised to extinguish any prospect of satisfaction. Despite my ardent desire to confer a rating of four stars, owing to the undeniable quality of the cuisine and wine, my past distressing encounter compels me to assign a rating that falls short of excellence. Perhaps, in the future, I shall have the opportunity to revise my appraisal, reflecting the true potential of this establishment.

"As a resident of the surrounding area, I recently had the opportunity to visit this establishment and witnessed a portion of its promotional presentation. My initial impression was that the club card perks were somewhat mediocre, yet still managed to pique my interest upon signing up. The gaming selection featured an agreeable balance of contemporary and vintage machines, which catered to my penchant for more intimate gambling venues. Although my own gaming experience was relatively unremarkable, my spouse enjoyed a streak of good fortune. We opted to utilize the provided coupons and sample the culinary offerings at the on-site deli. The breakfast special I ordered was satisfying, with a generous serving of fresh tomatoes, crispy bacon, and a warm, toasted muffin. My spouse's burger was equally impressive, boasting a juicy patty, crisp lettuce, and flavorful tomatoes, accompanied by a side of golden fries that were cooked to a perfect crispiness. While the quality of the food was undeniably impressive, the true test of consistency lies in future visits."

"On a Tuesday (December 18, 2012), we embarked upon a culinary excursion to an Italian eatery in Edinburgh, which, regrettably, did not live up to our expectations in terms of gastronomic excellence. Despite the presence of some delectable antipasti, the crostini unfortunately exhibited a discernible staleness, thus somewhat diminishing our overall satisfaction. However, the pork belly proved to be a redeeming factor, boasting tenderness and flavor, while the roast potatoes were cooked to perfection, earning them high praise. Unfortunately, the chocolate tart that followed left much to be desired, as its richness bordered on overwhelming. Notwithstanding the shortcomings in the food department, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a certain charm and appeal, rendering it an enjoyable experience for all. Nevertheless, in light of the middling quality of the fare, it remains uncertain whether a return visit would be warranted, especially when considering the abundance of superior, family-run establishments in the vicinity, such as Nonna's in Morningside, which undoubtedly outshine their competitors in terms of sheer excellence."

Is a pretty large storage facility with a lot of different size units. The facility is pretty clean. I use it to store files so I have the smaller unit they offer.  People in the office seem pretty nice. My only complaints I have are how much dust gets into the units and how far away it is from my house.  They could use better doors to seal out the dust.

I was driving through downtown Chandler and spotted this free standing location, the first I've ever seen for a JJs. 

It's the usual Jimmy John's faire, but slightly less expensive ('bout 50 cents) than their Chandler Fashion location. Now I love JJs, but I need to take them down a half star for all the nonsense going on inside the store.  

It's very much like the old high school cafeteria. Employees yelling at each other, goofing around and tunes dial up to ear splitting decibels, which makes it hard to enjoy a meal here.

We've all enjoyed high school once, once. Bueller? Bueller? Bueller?

"My predilection for dining at Pei Wei stems from their accommodating policy of enabling adult patrons to order from the children's menu, thereby providing a welcome reprieve from the typically excessive portion sizes that often accompany standard entree selections. Frankly, I find the restaurant's willingness to cater to my dietary requirements and preferences, particularly in regards to rice and sauces, to be a significant factor in my decision to frequent this establishment, rendering it one of the premier options that come to mind when I am in pursuit of satiating my craving for the aforementioned staple.
