However, I must admit that the ambiance of the parking area leaves much to be desired, which unfortunately detracts from the overall experience and precludes me from bestowing an additional star in my rating."

I have been to Toby Keith's a couple of times over the years. The first time was a couple of years ago for a local concert that became ridiculously overcrowded and claustrophobic but I will disregard that initial experience and review only this experience today. I met my mom here for a late lunch around 3pm because we were in the area so it was convenient. Our waitress was really nice and attentive and we wanted to take our time and she didn't have a problem with that.

I ordered a green chili chicken sandwich (with no bun) and a side of coleslaw. My mom had a turkey club sandwich. My chicken was pretty good. It was a little overcooked but it wasn't bad. Nothing to write home about. My mom's turkey club was a HUGE serving and she said it was just okay.

Overall for a midday dining experience we had an okay experience. The food was okay, the service was good. Would I be back? Maybe...

The overall quality of the performance was subpar, failing to meet expectations and commencing tardily, approximately 10 to 15 minutes behind schedule. Notwithstanding, the standup comedian's segment proved to be the most enjoyable aspect of the show, eliciting copious laughter and applause from the audience. However, my attempts to locate her YouTube videos have been futile, thus far. Additionally, certain female performers possessed aesthetic appeal, yet their movements lacked coordination and synchronization, detracting from the overall impact of their performances.

We came here because we had a Restaurant.com certificate to use. It was ok, but nothing special. The taco shells were fresh and made onsite and the chicken was delicious. The rice, however, was mushy. And they used preshredded cheddar cheese. Not very authentic but a nice cheap meal.

This place is located in a pretty low end locals casino but with that said it's a fun spot for a quick & hearty breakfast. It's also super cheap! They have a fully stocked bar so having some cocktails with your breakfast is always a good idea. The menu has a little bit of everything but I think the breakfast options are the tastiest. Service is always great as well!

It's so difficult to pick a place to eat in Vegas with the multitude of options. I guess a packed house, like one is sure to see at Mon Ami, is a good sign.

I found the bread to be stellar and a cute display (served as baguette style, as one would find in France; although in France, they don't have paper bags for their baguettes. I'm just sayin'). I had beef bourguignon and I bet even Julia Chiles would be proud of this version. Although, she might have been disappointed by my noodles that were waaaaaaay too soft.

I'm pretty disappointed by my cocktail. How can a French restaurant mess up a French 75? 

The ambiance was nice with the heaters, the music and the Bellagio fountain show. I did feel a bit crowded on the patio though. There was little space to move. 

All in all, I would like to have my money back to try an equally expensive restaurant with a higher quality food and experience. You know Vegas has it. When you find it, let me know.

Oh Espee, you have gotten way too expensive.  A three item combo is, get this, SIXTEEN DOLLARS!   I can go to a beautiful restaurant like Agave and not pay this price for a taco meal.  And it really seems like the tamales at Espees have gotten smaller.  And the salsa bar is completely disgusting now - what happened to the pico de gallo? \n\nThey still have a pretty good happy hour with 2 for 1 margaritas and half price nachos - but I had to knock down my four star review to a three because of the ridiculous prices and shrinking portions.  Why do order at the counter restaurants try to charge the same prices as a sit down restaurant?

I am fervently desirous of conferring a rating of four stars upon this establishment, as my previous experiences have been largely satisfactory. Upon multiple visits, I have endeavored to sample a variety of items, and each dish has proven to be delectable, to say the least. However, due to my proximity to MTO Cafe, I frequently opt for their delivery services, which regrettably, have proven to be somewhat unreliable, as certain items are often omitted from my order, such as green drinks, salads accompanying chicken and waffles, and side dishes like mashed potatoes, among others. Despite these inconsistencies, the food remains flavorful and nutritious, providing an ideal solution for alleviating hangovers or enjoying a leisurely weekend brunch at home. Furthermore, the recent opening of a second location at the new Summerlin Mall has piqued my interest, and I intend to visit it in the near future.

I have been to many sushi restaurants, cheap to fancy. But at Yokoso, sushi is definitely not their strong point. The sushi pieces were mouthfuls of mostly rice, that too little dry . I ordered a Rainbow Roll and The Pitt Roll. Not good. The prices are OK not very reasonable. I dont know about the other items on the menu, but sushi was meh!\nOnly go here if you are absolutely craving for one.\nBut the service was good and prompt.
The prices are a little high and the food is ok. I have had better pizza. The wings where also ok. The people where nice both times we have eaten there.

Came here a few weeks ago with friends. Breakfast was good, tea was nice, atmosphere ok. I wasn't blown away but I also wasn't disappointed. I love the location and the interior is vintage and original. The outside was ok to have breakfast and enjoy the weather. Moderately priced.

For a place that's supposedly known for wings, it wasn't so good. I was very hungry but couldn't finish the 20 wings I was sharing with my friend. The 10 grilled wings were tossed in this super spicy tangy Cajun sauce. Eeee. Should've had the sauce on the side. The other 10 wings had sauce on the side but the batter was chalky tasting. Eeee.\n\nThe shrimp and spinach salad was good. Tsk. Was so craving good wings though.

Rio De Janeiro

Please add...

*Looser slots 
*Cordial security staff
*More cute shops & under 21 crowd entertainment
*Some much needed glitz & glamor upgrades all around

To your already...

*Delicious seafood buffet
*Spacious rooms
*Fun vibe

...and it'll definitely turn the Rio back into a poppin' place! I'll be back nonetheless (YAY for rewards points).

Solid food, but nothing exciting or different. I'm not sure what kind of theme they are going for, which makes the place lack personality.

Strengths - good wait staff and some good beer options

Downfalls - not sure it is worth the price and nothing too exciting.

I attended this establishment on the occasion of a friend's birthday celebration, whereupon I partook in an assortment of delectable victuals, specifically the soft pretzels accompanied by a savory fondue, which were indeed scrumptious. Our server, though attentive, did not expedite the delivery of our repast and potables with sufficient celerity, unfortunately. Notwithstanding, I thoroughly enjoyed my entree selection, the Sweet Corn Cannelloni, whose rich flavors were abundant and gratifying. Furthermore, I appreciated the diverse vegetarian options available. In addition, we received a complimentary dessert, the Monkey Bread, which, despite its unassuming name, proved to be surprisingly delectable. Moreover, the ambiance of the venue was quite pleasant, characterized by comfortable, uniquely designed chairs at each table and magnificent chandeliers that contributed to an overall sense of elegance. However, certain drawbacks did exist, including an excessive delay in the preparation and service of our meals, an excess of noise, insufficient illumination, and portion sizes that seemed somewhat diminutive relative to the cost.

"It is imperative to note that this preliminary assessment has been lingering in a state of dormancy for an extended period (owing to its designation as a draft that slipped through the cracks of my attention); however, I am unable to revise it at this time. Review 1: 2 stars - Subpar service. A protracted waiting period of approximately six minutes ensued before a staff member appeared to take our order. Upon requesting mayonnaise and ketchup exclusively on the burger, the female server exhibited a condescending demeanor, implying that if we had frequented the establishment previously, we would have been cognizant of the fact that ketchup and mayonnaise were readily available on the table. Consequently, the entire burger was prepared incorrectly due to the server's interruption, coupled with her supercilious attitude. Nonetheless, the second female employee whom I interacted with rectified the issue and displayed a pleasing level of cordiality. Review 2: 4 stars - During my younger sibling's birthday celebration at the bowling alley, we partook of a meal. The quality of the service was satisfactory. The culinary offerings were relatively palatable. In conclusion, a generally agreeable encounter."

Ok, this place can get pricey quick, but if you know how to get \"bang\" for the buck like me you'll be ok.  My friend and I got the Veggie sandwich with extra roast beef.  I really need to invest in a real camera, because what we got was a 5 star Roast beef sandwich for 15 bux.  With Coffee and cake we were under $30 bux for the both of us.  I will say this....if you eat more food than what came out you really need a diet.  It was MORE THAN enough.  Split your food here as its just too much for one person and you don't want to take leftovers back with you do you?  Great sammy, half sour pickle with decent coffee.  Geez the chocolate cake is good.  Fries mehhhh.

"The venue boasts an endearing ambiance, augmented by a spacious outdoor area featuring a bar, thereby creating a picturesque setting conducive to leisurely dining experiences. Upon visiting during the daytime, I opted to sit outside on the synthetic grass, admiring the string lights that would undoubtedly imbue the atmosphere with a captivating charm come nightfall. While the culinary offerings proved satisfactory, they failed to elevate my dining experience to an extraordinary level. Specifically, my garden salad was unremarkable, and my fellow patrons' chicken panini sandwich, though flavorful, featured chicken breast that lacked succulence, while their strawberry salad showcased mushy fruit. However, what truly hindered my enjoyment was the sluggish pace of the service, as we placed our orders expeditiously only to endure an extended wait for our meals to arrive. In light of this, I surmise that addressing the efficiency of their service would be crucial in realizing the establishment's potential, particularly within a locality that lacks similar stylish and contemporary eateries."

"Peruse the menu, select your preference, and prepare your palate for an authentic culinary excursion, as this establishment's commitment to genuine flavors and traditional preparation methods is unwavering. Although linguistic barriers may exist, the staff's hospitable demeanor and willingness to accommodate curious patrons more than compensates for any potential communication difficulties. Indeed, an inquiry regarding the taste of the barbacoa was met with an offer to sample the dish, graciously provided by the attentive server. The robust flavors present in each taco are a testament to the culinary prowess of the kitchen staff, with the chicken variety boasting a satisfying spiciness and the guacamole maintaining a refreshing simplicity, comprised primarily of fresh avocado and a squeeze of lime juice. However, it would be remiss to neglect mentioning the somewhat questionable state of the seating area, characterized by utilitarian metal chairs and worn, torn booth cushions, with the occasional rusty nail protruding from the frame. Despite these shortcomings, the booths remain a preferable option for those opting to dine in. Unfortunately, the quality of the meat leaves something to be desired, thereby precluding this venue from becoming a regular haunt for this writer, who is admittedly particular about such matters. Nonetheless, the unique experience merits documentation and recommendation to intrepid gastronomes seeking an authentic taste of Mexico."

I had a very pleasant dinner at Fleur de Lys last month but nothing wow'ed me.  I ordered from the $59 prix fixe menu, which includes an appetizer, entree and dessert - all in all, a good value!   

I enjoyed the onion soup, served with shaved truffles and duck.  It was rich and earthy with an unexpected presentation.  Next I had gently heated salmon with juilinee vegetables and a green horseradish sauce.  My salmon was perfectly cooked and the dish looked beautiful, but the sauce, frankly tasted like grass clippings!  Bitter and overpowering.  My friend seemed to enjoy her stout braised short ribs.  The dessert, a "trio of chocolates", was a miss: a dry souffle, a salty peanutbutter shake and Baily's ice cream.  None of the desserts really did it for me.  

I may have expected too much from this place, but hey, it's Hu bert Keller's spot!  Who knows, maybe I caught them on a bad night.  I'd like to return some time and give the regular menu a chance, but with so many INCREDIBLE places to eat in Vegas I can't make any guarantees.

PROS: Great service, Great wine and Reasonable prixe fixe menus. 
CONS: Too many 'miss' dishes for a 4 star

Average at best.  I am pretty sure that my buttermilk pancakes, potatoe pancakes, eggs, and sausage links were not cooked enough.  Granted, I recieved my food less than 3 minutes after I ordered but I would have been okay with waiting another 2 minutes for a completely cooked meal.  \n\nMy mom's pancake recipe is much better anyway...

This place gets a 3 star because they've never blown my socks off with anything, but I've never had experience with them that made me want to quit pizza. It's pretty close to my house and my nephew loves pizza so I'm here a decent amount. They're very consistent, very friendly and my food is always ready on time. On the single time my order was messed up, they were very quick about fixing it,  which was majorly appreciated. To be honest I have nothing bad to say about them at all. They get the job done

We ate here on a Thursday night.  To begin, we have a 14 month old son.  Although the restaurant has child seats, it is not a good place for children.  So, we would not recommend taking small children to Steelz.

However, we do recommend eating there.  We started with the crabcakes, which were good but I wanted a little more crispiness on the outside.  This could have been achieved with a little more pan time.  The spicy aioli on the side was great.

I had the brie and bacon burger, which was wonderful.  Good quality bacon and beef, and a soft yet strong bun to hold it together.  Burger juicy and cooked to a proper medium.  It does not come with fries, which was a disappointment.  My wife had the lobster bisque.  This had good flavor, but was too strong on the sherry.  She also had the beef and blue salad, which may have been the star of the evening.  Very good quality blue cheese, we loved this salad.  

We will definitely return.

"Substantially superior to my previous recollection. During our last visit, we partook in breakfast, which was regrettably unpalatable. On this occasion, we opted to sample their dinner offerings. 

A twenty-four hour buffet pass for the reasonable price of forty dollars...an offer that cannot be declined! However, subsequent to the second helping, an overwhelming desire to hasten towards the nearest restroom or secure a quantity of antacids becomes unavoidable. In all seriousness, consuming more than a single buffet within a twenty-four hour period is not recommended for optimal digestive health. Nonetheless, such excesses are customary in Las Vegas...a city where both financial losses and gastronomical indulgences are embraced with equal fervor! 

Our third buffet excursion during our pass was a dinner visit. 

Highlights included: 
CREPES!!! Deliciously soft and fluffy crepes, which I preferred without any additional toppings, aside from a light dusting of powdered sugar. A friendly female attendant skillfully prepared them. The texture was delightfully chewy...I consumed two. *ugh* 

Seafood. A medley of crab, shrimp, mussels, and clams. While not exceptional, it was still adequate. 

Dessert. An extensive array, showcasing the standard assortment of sweets found at most buffets. Although nothing particularly remarkable, it sufficed in satiating our sweet tooth. 

The roasted duck was also quite satisfying...served with a tangy orange sauce and accompanied by rice pilaf. The remaining dishes did not leave a lasting impression, as they were largely similar to those encountered at other buffets. 

A respectable buffet experience...ranking third on our comprehensive buffet list."

Whenever my travel itinerary has necessitated that I be accommodated in the vicinity of the renowned Las Vegas Strip, but I have been reluctant to incur the additional expense associated with lodging within the Strip's premium hospitality sector, I have opted to take up temporary residence at this establishment, which, while not situated directly on the Strip, remains conveniently proximate thereto. The amenities available to guests include a refreshing pool and complimentary wireless internet access, both of which are certain to enhance one's stay. Furthermore, sustenance options are readily accessible, mere steps away from the hotel's entrance. Finally, the management has graciously elected to include parking facilities within the cost of accommodation, thereby obviating the need for guests to allocate additional funds for this purpose.

It looks just like the Hofbrau Haus in Munich. I think the only Germans in the place were in the band! Service was good. Music was good. Beer was good. The food was another matter. My wife's Jager Schnitzel was so tough you could barely cut it with a knife. The sauerkraut with my wurst plate was bland and over cooked. The mashed potatoes tasted like they were made from a mix. We definitely had better German food.

I like the suite at Mandalay Bay its 750 sq the service at the front desk are always friendly, But I dislike it when my room were comp and they still charge me if I didn't look at my credit card the same week I wouldn't catch it that they charge me for 2 nights when those 2 nights are suppose to be free.

This is a great bar for a Tuesday night and highly recommend going after 9pm to get the $3 burger special.  Go early to get a seat because this place fills up slightly after 9. I sat all the way upstairs and the bar was quiet but it was a Tuesday night after all.  They had a great list of draft beers including Pumking which I would have normally gotten but at $10 for a small glass that was a little much for me. I ended up with a bottle of Purple Haze another favorite of mine. The bartender told me there was a glitch in the computer system and it only rang up for $3-nice surprise.  Unfortunately this didn't happen for the second round but the bartender made sure to tell me in advance which was perfectly fine.  I stayed for the 9 o'clock burger special and it was declivous. Pleasantly surprised by the double burger and highly recommend the Stack'd special sauce!

I would give it 3.75. Never would guess a cool little breakfast spot would be located under some shady apartments on 7th street. Sat at the bar and ate. Could see right into the very small kitchen. I only had scrambled eggs and bacon which are nothing to rave about but it's hard to mess those up. Some of the other dishes that came out of the kitchen looked great!  I'll have to try the pancakes next time!  Would definitely come back.

I'm not sure what the hype is about this place. I came here expecting a lot given the large amount of 4-5 star Yelp reviews, and I left disappointed. I ordered the original because I figured that I couldn't go wrong with an original. I guess I should just not expect so much when I eat at a 4-5 star according to Yelp restaurant. The sandwich was tiny. The flavor tasted off because of the horseradish. I was so, so, so disappointed. \n\nI also got the chicken noodle soup because it was cold, and I wanted soup. That was average. I'm glad I got the soup or I'd have still been hungry after that tiny sandwich. To be fair, I was eating buffets during the earlier part of my trip to Vegas. But, I still think the sandwich could have been a lot better given all these rave reviews.

I had been cognizant of numerous laudatory remarks pertaining to Noca, and thus, I was eagerly anticipating partaking in a culinary experience at this establishment. However, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as my dining encounter was somewhat disappointing. 
  All four of us opted for the tasting menu, with two individuals selecting the wine pairing option as well. The visual aspect of the dishes was undeniably impressive. We initiated our meal with a preliminary palette cleanser of sorts. The first course consisted of either a mushroom soup or a salad, wherein I chose the former, and my spouse opted for the latter. While both dishes were satisfactory, they failed to elicit an exceptional degree of culinary delight. 
  The second course, which comprised pasta accompanied by a meat-based sauce, was indubitably the most delectable offering thus far. Moving on to the main entrÃ©e, we were served a flat iron steak, which, albeit enjoyable, did not quite attain remarkable status. The concluding dessert course featured blue cotton candy and chocolate cake accompanied by banana gelato, the former of which proved to be a pleasant surprise. 
  Lamentably, the wine pairings fell short of our expectations. Our server seemed to possess limited knowledge regarding the wines, and rather peculiarly, he adhered to identical pairings irrespective of whether we selected the soup or salad, and fish or steak entrÃ©e. Moreover, the entire wine selection was confined to the red family. 
  In summary, while Noca presented visually appealing dishes, adequate portion sizes, and passable service, the overall experience did not prove extraordinary. If one seeks a truly remarkable dining establishment, I would instead recommend Alto at the Hyatt Gainey Ranch.

"I thoroughly relish the ornamental elements within this establishment, as they exude an air of refined sophistication while simultaneously incorporating industrial undertones, thereby enhancing the overall ambiance. However, my enthusiasm for the decor does not extend to the culinary offerings, as they fail to surpass the quality one would expect from a typical Brazilian steakhouse. Patrons partake in an initial course consisting of a limitless supply of salad and soup, followed by the prompt arrival of sides and entrees upon the reversal of a card. The steak selection boasts an array of cuts, ranging from prime sirloin to flavorful flank steak, all of which are adequately prepared. Yet, the genuine gastronomic highlights of the menu prove to be the delectable pork ribs and savory lamb, while the chicken dishes remain unremarkable and somewhat perplexing, given the prevalence of superior meat options. Supplementary dishes include crispy fried bananas, garlic mashed potatoes, and irresistible baked bread rolls filled with cheese. Although the desserts come at a premium price, they provide a satisfying conclusion to the meal. My experience, unfortunately, was marred by several shortcomings, including subpar food that failed to impress, particularly in comparison to the superior quality offered at Fogo de Chao. Furthermore, the seasoning proved insufficient, and the variety of meats available was limited, which may have been attributed to our early arrival. Lastly, the lobster bisque received mixed reviews from my dining companions, with some expressing disappointment at its unremarkable taste."

This McDonald's is conveniently nearby the Pepsi Center.

It opens late, and was perfect for the post-clubbing crowd I was with.

A friend bought me a McChicken sandwich (not sure why, but I appreciated it), which I made short work of - it tasted normal, as expected.

As usual, the food and service is very good here but can you please refinish the floor? It's really showing it age. Worn and discolored, it takes away from the overall experience. The ottomans in the lounge area also need cleaning or even better, reupholstered. \n\nThe place is looking rundown and that's really a shame for a high end, Summerlin dining spot.

"An ostensibly charming location, replete with myriad opportunities for juvenile enjoyment. Nonetheless, upon venturing forth to the pumpkin patch to select gourds, my gaze fell upon a singular specimen situated within the field, bearing a store-affixed label, inclusive of a barcode. While I do not take issue with compensating a premium for pumpkins cultivated locally, I cannot reconcile the notion of remunerating fourfold the amount for a gourd procured from Walmart, which retails for a mere $4. Perceiving the presence of pumpkin vines, indicative of an authentic harvest, I nevertheless felt compelled to restore our selections, given the unsettling sensation engendered by the blending of genuine produce with commercially sourced stock."

"For individuals seeking palatable victuals, Oliveo's presents itself as an optimal destination, irrespective of the time of day, be it during the nocturnal hours or the midday interval. While the prices may be perceived as somewhat elevated, the culinary offerings are undeniably of Greek provenance, thereby justifying the additional expense. My personal experiences with their menu have been nothing short of satisfactory, as I have had the pleasure of indulging in their delectable chicken souvlaki, gyros, and chicken breast plates, all of which have been expertly prepared and bursting with flavor. Furthermore, Oliveo's extends its operating hours well into the late night, making it an ideal choice for those seeking a nutritious repast beyond the conventional fast-food options. Thus, I wholeheartedly endorse this establishment for anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience in a collegiate setting."

"This eatery exudes an ambiance that transcends the conventional 'pub' experience, with a menu that boasts an array of sophisticated offerings. My culinary adventure began with a novel dish, chicken tacos, which presented an unconventional twist on the customary shredded poultry. Instead, each taco encompassed a substantial, deep-fried chicken finger, proffering a satisfying crunch and delightful flavor profile. While the execution was generally successful, the sizeable nature of the chicken piece occasionally hindered the ease of consumption. Furthermore, our table exhibited minor signs of wear and tear, with a subtle stickiness that suggested a need for heightened attention to detail in the cleaning process. A comprehensive approach to sanitizing the surface, involving the removal of all items, would greatly enhance the overall dining experience."

"Gosh darn it! I thoroughly forgot about my significant other discovering an extensive dark-colored strand of human hair in our culinary creation proximate to the point of completion of our repast. How on earth could I have overlooked such an occurrence?! It's absolutely unacceptable for any eatery to have such a disgusting situation transpire, particularly when the victuals were as delectable as they were."

"Although I am uncertain of the criteria employed in the selection process that led to its inclusion on the list, I must confess that my personal experience with too many aspects of the establishment left me unimpressed. Despite the reasonable pricing, my visits yielded inconsistent results, and the ambiance, characterized by a fast-casual style, was marred by an excessive amount of oil on the poultry dishes, while the burgers, albeit flavorful, were rather messy. However, I would still consider patronizing this establishment prior to visiting the majority of fast-food restaurants. It is worth mentioning that my culinary exploits have afforded me the opportunity to sample truly exceptional burgers, thereby establishing elevated standards against which future dining experiences will inevitably be measured. Notwithstanding the reservations expressed above, I did derive satisfaction from the French fries and flash-fried vegetables, although the latter's excessive sodium content raises concerns regarding its nutritional value. Nonetheless, I applaud the restaurant's attempt to offer a distinctive menu item, even if it may not necessarily constitute a frequent order for me personally."

"My personal opinion is that the macaroni and cheese dish served at this establishment is perhaps the most delectable item on their menu, particularly when paired with their bologna. It exudes an essence of comfort food that is simply unparalleled. Furthermore, their cheese plate appears to be quite appetizing, and their onion rings, which are abundant in the thinly sliced variety, are undoubtedly a delight for those who relish such delicacies. However, I must express some disappointment regarding their perch, as it fails to meet my expectations as my preferred choice among the fish offerings. Nonetheless, I did have the pleasure of partaking in a bowl of their beer cheese soup during my visit, albeit accompanied by an uninspiring garnish of popcorn. In conclusion, while the remainder of their menu may not necessarily excel in terms of creativity or taste, it does possess a certain charm that is reminiscent of traditional Wisconsin cuisine, whatever that may entail."

I was actually at the Staples next door, but had seen this place several times before and was curious enough this time to stop in, not knowing at all what to expect. I was here in the early afternoon, and it was plenty busy, but nothing like the megacrowds that others are describing, presumably dependent on the time and day. I didn't get a chance to experience the aggressive customer aspect, but most likely because I wasn't shopping in the women's section, and 95% of the other customers were women, who did look a bit frenzied; the four or five men in the store were, by contrast, subdued. I will have to come back again when I have more time to explore what they have, but to say I was "impressed" with the selection of (men's) shoes would be understating itâit was wingtip heaven in there! Unlike many of the items in this place, most of these shoes were in great condition, with the worst thing being a missing lace or two, which is an easy fix anyway. I came out with a $30 pair of Maison Forte boots which have no imperfections at all and were originally priced at $215.00! (I should add that I'm not designer/brand aware at all, so I'm mostly impressed that the shoes are gorgeous and don't so much care about their brand names.) Will definitely come back, even if just for more shoes! :)

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment were of satisfactory quality, the ambiance and aesthetic appeal of the physical location left much to be desired in terms of creating an optimal dining environment. Notwithstanding, the eatery's maintenance and upkeep were commendable, and the staff's attentiveness and responsiveness to our needs were adequate. Under the circumstances, I would still consider patronizing this restaurant for takeout or delivery purposes."

"Opted to partake in an evening repast at Tofu Hut, and while the overall experience was not utterly unpalatable, it failed to ascend to the lofty heights of true gastronomical excellence. 

Upon entering the establishment, it became apparent that the staffing situation was somewhat lacking, as it took in excess of five minutes for any semblance of acknowledgement to manifest, despite the fact that our arrival had not gone unnoticed. A simple greeting or welcome would have been appreciated, but unfortunately, such courtesies appeared to be in short supply. 

We elected to eschew the all-you-can-eat option and instead opted for individual dishes, selecting short ribs and spicy chicken from the menu. While both entrees were certainly edible and even bordered on being moderately satisfying, neither dish could be described as particularly remarkable or worthy of enthusiastic praise. However, the complementary banchan offerings did prove to be a pleasant surprise, with the fish cake, japchae, spicy cucumber, and other unrecalled items (owing to a lapse in memory) combining to create a culinary experience that, while not transcendent, was nevertheless enjoyable. 

Although a return visit may be in order, it is unlikely that Tofu Hut will become a regular haunt, as there are superior dining options available in the vicinity."

"I have an immense fondness for this hotel, yet my allegiance remains with the Bellagio, as it continues to excel in my esteem. Upon arrival, my family and I were graciously upgraded to the 60th floor, affording us a breathtaking panorama. The accommodations themselves were quaint and immaculate, featuring a television set in the bathroom, which elicited a humorous response from me. Unfortunately, the primary television in our room failed to function properly, despite the presence of detailed instructions on the remote control. Additionally, we encountered an unexpected issue with the walls, which proved to be remarkably thin, allowing us to overhear conversations in the corridor throughout the night, as well as the neighbors' nocturnal activities (albeit, the latter may have been attributable to a heated argument). Notwithstanding these drawbacks, I remain a devotee of the hotel's overall ambiance, La Rev the production, the lavish buffet offered for both brunch and dinner, and the array of upscale shops situated within the premises."

The sushi was good.  The service was ok.  We couldn't keep track of who was serving us...there were so many coming and going.  We didn't like that different rolls we ordered were all coming at different times, instead of all at once.  We stayed at the Wynn so it was right across the street and we gave it a shot.

"The cinematic experience offered by this establishment possesses both beneficial aspects and drawbacks. On one hand, the relatively diminutive size of the theater enables the exhibition of merely six to seven films simultaneously. Nevertheless, the auditoriums themselves boast exceptional comfort and generous legroom between seats, much to the delight of tall individuals. Unfortunately, the luminosity of the pathway illumination within the theater is excessive, resulting in an annoying distraction akin to having a light source directed into one's eyes throughout the entire film. Not exactly an optimal viewing environment. 

The pricing scheme adopted by this cinema is generally unremarkable, with the exception of a discounted rate of $5.50 for students. To take advantage of this offer, it may be necessary to employ creative methods such as presenting an outdated student identification card or sporting orthodontic appliances to convincingly portray a youthful appearance. 

For convenient access to the theater, park your vehicle in the adjacent parking garage and traverse the food court on foot."

Seeing as I've been reviewing my recent Vegas adventures, I should probably get this one out of the draft burner.  I have a habit of letting drafts collect dust on Yelp.  So allow me to finish my four month old thoughts:

Zumanity is said to be "adults only," but it's no Absinthe.  It caters to adults with a few raunchy jokes here and there.  And it caters to Vegas with a few topless acts.  But for the most part, it's very tame and even a bit campy.  I didn't find the show pushing the envelop on anything and it didn't appear at all sensual to me.

I brought the boyfriend.  he enjoyed himself but didn't see why I fuss over Cirque du Soleil so much.  On reflection, I should have taken him to see something a bit more awe-inspiring (like "O").  

A lot of the comedy is just heckling the nearby crowd.  And a lot of the acts highlighted in the program were absent during our particular show.  No midgets, no fat twins.  Perhaps that would have added some flavor to an otherwise lackluster evening.  Maybe I was suspecting something too outside the norm and my expectations were bridging on pornographic?  To me, this was a typical Cirque show with some dirty jokes and sexier outfits thrown into the mix.

50% off tickets for military.  So a good deal to fill a few hours of your time.

We tried this restaurant because of all the good reviews, so I went in with high expectations. I was so disappointed that the food was just ok. The fish taco was dry and lacked flavor. The guacamole on the rolled tacos was tasteless. I also had the carne asada taco which was the best thing I ordered but still nothing to brag about. My husband had the steak and eggs. It looked more like machaca. The dining room was clean but the bathroom was disgusting. I would only revisit this restaurant if it was the only thing open and I was starving.

"Goodness gracious, the atmospheric conditions within this eatery were utterly saturated with the pungent fumes of tobacco, to the extent that visibility was significantly impaired, thereby diminishing our capacity to fully appreciate the culinary offerings. Notwithstanding this unfortunate circumstance, we opted to sample their renowned 'Steak Special,' which, to our delight, proved to be quite delectable. The accompanying vegetables, specifically the green beans and mashed potatoes, were likewise palatable."

As a \"gastropub\" Public House has the mandatory dark wood decor and decadent dishes like poutine and fois gras.  Being Vegas, all restaurants have a hook or gimmick, and Public House is no different with its expansive wine list  stored in its fancy schamcy ipad for guests to play around with it - half the fun was picking the wine.  \n\nPublic House also excels at some light fare as well.  Went with a group of girls, and half of the table ended up getting the scallops entree - the scallops were super sweet and tasted very fresh.  The salads were great, pomegranate seeds added a nice burst of acidity.

I must confess that my unwavering admiration for North Kierland had me anticipating an exceptional dining experience at North Arcadia, yet my maiden visit proved to be a somewhat underwhelming affair, save for the visually captivating ambiance. We arrived prior to 11:30 a.m., and although we were merely the fourth or fifth table to be seated, the service we received was regrettably sluggish, with a discernible air of indifference. Furthermore, the zucca chips, which typically rank among my favorite items on North Kierland's menu, were unfortunately overcooked, thereby diminishing their customary appeal. It is worth mentioning that the portion of bucatini with meatballs, priced at $17, was rather modest in size, given the cost. While none of the dishes were unequivocally unpalatable, the total expenditure of $59.00 for three individuals, exclusive of beverages, struck me as marginally excessive, particularly when juxtaposed with the superior quality and comparative affordability offered by neighboring establishments such as T. Cook's or Coup des Tartes, where one can indulge in a delectable meal for a considerably lower price point.

"City Cafe boasts an array of appealing attributes, including their delectable breakfast offerings, pool table, and affordable beer pitchers, all of which contribute to a convivial ambiance reminiscent of an American diner. However, their big burger challenge is a formidable feat, both to witness and undertake. Additionally, their chips arrive in unique wire fry baskets, adding to the eatery's charm. Unfortunately, their cocktail pitchers lack potency, failing to deliver a satisfactory level of intoxication even after prolonged consumption. Furthermore, their culinary offerings are somewhat unpredictable, with their guacamole-topped nachos tasting eerily similar to mayonnaise and their vegetarian burgers suffering from an unfortunate texture issue that results in a soggy, frothy bun. Despite these drawbacks, I frequent City Cafe and will likely continue to do so, albeit with a preference for pints and chips."

This place has a great location in Tivoli Village. They have a good indoor outdoor bar and several inexpensive offerings for happy hour. One of the best features of this restaurant is that they allow your dog to sit out with you on the patio while you dine. 

The food is not traditional (authentic) Mexican food which doesn't bother me. But, the poor execution is an issue. We have eaten here a handful of times. I guess because I keep hoping to select something on the menu that I love. Unfortunately, that hasn't happened. The highlight of the menu is their guacamole and chips which are made table side. Their complimentary salsas are also very tasty. 

I would give Cantina Loredo another try. It's a shame that we haven't found a good Mexican restaurant in the Summerlin area. My husband likes this place a lot more than I do. He is a fan of the fajitas. So, the 3 star review is an average of both of our opinions.

Food and service was good not great but  certaintly not memorable. The noise level is horrendous with the waitress having to almost yell to describe the specials,etc. This was in the dining room too not in the bar. Also, the table are way too close together. Better places can be had nearby.

"I have had the pleasure of visiting various Red Robin establishments throughout the Bay Area, and while it is undeniable that the uniformity of menu items across all franchises is commendable, my personal experience at this particular location was somewhat underwhelming. Admittedly, I do not frequent this restaurant with sufficient regularity to justify a zealous recommendation, but I do acknowledge the appeal of certain menu items. Specifically, the colossal onion ring tower, despite its unremarkable taste, commands respect for its sheer magnitude. Additionally, the chicken pasta dish we shared fell short of my expectations, rendering it an unlikely candidate for future orders. Nonetheless, I must concede that Red Robin does offer some delectable options, such as their fish, fries, and shrimp sampler appetizer, which I have had the pleasure of enjoying on previous occasions. In conclusion, while this establishment may not warrant an enthusiastic endorsement, it is not entirely without merit, and I would still advise others to sample their fare."

"On two separate occasions, I have partaken of culinary offerings at this establishment, with varying degrees of satisfaction. During my initial visit, the ambiance was lacking in vivacity, and it appeared that a sizable contingent of juveniles, ostensibly affiliated with a familial gathering, had commandeered the attention of my server, who, it must be said, demonstrated a conspicuous partiality towards them, to the detriment of my own dining experience, despite my status as a remunerative patron. My dinner selection consisted of the General Tso's Chicken, a dish whose description boasts an appealing combination of crispy fried poultry, scallions, and a spicy sauce, but which, regrettably, failed to surpass expectations. In contrast, my return visit, undertaken during the luncheon hour, yielded a decidedly more gratifying outcome, as I savored the Mongolian beef, a flavorful and visually appetizing entree, replete with sauteed scallions, sweet yellow onions, and a bed of crispy rice noodles, all sprinkled with sesame seeds. The attentive and proficient service I received during this second visit engenders hope that future dining experiences at this venue will continue to improve."

In my search for great BBQ this place stands out.  Not only is it tasty but it doesn't irritate my stomach.  That is a major plus in my book.  The one drawback is service.  I've ordered online and arrived at the specified pick up time 30-60 minutes later to still have to wait another 15-20 minutes.  So be advised to just go to the take out counter and order, as it will take just as long.

Here for dinner with my family.  We were staying at the Pointe Hilton Squaw Peak Resort.  Nice location, casual dining.  Good menu with choices.  Service was OK, food fairly well prepared although lamb was overcooked for one of our party.  Overall, OK experience.

The place was a lot of fun because I was with a group of girls and comped drinks kept on coming to our table.

The service and staff were amazingly friendly.  Although I wasn't there for the food, it wasn't too bad.  In fact, I don't remember much of what I ordered but it was only from the appetizer menu. 

The place does get really busy, so make sure you call for reservations.

GRIMALDI's PIZZERIA has a lot going for them with tools and technique at the top of the list. to my sensibilities, a coal fired oven really produces the perfect crust and, at least in my experience, GRIMALID's consistantly does it well.

but the quality of their toppings is really no different than the national chains that dispatch pimple-faced kids to your doorstep when you're too tired to drag your ass to a "real" restaurant and that's kind of disappointing.

and i can't say i'm wild about their sauce either. theirs is raw (and "lightly drizzled" over the other toppings so the crust stays crispy) and i'm partial to a long-simmered version -- i enjoy the additional depth of flavor.

so, the quest for the perfect pizza goes on ...

The Flamingo, a veritable bastion of gaming and entertainment, has been a fixture on the Las Vegas Strip for decades. My initial visit to this esteemed establishment dates back to 1987, when my friend's parents, ardent devotees of Lady Luck, ventured to Sin City to indulge in their passion for gambling. As we were still in our tender years and unable to partake in the adult pursuits of gaming and driving, I accompanied my companion to the arcade, where we became thoroughly engrossed in a turbo-charged Ms. Pacman machine, our minds and fingers working in tandem to navigate the frenetic maze. Following this exhilarating escapade, we embarked upon a leisurely perambulation along the famed boulevard, basking in the vibrant ambiance that enveloped us.

My return to the Flamingo last week marked a significant departure from my previous experience, as the passage of time has wrought subtle yet discernible changes in the property's appearance and ambiance. Upon entering the premises, I was struck by an unmistakable pall of stale, smoke-laden air that permeated the atmosphere, evocative of the smoking rooms found in certain budget-friendly motels. This initial discomfort, however, was soon dispelled by the improved circulation that greeted me within the hall, leading me to appreciate the venue's unique layout, which, while admittedly somewhat perplexing, afforded me the opportunity to savor a few pints of Sam Adams on tap at the bar in the company of my German colleague, who had recently arrived from abroad. Although I elected not to partake in any gaming activities myself, due to my lingering dissatisfaction with Harrah's properties, I must admit that the experience was not without its charm.

When I lived in the area, I used to come here a lot both to eat in and take out. The quality has gone down a bit over the last year - the last few times we went, the service wasn't great, the portions are getting smaller, plus they are giving too many vegetables and not enough meat. However, they do make a great Pad Thai.

It's a new small place, clean, order at the counter fresh fish fry. They had several types of dips and the french frys were good. No beer :( sad hope that's too come soon. There was plenty served in one serving didn't need more. Husband wished his was crisper and wanted Texas toast.  Fish was white and very good. Coleslaw ok.  Hope they stay and grow - we'll be back.

My maiden voyage to the shooting range transpired to be an enjoyable escapade; however, certain drawbacks tarnished the overall experience. Firstly, the staff members exhibited proficiency in their field, imparting valuable knowledge and ensuring a seamless experience for patrons. Additionally, an extensive array of firearms was available for utilization. Unfortunately, these advantages were counterbalanced by several negative aspects. Specifically, the range was characterized by a high volume of patrons, leading to extended waiting periods, particularly during peak days of the week. Furthermore, the physical space was limited, resulting in a cramped environment with individuals occupying every available spot, including the floor and corners, and shoulders were literally rubbing against each other. Moreover, the range officers appeared flustered, struggling to manage the throngs of people and maintain order amidst the chaos. Lastly, the cost of utilizing the range was deemed steep, with a shared lane, gun, and ammunition for a mere thirty minutes totaling a whopping eighty-eight dollars, which included a fifteen-dollar fee per weapon. Despite these limitations, the range still presents itself as a suitable destination for those interested in partaking in such activities, though it is crucial to be cognizant of the aforementioned constraints.

I was in search of Shrimp Pad Thai and found this via google. Ordered placed for pick-up, ready in 15 mins...Great! 

Parking was down a dimly lit drive thru/alley way. Got startled by what appeared to be a worker smoking in the corner; may I suggest you park on Spring Mt and walk around to Valley. 

Upon entering the restaurant, the staff was very friendly and the atmosphere was inviting. I must say the dish was very tasty with a spicy level of 4. 

The only complaint were the noodles were thinner than what I was used to, almost like angel hair pasta, and the shrimp were the tiny ones; I was a little disappointed, but yet it was still very tasty. You can order up for larger shrimp, but since it was my first time I wanted to experience the regular dish. If I had to eat here again, I would definitely order the larger shrimp next time.

"An abundance of seating options and diverse ambiances within the establishment rendered it an exceedingly comfortable venue, particularly during the warmer seasons when the outdoor patio area can be utilized extensively. However, certain aspects detracted from the overall satisfaction, specifically:  
1. The practice of pouring cream into coffee without first inquiring about preferences regarding dairy substitutes resulted in an unintended addition of half-and-half to my spouse's beverage, despite my desire to customize it with skim milk. Although the staff accommodated my request for a new drink, it would be preferable to have control over the creative process behind my coffee concoction.  
2. The background music consisted of a radio station featuring recurring advertisements, which created an atmosphere akin to being trapped in a shop playing the same irritating tunes and commercials repeatedly. A simple solution would be to curate a playlist or employ an iPod to create a more enjoyable auditory experience for patrons.   
3. While the coffee was satisfactory, the menu items appeared appetizing, but comments regarding the cost have been voiced. Nonetheless, it seems illogical to visit a coffeehouse anticipating a full meal. Prices were only marginally higher than expected.  
4. The availability of beer and the prominent display of a large pizza banner near the entrance raised questions about the establishment's identity. It appears that Hob Nobs may be struggling to define its purpose and target audience. A decision on the type of establishment would alleviate confusion and enhance the overall experience.  
Despite these issues, the visit remained generally pleasurable, with only minor shortcomings detracting from the enjoyment."

I had high hopes for Cheddatruck. I love a good burger, it's seriously one of my favorite foods. Unfortunately though, Cheddatruck did not really win me over. My boyfriend was hoping to get the burger with mac n cheese on it but they were out of mac n cheese so he got one with an egg on it instead. I got just a plain cheeseburger. We also ordered tots.

Our burgers were just okay. Mine was a little overcooked and just kind of lacking flavor overall. My boyfriend said his wasn't real memorable. The tots, while they were hand-made, were a disappointment. Like the burger, the flavor just wasn't there. Even though they had cheese in them (supposedly) and they were served with an herb cream cheese, they were bland and just kinda blah. And $3 for 7 tots is a bit steep. 

Overall (and considering the price) there are much better burger options around. Sorry Cheddatruck, but you can just keep on driving.

Ate here on a recommendation from a friend while on vacation in Phoenix from Chicago.

I thought the wait was pretty extreme; if I weren't on vacation and willing to just kick it I don't think I would wait 3 hours for a table anywhere.  Luckily hanging at the bar next door was fun, and the wait was bearable due to the circumstances.  

The pizza was very good and the bottle of wine we got was fine - I guess I'm a bit spoiled by Italian pizza (not to be confused with Chicago-style) in my hometown though, as this place seemed solid but not special.  Definitely a quality brick oven pizza with seemingly fresh ingredients though, and an enjoyable evening once you can get in.

"My experience at this establishment has been limited to cinematic pursuits, as I have yet to engage in any gambling activities or partake in culinary delights within their restaurants. My interactions with staff have been cursory, primarily pertaining to the procurement of cinema tickets. Notwithstanding, my impressions thus far have been favorable, characterized by effortless parking, affable staff, and clear wayfinding. In the absence of elevated expectations, I am unable to articulate grievances. However, I shall reassess my appraisal should I opt to engage in more substantive endeavors on the premises."

"A prominent location of a renowned coffee franchise, boasting an extensive array of freshly baked products, tends to experience heightened foot traffic during weekends, particularly from scholars seeking a conducive setting for academic pursuits."

Came here for lunch a couple of weeks ago, and it was just alright.  I've been on a pizza journey lately, trying to find little mom and pop pizza shops to try.  I've always been a fan of little pizza shops as opposed to the bigger chain pizza (Pizza Hut, Dominos, etc.). 

This place was kinda nice, personal and friendly staff.  But it wasn't too busy and that always concerns me.  The pizza came out in about 20 minutes, which is pretty average for a pizza joint.  But the pizza appeared to be sloppy.  I'm not one to critique the way food looks, but when it looks sloppy, it tends to taste that way as well.  

The pizza itself was alright, nothing to write home about, and not the worst pizza I've had.  I will definitely try this place again though.

Came in super late for some munchies and to cure our sweet tooth. I got the bread pudding and my friend got the french toast. The food was solid, but the service was less than desirable. The bartender was more concerned with her phone and gossip than being personable to us.

If the cafÃ© out of Eastenders were real, I'm pretty sure this is what it would be like. I've never seen somewhere that better encapsulates the definition of "good old greasy-spoon cafÃ©" as well as Brambles.

It's only just opened, and I assumed it would be yet another of these sandwich/wrap/panini type places that Edinburgh is teeming with, but I was very wrong. Although Brambles do offer things like baked potatoes and paninis, their specialty is anything fried served with chips and buttered bread. And I mean literally everything - from traditional chicken nuggets, chips, and beans that are reminiscent of school dinner days, to deep-fried haggis and chips and mushy peas.

They did have some slightly healthier options on the menu, such as lasagne (served with chips, of course!) but it's not really the kind of place you go to consume healthy cuisine. The lace curtains, neon sign in the window, and plastic tables should be the most off-putting thing you've ever seen, but it works in that sort of way that it's so bad it's good. It's kitsch, a bit tacky and dated, despite only being open a few weeks, but it does exactly what it says on the tin and serves good honest junk food at really reasonable prices.

"Certainly not comparable to the exceptional standards set by Ka or O, yet still a mildly entertaining spectacle in the city of Las Vegas. 

It is essential to note that the acrobatic feats performed during the production were undeniably remarkable. Nonetheless, the overall pacing of the show was somewhat sluggish, leading to occasional moments of somnolence experienced by my mother. Additionally, the brief interludes between the main acts seemed excessively prolonged and lacked significant relevance to the overall narrative. 

In conclusion, while Mystere may prove visually captivating for first-time viewers of Cirque du Soleil productions, those familiar with the company's superior offerings would be better advised to explore alternative options for their entertainment."

My girlfriend and I attend a soft opening dinner. The vibe is very man cave, which was cool with me. This is a great place to grab a burger and drink on a Saturday afternoon and watch the game or take a date on a week night. The Grind is a welcomed dining option for the Arcadia neighborhood! 

The wait staff was super friendly and attentive. Propers to them for having their act together for the opening. 

My girlfriend and I shared the melted rosemary brie with strawberry relish. The brie was cheesy goodness and did take on some of the rosemary flavor. The strawberry relish was flavorful. A balsamic reductions would make this dish. 

We moved onto the BLT burger and the Sweet and Spicy Burger. The 1000 degree coal fire oven does seal in the juices and creates an nice crispy exterior on the patty. All the other ingredients were fresh and tasty. The bun was toasted, yet fresh and spongy on the interior. 

Fries need some improvement, but again this was a soft opening. 

Drink list is inventive and educational. 

Looking forward to coming back.

This place is good, don't get me wrong. I love this Italian style pizza, the service was good, and i enjoyed my meal. The thing is, if you go a few blocks over to eastern there is Grimaldi's pizza, which is that same Italian style pizza, but its just much better. The pizza was a bit cold and soft, so maybe mine was just undercooked, i dont know. Also the flavors were a little bland. So try this and you wont be too disapointed, but missing out on Grimaldi's would be the crime when its so close.

"The culinary establishment boasted an impressive magnitude, its expansive interior exuding an air of opulence that was further accentuated by the warm welcome we received upon entry. Our server, a consummate professional, promptly escorted us to our table and presented us with menus, his affable demeanor putting us at ease. Opting for the 12 oz New York strip steak, cooked to a medium rare temperature, I eagerly anticipated the arrival of my culinary indulgence. Alas, the duration between placing our orders and the actual serving of our meals proved to be somewhat protracted, approximating thirty to forty-five minutes, which, coupled with the fact that my steak was overcooked to an unfortunate degree, left me feeling somewhat disenchanted. Despite this setback, I chose to maintain my composure and conveyed my dissatisfaction to our server, who expressed regret on behalf of the kitchen staff and extended an offer to prepare a fresh steak. However, given my pressing schedule and ravenous hunger, I elected to forgo this option and instead consume the steak provided, albeit with some reluctance. In spite of this experience, I remain willing to accord the establishment another opportunity to demonstrate its culinary prowess during my future visits to Las Vegas."
 Establishment rating: 4/5
 Waitstaff/Service rating: 4/5
 Cuisine rating: 3/5
 Price rating: 2/5 (lower score indicates higher price)
 Cleanliness rating: 4/5
 Overall rating: 3/5

Vovomeena why were you so hard to find!!! Whether you're driving down McDowell or 7th avenue you won't see it. Maybe we just missed it, but I didn't see any sign whatsoever. The only one was right about their door, but you can't see it well from the street. We got lost and drove around and couldn't find it. I had to text my sister to see where it's at. 

I ordered the banging pocket which I didn't think was very banging. Lol. It comes with sausage and eggs wrapped in a pita with a side of potatoes. It would've been nice with some onions or mushrooms or something. It just wasn't anything great. 

There isn't a lot of seating at the restaurant. You probably have to come early to get a table or you'll end up sitting outside in the hot weather. They should really install misters. The service was really good but it was a far drive for mediocre food.

This would be a 3.5 star place - 

Love the old vegas look, cheap prices, glittery light show, and more local feel.  99 cent frozen chocolate covered bananas are the bomb!  Hennessey's is a great value with really good food.  2 dollar blackjack!  Fresh donuts from Krispy Kreme!  Free shows (good and bad).

Not in love with the rude people (but they're everywhere).  The casinos have low ceilings, which means lots of cigarette smoke lingering.  Wouldn't walk far from the light show, but plenty of security on the strip itself.

In general, it's a good contrast to the mega-corporate new strip, doesn't have the awesome food, but doesn't have the awe-inspiring prices either.  A lot of fun for the right reasons.  Just a matter of what you're in the mood for.

Just remember:  Vegas is about fun - and the Fremont Street Experience packs a lot of it into a 3.5 short blocks.

From all the other reviews I read it appears my experience was the same as many others: great atmosphere, good good, terrible service. 

I go up for a refill of my coffee and a worker is standing in front of the espresso machine pouring herself and drinking espresso shots. After standing there for about a minute I finally say something to her, "Could I please have a refill?" She then decides to acknowledge my existence and hastily pours me a refill. 

The coffee tasted great and so did my sandwich, but I don't think I should have to wait for the barista to finish her self-poured shots of espresso before I'm allowed to get my refill.

It's not a bad hotel for the price.  Really.

The room I stayed in was fine (save for some odd stains on the curtains), the casino and show offerings are about standard (Carrot Top, Criss Angel), and there's a fairly diverse selection of restaurants.

That said, if you want to drop an extra $40 or $50 a night and stay somewhere else, I'd probably recommend doing that.  While I'd take the Luxor over the Imperial Palace, it's certainly no Caesar's or Mandalay Bay.

Dalkeith Road is so sad-looking. I don't know how a street can looks sad, but it does. It's sort of saying 'I'm out of the way, I'm long and there are other roads parallel to me that are much better and get there quicker. sigh.' Is it possible to feel sorry for a road? 

Anyway

C's Tasty Bites thus lacks the va va voom I look for in a snack shop. It tries, nonetheless, and 10/10 for effort. 
The place itself is small, I think too small to breathe so only ever come here for take-away. The price is alright and the food isn't amazing, but maybe i;m lacking enthusiasm because when I leave i'm left with Dalkeith road. aw.

"I decided to stop by for a beverage after work prior to proceeding home to surprise, and was informed by staff that if I opted to utilize a debit card as my method of payment, a minimum purchase of $10 would be required. This prompted me to ponder why such a stipulation would exist, particularly when it comes to the type of payment employed. Generally, I would consume an amount in excess of $10, but on this particular occasion, I found myself constrained by time. Furthermore, upon inquiring about the possibility of settling my tab with physical currency, I was met with an affirmative response, albeit accompanied by the caveat that the ATM was currently non-functional. While this turn of events did not typically bother me, it nevertheless proved vexing under the present circumstances."

MGM is a decent place to stay if you can get a good rate... Check-in/out is a waiting game, as with any other hotel on the Strip. My room was actually much nicer than I expected, and I especially loved the blackout shades. They really work!... Internet was fairly fast, the minibar selection is good, and I was fortunate to be on a quiet floor.

Their higher-end restaurants were also better than expected, except for Fiamma- blecch

Negatives included boring, often rude blackjack dealers, poor cocktail service in the blackjack area, very little shade available at the pools unless you purchase a cabana (and, you know, it's HOT in the Vegas sun... there was also very limited waitstaff working the pools), the room air conditioner couldn't keep my room cool, and huge crowds everywhere

Overall, if you like staying on the Strip, this isn't a bad place. There are better hotels, and there are certainly worse places

The staff hears what they want to hear. They don't really care what you say or order. I mean, I barely got \"cafe\" out of my mouth and the dude was already gone. What if I didn't want condensed milk, huh? What of that? Same thing for pho orders. And AND the menu had me flustered due to their lack of rice plates. Who does that? Who doesn't have just charbroiled pork as the first thing on the list of rice plates? \n\nDespite my complaints, the egg rolls were excellent! Loads of filling in them! And the coffee was old school, with the metal drip thing and the cup of ice. Pho was good, but something about 105 degree heat makes me not want to eat a big hot soupy bowl of pho.

"The culinary establishment under investigation is situated within the lobby premises of the Westin hotel, where I was temporarily residing; however, I refrained from partaking of their gastronomical offerings due to their subpar ratings on the popular review platform, Yelp. On the final evening of my tenure, I was exhausted and had worked late into the evening, thus opting to sample their fare.  

Upon perusing their bill of fare, I discovered an array of delectable options, including an assortment of seafood and sushi dishes that piqued my interest, although I ultimately settled on a pair of sushi rolls. The quality of the sushi was satisfactory, and their draft beer selection was quite impressive. Based solely on the culinary aspect, I would assign a rating of 3.5 stars, nearing the threshold of four; however, this assessment was derived from a limited sampling of their offerings. Thus, I shall endeavor to partake of their cuisine once more. 

Unfortunately, their service left much to be desired, potentially contributing to their mediocre reputation. The bar area was moderately populated, while the dining area was largely unoccupied; yet, patrons seated at the bar were compelled to signal the bartender to garner his attention, and the preparation time for my meager order of two sushi rolls exceeded 25 minutes. These factors might account for their suboptimal rating. Since I shall likely be extending my stay at this Westin for an indeterminate period, I shall consider giving their eatery another chance in the future."

"The positive aspects of this establishment are numerous; specifically, the flavors of the pork dishes are exceptional, and the variety of options available is impressive. Additionally, the team responsible for serving patrons is both clean and friendly, creating a welcoming atmosphere for all visitors. However, there are some areas that could benefit from improvement. Firstly, upon arriving for a late lunch, I noticed that the food did not possess the optimal level of freshness or heat that I would have expected. This may be attributed to the fact that I visited during an off-peak hour, and thus, the items were not as piping hot as they could have been had I arrived during the traditional lunch or dinner hours. Furthermore, I suggest that the sauces be served at a warm temperature rather than being cold, which would enhance the overall dining experience. Despite these minor drawbacks, I thoroughly enjoyed my visit and would unquestionably return to sample more of their delectable offerings. The concept itself is innovative and well-executed, making it a standout establishment in its genre."

"I had the privilege of indulging in the delectable brisket at a local establishment recently, and I must say that it thoroughly satiated my gastronomical desires. The meat was cooked to perfection, boasting an optimal balance of tenderness and juiciness that left me yearning for more. While I did appreciate the addition of the savory sauce, I would request that it be served on the side during my subsequent visit, thereby allowing me to relish the unadulterated flavor of the brisket without any distractions."

"Expended two hundred dollars on a culinary experience for two individuals at an upscale dining establishment, precipitating elevated anticipations. Unfortunately, my significant other's cut of meat, specifically the steak, was overcooked and lacked succulence, while the supplementary sauces presented were not merely unimpressive but also unpalatable. In contrast, my Beef Wellington was of satisfactory quality, albeit not exceptional. Furthermore, the macaroni and cheese accompanying the dish was excessively arid, prompting inquiry into the cause of such an anomaly. Considering the totality of factors, including ambiance and service, a sense of disappointment permeated our dining experience, leading me to conclude that future patronage would be unwarranted. However, I may opt to sample their burger alternative at a subsequent date."

Located in close proximity to the renowned Rio All-Suite Hotel and Casino, the Flamingo hotel boasts an unparalleled position, rendering it easily accessible by foot for those who relish a leisurely stroll along the Las Vegas Strip. However, it is worth noting that the pedestrian route traverses an overhead bridge above the highway, which may not be the most scenic or enjoyable trek. Despite its unpretentious nature, this establishment offers exceptional value for money, with tariffs that are considerably reasonable compared to neighboring luxury resorts. As a subsidiary of Coast Properties, this hotel benefits from an abundance of on-site facilities, effectively rendering it self-sufficient and obviating the need for guests to venture beyond its confines in search of dining or entertainment options. Thus, for travelers seeking a relaxed ambiance and economical accommodations, this venue is certainly worthy of consideration, allowing them to experience the vibrant spirit of Las Vegas without breaking the bank.

Didn't come here to eat just drink but can't really go wrong with 2.50 coronas this is definitely is a college bar and a bit noisy what's wierd is there Oregon duck fans and not ASU fans? Great place for day drinking though

Typical mall but a bit over priced and not geared towards locals. Definetly a tourist trap mall but still has a few nice specialty shops and occasionally a good sale here or there. The coffee bean here is awesome and the mall has free yoga on sundays at lululemon so thats a plus as well.
Popped in for a few tacos today... The carne asada was lacking in flavor, no marinade, and pretty bland. The carnitas were very good and I'd eat a dozen at one sitting :)

"A pleasant regional venue offering delectable cuisine and an expansive outdoor area ideal for leisurely summer gatherings. While the interior ambiance may be somewhat dim, the culinary offerings more than compensate for this minor shortcoming. However, the placement and size of the televisions could be improved to enhance the overall viewing experience for patrons. Locating this establishment may prove somewhat challenging for the uninitiated, but once arrived, visitors can enjoy a welcoming, well-maintained, and secure environment."

"This eatery can be classified as a typical Chinese dining establishment, offering culinary fare at a reasonable price point. As part of their lunchtime offerings, a meager $5.95 affords a clientele an entrÃ©e accompanied by a beverage. The level of hospitality displayed by the staff is commendable, as they exhibit attentive behavior, periodically inquiring about the satisfaction of their patrons and ensuring that glasses remain filled in a timely fashion. Unfortunately, the gastronomical offerings themselves are merely adequate, which is unsurprising given the affordable pricing. Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that the presentation of the food appears somewhat lackluster, as the utilization of Styrofoam containers and absence of serving utensils detracts from the overall visual appeal. In conclusion, this dining establishment is suitable for those seeking a rapid and economical meal, but may not cater to the preferences of more discerning gourmands."

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been thoroughly satisfactory, with both the service and culinary offerings meeting my expectations. In fact, I recently indulged in their delectable Peanut Buster Parfait, which not only tasted divine but also bore a striking resemblance to the advertised image, a rarity among dining establishments. Consequently, when the craving for a Dairy Queen treat arises and I find myself in close proximity, I will unhesitatingly patronize this particular location for a satisfying repast.

After having such a horrible experience at Babystacks (see prior review), my friend and I drove over to Lulu's. I don't know if it was the contrast to the poor service we just experienced but it was so nice to have such good service.  Although  you order at the counter, you can sit in the Metro pizza area which is easier with kids. Also, they brought out drinks over to us, which again helps with kids. They didn't bat an eye when my friend sent her egg back because she forgot to ask for it to be over hard instead of over easy as it normally comes. The manager is always nice and has gone out of her way to make us feel welcome before. 

 I had the Herman breakfast sandwich, a little pricey (about $8 if I remember correctly), but I love that it comes on a pretzel bun and it is surprisingly filling for just being a sandwich. It is just the sandwich with egg, sausage, cheese and a stone ground mustard. 

I have had the chocolate croissant before and it was okay - but of course I am a chocolate croissant aficionado (aka snob) and really only like the traditional french chocolate croissant (as served at Patisserie Manon and the Baguette Cafe). The lemon tart is really good and reminds me of a sour cream lemon pie my hubby makes which is phenomenal. They usually have cookie and muffin samples out which is nice.

"While my sojourn in Phoenix was underway, I elected to peruse the evaluations on Yelp to identify an optimal purveyor of donuts that could cater to my unwavering predilection for the delectable treat. Although Lamar's positioned itself as a mid-range establishment, my expectations remained grounded in the hope of securing a scorching hot and fresh batch of classic glazed donuts, which, regrettably, proved unattainable during my visit. However, despite the absence of optimal donut consumption conditions, my overall experience did not descend into utter disappointment."

Specialty food should be special. There should be a reason why you pay a bit extra for a few morsels of goodness. Reid's has a lock on these specialty foods with a nice looking meat department, array of choice cheeses and impressive wine selection. Let's break down this location a bit, shall we?

The Good: As mentioned, it's a great spot to grab a quick bite, snag a bottle of wine, some tasty snacks and get on your merry way. The service is pretty spectacular - whether your seeking said bottle of wine or dining on a sandwich during lunch. Many of the sandwiches and salads I saw coming around looked fresh and delicious. Also, there's a decent sized wine bar next to the wine vault/selection area that could kick your feet up while you taste away. 

The Meh: The parking is pretty much horrendous. Unless you're stealing parking from business across the street, you better be comfortable walking a ways. The sandwich I ate here was underwhelming - the grilled pimento cheese was gut busting-ly greasy (granted, it's grilled pimento cheese) and also missed the zing I was looking for. I barely got through half of the sloppy mess and had to put it down for fear that I may have a heart attack in the shop. 

If I'm walkin' around Selwyn and need to score a few snacks before heading home, Reid's is a fine choice, yet they definitely have plenty of competition in the area if we're talking tasty sandwiches and wine tasting!

"The delectable crepes boast an array of flavors, ranging from the traditional simplicity of lemon juice to the richness of Nutella complemented by bananas. In contrast, the savory crepes appear unimaginative and lacking in inspiration. However, the inviting ambiance of the coffee shop, enhanced by the well-crafted coffee, compensates for the deficiency. Unfortunately, the service has been inconsistent, marred by the presence of a bothersome fly during our last two visits."

"Upon entering the establishment, one is immediately struck by the presence of a mechanical bull, which serves as a central focal point within the venue and lends an air of rugged excitement to the proceedings. The atmosphere is further enhanced by the abundance of masculine patrons, whose boisterous revelry contributes to the overall ambiance of the establishment. The auditory senses are similarly stimulated by the high volume of the musical offerings, which serve to augment the convivial nature of the gathering. Of particular note, however, are the exceptional quality of the lettuce wraps served by the establishment, which truly distinguishes itself from the standard fare typically associated with such establishments. While the author's experience with similar venues may be limited, it is evident that this particular location offers a unique and enjoyable initiation into the local nightlife."

"I have been frequenting this establishment for approximately a decade, and while I have had a strong affinity for their culinary offerings in the past, recent experiences have left me feeling somewhat disillusioned and disappointed. The issues that have been raised by other patrons, such as the limited quantity of meat on the sandwiches, the high prices, and the sluggish service, have unfortunately become increasingly apparent. Furthermore, I must express my dismay at the lack of environmental consciousness displayed by the restaurant, as evidenced by their refusal to reuse punch cards and instead opting to discard and replace them, resulting in unnecessary waste. Despite these criticisms, I may still continue to visit, albeit with reduced frequency."
