The Pros: Inexpensive menu, fresh food, great malts, clean restaurant, friendly smiling employees, pepper bar. 

Cons: Stale and not creative dining area, awkward layout in the dining room, seen before menu options, pre-made salad dressings.

Good for a quick burger. In my opinion there are other burger options in town that I prefer.

"This establishment undoubtedly offers an excellent venue for procuring delectable and affordable sushi for a hasty luncheon, thereby catering to individuals seeking a quick and satisfying repast. Nonetheless, it is essential to note that this eatery does not possess the optimal ambiance for a leisurely dining experience, as the seating arrangements are limited and the table settings consist of disposable utensils and Styrofoam cups. Furthermore, the waitstaff may exhibit a certain degree of inattention to detail, as evidenced by the delay in preparing the sushi rolls and the absence of sugar for the tea. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the rainbow roll and green tea offered by this restaurant are indeed exceptional, thereby rendering it a suitable destination for those seeking a satisfying and expedient meal. However, it is not recommended for dates or dinner due to the aforementioned limitations."

"A pleasing culinary establishment removed from the gambling venues, offering an assortment of delectable seafood dishes, proficiently prepared and presented with a satisfactory degree of taste, although not particularly remarkable in terms of their flavor profile; complemented by a clean and welcoming ambiance, both indoors and outdoors, with ample parking facilities and unremarkable restrooms, resulting in an overall assessment of 7/10, with a personal preference for the adjacent Texas de Brazil, rated significantly higher at 9/10."

Walked in and the SeaHawkers club had just left.  The place was a wreck and they were scrambling to get the tables cleaned and the restaurant back in order.\n\nGood service, good food and cold drinks.  Use the 4Square app and unlock an additional dollar off your drinks, even during happy hour.

Fun environment, good service.

If you are tired of high prices for average drinks, then this is another place to bring a flask to. I did not see a single tap and the beers are kinda standard; nothing to exciting and prices just over reasonable.

Been there 3 times and the bartenders are attentive and helpful. One bartender accidentally gave me too many beers in a bucket and other other politely explained to me that "she gave you an extra, enjoy it and don't worry, but I didn't want you to be surprised when there is 1 less next time." This is a situation that makes guest service snobs like me very proud to give an establishment by business.

I accorded it a three-star rating due to the fact that, overall, the hotel was merely satisfactory; I had anticipated a superior experience. My first visit to the Trump hotel was marred by the discovery of moldy food in the refrigerator! The customer service was subpar...The housekeeping staff took an inordinate amount of time to clean my room, despite my having made a timely request for their services early in the morning; however, they did not complete their task until approximately 3 pm. The hotel's location, remote from the strip, necessitated our reliance on taxis to travel to and from Caesars Palace, despite the availability of a shuttle service, as we were compelled to wait a minimum of twenty-five minutes for the shuttle, which ceased operating at midnight, thereby limiting our ability to fully enjoy ourselves and creating anxiety regarding the impending cessation of the shuttle service, prompting us to opt for taxis that charged us $20, inclusive of tips and taxes, and the taxi drivers, dissatisfied with a mere $1 gratuity, sought larger sums...It is preferable to stay on the strip to avoid the inconvenience and expense of taxi and shuttle rides! \nPros: Quiet, luxurious, odorless, well-appointed kitchen in the suites, sumptuous bathroom\nCons: A few relatively minor drawbacks. The shuttles cease operation too early and experience considerable delays in pickup. The hotel's distance from the strip makes walking an unfeasible option. There is a dearth of activities and amenities at the hotel, rendering it a rather basic establishment, despite its pool and gym facilities.

"Gastronomical indulgences of unparalleled quality, even when forgoing the limitless spaghetti option. Enjoyed an arugula and white bean salad, accompanied by a pair of penne pasta dishes, both of which demonstrated culinary proficiency. Ambient surroundings, reasonable tariffs, and attentive servers further enhanced the overall dining experience."

We have frequented this venerable establishment, which boasts an eclectic array of culinary delights, gaming facilities, and artisanal brews, on several occasions, and we must confess that the experience has been nothing short of delightful. The breakfast menu, in particular, offers an unparalleled combination of quality and affordability, with the steak and eggs option being a personal favorite, available for the remarkably reasonable price of $3.99. It is worth noting that this eatery also houses a brewery, which produces an impressive selection of craft beers, including an exceptional root beer that is not to be missed. While this may not be the most luxurious or high-end destination, it undoubtedly provides an excellent value for the money spent, and we would highly recommend it to anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience without breaking the bank. On a previous visit, we had the pleasure of enjoying a promotional offer, which allowed us to indulge in an unlimited number of Corona beers for a full hour, sans any obligation to make a purchase, and we were able to sample an impressive total of 22 Coronas, an experience that we found to be truly remarkable.

"Our dining experience was marred by an overwhelmed server who appeared flustered by the numerous tables she was attending to, and we felt somewhat inconvenient when requesting a replenishment of celery sticks, which were scantily provided alongside the delectable buffalo wings that boasted an impressive quality, albeit with varying degrees of spiciness; specifically, the mango-spicy variety was quite piquant, while the garlic Asian version was noticeably milder, and the jerk chicken offering was surprisingly bland, thus rendering the overall enjoyment of the meal somewhat inconsistent; furthermore, we were taken aback by the unexpected charge for additional celery refills, which amounted to $1.20, a sum we deemed disproportionate considering the minimal cost of a single celery stalk."

Napa location is on a different level compared to Vegas. The food and service at the bar were both a little rough. Our server/bartender completely forgot about us several times and we had to reorder a few times as well. In addition, I overheard the bartender blame the chef for an error in food to a customer. I thought that was very unprofessional. Quality of the food did not seem up to par from my previous experiences in Napa.

"I must confess an unwavering fondness for Trader Joe's; may I be so bold as to express my enthusiasm for this establishment? The prices and quality of their nuts (encompassing almonds, pecans, walnuts, et al.) and nut-based products (including almond butter, and so forth) are, in my humble opinion, unparalleled. Furthermore, their produce is of exceptional quality, and they offer an array of unique items that are simply unattainable elsewhere. Allow me to emphasize my unequivocal endorsement of Joe Joe's; indeed, it is nothing short of magnificent! 

However, I must deduct two stars from my rating due to the following factors:

1. The quest for a parking spot during peak hours (specifically between 12 pm and 1 pm from Monday to Friday) borders on the impossible. Accept the challenge at your own peril, dear reader! 

2. Lamentably, the store's dimensions are rather diminutive, leaving me with an inescapable feeling of disappointment. In spite of these drawbacks, I maintain that Trader Joe's is an outstanding retailer."

Oh Treasure Island, and your old-school pirate show, where have you gone?  Welcome to TI, and the scantily clad pirate show...my have times have changed.  Across the street from the Venetian/Palazzo sits TI.  Definitely has seen better days, and by that I mean pretty much everything.  Rooms, casino, food.  If you want to save a few bucks and stay down at this end of the Strip, this is your place.  Just be prepared to hear the pirate show every night!

You know, after going back to the convention for a second year and eating at the Golden Palace Buffet again, I have to say that ordering off of the menu provided a significant improvement over the buffet.\n\nThe food wasn't nearly as greasy and was actually quite flavorful.  I was pleased with my meal and I'm sure my friends were, too.  My friend, who was wearing a giant costume, was treated with courtesy.

"Preferring a culinary experience characterized by a pleasant combination of texture and flavor, specifically, a dish wherein the tofu is cooked to a satisfying firmness, devoid of excessive softness or squishiness, I placed an order for the yellow curry tofu, anticipating a delightful repast. Unfortunately, the restaurant's interpretation of this popular Thai dish fell short of my expectations, as the tofu was presented in a state of uninspiring softness, lacking the crispy exterior and tender interior that I had hoped for. Instead of being expertly fried or otherwise prepared, the tofu was merely cut into small pieces and added to the curry without further ado. While the rich, well-spiced curry sauce and generous portion of vegetables did somewhat compensate for this disappointment, the overall effect was diminished by the absence of a satisfying textural contrast. Notwithstanding this letdown, the eatery does offer a diverse selection of Thai dishes at reasonable prices during the lunch hour, and the unpretentious ambiance of the establishment, replete with high-top tables by the window and conventional tables inside, provided a suitable setting for a casual meal. However, the dearth of patrons during our weekday visit suggested that the restaurant may struggle to attract a consistent clientele."

Stopped by this Subway on the drive back home to Vegas from Phoenix.  It is conveniently located on the right side of the road heading to Vegas.

I ordered a 6" BMT w/Jalapeno Cheddar Bread & had it toasted.  I added Tomatoes, Lettuce, Green Peppers, Pepperoncinis, Mustard, Mayo, Oil, Vinegar, Salt, Pepper.  They made it quickly and I was eating in no time.

The ingredients were very fresh and the Sandwich tasted great.  A nice snack for the ride home.

A bonus is the clean restrooms....a quick tip is to stop here to use the restroom instead of a nasty gas station....every gas station in Wickenberg was busy with travelers using the restrooms.

Will I return?  Next time I drive to/from Phoenix, I will.

"During our most recent sojourn in Las Vegas, my associates and I opted to take advantage of an offer that allowed us to lodge at Treasure Island at a price that was considerably lower than usual. Upon arriving at the establishment, we observed the presence of a restaurant specializing in Vietnamese cuisine, which we found rather peculiar. Furthermore, we expressed our skepticism regarding the quality of the fare served within said eatery, as evidenced by our derisive comments directed towards those who had chosen to partake in their meals there, and presumably, pay an elevated price for the experience. Ironically, we would later find ourselves returning to the very same venue, albeit under different circumstances, as we sought sustenance to alleviate the unpleasant symptoms brought about by our excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages during the previous night's festivities. In conclusion, while the cost of dining at this particular Pho restaurant may be somewhat prohibitive, it remains a viable option for those seeking nourishment in the midst of a debilitating hangover, particularly for those already lodging at Treasure Island."

"It is rather perplexing that the culinary offerings at mainland L&Ls seem to lack the distinct flavor profile associated with those from Hawaii. The fare is palatable yet uninspired, which is somewhat disappointing given the brand's reputation for serving quality local-style comfort food. Furthermore, patrons should exercise vigilance when settling their bills, as the menu board prices may not align with the actual amount charged. Upon bringing this discrepancy to the attention of the staff member responsible for processing my transaction, their response was dismissive and unhelpful, citing the computerized system as the basis for the inconsistency. This raises concerns regarding the establishment's pricing policies and practices, which could potentially undermine customer trust and loyalty."

"I partook in a culinary excursion with a considerable assemblage of individuals. Our host selected a remarkable vintage, the cost of which was undoubtedly substantial. Alas, the gastronomical offerings did not entirely meet expectations. The chopped salad was unremarkable, its flavors overpowered by an excess of red kidney beans. The accompanying table breads and muffins were arid, rendering them somewhat inedible. The duck pancake, saturated with an abundance of saccharine syrup, obscured the bird's natural flavor. However, the porterhouse lamb chops proved to be the highlight of my dining experience, boasting perfectly grilled meat complemented by an unobtrusive sauce. A warm, pudding-like cake, whose name escapes me, constituted the dessert course. Unfortunately, the coffee service was tardy, prompting us to consume the cake before its arrival. Notwithstanding this drawback, the eatery remains a pleasant venue within Caesars, and I would advise future patrons to focus their orders on grilled meats and maintain tempered expectations regarding the remaining dishes."

It is a Wal-Mart store location that has recently opened its doors to the public, and my initial thoughts were that perhaps it might possess a distinct ambiance, a departure from the conventional Wal-Mart experience to which I had grown accustomed. However, upon entering the premises, I was quickly disabused of such notion, as it became apparent that this establishment adhered to the standard template associated with the Wal-Mart brand, complete with an array of unremarkable products offered at prices designed to appeal to budget-conscious consumers. Furthermore, the clientele that frequents this store appears to be drawn from the same demographic that has come to be synonymous with the Wal-Mart shopping experience, as depicted on websites such as peopleofwalmart.com, characterized by an atmosphere in which children vociferously proclaim their knowledge of numerals, while adults engage in behaviors that impede the progress of others, all within an environment that seems tailored to accommodate the preferences of senior citizens who prefer a leisurely pace when navigating the various aisles.

This particular retail establishment, which can be classified as a 'Superstore', serves as the preeminent and proximate supermarket for those residing in both Leith and Shore localities. It boasts two separate points of entry; one situated within the Tesco car park at the rear, while the alternative entrance lies on Duke Street itself. As a Tesco supermarket, it partakes in the customary activities associated with such an establishment, including the provision of clothing and electronic items for purchase. Although this 'Superstore' may appear somewhat diminutive in stature, it nevertheless manages to supply the essential provisions and maintains a convenient schedule, opening at 06:00 and closing at midnight. It is worth noting that the legal restrictions regarding the sale of alcoholic beverages before 10 am and after 10 pm apply to supermarkets as well, and some residents of Leith have been known to forget this fact, resulting in occasional disputes at the checkout. The store features a designated area for self-service tills, as well as two express lanes reserved exclusively for customers with baskets. While I do not frequent this establishment as often as I once did, particularly in light of the horse meat scandal, I still find it to be a convenient destination for procuring packaged goods such as whiskeys, spirits, wines, and chocolates. In conclusion, although this shop may not rank as the finest, it remains a serviceable option.

"Based on the copious acclaim this establishment had received, I was anticipating an exceptional experience, but unfortunately, it fell short of my expectations. Notwithstanding, I must commend the ambiance and aesthetic appeal of the venue, which were undeniably impressive. My beverage of choice, a nonfat chai latte, was somewhat unremarkable and lacking in distinctiveness, which may have contributed to my underwhelming experience. However, I must emphasize that the company was pleasant, the atmosphere was agreeable, and the interior design was indeed captivating. If I were to revisit, I would perhaps reconsider my beverage selection and opt for their coffee offerings instead, in the hopes of a more satisfactory encounter."

"Satisfactory, yet with an unfulfilled potential for further enhancement. Comparatively, a superior alternative to other establishments of similar nature within Scotland. However, my expectations were not entirely met, as the culinary offerings, despite the presence of a delectable rootbeer float, failed to completely satiate my gastronomical desires. Specifically, the primary component, i.e., the burger, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a quality that would have elevated it to an exceptional level. Furthermore, I erred in opting for the onion rings instead of the Cajun fries, as the former were merely adequate, having been previously frozen, whereas the latter held the promise of being freshly prepared. Consequently, I am now determined to seek out freshly crafted onion rings; any recommendations would be greatly appreciated."

well i wanted a place at center strip. would i have gone for the flamingo for a little more money, knowing what i know now? yes.

but... hey, can't complain. it was a little shoddy, a little dirty, and totally just fine. we had a balcony! which my sister's suite at the mirage did NOT! so there.

the buffet was fine. nothing to write home about, but so far no food-borne illness, which i'm all about.

so yes, it may not be much of a step up from the motel 6, but it is a step. a good deal at center strip. and if you're spending too much time in your room you're doing something wrong anyway!

Went here for dinner last night. 3 courses and a glass of wine (making use of the £10 set menu) strikes me as good value for money. The service from boath the greeter and waitress was pleasant and attentive and my sardine starter and hake main course w/ side of spinach were both very well cooked and presented.


 I'd like to give them a further half star but as ever having to dock a full one instead. The cheese board was the one minorly negative aspect of the meal. It could have done with a couple more oatcakes and maybe more onion marmalde and the slice of brie had clearly been allowed to dry out and harden a bit + the cheese knife had seen better days (the plastic handle was cracked clean through on both sides near the base of the blade).


 No idea if the interior's changed much since it was a Harry Ramsden's but it's well decorated and gets a lot of sun. I intend to go back.

"Utopian haven for hipsters. Bring on the 1920s era boots with dungarees that are a perfect match. 

Exquisite ambiance. A magnificent, vintage roaster is showcased and utilized extensively. 

Evidently, there is a scarcity of artisanal coffee in my hometown. A queue extended nearly to the entrance. 

I managed to acquire an espresso. It was presented promptly and proficiently. In my modest opinion, the coffee was satisfactory...not exceptional. An excess of fruitiness/acidity. Insufficient rich, velvety texture reminiscent of chocolate. However, that's merely my taste. Not necessarily everyone else's preference.

Nonetheless, my companion ordered a pour-over. And, pour-overs require a considerable amount of time. Following ten minutes of waiting, we inquired. Oh! We neglected your pour-over coffee! Wait an additional ten minutes. Derrrr...I'm unwilling to wait another ten minutes, but I suppose I must since my girlfriend and I both have an addiction to caffeine and cannot function adequately without it. 

Fortunately, I had the opportunity to sample my companion's brew, and it was delightful. 

In summary, they possess a successful formula, but minor adjustments are necessary. I would certainly revisit."

We partook of a culinary experience at this establishment in the company of our kin, and we must say, the ambiance was quite pleasant, albeit a tad tranquil for a Sunday afternoon. Upon entering the realm of the all-you-can-eat extravaganza, we were struck by an unpleasant olfactory sensation akin to that of a sewage system, which momentarily deterred us from indulging in the gastronomical offerings. However, our ardent fondness for sushi (a staggering fifteen times per mensem, no less!) impelled us to persevere and sample the wares presented. Alas, our expectations were not entirely met, as the quality of the sushi failed to meet the standards of a top-tier establishment, eliciting comparisons to the pedestrian offerings found at your run-of-the-mill grocery store. Notwithstanding, the diversity of options available on the buffet table was quite impressive, and it would have been even more satisfactory had the taste lived up to the price point.

We decided to visit this establishment subsequent to witnessing its featured appearance on Bar Rescue, and we arrived at approximately 9:30 PM. My spouse and I were eager to partake in their culinary offerings; however, the bartender informed us that the kitchen was no longer serving due to an underwhelming patronage during the evening. Despite my considerable hunger, I opted for a single beverage, primarily to facilitate my continued consumption of alcohol, as I was unable to consume sustenance. In the future, I shall unquestionably provide this venue with another opportunity to demonstrate its merits, and perhaps confer additional stellar ratings. It is worth mentioning that the local patrons were remarkably hospitable and welcoming upon our entrance, and the bartender exhibited a similar level of cordiality. I genuinely regret not being able to sample their fare.

"I thoroughly relished the culinary offerings, specifically the chicken fried steak, which was served with an ample portion of mashed potatoes and a savory gravy that complemented the dish perfectly. Additionally, a side of green beans and a preliminary salad preceded the main course, contributing to an overall satisfying gastronomical experience. However, upon entering the establishment, we encountered a degree of perplexity due to the absence of a clear greeting protocol. Despite the cozy ambiance, it is crucial for the staff to maintain a vigilant attitude towards welcoming patrons and clarifying the waiting process, which currently seems to rely on an informal 'first-come, first-served' basis. Notwithstanding this drawback, my evaluation of the restaurant remains neutral, augmented by my appreciation for its family-owned nature and the palatable fare."

Food and service were okay. Among the dishes I ate were sweet & sour soup and tofu with baby bok choy.\n\nThe decor seemed fancy. I liked the jellyfish lights near the entrance and the wood-covered menus.

"It is patently evident that this drinking establishment boasts an exceptionally pleasant ambiance, further enhanced by the rational pricing strategy implemented for the consumables served. However, it is suggested that the proprietors consider augmenting the seating capacity by introducing two diamond-shaped tables, preferably situated in a proximal location to the existing bar counter, thereby creating an atmosphere conducive to social interaction and potentially generating increased revenue through the accommodation of pool league tournaments and round-the-clock patronage."

"Average American eatery providing satisfactory culinary offerings, yet lacking any truly distinctive features. Suitable for those seeking an unremarkable dining experience. The bar section tends to be rather boisterous, making communication and auditory comprehension somewhat challenging."

Pros: Nicely laid out store with a wide variety of vintage merchandise.\nCons:  Booths are not individually signed with percentage off discounts for store sales which makes things rather confusing.  Employees are hard to identify as they don't wear aprons, badges, etc.  Your purchase will be wrapped in used newspaper instead of clean wrapping paper.  All things that can be improved upon for a better shopping experience.

"I found this establishment to be quite appealing, with an ambient atmosphere that was thoroughly enjoyable, and the hospitality we received was of an exceptionally high caliber. The beverage I consumed, specifically the mojito, was truly delectable, and the waffles were similarly impressive in terms of their culinary excellence. My offspring, who accompanied me to this venue, was particularly enthused by the red velvet pancakes, which she sampled with great relish. However, there was one aspect of our dining experience that proved to be somewhat prohibitive, and that was the cost - the prices were exorbitant, with a single order of pancakes commanding a fee of $13, a sum that I found to be rather steep and prohibitive for frequent patronage."

"An establishment that offers culinary delights, possessing an air of contemporary sophistication. It is advisable to anticipate a brief period of time, approximately 20-30 minutes, in which to secure a table, as advance arrangements or reservations are not feasible. The fare served is of satisfactory quality, however, upon my recent visit, I opted for the Eggs Benedict and was somewhat dismayed to discover that the eggs were cooked to a greater degree of doneness than I had anticipated, although the seasonings employed were indeed flavorful. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, I am inclined to accord the venue a subsequent opportunity to demonstrate its gastronomic prowess."

We halted our perambulation at this establishment for the purpose of partaking in a midday repast, as we were experiencing fatigue and an absence of inclination to continue our pedestrian journey. Both of us opted for the creamy potato and leek soup, which proved to be a delectable choice. My companion had the tuna sandwich accompanied by a side of fries, while I selected the unembellished green salad, also with a side of fries. I was dismayed to discover that my salad contained several leaves that were not as fresh as they could have been, yet the waitress, Dana, did not include them in the calculation of our bill. The fries were served hot and crispy, their flavor being enhanced by the addition of aromatic herbs. While the culinary offerings were certainly satisfactory, they did not possess any exceptional qualities that would render them memorable. Nonetheless, Dana's hospitable demeanor and attentive service left a favorable impression upon us.

Quite disappointing when I expected the same flavor and price when I was in LA. 

Don't get me wrong, the waiters/waitress were super friendly. We ordered bulgogi and ribs. The food was flavorful but average. No refills for the side dishes when you are grilling at the grill-your-own-bbq table. 

Extra: went with a groupon deal but still ended up paying way more than expected and received less food. 

TL;DR: ok place for food, clean, but does not justify the price.

Upstream is probably thought of as one of the best restaurants in Charlotte.  I am from Philadelphia where there are excellent restaurants with iron chefs so my viewpoint may be a bit skewed.   The food was good but not great or amazing.  Every dish (except the house salad) was over salted.  My husband had the tuna and I had the seabass. They were both very good but as I said before not great.  We would go there again but for sushi/raw items not necessarily the cooked menu items.  The salad was was the highlight for me (house salad) and the crab bisque was pretty tasty too.   Overall the service was very good but slow.  Our waiter was one of the most knowledgeable wait staff we have encountered since moving from PA.

After our unsuccessful attempt to dine at Harlow's due to an overwhelming influx of patrons, we opted to venture forth and sample the culinary offerings of this novel breakfast establishment. The copious servings were indeed impressive, and the fare, in general, was of superior quality. However, a slight increase in tariff did occur, yet the cost did not preclude the possibility of future visits. Unfortunately, a minor deduction in rating was necessitated due to the subpar quality of the ham, which possessed an unmistakable hint of being past its prime, and the orange juice, which was merely average. Notwithstanding, the gratuity of delectable chocolate-covered strawberries was truly remarkable.

It's BBQ at an airport.  If you're in the mood for BBQ while in the airport, well friend, you have pretty darn limited options.  This place is affordable for an airport, and decent.  Great BBQ it is not, but it's serviceable, and quite a bit better than your options to the left and right.

I went with the three meat platter.  The brisket was 1/2 fat; I'm pretty sure I got the end chunk.  The pulled pork was decent, and the turkey had a good smoke but was pretty dry.  They have one sauce option...yes or no.  Definitely not mustard-based, but recommended as it's not overbearing.  

For healthy sides...well, you're at a BBQ joint, so good luck with that.

....and boy are my arms tired!

Comedy clubs are easy to review when focusing on the club itself, and not the talent.  You could be in the perfect comedy club and see a horrible act, just as you could see something amazing at a dive bar's open mic night.  

This "club" is really  a conference room that has been converted into a comedy club.  The staff sets up chairs around the room for the patrons the night of the show, adding seats when needed.  There are a few VIP couches, but since this intimate setting is quite quaint, there really is no reason to pay the high price for them.

There are two waitresses who run around frantically trying to fill all the patrons' orders, but be ready to wait for your beverage.  Walking up to the bar in the room is usually a better way to go.  

I saw the late (9pm) show on a Saturday night.  Seating starts at 8:30, so get there early if you want to sit in the front.  Really, there isn't a horrible seat in the house though.  

I saw Todd Paul the night I went in, and laughed my A$$ off.  He was charismatic and hilarious.  His act was a mix of magic, stunts, and comedy.  He did an amazing job of making fun of Las Vegas shows, specifically magic shows.  I would definitely return for another fun night.

We ate here a few weeks ago per a recommendation from the hotel we were staying at.  While I do not eat steak a few of my friends do and they said they liked it.  I ordered the Chicken Peppered Penne which was delicious.  I asked them to make it extra spicy which they did.  The pasta was cooked perfectly, the sauce was creamy, and the dish had a great flavor.  The service was good and the prices were reasonable.

This culinary establishment serves the most delectable and flavorsome Pho within the confines of Scottsdale; however, in relation to the quality and magnitude of the dish, it can be classified as merely average or unremarkable. The broth, which is the fundamental component of the dish, is rich and savory, but unfortunately, its quantity is rather limited and its cost is disproportionately high. It appears that the restaurant is reluctant to provide an adequate amount of noodles and meat, leading to a sense of dissatisfaction and underfillment. Despite this, the service staff is quite attentive and friendly, which somewhat compensates for the deficiencies in the food. Ultimately, it is recommended to patronize this establishment, but it would be wise to supplement your meal with additional noodles and meatballs to ensure a satisfying dining experience.

"This public house exudes an aura of pleasantness, albeit with a strong inclination towards catering to the sensibilities of travelers and sightseers. Within the confines of its upper level, the culinary offerings are undoubtedly delectable, yet the ambiance fails to compare favorably with the environs situated below. Downstairs, an impressive array of authentic ales awaits discerning patrons, raising questions regarding the logic behind offering a glass of effervescent wine as a token of appreciation for relinquishing one's calling card, when either a sampling of these exceptional brews or a dram of fine whisky would prove far more apropos. Furthermore, the establishment takes pride in meticulously tracking the volume of hand-pumped ales dispensed on a weekly basis, as evidenced by the tally of 1987 recorded during the previous week, which I found rather fascinating."
Not a big fan but Tax free yeah!  Off base has more selection and you can find deals. Unless your buying a high price item i would shop elsewhere. The lines get bad so don't be in a rush.

"Alright, the embellishments within this establishment are rather kitsch and over-the-top, yet they seem to be an integral aspect of the overall experience, perhaps even intentionally so, as if to convey a sense of steadfastness and tradition amidst an ever-changing landscape; furthermore, the wait staff's attire, while aesthetically displeasing, seems to be a deliberate choice, evocative of the utilitarian and somewhat oppressive nature of workplace attire, as seen in films such as Office Space; we visited this venue for breakfast, and while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the divergence from the typical buffet-style fare found in nearby Disney-fied Las Vegas strip locales was palpable."

"Although the beer did not possess any extraordinary qualities, it was still palatable. It is worth mentioning that the establishment boasted an agreeable ambiance. However, it appeared that their primary emphasis lay in offering beverages with a sweeter flavor profile. Upon further inspection, it became apparent that they had depleted their stock of lighter brews, including the blonde variety. Consequently, we shall endeavor to sample their wares at a later time and reassess our initial evaluation."

I would not endorse this airline if you are embarking on a journey with minors, as it offers only basic amenities and lacks entertainment facilities, particularly on lengthy flights; there was no television on our five-hour voyage from New York, which resulted in the children on board becoming restless and irritable due to the lack of diversions; the seating was also quite confined and diminutive, which further exacerbated the discomfort; additionally, the aircraft appeared to be somewhat antiquated. Instead, I would suggest opting for Delta Airlines, which offers a more comprehensive range of services and amenities tailored to accommodate families with young children.

Decent place, good food, great  atmosphere to watch a game. Thank god the karaoke was not there tonight. Service could be better, mainly faster. The servers are spread too thin, as there seem to never be enough top handle the crowd. Otherwise a decent pace too have a drink, grab a bite and watch sports.

This eatery maintains a 24-hour operation and boasts an outdoor location within the Paris Hotel Casino, presenting a welcoming ambiance that exudes sophistication and refinement. While the culinary offerings may not be particularly remarkable, the dessert menu showcases an impressive array of sweet treats that are both generously portioned and affordably priced. A personal favorite is the banana split, which can easily be shared among several individuals and still leave you craving more. However, it is important to note that the Sugar Factory store on the premises tends to inflate prices for items such as mints and other confectionaries, with prices ranging from $5 to $8 for a relatively small quantity. Despite this, the venue remains a popular destination for those seeking a unique dining experience, complete with al fresco seating and a focus on delectable sweets and beverages.

"Gastronomical assessment on a scale of one to ten, based on a singular visitation:
Eight for comestibles
Five starred beverages
Eight for hospitality
Eight for ambiance
Seven for value

Personally, I found the culinary offerings to be relatively satisfactory. Particularly noteworthy was the manner in which the yolk of the eggs rested atop the dish, a hallmark of New Mexico's gastronomical tradition. The blue corn tortillas accompanying my enchiladas were substantial and possessed an appreciable texture. Regrettably, the margaritas failed to meet expectations, exhibiting an unpleasant sweet and sour taste, devoid of any discernible bite or depth. Furthermore, the machine-made quality of their production was evident, detracting from the overall experience. Lastly, the serving of salsa, while possessing a commendable level of piquancy, lacked distinction in terms of flavor profile."

While at Fiesta Mall with my son who was getting his hair cut we decided to eat. We wondered around the food court and was approached by an employee of Sarku Japan offering free samples of their teriaki chicken. After trying it my son just had to order from there.  The staff was friendly and the price was reasonable.  He ordered the teriaki chicken & shrimp. The amount of food that he got was way more than expected and he was happy it tasted like what it was suppose to. \nA definate place we'll visit in again and highly recommend!!

Maria...host, rolled her eyes and seemed to have a attitude problem\nKyahl?  Sounds like Kyle. was actually pretty good, he answered my mother in law's questions to the best of his abilities.\nThe food is always kind of hit or miss...the veal parm was good but the macaroni rosa was very bland and the broccoli in it weren't cooked and the pasta was a more al dente than we are use too...there was still a crunch

I've been here a few times and its decent food. There is nothing special about this place that makes me want to specifically go back. Although, if someone is holding a party or special occasion here I doubt I would avoid this place.

I've never been here just for lunch or dinner, so that may effect my review. Although, I've eaten this food on multiple occasions for events at the restaurant. Its good Indian food, and you can never say no to good Indian food. It just wasn't spectacular. I would give most Indian food places 5-stars if the quality of the meat they used was better and if the quality of everything they use is just better. The salads weren't green, the meat in the korma and tikka was very small. It just felt like they were cheaping out on us.

Desserts weren't really special either. If you give me gulab jamun or some jelebi, I am a sucker for that stuff. Theirs was decent, but there wasn't much of it available. However, there really isn't much better stuff in AZ in this vicinity. I'd say India Gate is a little better, maybe try that place out first.

Awwww MAN!!! I have written a review on their Pecos and Washington location, which I love and obsess about during the summer when craving sea food. However, felt like this location is lacking that \"touch\". I ordered the shrimp ceviche and fish tacos and they were definitely not as flavorful as they are at their north town location. The ceviche tasted way too fishy, needed lots of lemon and salt and the tacos where just blah!  \n\nThe restaurant itself is nice. Waitress was nice and attentive, just didn't get the same experience. The people I was with also agreed as they have also tried the other location. I will not be coming back to this location, especially because the prices have increased but worth it if you get the \"Islitas\" experience. This place does not have it. Go to north Las Vegas location. They are overpriced for the quality. I give them 3 starts only because I know they have potential on improving, or else I would give them 2.

"I placed an order for the white pizza, featuring a delectable combination of tomato, onion, and Kalamata olives, and upon consuming this culinary masterpiece, I must say it was quite flavorful. However, I must note that the cooking time was somewhat excessive, resulting in a crust that was marginally overcooked, leading to an unfortunate texture that was slightly too crunchy for my liking. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the establishment appeared to be well-staffed, and the interior ambiance was passable. Nonetheless, I must express my reservations regarding the pricing policy, as I perceived it to be somewhat steep and lacking in value. Therefore, I am unlikely to return, especially considering the distance between my location and the restaurant, and the abundance of alternative dining options that are more likely to receive my patronage."

This place was not what I expected.  It is a huge open space with a large bar stuck right in the middle.  The menu is more upscale than the usual sports 'bar' selections, but I guess that is the difference between sports bar and sports grill?

The food was good, but if I remember correctly they had little to no draft beer.  They could have had Bud or Coors or something, but to me that translates to no beer on tap.  

They have a lot of flat screen tvs as they should,  but I like a little bit more character in my sports bar.  This is much too commercial for my taste.

Nothing really special about this hotel within the hotel besides maybe shorter check in lines which is nice and asain themed room. Basically this just seems like they tried to do something special with some old space and while its nice its not really 5 star worthy.   The problem is Caesars palace is old and has horrible customer service.  Everything is slow and understaffed.   Wynn, Bellegio and Venetian are all better places to stay.

Have been to Joe's a number of times and enjoyed their food.  We have had terrible service every time, though.  It's worth going because the food is good and the atmosphere is fun.  Just be patient, and your night will be fine.
Great selection of beer. Plenty of it! The food is so-so. Typical bar-food. Very nice wait-staff and bar tenders. Large enough place to accommodate a busy night. Worth the stop.

I went here for dinner with my guy last night and I completely agree with the other reviews, the patio is fantastic. It has a great view and its surprisingly quiet and secluded while being right above Indian School road. The wine and beer selection is impressive. I really like all of the local choices. \nThe food however was underwhelming. I started with the fries which had rosemary and parmesan and a dipping sauce similar to a thousand island on the side. It was good, but not great. For our entrees we had the sausage and mushroom pizza, and the penne ragu. The pizza was tasty, it had caramelized onions three types of mushrooms and Italian sausage, the crust was just the way I like it not too crispy and not too soft, but definitely a fork and knife needed pizza. The ragu was interesting; it reminded me of everything that would be inside a shredded beef burrito but instead of a tortilla it's in a bowl with penne pasta underneath. It wasn't bad just unexpected. I wish we would have tried desert they all looked delicious, perhaps next time. \nAll in all I think this is a great place for appetizers and drinks especially on their wonderful patio.

"Prodigious coffee connoisseurs who relish the rich flavors of expertly brewed beverages may find it challenging to accurately assess the quality of a cafe's signature edibles, such as doughnuts or bagels, if they are currently abstaining from consuming them; thus, it is advisable to solicit my opinion on these culinary staples at a later time, when I have had the opportunity to indulge in them and formulate a well-informed evaluation, perhaps after a 40-pound weight gain."

Upon entering the establishment with a group of companions, I was immediately struck by the pleasant aroma that permeated the atmosphere, which piqued my interest in sampling their waffle offerings. However, upon being seated, I observed that the service was lacking in attentiveness, as no staff member inquired about our need for water or additional menus for our group of three. We eventually determined our orders and approached the counter to place them, only to be interrupted by the lady behind the counter, who shouted to another employee while my dining companion was attempting to order, which I found to be somewhat discourteous. Our meals took a considerable amount of time to arrive, but they were visually appealing. The red velvet wafflenut, Nutella and almond wafflenut, The Fat Elvis waffle, strawberry and chocolate waffle, and Vegas churro waffle with honey, cinnamon, sugar, and vanilla ice cream were all satisfactory. The churro waffle was the preferred selection among our group, while I personally enjoyed the strawberry waffle, excluding the chocolate sauce. However, due to the subpar service and inconvenient location, I do not foresee myself making a concerted effort to revisit this establishment in the near future.

Service was fast, but the burger, hotdog, and fries were overrated for the expensive price.\nInn n Out  is still my favorite fast food burger and Bachi Burger is my favorite gourmet burger place in Vegas!

It's a tourist destination, and sometimes the wait can be atrocious. So I mean you need to know that heading in. The Crispy Duck on noodles is freaking amazing, but for what it costs it should be a portion about 50% bigger. That's really my knock with LOS. The portions should be bigger given how much you're paying, or the food should just be perfect. That's where my 2 stars were lost.

My wife dragged me in here after she tried their surf n turf and raved about it. I can't comment on that yet.
We sat at the bar and played poker for awhile. Not a big deal but they make you play max bet for a 2nd drink. They were nice enough to warn me about that and still comped my 2nd drink. Might be a reason why we were about the only ones playing.
We ordered food and then sat at a table and brought our drinks with. The portions were big for the sandwiches (philly is great) and very good BUT wait till you get the bill. Yes, we saw the prices but by the time we got done with food and tip it was almost $40 for 2 sandwiches and we didn't have any drinks to pay for. 
It was good but I just don't see the attraction for a sandwich place and their prices.

We went here for our engagement dinner with our family. It was BUSY for a Wednesday night and parking...well let's just say there isn't that many parking spaces available. For a party of 13, we were stuck in the corner closest to the door. Every time someone opened the door a gust of cold air would come in or the smell of cigarette smoke. YUCK! This was when it was raining for a couple days straight. Luckily, my brothers and sister are tiny, because putting them 4 in the chairs closest to the wall worked out. No average size adult would be able to fit....yes that is how crammed we were. \nIn typical Chinese fashion, there was Lobster, Red Trout, Fried Flounder, Chicken, Beef and a lot of veggies. I felt that everything was just ok. Nothing too special and they had messed up one of the kids orders. I believe my Grandma liked it for the most part and that's all that mattered to me. Overall, I do prefer other places, but I won't be against coming back here again as long as I'm not sitting next to the door when its freezing outside.

Paul Martin's possesses numerous attributes that render it an appealing dining establishment, regrettably, the peripheral aspects are subpar. Paul Martin's exudes an air of refinement, reminiscent of upscale steakhouses in the nation's capital, with its dim yet pleasing illumination, vibrant but unobtrusive musical ambiance, and welcoming atmosphere.

The culinary offerings at Paul Martin's are generally satisfactory, with the Sunday special, comprising a salad, prime rib, and ice cream, priced at $25, being a notable example. The salad boasts a diverse array of flavors without becoming overpowering, while the prime rib is tender and benefits from an exceptional spice rub that elevates it to a higher level. Unfortunately, the interior of the prime rib is somewhat lacking in quality, resembling a vast expanse of mediocre meat. The dessert option fails to impress, as the absence of lactose-free selections renders it inaccessible to patrons with dietary restrictions, which is both disappointing and perplexing, given the high standards that Paul Martin's purports to uphold.

The service at Paul Martin's falls short of expectations, as the server appears overwhelmed on occasion, exemplified by their response to our query regarding lactose intolerance, where they erroneously inform us that the ice cream is gluten-free. Furthermore, the staff's handling of gift cards sold by the establishment borders on offensive, as paying customers are made to feel awkward and guilty for utilizing them.

In conclusion, Paul Martin's cuisine warrants a rating of four stars, whereas its service only manages to achieve two stars. Thus, a rating of three stars seems appropriate.
Staff here is usually very nice and helpful and not overbearing. Everything is kept nice and tidy. I just feel that this location does lack in variety and sizes...

So, heres the deal...Uncle Bears is a great place to meet up with friends for dinner, a few beers and a game. The menu is ok. Nothing too great, nothing bad. I like the sliders. They're pretty solid every time I get them. The Chicken Fajitas are good too and contrary to what some other yelpers have said, they do not taste like rubber. 

Beer selection is great for the area. There are several local beers on tap from Four Peaks and several national micros as well.

The theme and decor are great. As a dog owner, we love looking at pictures of everyone else's dogs and wondering after all these years of going to this place, why we've never brought in a picture of our own dogs. 

This is just a good old all around neighborhood bar and grill.

D'Arcy McGee's serves up a mix of various cuisines that can be best summed up as Anglo-Saxon origin.  Ranging from dishes such as Irish boxty, corned beef and cabbage, Scotch eggs, Canadian poutine, and British Yorkshire pudding, portions are hearty and service is cheerful and pleasant.  The food quality itself is just OK, but it's a nice change of pace from your standard wings, pizza, or sandwiches that you find at other bar-type restaurants.

"Although the pho served at this establishment may be of satisfactory quality, it fails to rank among the superior offerings of its genre that are available in the city of Pittsburgh, particularly when considering the absence of fresh lettuce and herbs as an accompaniment. However, it is worth noting that the proprietor of this business exhibits a commendable level of cordiality towards patrons."

This Marble Slab Creamery is located in Stonecrest Shopping Center, towards the front of the development near JoJo's, Miro, Dean & Deluca, etc.  It's your standard ice cream shop.  It had a decent variety of flavors, along with some \"Ice Cream Cupcakes\" that I had never seen before.  Whole ice cream cakes in various sizes were also included in a stand-up freezer.  A few chairs and tables scattered about, but this is located near the plaza with plenty of outdoor seating near the big fountain, should weather permit.  \n\nOn this visit, I decided to get one of the ice cream cupcakes to try later - it was fine.  I purchased a Birthday Cake milkshake along with that, which wasn't blended particularly well, so the first sips were just sweet milk, followed by clumps of ice cream.  Again, fine.  Nothing special.  The employees were nice enough.  I wasn't wowed, but wasn't expecting to be - it was A-OK.

This particular venue boasts a proximate location in close vicinity to an outlet mall, thereby rendering it easily accessible to patrons. Within the establishment's premises, staff members proffer packing tape to customers upon request, a convenience notably absent at certain alternative locations where purchase is mandatory. Furthermore, the personnel assigned to customer service duties exhibit a demeanor characterized by kindness and helpfulness, a stark contrast to the demeanor displayed by certain individuals employed by the United States Postal Service.

My husband and I stopped in before we went to see a movie. We had already had dinner so we only stopped in for a cocktail and some deserts. 

We sat on the patio which was really nice. We were the only ones sitting at the patio, so we were worried that we would be forgotten about but the service was still rather good.

He had a beer and I had a frozen strawberry margarita. The margarita was slightly watered down and could have used a bit more strawberry to it. My husband tried a beer called Victoria which actually wasn't bad at all. I also ordered a frozen ice cream. I went with the vanilla ice cream. The presentation was lovely and I enjoyed the deep fried ice cream. 

I did hit up the bathroom before we headed out to the theater and I was very impressed with the bathroom. The women's bathroom has a large full sized mirror and the handicapped/nursing bathroom is very large and has ton of room. 

Overall, it was a nice experience and we may end up going back for dinner on our next date night.

Rented a 25 footer that had electrical difficulties on three occasions over a ten day trip.  Luckily their help desk personnel were fabulous in getting a service technician out to remote national parks to try to fix the problem.  Unfortunately the rig had been improperly serviced before and the problem persisted.  It was disappointing the rig was put on the road but once we got the battery problem solved our experience was quite good.  I would rent again but would try to get a newer vehicle (ours had 98,000 miles) and try to verify the condition.

We went to Fairview Grill for dinner and drinks one night. We expected an evening of pub food, draft beer, and an unpretentious atmosphere, and that's exactly what we got.  

We had a coupon for a free entree, so to us the prices were VERY reasonable.  Generally entrees (mostly sandwiches and burgers) are about $8, which is an excellent value considering the quantity of food you get. We both had burgers, and we were both very pleased. My husband had fries, which he enjoyed, and I got onion rings (of course), and they were above average. The waitress got our order correct (even the "hold the X, extra Y" order we placed) without writing it down.  She was very attentive, and kept the beer and water flowing.  

The atmosphere is one of a relaxed pub--everyone was very friendly there too, including two guys who waved at us upon entering and asked how we were doing.  

Because we are right down the street from Fairview Grill, we will definitely be returning.  Might even shoot a game or two of pool. I don't know if it stands out among pubs in town, but it was an enjoyable evening overall.

"The lodging establishment and its personnel are exceptional. I have a predilection for Hilton hotels and, in terms of accommodations, this particular venue is satisfactory. However, the location is not optimal due to the necessity of utilizing taxi services to reach destinations beyond walking distance; nevertheless, the guestroom and overall structure are quite pleasant. 

It is advisable to avoid participating in a timeshare sales presentation if feasible. The reduced tariff for the hotel stay was not worth the unpleasant sensation lingering in my mouth after enduring a prolonged sales pitch lasting two and a half hours. 

In the event that you already possess ownership and have dedicated yourself to taking vacations, then indeed, this would be a suitable place to lodge. 

In the event that you resemble the majority of individuals and are unable to tolerate aggressive sales tactics, I would refrain from accepting any offers that may appear appealing in exchange for attending a sales presentation, as it is unequivocally not worthwhile. I would willingly return in time and compensate someone to avoid reliving that experience once more."

I am fond of the concept of this establishment, as it offers the opportunity to partake in live musical performances while enjoying a meal before proceeding to witness a comedic act in the adjacent venue. The culinary offerings were indeed delectable. However, my sole grievance pertains to the sluggish pace of the service, as it required an excessive duration of time to receive our initial course of fried potato slices. Despite their flavorfulness, the prolonged wait was unacceptable. Nevertheless, the assortment of beverages available on tap was impressive. It is my hope that the efficiency of the service will improve with the passage of time.

"My expectations were not entirely met, as I had anticipated a more satisfactory culinary experience, encompassing an unhurried and indulgent dinner, marked by seamless service and a palpable sense of refinement. However, my entrÃ©e arrived prematurely, prior to my completion of the appetizer, and the concluding dessert course fell short of my expectations, thereby diminishing my overall satisfaction. Despite the laudable quality of the cuisine, the hurried pace and perceptible deficiency in attention to detail detracted from the dining experience, leading me to question the commensurability of the cost with the value received."

"This particular paper possesses adequate quality, augmented by the convenience of accessing the writers. Moreover, I find the geographical positioning of the publication to be highly advantageous, as it lies in close proximity to my workspace, thereby enabling me to easily acquire the necessary materials through a brief pedestrian excursion. Furthermore, this newspaper serves as an excellent supplementary fuel source for my outdoor fire pit, eliciting mirth and providing an additional practical utility."

"In conclusion, an enjoyable night was had within the confines of this vibrant, pseudo-loungy Portuguese establishment, boasting a dynamic ambiance that afforded patrons the opportunity to observe the culinary process, while simultaneously socializing with an upscale clientele. The advantages of dining here include a wide-ranging menu replete with delectable options and an atmosphere conducive to conviviality. However, it is imperative to note that the cost of indulging in a diverse array of tapas, main courses, beverages, and wine can quickly add up, resulting in a substantial financial investment, especially considering the premium pricing of certain seafood and fish dishes, which hover around the $40 mark. Therefore, those with limited financial resources would be wise to exercise caution when deciding whether to partake in the culinary offerings of this esteemed eatery."

This is my first time to this Hampton Inn location. The set up is typical of other Hampton Inns. But, the staff is friendly and helpful unlike some other locations I have been to. I arrived before 3 PM and the front desk was able to put me into a room right away without fuss. The room is clean.\n\nI went to the Fitness Center in the late afternoon and discover the fitness closet instead. It was mislabeled as a Fitness Center. It was a small space with three pieces of equipment and a few balls. This fitness closet cannot accommodate more than 4 people at at time. So disappointed.

was, okay.

I had the lamb entree, nothing exceptional.  could use more fresh veggie on the plate versus just legumes.

lamb cooked well but was not memorable at all. (no rosemary or other good taste)--was SOO PLAIN as if i was eating british food.

service:

waitor was nice
one server came with our dishes and we had to move things on our table to make space.  we are used to services being experienced enough to prep our table or manage the dishes they are carrying.

department stores are always awful spaces to be in, BUT, there IS something that changes a bit during the madness of the holiday rush, like the mania of our commodity/consumer culture reveals itself in a particularly fascinating way... the emphasis on the DISPLAY takes on new urgency and obsession during december. I had kind of a great time just people watching as i tagged along behind my brother who was looking for a necklace for his gf. Call it a sick fascination, but i actually like being in the thick of the spectacle for the holidays... so, even though i bought nothing, i did have kind of a fun 25 minutes skulking around the multi-level store.\n\nI will also add, that this particular Bay has the most enormous and endless perfume section I've even experienced... each of the aisles in the near-infinite procession of stocked smells is equally attended by some charming model-esque figure who is only too eager to spritz some Cher-endorsed stink in your face... hellish yet hypnotic!

those that know me know i like to have a good time. 

i usually do.

went with a group of around 30, so yeah it was crazy.

for some strange reason, i just wasnt feeling this place. yeah the usual things youd find at a strip club are here..  cute to a few HOTT ladies walking around preying on drunk folks. random ass femalecustomer getting it on with a group of said ladies.... hella expensive ass drinks......

but strip clubs are like masturbation.... in the begining it all seems like a great idea, youre all excited and during, youre having a great time..... but after a few minutes after, you realized, damn i just fucked myself.
 
+1 star for that cute stripper that actually seemed like she was enjoying chatting and took me over to an abandoned area not being used that night just to chat about random ass shit and not to clean me out of all my money.

"Culinary indulgence, atmospheric delight, and aesthetic appeal are hallmarks of this establishment, but regrettably, the service experience falls short of expectations due to evident ineptitude and inefficient management, leading to an unfortunate and prolonged waiting period for patrons."

I was excited to come here last Saturday to see Billy Gardell.  I knew I was going to get royally screwed out of tons of money by this place so I was semi-prepared.


Pros:
* Great acts
* Very intimate setting = every seat is a good seat with a good view of the stage
* Reasonable ticket prices
* Parking validation
* Decent food at reasonable prices for good portions
* Friendly service that is relatively fast and efficient

Cons:
* They cram you in like sardines
* Their drink prices are ridiculous and they make you buy two of them
* If you order food you still have to buy 2 wicked overpriced drinks.  The price of your food does NOT count towards some stupid minimum.
* They add a mandatory tip % to your bill


The bottom line is that I won't be back to this place until they fix how much they rape you or there is a comic that I really really really want to see.  I realize that they are in biz to make money and are probably raking it in, but they can go fuk themselves for being greedy and making me hate comedy theaters.

My companions hold this establishment in high regard, yet my personal assessment is somewhat tepid. It is contingent upon one's penchant for a particular type of pizza, as individual preferences vary greatly in this regard. I do not partake in pizza that is heavily reliant on bread, as the sauce is the paramount component that determines its quality. Unfortunately, the pies served here are rather parsimonious with their sauce and cheese, which does not align with my predilections. Those who appreciate a superior crust may find this place appealing, but it does not suit my tastes. Being a native of Chicago, I have been exposed to an abundance of exceptional pizza venues, which has elevated my standards. While Phoenicians may recommend various establishments, my experiences have led me to conclude that they are merely mediocre in comparison to the renowned Lou Malnattis or Giordano's in Chicago.

"It is Carowinds, an amusement park boasting an array of thrilling rides, albeit the majority are encircled by attractions that may not pique one's interest or warrant expenditure. Nonetheless, the juvenile contingent is bound to experience enjoyment, undoubtedly. The patrons are amiable and courteous, fostering a welcoming atmosphere. Notably, the collective hospitality extended to gatherings is commendable, featuring delectable brisket and chicken dishes. One can derive satisfaction from partaking in such amenities."

Came here as one of the stops for the \"Buffet of Buffets\" 24 hour pass thing. It's nothing compared to the buffet at the Wynn but I don't think this buffet deserves so many one and two star reviews. Yes, the selection is limited but the food isn't crappy either. The interior is inviting. The line sucks unless you're a diamond/platinum member.

Need a 1/2 star button. 3-1/2 stars here. Tried tamale chx salad and raspberry tea. The chx salad was good (grapes, celery, green onion, almonds) sliced so thin makes not one thing overpowering..tamale was not bad not dry somewhat flavorful...they were out of strawberry honey tea, settled for raspberry-typical... Meal was only $8, not bad..probably won't be back except to try this strawberry-honey tea ppl are yelling about..very friendly and fast

We arrived too late to be seated and were quickly told as much the second we walked through the door.

But we were hungry and so very pleased to find out they would let us order take out. 

The food was prepared fast and tasted good. It was my first time eating at this chain so I'm not sure how it normally tastes. I really liked the garlic aioli that came with my pasta. The salad was tasty.

The manager Adam Wilcox, accommodated some of our party's particular requests.

They have gluten-free options - make sure you order them specifically even if you are ordering off the gluten-free menu.

I had a great burger here the night--it was a no-frills deal, like something you're mom would've made if she were in a rush. But it was tasty. Coupled with a few beers (and the P-stone has a TON), it was a great little meal. \n\nThe P-stone's a cool little place, although it doesn't look like much from the street. In fact, it really doesn't look like anything at all, really. Groovy, mellow crowd hangs here, so it's not a real rowdy scene if that's what you're looking for. Very familiar feel--like a mom and pop deal, if that makes sense. It seems like a cook place to hang out with a bunch of friends on a random, quiet night.

Came here a little while back to see Fu Manchu - the stoner rock band, that is, not the movie. This little dive on the southeast corner of Hayden and Roosevelt in a little strip mall used to be called Chaser's. Saw a few local bands there a few times back in the day - Zen Lunatics, One Foot In The Grave. One Foot In The Grave was sort of a Sun City novelty punk band about 2 decades ago when all members being over 50 was actually a novelty. Now that most punk bands from the first wave or even the hardcore years are all past 50 that novelty has long worn off. :) So the bar pretty much looks the same as it did during the Chaser's years and place had a good sized crowd - you had to squeeze your way through to get from point A to point B. Men's bathroom didn't even have a door but at least it had working toilets - no peeing in coffee cans here. Had one gin and tonic - tasted a little watery so I didn't get any more. Headliners were super loud. Like holy crap I forgot my earplugs loud. Like stop by the bookstore tomorrow and get the Sign Language For Dummies LOUD! It's ok for shows but I wouldn't come here again unless I  REALLY REALLY want to see whatever band is playing here.

Best way to describe this place- you get what you pay for. It wasn't a super classy or fancy joint, but it was a decent, cheap place to crash.  Can't complain too much about it.  The service was good, my room and bathroom were clean, and there was shuttling to and from the strip (if you don't mind walking a bit of distance... it only goes to the mall on the Stratosphere end of the strip) and to and from the airport. All my needs were met, thus I was content. Overall, decent hotel at a very good price (especially for such an expensive place like Vegas).
friendly folks and unusual items. I've always found the quality good and the produce fress. I like the dried fruit and nut selection too.

"Positives:  The concoction of a muddled cocktail elicited a profound sense of satisfaction, its intricate blend of flavors harmonizing in a manner that transcended mere palatable considerations.  The service, characterized by an acute attention to detail and a genuine concern for the patron's comfort, contributed significantly to the overall enjoyment of the dining experience.  Furthermore, the menu featured an array of options diversified by both price and culinary style, thereby catering to a broad spectrum of gastronomical inclinations.  Finally, the ambiance of the establishment exuded an air of modern sophistication, the sleek decor fostering an atmosphere conducive to conviviality and relaxation."
"Negatives:  Unfortunately, the cuisine did not quite live up to the lofty expectations engendered by the restaurant's otherwise laudable attributes.  Although the menu boasted an impressive array of creative dishes, their execution often fell short of the promised experience, with the result that the gustatory component of the meal proved somewhat anticlimactic.  Moreover, the sheer volume of stylized menu selections tended to overshadow the actual quality of the food, leading to a disproportionate emphasis on aesthetics at the expense of culinary substance."

We were eager to indulge in a culinary escapade at Julian Serrano, primarily due to their extensive selection of tapas and their renowned ceviche. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the mixed seafood ceviche, which, unfortunately, did not live up to my expectations, as it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that I had anticipated. However, the steamed mussels proved to be a satisfying alternative, with their tender texture and subtle flavors. Our companions opted for the spare ribs and mushroom risotto, respectively, neither of which particularly impressed them, sadly.

It is alright.

Ordered a chicken pita sandwich. The pita bread itself was good, wished more of the cucumber sauce, and the chicken was thick and enough - to make your money's worth. Just needed something else to give it a 4 or 5.

Of course there are plenty of other options to go to, if not feeling for chicken pita sandwich.

BEWARE. THEY USE LEAN MEAT!!\nhaha, Just sayin', the burger was kinda dry. but definately a pretty good burger and fries. got 2 burgers, and shared a thing of fries. total bill $30. Not bad, wouldn't go back though
Can't beat $2 for a any size latte on Wednesdays.  Small latte?  $2 please.  Medium latte?  $2 please!  Large latte?  $2 please!  You get the idea.  Hint:  I'd go with the large...

"There isn't a remarkable amount to articulate regarding this establishment, as it embodies a quintessential character that is reminiscent of numerous other similar venues. Its aesthetic appeal is pleasant, yet unremarkable, and the culinary offerings, while satisfactory, do not possess an exceptional quality that would render them memorable. Although I did not have the opportunity to sample their signature pizza, my impression remains that the experience was unexceptional and unlikely to prompt an enthusiastic return visit. However, I would suggest this location to groups of acquaintances seeking a casual atmosphere where they can enjoy beverages and fare while viewing sporting events."

While holding a divergent perspective regarding the superior quality of the fried poultry served at this establishment, I concur with the notion that it constitutes a remarkable local discovery within the city of Charlotte, offering delectable fried cuisine that caters to both regional patrons and visiting gastronomes with equal proficiency. The venue experiences a high volume of patronage, with a constant influx of customers from 11 am onward, culminating in either the exhaustion of the daily menu items or the closure of the eatery. It is imperative to note that the restaurant only accepts paper currency, thus it is advisable to verify the availability of funds in one's wallet prior to arrival, and refrain from allowing the presence of pedestrians gathered adjacent to the sidewalk to deter you, as this phenomenon is customary and not indicative of any anomaly. The ordering process is expedited, resulting in the rapid procurement of culinary items, followed by a prompt departure to accommodate the succeeding patron in line. The menu features a variety of fried delicacies, including chicken and fish options; personally, I advocate for the unwavering preference of poultry. Supplementing the meal with hush puppies and coleslaw contributes to an enhanced dining experience. I recommend paying a visit to this establishment to form your own opinion.

I failed to acquire any edible items to consume during my visit due to the fact that I was in the process of recuperating from a bout of food poisoning. However, my significant other managed to procure the spicy pork tacos, which he asserted were the most delectable tacos he had ever had the pleasure of consuming. This establishment exudes an aura of authenticity, as evidenced by the lengthy queues and numerous patrons in attendance. My companion awarded five stars in recognition of the culinary excellence displayed by the eatery. 
  Notwithstanding, one cannot help but wonder if the prolonged waiting period is truly justified. The duration of the queue significantly diminishes the overall rating, relegating it to a mere three stars. The system employed for organizing the queue was utterly perplexing. Numerous patrons have pointed out that there are separate lines for various types of fare. In total, there are six distinct lines, divided into two sets of three. The first set consists of lines dedicated to pork (abodaba), offal (including brains, tongue, stomach, tripe, intestines, et cetera), and beef (encompassing asada, et cetera). Despite its apparent length, the queue moved at a glacial pace, making the prolonged delay seem utterly absurd. 
  Upon drawing closer to the front of the line, it became apparent that the sluggishness was attributable to a single individual performing the duties of two people. Although he demonstrated remarkable speed in crafting the tacos, he was responsible for preparing a minimum of five tacos for every patron. Moreover, he produced an excess of fifty tacos while we waited, ostensibly for takeout orders (wrapped in foil and placed on paper plates). The combination of the time required per person and the additional tasks undertaken by the taco artisan for the benefit of those not present in the queue contributes substantially to the interminable delay. It appears that there must exist a more effective method for them to manage their operations!

Gorgeous casino, décor scheme seems to be taken from the Bellagio gardens- good mix of stores, restaurants, and gaming. Really appreciate how spacious this casino is, lots of space to walk around without cramming slot machines into every available nook.

Service is typically very top notch, and restaurants on site are known for being able to accommodate any dietary restriction and have several vegan, vegetarian, and vegetable-laden options at each.

Parking garage is smaller than most but easily accessible, casino itself is on the smaller side but more intimate and upscale rather than crowded and gaudy.

"Indulged in the popcorn embellished with bacon as an introductory course - it was satisfactory, but failed to elicit an enthusiastic response. Opted to share the chicken and waffles - not remarkably delectable, but perhaps my taste buds are simply not attuned to the combination of poultry and waffles (forgive me if my opinion seems heretical). However, we did sample the short rib, which proved to be rather savory! Accompanied by an assortment of unpalatable greens that we merely nibbled at before abandoning them entirely. \n\nIn the event that you decide to partake in the culinary offerings, it is advisable to arrive promptly, lest the interior space becomes excessively boisterous, rendering communication across the table a strained endeavor."

This eatery presented an aesthetically pleasing ambiance, with tasteful ornamentation that contributed to a welcoming atmosphere; however, the culinary offerings proved to be merely adequate. Our dining experience was initiated due to a recommendation from a patron who had partaken in their beef noodle soup approximately one year prior and expressed immense satisfaction with its quality; regrettably, their expectations were not met during our visit, as they conveyed disappointment regarding the lack of flavor. It is worth mentioning that the prices listed on the menu were considerably elevated, particularly when compared to other establishments within the vicinity; nevertheless, as we were recipients of complimentary meals, I cannot express dissatisfaction with regard to cost. My individual order consisted of Hainan Chicken Rice, which unfortunately exhibited an excessive degree of dryness, as the grains were not adequately saturated with sauce or broth, resulting in a comparatively unremarkable dish. In addition, the Beef Chow Fun failed to impress, despite being cooked to an acceptable standard. Noteworthily, the Iced Coffee we ordered was the highlight of my meal, priced at six dollars per cup. Furthermore, the Fried Shrimp Balls garnered favorable reviews from our party, appearing on a dim sum trolley. To my dismay, the Soupy Dumplings, which I eagerly anticipated, were not characterized by an abundance of moisture, leading to middling enjoyment. Ultimately, the majority of dishes sampled fell short of exceptional quality, thereby rendering future visits unlikely.

I recently had a quick bite to eat at this location.  My usual......Bean Burrito and 7 Layer Burrito.

Order was accurate.

Place was clean.

Food was ok.

It's Taco Bell....not much to say.

Will I return?  Sure.

"I had the privilege of partaking in a culinary experience at this esteemed establishment on Valentine's Day, and thus, I was presented with the opportunity to sample their pre-fixed menu. Unfortunately, the cost of the meal was somewhat prohibitive due to the festive nature of the occasion. Moreover, the quality of the cuisine did not quite meet my expectations, perhaps owing to the fact that the kitchen had to prepare large quantities of food for the influx of patrons. Notwithstanding the diminutive proportions of each dish, I failed to complete any of them, as my palate was not sufficiently impressed. Furthermore, my companion and I still felt a lingering sense of hunger subsequent to our meal.
