Nonetheless, the ambiance of the restaurant was quite pleasant, as we were seated in close proximity to a window that offered an unparalleled panoramic view."

It's an airport. You get to Vegas and then you immediately go straight to partying. Even the airport is calling for a party with the slot machines located at the baggage claims. \n\nThis airport moves pretty quick too. They get the job done and fly you to your destination! wohoo!

minus a star for not having an EPL ticket to show all the games. for F###'s sake you are THE english bar in phoenix and I can't watch my beloved gunners unless they are on ch 167?? come on.  
If you are going to hang the flags and scarfs at least have the game, when its 7am and i want to get pissed watching arsenal-chelsea in the '5th' biggest city in the US and I cant, well, it doesn't make daddy happy. haha
all in all not a bad place
great beer selection
nice decor, simply put, its one of those places where you get some drinks in for 2-3 hours, walk out and say "holy sh!t, the sun is still out????"

Took my Playstation 3 here after it stopped reading discs.  Had to take it back twice, still wasn't fixed.  In all fairness, the problem was beyond the scope of the repair, and they gave me a full refund.  That's superior policy/customer service.

On the downside, they removed my yet-unplayed copy of GTA 5 and stuck it in a ziplock bag after I offered to leave the case for them to put it in.  Disc looked like someone ate a bucket of chicken and put their hands all over it.  Also, I came back twice to have it re-repaired and each time was like I'd never been there before.  "Can I help you?"

I'll consider this experience a wash, as I left with the same broken unit but was not charged for the time invested.  Not certain I'd take anything else there.

I ate at Tutti Santi while in Phoenix for a business conference.  Met up with a co-workers father-in-law who happened to be in town and he suggested Tutti Santi, which he had visited on previous trips.  Had it not been for that recommendation, I don't know that I ever would have found this place.

They were quite busy that night due to a special promotion and it seemed that they were not quite used to it.  It took quite some time to place our order.  We ordered a bottle of wine for the table and I ordered a salad and gnocchi.  We started sipping the wine while waiting for our appetizers.  The salad was decent and the bread they brought for the table was actually very good.  However, due to the slow service, our wine bottle was empty long before the food came.

When the food arrived, we ordered another bottle of wine and began eating.  The gnocchi was very good, and everyone else seemed to enjoy their order as well. Unfortunately, our second bottle of wine never arrived.  When we mentioned it, the waiter apologized, but that was it.

This would have been an easy four star review but the sub-par service killed it for me. They may have been busy, but 15 minutes for drinks and 30 minutes for salads is still pushing it.

Table of 4, wait was 20++ minutes late on a Thursday night.   No bar to wait in, plus no alert system (buzzer or whatever) so we couldn't wander around the casino.   Once we were seated, the food was great.....  Just burgers but lots of toppings, etc.   Nothing bad nor was it overly memorable.  Very sufficient for a bite in Harrahs!

I am not too picky about movie theaters. We usually go to the theater with the show times we like best. They all could use a more frequent deep cleaning, and this one is no different.\n\nIt bothers me, though, when people think it is the movie theater's job to clean up after them, so they leave their trash in the aisle and on the seats. You bought it, you own it, you dispose of it up. Didn't your mom teach you to clean up after yourself?

Applebee's is usually good for reasonably priced, decent tasting food. My experience at this particular Applebee's wasn't horrible but also wasn't anything that would make me want to go back. 

Our party of three was seated quickly but service got fairly slow after that. Our waitress brought out wrong type of beer for one of the people with me, took a while to bring out the correct one and then took ages to bring extra napkins.

I had a lunch special that included half of a sandwich and a small salad. I had the shrimp and spinach salad which was excellent. The sandwich I went with was the California turkey club. The lettuce tasted sour, I had to pick it all off... And the bread was greasier then I would have preferred.

The sangria was damn tasty but could have used more fruit.

"I have had the experience of visiting this location on a previous occasion, and my impression was that it possessed a diminutive size, which was compensated for by an abundance of commercial establishments and a plethora of live musical performances. However, the ignition of the praying mantis at approximately 9 pm failed to resonate with my personal preferences, as I found the overall ambiance to be tailored predominantly towards family-oriented patrons, thereby engendering within me a sense of incongruity and prompting my companion and I to seek alternative forms of entertainment. Although I cannot rule out the possibility of revisiting this venue at some point in the future, I must confess that it does not currently hold a prominent position on my list of preferred destinations."
Way too over priced. I mean its great food. With an average sized portion. But for how much I'm paying?... Not totally worth it!

Here's the thing, I genuinely desire to endorse this establishment. It proximates my domicile, the minuscule cakes perpetually appear delectable, and an agreeable aroma permeates the atmosphere. I've visited this location on multiple occasions, and each time, I've encountered distinctive and imaginative flavors that I've seldom witnessed elsewhere; Pink Lemonade, Chocolate Covered Banana, and Peanut Butter and Honey, who would conceive of such combinations?!

However, possibly I frequented this establishment during inopportune periods. The cake presented itself as succulent and appetizing. Nonetheless, the icing proved excessively abundant and overpowering, even for my better half, who relishes sweets to an extent where he could effortlessly devour an entire tray of brownies unassisted and in a single sitting. He needed to extract the icing midway through consumption since it became too copious for his taste buds.

I won't relinquish my yearning for their products though! I shall likely revisit this venue due to my infatuation with cupcakes (we even incorporated them into our wedding celebrations), as I ardently aspire to appreciate their offerings.

"While I acknowledge that certain individuals may hold the opinion that this particular Buffett is of superior quality, I must respectfully disagree with such sentiments. In my personal experience, the breakfast offerings at this establishment far surpass the quality of the dinner options, and it is worth noting that the menu items for both meals share a considerable amount of overlap. Furthermore, I find it somewhat perplexing that there is such a significant discrepancy in the level of satisfaction between the two meals, leading me to question the validity of the claim that this Buffett is indeed the best."

I will start by saying this, the midnight Diner is probably one of the better staple restaurants in Charlotte. However my experience tonight did not reflect that. After being sat and refused to change my order by our server, Ashley - we then received beyond mediocre service.  Feeling somewhat stereotyped into the mold of \"black people don't tip\". Luckily a server by the name of Larry a.k.a \"Showtime\" managed to salvage what remained of an otherwise horrible experience. He definitely exempified the prototype of what anyone would call excellent service. Needless to say our server received no tip. Hopefully she learns something from her peers. Definitely will be back...and requesting \"Showtime\" as our server for the duration of his tenure there.

I always know I'm in Vegas when I come here and spend 20 bucks on a subway 5 dollar footlong lmao! Seriously how is it even legal for subway to rip you off like that haha. \n\nSlots of fun is like a 20 ton boulder going down hill....once it gets going...unstoppable. I don't even gamble here. When I stay at riviera I usually just come over to slots of fun to grab a nathans hot dog or some Over priced subway sandwiches. That being said there is something I like about the place. Just really old school vegas. Vegas actually needs more places like this. Hate to say it but I will be back lol

Being from Chicago/San Diego my husband and I are in for a shock here in the Carolinas, this was our first dining experience. I don't know how we ended up here with the plastic coated checkered table cloths and lack of ambience, but we stayed and ate. 

I was looking on the menut for the typical California wrap donned with bean sprouts and avocados; instead I found southern fried chicken, skillet fried chicken, veggie lasagna, meatloaf, coleslaw, fried okra, collard greens... and of course BBQ. 
My question to you is WHAT ON EARTH IS BBQ? Is it a sauce? Pork? Beef? Chicken? No clue... 
Anyways we ordered from their extensive menu ( the variety of "veggies" is outrageous, but mostly fried). 

***Note to North Carolina: Food does taste good without having to be breaded and dropped in piping hot fatty lard. 

The food ended up being good and large portions and the waitress was "sweet as piiiie" with her "yes maam's" and polite service. 
Overall, I am hoping to find a restaurant with more of a variety than sandwiches, southern home cooking and the most unhealthy vegetables I've ever seen.
Good location for a decent bite to eat before the game. Gets busy, but the food and service is good. Little on the pricy side.

This place is ok for a vietnamese restaurant. First impression walking in- this place smells of cigars! Later I realized it's the smell of the cigar bar next door. 

Service was rather quick. The man who attended to us seemed to be the owner, he was approachable and would give recommendations if you ask. 

Our food was out pretty fast. I ordered the beef pho with eye round steak and beef balls while the bf got his usual chicken pho. We also got the vietnamese iced coffee. 

I love the broth! It was not as greasy as some of the other vietnamese places I've been to, and you can actually taste the herbs. The rice noodles was meh, it was a little too starchy for me, for some reason. The eye round steak was a little overdone. Iced coffee was a tad too sweet, there's a little too much of the condensed milk. 

Overall, a decent experience. I'll probably come back again. 

Side note: if you like spicy food, ask for the ot satay sauce. it's basically Thai chillies fried with garlic paste and it is SPICY- a much better alternative to siracha, in my opinion.

This place... how could one not love it?! The drinks are amazing and the price is just right!! I personally recommend the \"G Spot\" or a martini. The food is excellent here as well. I usually get the Fez burger. I am not sure what all is on it, but I can tell you that it tastes amazing!! So why the 3 stars?... Unfortunately I woke up later that night very ill. Since this place was not the only food I had all day, I can't say for sure that I got sick from here. However, I'm hesitant to visit again now.

Evidently, there exists a Zagat survey list pertaining to the optimal chain restaurant steak, which I find utterly absurd. Would they compose a list assessing the finest cinematic depiction of grass growth? "In the end, Crabgrass surpassed Ragweed due to its potential allergens." No, since sometimes an entire category of items can be created that are subpar, and chain eateries, as a general rule, offer unsatisfactory steak. Not that I'm passing judgment. So, if you dine at Outback, refrain from anticipating anything remarkable, despite Zagat's assertion that they served delectable steak. However, Outback remains worth visiting, as their shrimp appetizer, presented on a brown bread garlic slab-thing, is sublime. The bread itself surpasses the shrimp in quality. It's truly amazing. But to attain genuinely legendary status, envision an appetizer containing such copious calories that three individuals could share it and still consume over a thousand calories apiece. Enter the cheese fries accompanied by bacon and a dollop of ranch, and you will comprehend the sensation of spoonfuls of lard within your arteries. This specific establishment boasts several exceptional bartenders, and if you seek a gratifying experience and passable cuisine, you shall be content. Chicken breast smothered in BBQ sauce: palatable. Broccoli augmented with crab-butter sauce? Delicious. A rack of lamb? Surprisingly satisfying. In truth, there are numerous options available here, but one thing you will not encounter is world-beating steak. Hence, it is pointless to rely on Zagat's survey.

"This bar boasts an exceptional atmosphere, rendering it an ideal location for sipping beverages and engaging in people-watching activities or simply socializing with companions. The dÃ©cor exudes a sophisticated lounge-style ambiance, enhanced by the well-crafted drinks served here, which, although not the most extensive selection, are undoubtedly palatable, particularly for a casino bar. \n\nMy companion and I opted for a vodka grey goose accompanied by tonic, and we were pleasantly surprised by its robust alcohol content, constituting approximately three-quarters of the beverage. Similarly, our server, clad in an adorable lacy mini dress, delivered a rum and diet coke, generously portioned with a substantial amount of rum. Although the prices appeared reasonable, they did not strike us as extraordinarily affordable. Nonetheless, the overall experience at this hotel lobby bar was satisfying, primarily owing to the welcoming demeanor of the staff."

Overhyped. Capriotti's has some good sandwiches and some that just don't connect.

My favorite sandwich here is the Capastrami, greasy pastrami grilled with melted Swiss, generously topped with creamy cole slaw and Russian dressing. Reubenesque and held together well by the bread.

Unfortunately, that same bread is the reason why Capriotti's cheesesteaks and Italian subs don't work. The rolls on which its subs are served are hard and dense, which means they don't absorb the favors and moisture of the rest of the sandwich.

The cheesesteaks also suffer from meat that's grisly, dry and flavorless. Bland would be a word for it.

The Bobbie isn't my thing - I think mayo is gross, and without it the Bobbie sandwich gets unbearably dry. That being said, the store roasted turkey goes great on cold subs with provolone and hot peppers.

Jersey Mike's is better for cold subs and Pop's is the place to go in Vegas for cheesesteaks.

"Ambivalent about the experience, as the prolonged waiting period for a table, owing to its current popularity, detracted from the overall enjoyment. Despite the diminutive size of the establishment, the delay in being seated was considerable and may deter some patrons. However, upon being accommodated, the culinary offerings proved to be somewhat inconsistent, specifically the red velvet pancakes, which were excessively sweetened and thus, disappointingly overrated. In contrast, the buttermilk pancakes fared better, boasting an optimal level of moisture and flavor, enhanced by the complementary butter and syrup. Additionally, the corned beef hash was satisfying, although the accompanying potatoes were unremarkable."

My review is mainly for the Casino (As I was staying next door at the Palazzo).  I really wanted to like this place and went in with high expectations. The place itself was crowded with mainly foreigners taking pictures everywhere and walking super slow. I found one slot game that I liked, but could not play long because the guy next to me had his entire family sit on the other machines and they were not playing. Really wanted to get into the table games but just too many people out and about to get by. I will stop in again next time because I did have a good feeling.

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment on three separate occasions, with two of those experiences being of the drive-thru variety and the most recent being a dine-in visit. I must say, I am delighted that I opted to dine in, for it afforded me the opportunity to observe the kitchen staff in their natural habitat, so to speak. One of the cooks, a Caucasian male, was not adorned in the customary gloves worn by his colleagues, which, in conjunction with his unfortunate lack of hygiene, led me to question the overall cleanliness of the kitchen. Furthermore, upon venturing to the restroom, I discovered that the paper towel dispenser was devoid of its intended contents, thus necessitating my utilization of the blower, which, in turn, produced an abundance of noise that served as a stark contrast to the otherwise tranquil ambiance of the dining area. This sequence of events led me to deduce that the aforementioned cook had neglected to properly sanitize his hands prior to resuming his culinary duties. Lastly, as I emerged from the restroom, I was greeted by the sight of the same individual grasping a generous portion of bacon, which, coincidentally, happened to be a key component of my companion's bacon burger. It is worth noting that the cook's attire, or lack thereof, accentuated his posterior region in a manner that was conspicuous and, some might argue, inappropriate. While I do intend to return to this establishment in the future, I do so with the hope that the aforementioned cook will not be present during my subsequent visits. Notwithstanding the aforementioned issues, I must admit that the quality of the burgers and fries served here is quite impressive.

I had previously become cognizant of the existence of Pink's Hot Dogs in Southern California and had always harbored an ardent desire to sample their culinary offerings. Thus, when I became aware of the presence of a Pink's establishment in Las Vegas, my excitement reached palpable levels. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, to put it mildly. I opted to order the mushroom swiss dog, which carried a price tag of $6.50. Upon consuming the hot dog, I was struck by its rubbery texture, which was somewhat disappointing. Furthermore, the Swiss cheese component of the dish was not as copious as I had anticipated, leading to intermittent bursts of flavor that were not as pronounced as they could have been. While the combination of mushrooms, Swiss cheese, and hot dog was undoubtedly delectable during those fleeting moments when all three elements converged, the overall experience was marred by an imbalance in ingredient ratios. Specifically, an excess of mushrooms and an insufficient amount of cheese detracted from my enjoyment. However, despite this underwhelming encounter, I would still be willing to partake in Pink's offerings once again in the future, albeit with a differing menu selection. Rumor has it that their chili cheese dog is positively sublime, and I am eager to verify the veracity of such claims.

Any pub on Rose St immediately has to compete with swathes of competitive drinking holes. As a result the Auld Hundred seems like another humdrum offering with nothing of particular attraction here. Then again, that may be exactly what the clientele like: a reliable and no frills establishment.\n\nYou'll find typically generous pub size portions with regards to food and a modest selection of ales, A- OK.

I had the pleasure of indulging in a bachelor party at this esteemed establishment, and I must say, it did not disappoint. As an experienced patron, I have had the privilege of visiting this hotel multiple times, and each occasion has been a testament to its enduring appeal. Strategically located within close proximity to an array of luxurious hotels, this venue offers unparalleled convenience for those seeking to immerse themselves in the vibrant nightlife that Las Vegas has to offer. Furthermore, I was delighted to discover that my associates' accumulated player points afforded me a substantial discount, which served as a welcome surprise. Although this hotel may not boast the most contemporary ambiance, the accommodations were spotless, and the staff demonstrated exceptional hospitality. Their sportsbook was an added bonus, providing an exciting diversion from the usual gaming fare. Regrettably, I did not have the opportunity to partake in their culinary offerings, nor have I ever had the pleasure of dining on the premises. This, indeed, is a regret, as I am led to believe that their gastronomic delights would have been a fitting complement to the overall experience. Notwithstanding, I would unhesitatingly consider returning to this hotel in the future, primarily due to its competitive pricing, although I am cognizant of the fact that Las Vegas harbors a plethora of superior hotels that may better cater to my discerning tastes.

The staff is attentive and helpful. We brought our kids one night to get dinner. Our food was predictably bar food- fried and heavy but not bad. We visited on a week night and they had a musician playing. We literally could not talk at our table. It was so incredibly loud we couldn't even hear each other. I am giving 3 stars only because of service. \nI would give 2 stars for the ambiance and because I wouldn't go here for date night or with my kids for dinner. It would be great just to watch a game or to go with someone you don't want to talk to.

"Cutting directly to the point, my culinary assessment of this establishment's offerings can be succinctly summarized as follows: the victuals served are merely passable, barely meeting expectations. In the event that you find yourself in close proximity and are seeking a rapid consumable meal, this venue may prove satisfactory. However, if your gastronomical inclinations lean towards genuinely exceptional Chinese cuisine, I would strongly advise venturing elsewhere, perhaps to Spring Mountain or, more specifically, the Golden State itself. Having recently returned from Los Angeles, where I indulged in some truly remarkable Chinese fare, my dining experience at this location proved underwhelming. For categorization purposes, I would relegate this eatery's culinary style to the same realm as Panda Express - while certainly palatable, it falls short of authentic Chinese cuisine."

I had not partaken of Papa John's culinary offerings for at least a year, and thus, my taste buds were eager to indulge in their delectable pies once again. As one of the superior chain pizza establishments, Papa John's boasts a prime location along my route home from work, thereby rendering it a convenient dining option. Furthermore, I had acquired a $10 gift card for the paltry sum of $5 via the online marketplace, Saveology.com, which made the prospect of savoring their large specialty pizzas all the more enticing, particularly given their affordability, with each pie priced at a mere $11. While the large pizza, measuring a scant 14 inches in diameter, may not be considered substantial by some standards, the Spinach Alfredo variety possesses an undeniable appeal, its flavorsome combination of fresh spinach, rich Alfredo sauce, and melted mozzarella cheese rendering it a veritable gustatory delight. However, upon receiving my order, I was dismayed to discover that the butter sauce and pepperoncini, typically included in the pizza box, were conspicuously absent. Nevertheless, I comprehended the reasoning behind this omission, attributable to the establishment's desire to streamline their operations and enhance efficiency. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the quality of service remained somewhat lacking, as only one of two available registers was manned by a lone employee, resulting in a discernible delay in processing orders, while several patrons idled nearby, awaiting their turns. Despite these inconveniences, I would still consider halting at Papa John's for a pizza en route home, provided the price remains reasonable.

"I recently had the opportunity to observe this production for the second time, having previously experienced it without my spouse, who expressed a strong desire to view it. This particular show diverges significantly from the conventional Cirque du Soleil offerings, possessing a distinct emphasis on Asian-inspired elements, swordplay, and acrobatic feats. Unlike the majority of Cirque du Soleil performances, which tend to resemble a dreamlike state with little coherence and an assortment of breathtaking, heart-stopping acrobatic acts, KA boasts a discernible narrative thread and utilizes wires in a manner that mitigates any sense of fear or apprehension. 

However, certain aspects of the production, such as the linguistic style employed and select characterizations (including a Tarzan-esque figure), prove challenging to fully comprehend or appreciate. Despite having had the chance to experience the show twice, it remains outside my personal preferences within the Cirque du Soleil repertoire, and thus, I am grateful for the affordable ticket prices obtained on both occasions. The single aspect that truly captivated me was the expansive mobile platform capable of shifting between horizontal and vertical orientations, with the concluding sequence featuring combat on the vertical surface being my favorite; regrettably, the remaining segments did not hold my interest to the same degree as other productions within the Cirque du Soleil canon."

C'est un caf\u00e9 correct pour travailler et pour se prendre un lunch quand on a oubli\u00e9 le sien \u00e0 la maison. Je suis all\u00e9e \u00e0 l'heure du lunch et \u00e7a n'\u00e9tais pas trop occup\u00e9, donc la combinaison de wifi gratuit et grandes tables pour travailler \u00e9tait exactement ce que je cherchais. Ils ont un bonne vari\u00e9t\u00e9 de plats et le service est bien correct. J'ai pris deux salades : une aux l\u00e9gumes et moutarde dijon, puis l'autre l\u00e9gumes et p\u00e2tes \u00e0 l'orientale, ou bien plut\u00f4t simplement \u00e0 la sauce soya. Les deux \u00e9taient super bonne et j'ai bien aim\u00e9 avoir l'option d'un lunch sans trop de pain. Ils ont aussi des plats chauds et des plats du jour qui ont l'air de changer r\u00e9guli\u00e8rement. Somme toute, c'est un endroit qui m\u00e9lange le style caf\u00e9t\u00e9ria avec le style caf\u00e9 sans fla fla. C'est argent comptant, mais il y a un ATM au caf\u00e9 m\u00eame.

We visited this establishment for our evening meal on a Friday... Our group consisted of eight individuals, yet despite possessing a prior reservation and the lateness of the hour (9:45 PM), we were compelled to endure a brief delay before being seated, and furthermore, were assigned an outdoor table... in the intense heat of approximately 100 degrees Fahrenheit.  Although the temperature itself did not pose a significant inconvenience, we unfortunately failed to experience the full ambiance and interior design of the venue.  The kobe meatball dish was quite satisfactory.  My personal selection was an eight-ounce filet, which, while satisfying, did not include any additional sides, such as a potato, and so forth... However, the asparagus side dish I chose was both copious and flavorful.  The filet itself was cooked to my precise instructions and seasoned with great care... Most of the other patrons opted for pasta dishes, the quality of which I cannot accurately assess, as their appearances varied.  The service we received was proficient and attentive, with no notable errors committed.  While not excessively expensive, the prices charged were still somewhat elevated... Ultimately, I felt underwhelmed by the entire experience, harboring the sentiment that either a greater expenditure for superior cuisine or a lesser cost for more casual fare would have been preferable.  No major grievances can be reported, yet neither was I particularly impressed by any aspect.

The patrons of this establishment have the option to sample their culinary offerings by purchasing two fish sandwiches for the sum of five dollars, in addition to which they may also opt to acquire a side salad at a cost of one dollar and eighty-nine cents. Upon partaking in these delectable dishes, it became apparent that the bread utilized in the construction of the fish sandwich was excessive in quantity, thereby detracting from the overall quality of the dish. Furthermore, the salad, consisting primarily of iceberg lettuce, did not possess sufficient flavor or nutritional value to warrant future consumption. Despite these shortcomings, the level of customer service provided by the manager, a female individual, was quite impressive and worthy of commendation. The interior design of the restaurant was also notable for its aesthetic appeal, contributing to a pleasant ambiance for patrons. However, it is regrettable to report that the gustatory experience did not meet expectations, thus rendering a return visit unlikely.

Great food and great WINE. Awesome pasta, the description matched exactly what I got. When I asked the waiter to describe the wine I wanted to order, he described it to a T. What was just supposed to be a small appetizer and a drink turned into a meal. Very elegant, very nice, VERY GOOD!

Paid for a venti green tea lemonade and got a tall green tea lemonade . Reason why I didn't go back was because I had to go to school was in a rush I wish the girls that always take my orders were there

"The superior quality of the donuts at this establishment in South Phoenix renders it an optimal destination for indulging in such delectable treats, thereby making the arduousness of laboring in the aforementioned location thoroughly worthwhile; specifically, the maple bar variety is exceptionally scrumptious."

"It is palpable that the singular attribute which renders this establishment appealing is the captivating appearance and texture of their bread, which boasts an unparalleled freshness and taste. However, it is conspicuous that the sandwiches themselves are rather unremarkable and overpriced, with a cost of $5-6 for a meager offering. \n\nThe level of service provided by this establishment is glaringly inadequate, as there are merely a few employees present at any given time, leading to a sluggish and impatient experience for patrons. Furthermore, the antiquated nature of the building and the limited parking options available, including a minuscule rear lot, contribute to the overall dearth of convenience. Notwithstanding, I do concede that the diminutive original sandwich is moderately satisfying, primarily due to the exceptional quality of the bread. Nevertheless, if this eatery were to adopt a more conventional sub bread or baguette for their sandwiches, it is improbable that I would opt to dine here."

The short: Get the \"white cookie\" fresh from the oven, at the front cafe for $5. OMG. OMG. \n\nThe long: inside at the restaurant: long waits, water refills - had to ask each time. \"Sunday pasta\" did a number on my tummy! :-(. Best thing on the menu - the $5 white cookies in front cafe, fresh out of the oven. Wish i spent my groupon on just those cookies. Forget the entrees, they're nothing special - typical ingredients prepared en masse so they can be thrown together and then onto your plate. That's how it tastes. And you'll pay a premium to find out I'm right.

"Culinary indulgences abounded at this eatery, yet an enigmatic quality remained, eluding my comprehension. Ambience was satisfactory, despite the auditory assault emanating from the adjacent gaming arena. Prompt seating was accorded to us, sans reservation, during the meridian repast. The bill of fare, though diminutive in scope, boasted a diverse array of delectable options. I opted for the prime steak panini, accompanied by a tangy potato salad. A delightful confluence of flavors, complemented by the subtle pungency of barbecue sauce and a trace of horseradish, permeated the panini. The potato salad, a veritable masterpiece, struck the perfect balance between piquancy and richness, with just the right amount of mayonnaise. Regrettably, the hospitality encountered a marked decline, as sluggish service prevailed. An extended wait ensued before our check was delivered, followed by an even lengthier delay in retrieving my credit card. Infrequent were the instances wherein the server graced our presence with her attendance, post-consumption of the meal."

"The beet salad was an absolute culinary masterpiece, boasting an unparalleled harmony of flavors that left my taste buds in a state of pure delight. However, the service we received was somewhat lacking in its execution, as evidenced by the unfortunate incident involving the spillage of water onto my table while I was partaking in my meal. Furthermore, I must say that the short rib loco moco, despite its otherwise delectable appearance, was unfortunately marred by an excessive saltiness that proved to be somewhat off-putting to my palate."

"The establishment boasted an impressive rating of 3.5 stars, prompting us to visit with a group of companions this weekend, particularly for the open bar. Upon arrival, the gentlemen were charged a reasonable fee of $20, which we deemed acceptable. However, the bouncers exhibited discourteous behavior while managing the cover charge, leaving a negative impression. 

TAO's interior presented itself in an aesthetically pleasing manner, arousing our curiosity and hunger as we walked through the restaurant en route to the club. Unfortunately, we failed to fully capitalize on the venue's offerings due to our primary focus on consuming alcoholic beverages. Arriving early allowed us to avoid concerns regarding capacity, enabling us to appreciate the spaciousness of the dance floor. Although the majority of the drinks were satisfactory, some fundamental well drinks were poorly prepared, and the delay in obtaining beverages proved frustrating. Nevertheless, our overall experience at TAO remained largely positive, as we were able to dance with ample space and enjoy the musical offerings, including an unexpected performance by Dash Berlin. Our group successfully navigated the evening without encountering excessively crowded conditions, allowing us to depart before the venue reached its peak occupancy. In conclusion, our visit to TAO yielded an enjoyable experience, albeit with room for improvement in certain aspects."

"My expectations were elevated upon entering this establishment due to the numerous favorable critiques I had perused prior to my visit. However, what I encountered was a satisfactory yet unremarkable local eatery that was perhaps slightly overrated. My culinary experience began with a palatable but overcooked burger, which elicited an involuntary mental protest as the chef applied excessive pressure to the patty, resulting in a regrettably desiccated texture. The accompanying fries, while possessing a satisfying crunch, lacked any discernible distinctiveness or flavor profile, rendering them unmemorable. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the quality of the ingredients utilized did meet my expectations, as the beef patties were freshly prepared and not frozen, and the generous allocation of bacon ensured a consistent presence of savory flavor in each bite. Additionally, the lettuce was fresh and crisp, contributing to an overall adequate, albeit overpriced, dining experience. While I am unlikely to return, I might consider patronizing this restaurant again in the future if circumstances necessitated a convenient and casual meal option."

Good place to go and eat gyros if your up in North Scottsdale. The staff is friendly and the food gets to you real fast. The price is somewhere between 7-10 per meal but that's usual for N. Scottsdale.

Maybe I've had better Chinese in the past than I realized, or perhaps I ordered the wrong things, but I can't see giving this place five stars. The egg rolls were too salty, the hot and sour soup was lacking in sour, the vegetable pork was bland.\n\nIt's quick, not over priced and not over cooked. I'm willing to try it again.

Grampa's Pizzeria - aptly named.

No one makes pizza quite like Grampa. It's delicious! He uses quality ingredients and bomb flavor combinations. Seriously, I love Grampa and I love his pizza.

However, my last visit to Grampa's made me wonder if he's maybe going senile. Walking in, we got a friendly, though confused look from the host that said, "who are you and why are you here?" That should probably have tipped me off that something was amiss. When we got an appetizer, it came out cold - I asked, "Did you maybe forget to cook this pork?" They poked it, shrugged, and put it back in the oven. Then finally, something happened with the pizza. I don't actually know what happened, our server just came out saying that it was going to be a while before we got to eat. But hey, Grampa is nothing if not generous! We got a free beer for all the confusion.

It's probably for the best that there were only 3 other couples in the restaurant. A busy Monday would have just gotten Grampa all flustered.

It has been an extended period of time since I have had the opportunity to undergo a comprehensive ocular examination, and my previous experiences with eye exams have been limited to cursory evaluations conducted primarily for the purpose of obtaining a driver's license or briefly gazing into a machine to identify objects. However, in light of Denise's recent efforts to prioritize her own eye care, I recognized the importance of scheduling an appointment for myself as well. Consequently, I registered at the Christenbury Eye Center, which boasts a highly organized and professional environment, characterized by a seamless procession of patients through various rooms, wherein specialists administer a diverse array of assessments designed to evaluate the functionality of one's visual acuity. Although I cannot verify the authenticity of their methods, the center's reputation is reinforced by endorsements from renowned individuals who attest to the staff's expertise. Moreover, they offer advanced laser eye surgery procedures, but subsequent to administering medicated drops that caused my pupils to dilate and significantly impaired my vision for several hours, the specialists concluded that my eyes were in fact in optimal condition. Hence, I am hopeful that I will not be required to return for an extended interval.

Went here last night for the first time last night... Took forever to get in, then another customer decided to get into a fight with us because they didn't want us parked next to them, it was hard to hear parts of our movie because we could hear the movie that was playing next to us, and the helicopters flying around were really distracting. BUT the prices were VERY reasonable for admissions and if you wanted condensations (plus we had coupons)

I imagine at least a solid 60% of people who are trying to catch morning or afternoon flights out of here are hung over. \n\nWho thought it was a good idea to make this the loudest, brightest airport in the country?

Great menu options. Service was hit & miss. Atmosphere lacked a little bit of energy. Food was good. Grits & Pork Belly was my favorite . Quality of food was even better. Pricey for BBQ. Once management figures it out will be a great place.

"Halted momentarily for a pie with my progeny, considerable portion of pizza, copious toppings, a wee bit excessively lubricated, presumably attributed to the pepperoni. In general, considered it satisfactory. Cuisine materialized expeditiously, will pause briefly to sample another item on a subsequent visit... Oh yes, no fountain beverages were available.... For me, a drawback."

This critique pertains to the culinary indulgence; specifically, the savory meatballs served at a recent evening meal, which, despite the lackluster and detached demeanor exhibited by the servers, proved to be a veritable gustatory delight, rendering the overall dining experience gratifying, albeit partially mitigated by the unfortunate deficiency in attentive hospitality. Furthermore, the agreeable climate and picturesque terrace setting, offering an unobstructed view of the iconic Las Vegas Strip, contributed significantly to the enjoyment of the repast. It is worth mentioning that previous experiences within the eatery's indoor confines were markedly less captivating.

I indulged in certain potations and a pie here on the twenty-eighth of June, two thousand and twelve.

On a Thursday, I visited this establishment, and it was teeming with patrons; the space was filled to capacity, rendering it challenging to maneuver and nearly impossible to secure a seat. The ambiance was boisterous, bordering on cacophonous, and the dearth of personal space was palpable.

The hospitality was commendable, but the culinary offerings were exorbitant, considering their quantity and quality. The flavors of the thin-crust pizza were satisfactory, albeit slightly overcooked and excessively crunchy for my taste. However, individual preferences regarding the degree of doneness may vary.

The restrooms were minuscule, accommodating a single occupant at a time, which was incongruous with the restaurant's capacity. Anticipate a delay if you need to relieve yourself, as the limited facilities hinder efficient usage.

I am uncertain about the likelihood of my return, as my experience was marked by both positive and negative aspects.

"While my familiarity with authentic Korean cuisine may be limited, my appreciation for diverse Asian-inspired gastronomy remains unwavering. 

The unpretentious ambiance and prompt service afforded us an opportunity to sample their offerings without delay (our table being the second to be attended to). The Korean BBQ ribs and dolsot (I believe) were our choices, the former characterized by rich, fatty meat complemented by a subtle sweet sauce, while the latter arrived in a sizable stone bowl, its scorching temperature and copious amounts of rice, vegetables, and meat necessitating a thorough mixing with one's spoon to achieve a satisfying blend of textures and flavors, albeit with a somewhat muted overall taste profile. 

The accompanying sides, though perhaps lacking in inventiveness, still managed to contribute a welcome contrast to the spicy kimchi, their inherent sweetness offsetting the piquancy of the fermented Korean staple. When seeking a culinary experience that diverges from the norm in downtown Chandler, this establishment constitutes a viable choice."

The quality of service rendered here is truly commendable, however, my expectations regarding the Fuku Burger were not entirely fulfilled, as the patty and its constituent elements failed to surpass the threshold of mediocrity, prompting me to question the value offered by this culinary establishment, particularly when juxtaposed with the cost associated with said burger, which, in my opinion, ought to have been accompanied by a more impressive gastronomical experience, akin to that proffered by Stout; furthermore, the Togarashi French Fries, though novel in their conception, were merely average in their execution, thereby contributing to an overall sense of underwhelment. Notwithstanding these criticisms, it must be acknowledged that the eatery boasts an enviable location within a trendy food court, fostering a dynamic ambiance conducive to social gatherings and casual dining.

"Well, the service was indeed of a superior quality, as one would expect from an establishment of such stature. The bread, accompanied by a delectable olive paste, was truly a delightful experience for the taste buds. However, it is unfortunate that the culinary prowess of the restaurant did not persist throughout the meal. The calamari, while possessing an adequate level of saltiness, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated it to the next level of epicurean satisfaction. Furthermore, the sauce accompanying the seafood dish was overpoweringly piquant, thus rendering it somewhat incompatible with my refined palate. As for the pesto gnocchi, it was, in my humble opinion, a tad uninspired and unremarkable, bearing a striking resemblance to Chef Boyardee's offerings, albeit with a faint hint of verdant sauce. My dining companion's steak, unfortunately, suffered from an excessive amount of pepper, which, when combined with the richness of the Alfredo sauce accompanying the pasta, resulted in a flavor profile not dissimilar to that of a certain high-end steakhouse. Lastly, the dessert, while undoubtedly satisfying, proved to be the sole redeeming quality of an otherwise underwhelming dining experience. In conclusion, while the bread and dessert were indeed impressive, the remaining dishes fell short of my lofty expectations, leaving me with a lingering sense of disappointment and a yearning for more refined culinary experiences."

Went there yesterday to watch a postseason game with other Yelpers.  As far as watching TVs went, there wasn't a bad seat in the house.  For those that hate smoke there is a non smoking entrance in the back to the bar side but if you want to play pool or use the Men's room you still have to run the gauntlet of the smoking patio.  Speaking of the Men's room, I have seen worse but this one wasn't really kept up that well and it could use a mopping as my feet stuck to the floor by the urinal. 

They had plenty of good choices for beer on tap.  I was intending on a burger but table quantities of other stuff arrived.  The nachos were ok.  I don't normally care for hot wings because they are, well, hot.  These were grilled and while they left a slight after burn for me were really quite good.  I also had an onion ring, a potato skin and a cheese stick.  Good solid bar food without being Wow.  Service bounced between really good and "where did she go?".  They were out of stuff like iced tea, some brownies and some of the beers.  As a table we were buying enough drinks that those that mixed in glasses of water were not questioned.

All in all a good solid neighborhood bar.

OK,

Pizza delivered to my hotel.  Check.
Opened up the box and the pie looked delicious. Check.
Pizza had ingredients as requested. Check.
Pizza cut in squares, like a true Chicago pie. Check
Pizza cut all the way through the dough. EPIC FAIL.

My oh my.  When you pick up a slice (Chizona's cuts the pie is squares) you want to pick up a slice with all of the ingredients on top of the slice.  Three of us (two who never had a Chicago style thin crust) and not one slice was cut all the way through.  In a hotel room, with no cutlery we tried our best to keep the ingredients on top of each slice, but pulling apart slices, that are not cut, created an awful mess.  We ended up with a bunch of hand pulled empty slices, and trying our best to put the ingredients on each slice.  We gave up.

If you cant cut a pie, which is so Pizza 101, than you create a crappy experience for your customer.  

3 stars for the fresh ingredients, great sauce, the owner adding some Giardiniera (very fresh and tasty). Minus 2 stars for the mess that was created by the pizza not being cut all the way through.

I had so much higher hope's.

Stay hungry my friends...

"My recent visit to this establishment served as a stark reminder of the transient nature of culinary experiences, as my expectations, cultivated by a previous visit several years prior, were drastically diminished by a subpar dining experience. The ambiance, while undeniably opulent, failed to compensate for the underwhelming array of dishes presented at the buffet, which, regrettably, did not live up to its promised extensiveness. Moreover, the prolonged waiting period, amounting to a full hour on a Sunday evening, only exacerbated my disappointment. In conclusion, I would advise potential patrons to exercise caution in their expectations, as the experience, though ostensibly luxurious, does not necessarily warrant the lengthy queue."

Very representative of the situation my wife and I often find ourselves in: it is hard to find good food on vacation. Lemongrass offers classically mediocre Thai food, plus you will get a 1 hour wait for absolutely no reason. Our meal: fried spring rolls ($10) these were clearly straight out of the freezer, no flavor, soggy vegetables; pho reeked of cinnamon ($15); Singapore Noodles Stir-fried rice vermicelli, BBQ pork, shrimp, onion, bean sprouts, bell pepper, egg, curry powder ($18) this was quite good and very spicy, earning Lemongrass 3 instead of 2 stars.\n\nPoor food, poor service, long wait. Do not make a reservation; I would suggest trying a different restaurant.

"I am taken aback by the dearth of reviews pertaining to Betty Lou, given our thoroughly enjoyable experience aboard the Monona brunch cruise. While the overall experience was indeed pleasant, there are several areas in which improvements could be made. Specifically, the value proposition relative to the cost, the limited selection of seating options on the vessel, and the sporadic availability of crew members and service staff are aspects that warrant attention. On the other hand, the gastronomical offerings were undoubtedly impressive, with both the quantity and quality of the fare receiving high marks. The ambiance of the boat and the surrounding environment contributed to an overall agreeable experience. However, upon embarkation, we encountered an unexpected and unfortunate situation involving a group of boisterous youths who managed to secure prime seating at the expense of those who had arrived earlier. To avoid such confusion, it would be wise for management to implement a more structured approach to boarding, such as calling groups in the order in which they were reserved. The culinary offerings were truly exceptional, with each course expertly presented and paced throughout the meal. Unfortunately, the mimosas, while flavorful, lacked potency, and attempts to procure additional drinks proved challenging due to the scarcity of bartenders and servers attending to the sizable crowd. Furthermore, our table was not released for the initial round of food, adding to the confusion. Despite these issues, the panoramic views afforded by the boat's route were undeniably breathtaking, and the captain's obliging gesture of executing a photo-op spin at the conclusion of the voyage was greatly appreciated."

As much as I love this place, I really think I'm twenty years too young to be here. I really love the genres played here and I consider myself pretty well versed in the music. I can't figure out if I'm a young person with a taste for real music, or if everyone who likes real music is older than I. 

I showed up on a Friday which is the night when Baddness plays. I think it was them because they played stuff from EW&F, Gap Band, Maze, and bunch of others. No blues that night, just funk. The thing I loved about this band it that I would've expected to see them in an early Jarmusch film like Mystery Train. They were a five or six piece band in all red suits with the lead vocalist in an all red, sequened coat. It was quite possibly the most badass thing I've seen on a music stage in Phoenix. A definite A plus for music and style.

As far as a blues house goes, I don't really know if I'd consider this one. The Rhythm Room seems to be more up my alley and they seem to have to be a real venue for artists passing through. This definitely seems more like a dive bar/lounge for people who like the music. Again, I really want to come back to this place but I think I should wait a few more years because clearly I should've been born twenty years earlier.

I must confess that my experience at this establishment was merely average, and I must attribute this to my own lack of sophistication in regards to genuine Asian cuisine, as my brother and I both failed to consume the entirety of our meals, perhaps due to a lack of hunger. However, I must acknowledge that the proprietor of this establishment exhibited an extraordinary level of hospitality, bordering on the absurd, which was quite perplexing, yet simultaneously endearing. Furthermore, he presented us with a pictorial menu, which was considerate given our unfamiliarity with the culinary offerings. Despite these positive aspects, I would not necessarily recommend this restaurant, unless one happens to be in close proximity and accompanied by a fellow patron who expresses a desire to dine there.

Whenever I chance upon this culinary establishment, it consistently evokes a warm and welcoming ambiance that piques my curiosity and inspires me to allocate some time to partake in their gastronomical offerings. Upon entering the eatery, I was promptly accommodated and made a concerted effort to maintain an impartial demeanor throughout the entire dining experience. The hospitality was commendable... However, their victuals fell short of my expectations, given the tariff I had to pay. Their menu could be described as "tourist-oriented" (overpriced), as Tofu Hut, a comparable establishment, offers analogous dishes at a more reasonable cost. Had their cuisine been on par with the quality of their decor, I would have considered awarding them an additional star, but unfortunately, their fare was merely satisfactory.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by this establishment's culinary offerings is undoubtedly palatable, yet the copious amounts of monosodium glutamate incorporated into their dishes are somewhat problematic for my taste buds, despite my typical resistance to the aforementioned flavor enhancer; indeed, the sensory assault precipitated by the consumption of these fare leaves me with an unpleasant lingering aftertaste that is decidedly disagreeable."

Why the hell does everyone have stuffed animals?!

Apparently, they give you a stuffed animal after taking your order so when you're seated, they know what table to deliver the food to. I thought it was a just a nice gesture so I said 'No thanks' to the dirty stuffed animal. Then I wondered why the food never came.

Chuy's reminds me of the surf n' turf taco shops by the beach. I like the meat and seafood options and especially the smell of grilled food but the flavor could use a lot more spice. The menu was expansive and offered a lot. Too much to list and I think they even have fried chicken? Weird. 

I ordered the Broiled Whitefish Taco Platter ($6) with a side of Shrimp Skewers ($4). The shrimp skewer was awesome, sprinkled some lemon juice on it with some hot sauce and that was a better meal than my taco platter. The fish didn't taste 'fresh" and I'm not exactly sure what whitefish is either. The rice and beans were standard. The cabbage salad could use some help. It was chopped cabbage with a vinaigrette. 

I was not impressed by Chuy's but I could go there again. It's a safe option, maybe next time I should try their $2 margaritas that they serve all day, every day. Now we're talking!

OH MY!! I cannot believe I forgot to rate this place.. I went I believe July 3rd around mid-day. It was hot as he** outside and didn't help that half the seating for serendipity is outside on the patio. Needless to say we waited to be seated about 20-25 mins or so. 
The food was pretty good. Huge portions, for me anyways so I split the sandwich I ordered which was "The strip steak sandwich". Good but I would prefer a better cut of steak... eh anyways moving along it was all good but a little overpriced. 
 
If weather permitted would have preferred outside seating and dessert but I was too full and it was too hot to try either.. However I did come back the next day and I tried the frozen hot chocolate and the oreo frozen hot chocolate but this time I went to the walk-up, to-go window...super convenient and fast by the way.

Both were good but oreo one was better. Had a richer taste to it. The plain one was somewhat iced down.. I'm a chocolate lover so.... they also weren't as big as the ones I seen inside. not sure what difference was.. I posted some pics also of the items. 

Anyways I will go to the one in New York next and see what the diff is and I will come here again next time I visit Vegas.

Underwear for $1 and bras for $10?!?! Yes, please!*














*Disclaimer: Only in the sale section, and only if you can locate your correct size.

They proffer the unpretentious "street" style tacos that I relish. My culinary exploits encompassed one al pastor and one asada, both of which were scrumptious. Notably, the former boasted an agreeable piquancy. Alas, my gustatory excursion was not without its drawbacks, as the green tamale I sampled was quite unsatisfactory. The dearth of verdant chile and cheese within the masa rendered it rather insipid. Regrettably, my quest for a delectable tamale has yet to be fulfilled in this vicinity. Furthermore, my beverage of choice, jamaica, was disappointingly diluted and tart, prompting me to ponder whether I should have opted for the horchata I initially coveted instead. In essence, the eatery's redeeming quality lies in its tacos; thus, it is advisable to restrict one's order to these delectable morsels and forgo any additional items.

Please note that the output may contain some minor variations in wording or punctuation compared to the original text, but the overall meaning and content should remain the same. Also, please ensure that the modified text does not exceed 512 tokens.

I go to Vegas a couple times a year  and I stay at different casinos .  This last time in September I stayed at the Excalibur.  We have stayed here before.  We always enjoy this casino, the rooms are clean and comfortable and the price is reasonable.  This last time we left a tip for the maid who was cleaning our room. She left us a thank you note, which I thought was very thoughtful of her.  It is the first time anyone has written us a thank you note for a tip. Her name was Clementine and she did a wonderful job.

"This particular Costco establishment does not rank among the most exceptional I have had the privilege of visiting. Several aspects of the experience leave room for improvement, in my opinion. Firstly, the parking situation can become quite congested, although this is a common issue among Costcos and, therefore, tolerable. My primary concerns revolve around the sampling services. Specifically, the pace of distribution is sluggish, leading to frequent depletion of samples, followed by an inefficient replenishment process. This results in a prolonged waiting period, which can be frustrating, especially given the significance I attach to sampling as an integral aspect of my Costco excursions. In fact, I have visited other Costco locations where the sampling process operates with greater efficiency, characterized by a steady supply of offerings and a more seamless experience.  

Another drawback of this Costco lies in its car wash facilities. While the exterior cleaning function performs admirably, the interior remains unattended, lacking essential vacuuming amenities. Notably, this absence of vacuum services distinguishes this car wash from others that typically provide such features.  

Despite these shortcomings, I still derive pleasure from procuring beverages, such as beer and wine, at this Costco. Their extensive selection of alcoholic beverages, including sizable vodka bottles, holds appeal for me. Additionally, I recently became aware of their discounted restaurant cards, which offer welcome savings.  

In summary, while this Costco presents some limitations, I shall persist in visiting, albeit with a slight scowl during the prolonged sample intervals."

"A triumvirate of culinary excellence and unparalleled gastronomical innovation warrants a rating of three celestial bodies, specifically pertaining to the unmatched flavor and inimitable style of the pizza; however, a rapid midday repast is unfeasible due to an absence of efficiency in the service, leading to an interminable wait time that precludes the possibility of a swift return to employment for patrons in the adjacent industrial area, thereby necessitating the implementation of a convenient and expeditious solution, such as offering individual slices and a complementary beverage as part of a fixed-price combination meal, a ubiquitous practice among establishments specializing in pizza, which would enhance the overall experience and increase the frequency of my visits, provided that said adjustments are executed within a reasonable temporal frame and at a cost commensurate with the quality offered."

We happened upon this culinary establishment by sheer serendipity and opted to partake in a tardy midday repast. Our order consisted of the delectable hummus and crispy potato slices, accompanied by an assortment of golden onion rings and crispy fries. Upon consuming these delights, we found that they were skillfully prepared and offered an explosion of flavors on our taste buds. However, our dining experience was slightly marred by the lackadaisical attitude displayed by the servers, as their attentiveness waned noticeably as the patronage dwindled, leaving us waiting interminably for even the most basic acknowledgment or assistance. Despite my concerted efforts to capture someone's attention, it became apparent that they had adopted a deliberate policy of avoidance or feigned obliviousness.

Popped in here for a dinner with friends and having only been here for lunch I had yet to try the BBQ.  I ended up splitting the big boy plate (I forget the actual name) with my girlfriend.  All the BBQ on the plate was delicious although I thought the chicken BBQ was a bit too dry.  That's a hard one to keep from drying out though.  The pulled pork was good and moist.

The interior is a little dated but I'm doubtful any of the patrons of this place really care.  It's got a pretty cool neighborhood feel.  The service was great and friendly.

Bottom line is, there are so many great choices for BBQ in Charlotte, this place is easy to overlook.  It just didn't stand out to me.

On the weird chance that someday I'd get to meet the inventor of the soft serve ice-cream machine, this is how our conversation would go;

"So..how did the idea of a soft serve machine come to you?"

"Well, I was taking my dog Toots for a walk one day when all of a sudden, he decides to shit all over Ed and Dolores Feinsteins front lawn.
I was horrified. 
Ed's an attorney and he warned me about Toots shitting on his front lawn one more time...how he'd come after us both.
He did. 
There Toots is, happily shitting away...a huge creamy brown dump slowly oozing its way out , when Ed comes flying out of the house with a broom.
Toots freaks, and hauls ass without even pinching it off. 
And that was my inspiration.
I thought, if I ever invented an ice-cream machine, I'd want it to cleanly pinch-off, unlike Toots who left a dashed trail across Ed and Dolores's lawn.
So I guess we can thank Toots for the idea."

Many thanks Toots.
I used to love frozen yogurt...when someone else was serving it up.
Now that I have to serve it up,  all I can think about is how this machine was designed by some lunatic who managed to create a replica of his dog, shitting on Ed and Dolores Feinsteins front lawn.

I would probably not visit Galaxy again if I still lived in Vegas. The people who work there are straight up weirdos when it comes to customer service. I went twice in a week, and both times the people working were so clueless as to how to work or, more importantly, work together, that I would not come back. 

The breakfast sandwiches are alright, but they are a bit on the pricey side for the ingredients being from the freezer. It filled me up on the way to LA so I can't complain too much. 

The coffees are alright, but nothing outstanding. Something that I like is that they have almond syrup, which I have a hard time finding, so they get a few extra points there. 

Star Wars and other "nerd" decor make for a cool atmosphere, but I wouldn't seek out a business that can't train their staff to work together or efficiently.

Stopped in for lunch.  They have nice specials which include: Miso soup, salad and sashimi with rice.  Staff is very friendly.  Here's the thing: Miso was great. Salad was wilted and with bell peppers?  Never had Asian salad with Bell peppers..chilis yes, but bell peppers? Yuck.  The rice did not come out with my meal.  I had 4 people come over all confused about who was doing what. They had the right heart, but..service was disorganized, but friendly.  When asked if everything was okay..I made the statement about the salad..it was old and wilted and... I wasn't offered a replacement.  When the rice finally got to me it was a HUGH softball size and so dry and nasty and tasteless that  I didn't eat it.  The Tuna sashimi though...was EXCELLENT,  the wasabi was powerful and they serve white ginger, but it was dry.  So...they need improvement--period. It was a $12 lunch plus tip.

We order our food from their carside service.  We found the food to be great, but patience trying to get your food from the carside pickup!!  (over 15 minutes past the time promised and ignored until the manager brought it out!!)
This place is now \"Las Americas\" and its Colombian food. It's authentic and the people are nice, but nothing about it really stood out.

"What I find particularly appealing about this establishment is the fact that I tend to be the youngest patron by a significant age gap, which is a refreshing change from the usual crowds that frequent such places. Moreover, having reached an age where I have had the opportunity to utilize both wall-mounted telephones with rotary dials and modern smartphones, I must say that I appreciate the diversity of clientele that this location attracts. It appears that the elderly population takes great interest in purchasing fresh produce at reasonable prices, which is often available here. However, it is advisable to exercise caution when shopping, as certain items may be priced exorbitantly, following a pattern seemingly inherent to Basha's business model. Nevertheless, if one adheres to the principle of selecting only the most competitively priced merchandise, a satisfactory shopping experience may still be attained. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that the parking spaces are generously sized, allowing for effortless ingress and egress from one's vehicle, even when driving a luxury sedan such as a Buick Park Avenue."

This place was pretty good! My husband and I got a take out order and were very happy with it. That was probably one of the best chili rellenos I've had. I was disappointed with the veggie salad, however, as it was mostly just lettuce. The black beans were pretty spicy and salty, so plan on having something to mix them with like rice or an extra tortilla. I probably wouldn't dine in if I could help it, the dining room isn't very comfy, (free wifi while you wait for your order is nice, though) but I will definitely be getting more take out! \n\nOh, and: a snickerdoodle with every order! A good one, too!

Never knew how big the place was. Seems like an awesome place for sporting events. I didn't get any drinks, but the specials appear good. It was freaking dead in there, but I want to try and go on a busy night for further review.

Jin's poultry and aquatic products were nowhere to be found in their customary location, prompting us to explore the surrounding area in search of an alternative venue that could satiate our post-bar cravings for fowl and fin. Upon discovering this establishment, we determined that it fulfilled our requirements for a satisfying repast, albeit not an ideal setting for a full-fledged meal. My culinary selection consisted of a juvenile avian specimen, breaded and deep-fried, served on a diminutive bun and accompanied by minuscule leafy greenery and copious amounts of Frank's RedHot sauce and mayonnaise. Suffice it to say, my expectations were adequately met.

Some healthy-ish options on the menu. Breakfast till 10.30am would be even better if it was all-day (as I arrived here at 11am.)\n\nI got the chicken beer bread... What is that? Grilled chicken in a wrap and served with fries or salad. Of course I got the fries as I really wanted fish and chips but tried to be good. That was a mistake. The chicken was processed, covered in melted cheese which I picked out as cooled and congealed...(better left on the plate than in my veins.) I tried to enjoy this meal as I picked out the good stuff. Because the wrap was cut up you couldn't pick it up and it was too \"wet\" to cut. Then I looked around at this decor and noticed the odd combo of a dance music soundtrack. Very odd...something not quite right here. If I had to come again I'd probably go with the fish & chips or a burger.

"The terrestrial poultry served as the piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance of my culinary experience at this establishment, boasting an abundance of savory flavors with each mouthful. However, the boneless fragments of poultry accompanying the chicken soltani ($17.99) failed to live up to expectations, suffering from a dearth of flavor and a rather unpleasant texture. In contrast, the beef kabob ($16.99) presented a more aesthetically pleasing appearance, yet its gustatory qualities were found wanting due to an absence of seasoning and a coarse consistency. 

Fortunately, both main courses were complemented by exceptionally fluffy and delectable Basmati rice, which partially compensated for their shortcomings. Notably generous portion sizes ensured that each dish could easily suffice for two individuals, rendering the moderate tariffs somewhat more palatable. It would have been wiser for us to share one of the entrees, given the prices they command. 

The hummus exhibited passable quality, while the yogurt and cucumber dip was overpowered by an excess of dill, detracting from its overall enjoyment. 

The spacious interior of the restaurant features a modern, well-lit ambiance, accentuated by the presence of two illuminated trees positioned centrally. For those seeking a more relaxed dining experience (and lower prices), alternative establishments may be more suitable."

I can't believe I forgot to write a review for Ceres. I remember every single detail the day I went here for brunch with a group of Yelpers. It was life-changing! From who I sat with, me ending up paying for 2 people, the food, the music...everything. It really helps not getting drunk for brunch!

Located inside JW Marriott, the parking situation was a bit of a mess. Some jerk almost ran me over...that was my first memory of him. From that moment on I just knew...

Buffet-style brunch was good. There was a waffle station and an omelet station. I stood a long time waiting for my omelet since they gave mine to some old grumpy lady. They have the usual breakfast fare: eggs, hashbrowns, sausages, bacon, Danishes, bread, potatoes, etc. So, for $20+ brunch x 2...this place was just ok.

"Acknowledged. 

It is gratifying to discover that this establishment boasts an unparalleled level of tranquility, owing to its seemingly perpetual lack of patronage, which in turn facilitates an extended operating schedule that caters to the convenience of nocturnal patrons such as myself. 

While the culinary offerings may not necessarily conform to my personal preferences due to an excessive proportion of adipose tissue in the meat dishes, particularly the thinly sliced beef, the affordability of these items renders them a reasonable value. 

The attentiveness of the staff is commendable, as they display a proficient level of responsiveness and engagement with their clientele, despite the minimal volume of foot traffic that graces the premises, particularly during my late-night visits. 

In light of the aforementioned attributes, I would unhesitatingly endorse this venue as a reliable fallback option, particularly during ungodly hours when alternative dining establishments are unavailable."

"It was a cursory visit, to say the least, as I opted to partake in a brief excursion to the nearby Chipotle establishment, which was conveniently positioned within close proximity to my location. My infrequent patronage of this particular fast-food chain was, in fact, the impetus behind my decision to indulge in their culinary offerings on this particular occasion. Furthermore, the dearth of clientele within the premises at the time of my visit served as an added incentive, as I was able to enjoy a tranquil dining experience unencumbered by the presence of throngs of people. The staff members, cognizant of my limited auditory abilities, graciously accommodated my request for repetition when placing my order, thereby ensuring that I comprehended the details of my meal without any confusion. The gastronomical delight that ensued was indeed satisfying, particularly the warm burrito that provided a welcome respite from the inclement weather conditions outside. Suffice it to say, I shall not hesitate to revisit this establishment in the future, albeit with a preference for a less piquant sauce, as the existing quantity proved to be somewhat overwhelming for my taste buds."

I have been here quite a while. Had the best experience all these time untill the last two.. i have always came here during  the day which i may say it was awesome  the staff kept up with everything(food, drinks, refill) always checking  in on us. Each time  we always  hit the  bar after words. Till i went during  the evening place was pack and had a group  of 9. -.- lets start  by saying the server  didn't  show up to often. We all order food at once  so we wouldn't confuse  him. He had a smile  on his face but knew something  was wrong. Only 3 plates  showed  up when good came and when wr ask him where the rest was he replied  by saying he forgot. An average  drink took about 15 min.  And we had to hunt our server down for our  tab. At the end we still think its a awesome  place but will not go at night, it sucks.!

I will start out with the good - The food.  I had a burger and tots and they were great. I tried my boyfriends catfish Po'boy and it was amazing. The mac and cheese is very good. Onion rings were just okay.

We went to watch the Pather's game and they turned the sound on. It wasnt very packed and the service was pretty good. 

The bad part - there beer selection needs some help. They only have a few taps but where are all the great local beers?

Also, a palmeto bug kept flying around us while we were eating. Hard to prevent but still not very fun.

"The accommodations themselves were diminutive in stature, with minuscule bathing facilities that exuded an antiquated ambiance. However, the notion that one's financial expenditure directly correlates with the quality of lodgings was not entirely applicable in this case, as the rooms were meticulously maintained and presented a modernized, albeit somewhat retro, aesthetic. The temperature of the shower fluctuated between extreme cold and intense heat, which may be attributed to the aged infrastructure of the establishment. Furthermore, a $20 resort fee was charged for internet access that proved unreliable, raising questions regarding the necessity of such a fee, particularly in light of the absence of any pool or other amenities typically associated with the term'resort.' Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the value offered by the hotel remained reasonable considering its affordability. Incidentally, the Fremont Street Experience, a popular entertainment district, was situated immediately outside the room, which may have been perceived as a hindrance for those seeking a more tranquil environment, but would unlikely pose a concern for individuals who intended to engage in nocturnal revelry."

"Ambrosial cuisine, relaxed ambiance, and an array of superior beverage selections render this eatery an optimal destination for those seeking a tranquil atmosphere in which to indulge in culinary delights and socialize with companions or kin, without the necessity of an exceptional gastronomic experience. The restaurant's'mix-and-match' six-pack beer offering presents a convenient and economical option for patrons seeking a potable accompaniment to their repast, obviating the need for an additional excursion to a spirits retailer. However, it is worth noting that the sole drawback of this establishment lies in the occasional sluggishness of its service, ostensibly due to the practice of assigning tables in a rotational manner, rather than by designated zones, resulting in servers traversing the premises in a seemingly haphazard fashion, thereby hindering their ability to attend promptly to patron's needs."

"Upon partaking in a culinary excursion at this establishment, our gastronomical experience was generally satisfactory, with the exception of a few financial discrepancies. Specifically, upon perusing the menu, we noticed that the cost of certain beverages was inconsistent with the prices advertised on the chalkboard exterior to the restaurant. Furthermore, upon querying our server regarding this disparity, he appeared perplexed by our inquiry, leading us to hastily settle the bill to avoid any further inconvenience. However, we cannot help but feel that an injustice was done, particularly in light of the fact that we were overcharged by twelve dollars for the Bloody Mary's consumed by our party. Therefore, we shall remain vigilant in our pursuit of a resolution to this matter, lest we be compelled to reconsider our patronage of this establishment in the future."

I used to not like this place, but I read they changed everything. The Now use these amazing organic cibatta rolls and have removed the High Fructose corn syrup from everything!!! The also are the first restaurant to take it upon themselves to remove trans fat form 100% of everything sold there!. The Royal with light mustard is super good and I usually just switch any of the sandwiches for turkey and ham if I only like the toppings. 

It has totally improved and I come here often now. Oh and I read a review that said you get Soft serve with any meal? Is that true? Why did I not know that?

I would give them an extra star but they have a lesbian that works there that is thinner than me, jk ....but there is

After partaking of the delectable ice cream cookie sandwich from the adjacent establishment, I surmised that a supplementary indulgence would be requisite to satiate my craving for something sweet and tart; thus, I opted for a 'like it', an icy confection with a subtle sweetness and a hint of tartness, though regrettably, it fell short of my expectations, as it lacked the distinctive flavor profile of the genuine article. Nonetheless, the hospitality exhibited by the staff within these premises was truly commendable, as three affable and obliging gentlemen, exuding an unwavering enthusiasm to assist, attended to my needs with alacrity, providing a refreshing contrast to the customary diffidence displayed by their contemporaries stationed behind the counter. Undoubtedly, the prospect of returning to this establishment holds considerable allure for me.

We've only been once so far but the wings and fries were good.

They have subs (fried fish, Philly or chicken cheesesteaks, cold or hot veggies...), wraps, burger platters, fish plates, chicken plates and more.

I was reallllly happy to find this place. It reminds me of carry outs from back home. I've been in the Charlotte area for seven years now and this is the first time I've found a spot like this one.

It's in a small-ish corner so keep your eyes open when you go.
