Just came in for a smog check. It's $19.95 regular price but with the coupon mailer it's $14.95. Can't really complain much about it. Simple service in and out and cheaper than jiffy smog definitely.

This place was so packed when i was here. Like everyone else says the dance floor really isnt big at all. EVERYWHERE, and i mean everywhere possible is reserved for bottle service. Lucky for me im a woman and flirted my way to a grey goose cran and a seat- i feel sorry for the guys!\n\nAdd 2 stars because the line was HUUUGE and we walked straight to the front and into the club.

Lightning fast "strip-mall" style Chinese food.  It's exactly what you expect it to be.  It's a great spot to stop by after work and pick up a quick take-out meal for the family, but I wouldn't expect too much by the way of "cuisine".

Had the beef with broccoli, kung pao chicken, and sweet and sour chicken recently.  All of which were made from picky-eater friendly ingredients, and were a hit with the kids.  I do like the fact that the staff is all Chinese and a few words spoken from the customers in Mandarin seem to go over well.

Overall it's nothing special, but a decent value for a mid-week take home meal.
They have a grill for those steaks that u are craving for. Typical ham and roast beef! It was good for the price and for my boys who are at that age they can't stop eating.

Decided not to come back because last time I was very disappointed with the super expensive honey toast ( cant remember the name all I know is $12.99) and it wasn't that good but had to come back because we couldnt find anywhere else to play card. At least this place has a better service than tea station tho. Overall is not that bad just a little bit pricey.

The culinary offerings were of an exceptionally high quality, boasting an unparalleled freshness and authenticity that was undoubtedly palpable; however, the prices were exorbitant, bordering on the outrageous, which made it challenging for this patron to justify the cost, despite the proprietor's amicable demeanor and the hospitable nature of the young woman manning the counter, thus rendering the prospect of a future visit uncertain, contingent upon a reevaluation of the menu items' pricing, particularly when considering the supplementary charges for beverages and desserts, which tended to inflate the total cost beyond what could be deemed reasonable or appropriate.

"The West Room presents an intriguing culinary experience, boasting a sophisticated ambiance and an extensive cocktail selection that is sure to captivate discerning patrons. However, our dining excursion yielded mixed results, as certain aspects of the fare failed to meet our expectations, thereby casting doubt on the likelihood of future visits. Despite its self-proclaimed status as the 'hidden gem' of the west end, a more judicious curation of menu items may be necessary to elevate The West Room to the level of gastronomic excellence it aspires to."

My family, hailing from Korea, embarked upon a visitation to our humble abode, and during our sojourn to the gastronomical Mecca known as Las Vegas, they expressed an ardent yearning for culinary familiarity. My stratagem was to escort them to the esteemed Grand Lux, but en route, my grandmother's complexion assumed a pallid hue. Thus, we diverted our course towards Imperial Palace, guided by conspicuous signage. Upon ascending the elevator to the fifth floor dining plaza, we were greeted by a warm, familial Korean salutation, which elicited a visible improvement in my grandmother's countenance.  
The menu proffered an array of Korean, Japanese, and Chinese delicacies, but we elected to indulge exclusively in Korean cuisine. Our repast consisted of duk mandoo gook (a hearty soup composed of rice cakes and dumplings), dolsot bibimbap (a medley of rice, vegetables, and a fried egg, served in a sizzling stone bowl), soft tofu soup, and bulgogi (tender, marinated meat). While the fare was unremarkable, observing my grandmother grasp her rice bowl with both hands and devour its contents with unbridled relish rendered the meal decidedly more satisfying.  
Although the cost proved moderately exorbitant for unexceptional Korean cuisine in Las Vegas (amounting to approximately $90, inclusive of tax and gratuity, for a mere luncheon), the staff displayed commendable hospitality and amenability. Personal preferences notwithstanding, I would not revisit this establishment, yet I acknowledge the value of their attentive service and practical accessibility.

We disembarked from the aircraft and meandered towards a delectable repast, savoring an array of gastronomic delights that included, but were not limited to, succulent squid expertly grilled on a plancha, a visually appealing xato salad boasting a medley of colorful vegetables, tender scallops enrobed in a rich, nutty romesco sauce, and a refreshing white ceviche punctuated by the subtle sweetness of fresh raspberries, all artfully arranged on a platter and served with a smile; however, we opted to abstain from beverages, and while the quality of the cuisine was undeniably impressive, the total cost of $80 for a meal that, albeit satisfying our hunger, did not prove particularly filling, struck us as somewhat excessive.

I had the pleasure of dining at CUT with a group of acquaintances, and while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, albeit slightly overcooked and burnt, the ambiance left much to be desired. Specifically, the illumination was excessively dim, making it challenging to discern the appearance of the cuisine, and the service, although plentiful in terms of staff-to-patron ratio, lacked a certain authenticity and warmth in their interactions with customers. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the pricing was reasonable in relation to the quality of the fare provided, and I would consider giving the establishment another opportunity to demonstrate its capabilities under different circumstances.

We only ever get the Louisiana Chicken pasta or cheesecake any more.  I think the menu is so big that it is hard for them to have any specialties (other than cheesecake).  The last 5 dishes I've had have been nothing special at all, and one I even sent back because it was so bad (and I NEVER do that).

My boyfriend and I just had dinner here. I have to say, I'm very underwhelmed by the food here. I was pretty stoked to get a tastey but simple sandwich and fresh made soup. Regretfully, I had the grilled cheese and it was quite lacking in flavor. The red pepper lobster bisque, though a tad \"clumpy\" was quite tasty. I will give Cafe Zupas another shot, but I'm hoping my next choice in sandwich will turn it around for me.

Maybe I was just super hyper up and expected way too much but the Blue Man Group wasn't all that.  Don't get me wrong, there were some really cool parts but there were also some boring parts.  I wanted to fall asleep a couple of times.  My husband's review would be even more critical.  He thought almost the whole show was boring.  For the price of the tickets, I don't think it's worth it.  Maybe if the tickets were $20-30 cheaper, it would be a better bang for your buck.  Some parts were very funny, some parts were neat, and some parts were just like okay-can-this-be-over-already.  Overall, it just gets three stars from me.

I really like this place.  The food, drinks, and wine are always delicious.  The service is great,  but I can't get over how loud they play the live music on Friday and Saturday nights.  The music itself is fun and provides a great feeling, but don't plan on being able to have a conversation if you're in the main room while they pump it in on a speaker.

I was looking for something to do with the in laws and this seemed right up their alley. It's a tourist trap, lots of  touristy stuff for sale and everything costs extra money. It was neat to see, got great pics and the history was great. Won't go again, once was enough but it was something to experience and glad I did.

"In the event that the temperature exterior is either extremely frigid or sweltering hot, and you seek an indoor venue to pass the time without the necessity of migrating between hotels, there are numerous alternative attractions and activities to explore in Las Vegas that would render a visit to this shopping center superfluous, despite its aesthetic appeal and sizable food court. However, if your financial resources are plentiful, this location may serve as an optimal site for indulging in retail therapy. Alternatively, consider visiting one of the several outlet malls situated in the surrounding vicinity of Las Vegas, whereupon you may discover more reasonable prices on merchandise."
Went here with some friends and was not familiar with the menu.  The order counter seemed confusing to me too. Got a turkey sandwich,  but think they used miracle whip not mayo.  Not a fan though.

I perused these critiques and opted to sample this eatery. The Pellini constitutes an Italian burrito, wherein patrons select their preferred protein (chicken, steak, Italian sausage, or shrimp), sauces (either tomato or white), and toppings (cheese and/or vegetables). Numerous options exist, thereby enabling individuals to tailor their dining experience according to their preferences. 
  I experimented with the chicken and Italian sausage combination and found the flavors to be relatively subdued. Perhaps my assemblage of the Pellini contributed to the lackluster taste. 
  My spouse chose the chicken and shrimp variation, and the shrimp significantly enhanced the flavor profile. Her Pellini boasted an impressive gustatory quality. 
  Contemporary and well-maintained ambiance characterized the establishment's interior design, while the staff exhibited attentive and cordial behavior. 
  Although unsure about returning, my partner's positive experience may warrant a future visit.

"Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar offers an extraordinary experience, garnering an overall rating of 3.75. Patrons can revel in the exceptional musical prowess of the pianists, who possess an unparalleled repertoire of songs spanning diverse genres, including classic rock and heavy metal. The ambiance is characterized by a vibrant and lively atmosphere, fostering an environment conducive to socializing, dancing, and merriment. Entrance is complimentary, negating the need for an admission fee or minimum drink purchase, thereby allowing patrons to enjoy the entertainment stress-free. While the audience primarily consists of individuals aged 40 and above, the venue's unique concept and appeal have the potential to captivate a broader demographic. By offering a system of song requests accompanied by tips, patrons can actively engage with the performers and enhance their experience. Embrace the joy of dueling pianos and create unforgettable memories at Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar."

"I had the pleasure of partaking in a midday repast at this esteemed establishment on a recent occasion, and I must say that the ambiance was quite pleasant - it possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that managed to effectively mitigate the inclement weather conditions outside. The service I received was certainly satisfactory, although I cannot claim to have been utterly blown away by the culinary offerings. I opted for an halloumi sandwich, which was accompanied by a side of ciabatta and a mixed green salad. While I did enjoy the salad and the halloumi, I must admit that the ciabatta failed to impress - it seemed to lack a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated the dish to the next level. In conclusion, I must say that the ciabatta did not complement the halloumi in the manner that I had hoped. As for dessert, I sampled the carrot cake, which regrettably proved to be somewhat arid. However, I am willing to give this establishment the benefit of the doubt, as I have heard that their eggs benedict is quite delectable. Therefore, I shall indeed return in the future, armed with an unwavering sense of optimism and a healthy appetite."

"I have a penchant for this establishment due to its affordability, despite the fact that the culinary offerings are not particularly exceptional, yet still manage to satisfy my taste buds. We frequent this venue with a certain degree of regularity, owing to its accessibility and convenience. I would unhesitatingly advocate for a visit to this locale."

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of Spinato's on three separate occasions, with two instances involving takeout and one wherein I indulged in the dining room experience. Upon reflection, I have formulated three distinct musings regarding my experiences at this establishment:  

Firstly, the pizza served at Spinato's is undoubtedly of satisfactory quality, boasting flavors and textures that are bound to satiate even the most discerning of palates.  

Secondly, it is my opinion that the pricing of said pizza is somewhat elevated, perhaps to an extent that may deter potential patrons who are seeking a more affordable dining option.  

Lastly, and unfortunately, the service I received during my visits was subpar, bordering on unacceptable. On one occasion, I was mistakenly served a different pizza than the one I had ordered, and I was forced to wait an additional ten minutes before receiving my correct order. Moreover, no discount or compensation was offered for the inconvenience caused. Similarly, during my third visit, I was told that my takeout order would be ready within 30-35 minutes; however, I waited a full 57 minutes before finally receiving my food. When I brought this issue to the attention of the takeout staff, I was met with a dismissive and unapologetic demeanor, further compounding my frustration.  

In light of these experiences, I am inclined to seek alternative dining options, such as Grimaldi's, where I can enjoy high-quality pizza without breaking the bank.

Heading out for the night and want to get a drink before the craziness begins?  Caramel is a decent choice.  It's definitely nothing to write home about, but it made me happy for one reason;  It was my 3rd night of madness and my priorities were simple....I wanted a seat.  \n\nWe walked in after dinner and meeting up with a few other girls and immediately were approached by a cocktail waitress and told we could sit at one of their reserved tables.  That was music to my ears (and my tired feet!).  It's a small lounge and the crowd was random, if anything.  Not anywhere worth spending more than 30 minutes but  the music was decent and you can get some really good infused vodka and if you're lucky, a seat.
Not my cup of tea. I did not like my tuna entree, despite it being somewhere around $35. \n\nI do enjoy their cocktails, and like to come to the bar for happy hour.

I have an unwavering fondness for Cirque shows, having had the privilege of witnessing a couple of productions prior to this occasion (Ovo & Zumanity), thus, my anticipation was palpable when my partner was generously offered complimentary tickets for his birthday celebration in Las Vegas. Our seats were situated in an optimal location, specifically in the middle, approximately six rows away from the stage, offering us an unobstructed view of the performance. My expectations were surpassed by the captivating set design, which was further enhanced by the incorporation of water elements that contributed to the visual appeal of the show. However, my enthusiasm was tempered by a slight sense of disappointment. It is possible that my expectations were unreasonably high, but I found the comedic aspects of the production to be somewhat lacking. Specifically, the clown humor did not resonate with me, and I found it to be rather tedious. My hope was to witness more extraordinary feats of acrobatics, but apart from the breathtaking diving sequences (which require immense skill) and a select few other acts (such as the fire dancers and jumpers), I was left feeling underwhelmed. Furthermore, I struggled to decipher the narrative that the performers were attempting to convey, and certain scenes were downright perplexing. For instance, the presence of the individual holding the 1-800 sign was unclear to me. Additionally, I experienced a sense of unease during certain parts of the performance, as if it was attempting to transport me to a realm that was reminiscent of a surreal dreamscape. The red-coated performers, in particular, seemed to embody the stuff of which nightmares are composed. Despite my reservations, I still maintain a deep appreciation for Cirque du Soleil, and "O" provided a pleasant diversion for an evening. Nonetheless, I am grateful that we did not expend financial resources on the tickets. As the performance drew to a close, my partner and I found ourselves succumbing to yawns, and we were relieved when it finally concluded. In the future, I intend to explore alternative productions such as Ka or Mystere!

As a pub, it's fine, although it's an over-the-top Vegas version of a pub, and the price for a pint isn't exactly what you'd call reasonable.

As a restaurant, I don't think I'd go again. The food is perfectly good, and my appetizer (slices of pork belly over a kind of eggy bread with a maple glaze, topped with a poached egg) was delicious. But in contrast to the friendly barmen, the table service is passive aggressive, and my main meal (fish and chips) was nothing special. For the price, I'd expect better service, finer food and a better atmosphere.

Still, if you're on the Strip and hunting for a decent beer, it's worth a trip.

"My affinity for Famous Dave's feline culinary offerings is unwavering! In addition, the diverse array of sauces available at each table showcases the restaurant's commitment to gastronomic innovation. Particularly noteworthy is the Georgia Mustard, whose tangy flavor profile complements an array of dishes. However, my enthusiasm for the establishment is somewhat tempered by the inconsistent service, which has proven to be a recurring theme throughout my visits. Specifically, my most recent encounter involved a server who expended an inordinate amount of time engaging in a protracted conversation about his name, thereby delaying the taking of our order. Furthermore, he had the audacity to solicit financial support for a personal cause, an action that struck me as both inappropriate and unprofessional. The manager's failure to address this issue promptly only served to exacerbate my frustration. Ultimately, I believe that had the server devoted as much attention to our table as he did to his self-aggrandizement, the outcome of our meal might have been less problematic."

Who likes the DMV? Nobody. Then why do I give it a 3 star? For the self-service kiosks, where you can be in and out in less than 10 minutes. It's the best thing they could have done to help keep people moving. Now the only time I dread going is when I have to actually see a human to get done what I need. Visit the website to see what you can get done at the kiosk. And they have kiosks in other businesses (AAA's, grocery stores, etc) around Las Vegas, so check that out.

I thought the food was pretty good. I have done alot of really good Tapas and this was just pretty good. These guys pack it in like sardines and a young good looking crowd it is. Too busy for me on the weekends I would go back but there are many other fish in the sea so it won't be soon.

The service and ambiance were very good. Small and intimate. Tables were a little close together in our section, and the heater was blowing directly underneath our feet, so it got a little uncomfortable as the night went on. Used a living social deal, which made the meal an excellent value. Ordered the escargot appetizer and the french onion soup, which were both delicious. Unfortunately, several appetizer and entree menu items were unavailable, including the frog legs, which I was interested in trying. I ordered the steak and frites (ribeye). The steak just wasn't good. The meat seemed very bland and I had to chew through some very tough and rubbery bits. Even though I  enjoyed the soup and appetizer, I left a bit unsatisfied due to the less than stellar ribeye. I do intent to come back and try something else on the menu in the future.

"Refrain from purchasing the bananas, as they have been subjected to refrigeration, which will cause them to undergo an accelerated ripening process, resulting in an unpleasant browning effect by the end of the day. It is advisable to avoid acquiring bananas from Dole, as their quality is inferior compared to other brands."
This place used to be better and more knowledgeable and helpful.  I guess I hit bad staff day or something.\ngood prices and a great selection.   \nNeed chairs to sit and read.

"Subpar, and the notion of 'bring your own wine' has been rendered overhyped. Opting for the fillet mignon, my expectations were unfulfilled. In juxtaposition to the plethora of exceptional eateries within the historic district, this establishment falls short. Perhaps my carnivorous inclinations preclude me from fully appreciating an adequate steak. The reality is, I can effortlessly prepare a superior cut at home for a fraction of the cost, sans the cacophonous ambiance. This venue may be suitable for a corporate gathering on a weeknight, provided it is not too busy, expensive, or utterly deplorable."
Fries are great but everything else is terrible.  I would eat here more often if they improved their burgers even just a little bit.

This place was just "okay."  I would use the term "old timey" to describe it.... I would also use that term to describe the clientele.  I went there for a business lunch, I would say that most of the older male population of Phoenix did the same.  I must also note that there is ZERO ambience-- it looks like a Best Western dining hall.

On to the food.  I had been craving prime rib, so that is what I ordered.  Though it was accurately cooked to be medium rare, the texture and flavor were not great.  The meat was bland, and it was not all that tender.  Even the au jus lacked flavor.  It was served with some sort of potatoes that I didn't really like either.  However, I have to say that my companion ordered the filet-- also medium rare-- and said that it was really good.

I am not going to give this place a bad review, but I can't give it a stellar one either.  Im addition, the prices are a little high for such boring food.  I am truly ambivalent about Stockyards.... and life is too short to eat mediocre food.  ;)

I have a love/hate relationship with this place.. I used to go here for all of my nail needs but during the last couple times they did my gel mani/pedi at the same time which is way too much going on.. I can see if I asked for it or didn't have an appointment but switching hands and feet in to the lights at the same time is just too much, takes the relaxation out of it. However, they do do one of the better pedicures I've gotten in vegas (the hot stone one is awesome!)

It was 10:45 on a Saturday morning, and I was craving a cup of coffee, which led me to embark on a quest to find a suitable establishment where I could indulge in this beverage. Unfortunately, the first cafe I encountered was closed, much to my dismay. Undeterred, I continued my search, seeking a venue that offered a tranquil atmosphere where I could enjoy my coffee and peruse the latest edition of The New York Times. My initial intention was to visit a nearby cafe, but upon arriving, I found the ambiance to be too modern for my liking. I was in a peculiar mood and desired a more traditional coffee experience, devoid of any frills or pretenses. As fate would have it, I chanced upon an elderly gentleman who was enthusiastically promoting a restaurant, touting the "Best lunch in town!" with great vigor. His infectious energy convinced me to give the eatery a try. Thus, I discovered MacAlpines, a quaint establishment that had just opened its doors. I was immediately drawn to the cozy atmosphere and settled into a seat at the counter. Two cups of rich, diner coffee later, I realized my hunger and opted for a delectable stuffed tomato, replete with fresh vegetables. The charming decor and lively jukebox further enhanced my dining experience. Although it took some time for the staff to warm up and display their hospitality, I am eager to revisit MacAlpines with companions and assess its quality once more.

Not as good as their flagship out on Sahara, but this one's right on the strip, although with the renovation you have to wade thru some dust and scaffolding to get here. The portions were just as monstrously large though, and this time we split 2 dishes among the three of us lightweights, and we left full having not even finished either of them. I'd have picked the chicken and waffles for sure but democracy won out. Here we tried the chorizo skillet and the Tractor Driver Combo. The chorizo skillet was good, although the one tortilla it comes with is inadequate for the amount of filling it comes with. The tractor driver combo we upgraded to a banana pancake which was well worth the extra dollar. Service was excellent. \n\nThe experience at their standalone restaurant on Sahara was better in terms of the atmosphere, the food, and the overall experience, but this was still fine.

I celebrated my twenty-first birthday at this venue, and while the experience was enjoyable, it was somewhat diminished by the fact that the establishment appeared to be operating beyond its optimal capacity. Specifically, the dance floor was overcrowded, which made it challenging to fully appreciate the talents of the disc jockey who was performing that evening. Despite these issues, I must admit that I had an enjoyable time, albeit one that was tempered by the aforementioned limitations of space.

The food was good, portions huge, and there was a good variety on the menu.  However it took us an hour and 12 minutes from arrival to getting our food, even though the place wasn't full.  So worth it for the food quality and portions, but be prepared for a long wait to get it.

I was skeptical about authentic Hawaiian food in Vegas, but Island Flavor proved to be a spot that locals could satisfy their craving at.

Portions: HUGE. One plate could feed three of us had we known they were going to be so big. Kahlua pork is mild, but super tender. I could've used a bit more salt on the meat, but it was still good. Sweet and sour pork ribs were tasty but almost a little too salty. Furikake chicken was bomb. I added Sriracha and it became super bomb.

My only complaints are regarding the rice.
Brown rice - too much water so I basically had two scoops of brown rice mush.
Fried rice - now this is where I think Island Flavor failed because their version of fried rice is basically white rice with some lapcherng and veggies doused with soy sauce. I've eaten and seen fried rice made enough to know we weren't eating fried rice. The portion was a potful. No joke.

COCO PUFFS = yum. I have no idea what the buttery yellow stuff is on top of the chocolate cream puff but it's ONO.
Mud pie = good. I liked the chocolate cacao or coffee nibs in the kona coffee ice cream. Really nice touch. Could do without the flavored syrups on the plate though.

Staff were friendly even though very busy.

Spam musubi was right on. Reminded me of all the musubis we've eaten in Hawaii.

I love a good massage. My husband purchased a gift card for couples massage and gifted it to me for Christmas. Scheduling the massage was very easy. This location is very clean and the waiting room was very therapeutic. The massage room was ok. It was barely decorated and in kind of a weird layout. Our massage therapists were very friendly and professional. I can't say that I will be back after I use the rest of the money on my gift card, though. The massage was ok, but I've had much better ones. They really try to sell you on becoming a member when you are checking out, which I do not like.

"I was taken aback by the fact that the jerk fried rice did not possess the same level of piquancy as it had during my initial visit. Moreover, the portion size appeared diminutive in comparison to previous experiences, barely filling the circular aluminum receptacle. Despite these observations, the culinary offerings remained flavorsome and gratifying. I would advocate for the black beans over the refried variety, as they exhibit a more pronounced gustatory profile. The service was commendable, with the staff displaying promptness and amiability in their interactions with us. Notwithstanding, the ordering process proved somewhat perplexing, necessitating the guidance of the staff for novice patrons to fully comprehend the intricacies of the menu."

I was at the Starbucks in the Trails Village Center and needed to stop at the ATM at Wells Fargo.  There wasn't a single car in any of the three lanes even the one with the ATM.  That's almost 4 stars without thinking.

This is an OK place, but it's not in my neighborhood and it's a bit of a pain getting in and out with the traffic coming in and out of the Trails Center.

I have lived here over a decade and this is my first check in here says something.

My review of Fin is pretty much the same as all of the other Yelpers. I found Fin to be a bit pricey for Chinese food, and the staff is very overly incredibly attentive. If you take a sip of water, someone is there to refill it for you. 

The food is good, though, there's no doubt about it. I ordered the stir-fry chicken and was very satisfied. They also follow up your meal with a delicious house made fortune cookie and shot of Baileys. 

The ambiance is fantastic if you sit toward the back and can block out the chachings of the nearby slot machines. 

Highly recommended for a nice dinner as long as you're aware of the price and overly attentie service staff.

I suppose its well stocked and closer for me than Tesco but it just doesnt have that friendly neighbourhood shop vibe. 
Twice in the last couple of weeks Ive been short changed and instead of a 'are you sure' or a 'lets see' the dude looked at me as if I just declared an interest in his wife.
Both times they were out by a pound or so. we aint talking 2p here man!


 They are on to me though. Last week I was overcharged for a coke and so I said 'I paid less last week'. He replied 'oh we undercharged you by mistake'...Good move that one...


 Finally, dont try and haggle. I haggled them for 20p off some Snapple but the only one who sanctions haggled goods is the Old Man. The other staff were taken by surprise and looked a little scared as I tried the haggling.

"= = = = = = DAILY LUNCH BUFFET!  = = = = = = 

Monica O. orchestrated an unforgettable culinary excursion at a local Thai restaurant, enticing 15 fellow Yelp enthusiasts to partake in a sumptuous buffet showcasing an array of delectable Thai delights, fostering camaraderie and conviviality among the group. (Kudos to Monica!)  The bountiful spread boasted 15 diverse offerings, including two soups, a vegetarian option featuring egg and tofu, and a coconut-based delight with chicken; plain and flavored rice complemented the assortment, accompanied by an assortment of savory hot dishes encompassing chicken, beef, and fish, along with numerous vegetable combinations, totaling an impressive 19 items. 

The culinary experience was generally satisfying, and considering the scarcity of Thai buffets in the area, the establishment's presence is indeed a welcome addition.     :-)

Although the dining ambiance was pleasant, and the table service was adequate, several minor drawbacks marred the experience:

*  A preponderance of poultry dominated the meat selections.

*  Desserts were conspicuously absent from the menu.

*  The eatery enforced a restrictive policy, permitting a single credit or debit card payment per table, which proved problematic for our group, as only one member had sufficient cash on hand.  This particular stipulation seemed inconvenient and counterproductive, prioritizing corporate interests over customer satisfaction.  

                                                                                          `

Lunch Buffet Schedule and Prices:

Tuesday through Friday: $9.99, available from 11:30 AM.
Sunday: $10.99, served from 12 noon."

"I opted for the fish and tofu tacos as my midday repast, and I must say, they utilized corn tortillas, which I deem to be an admirable choice. The fish exhibited a palatable quality, while the tofu blend presented an intriguing flavor profile, yet the tacos themselves did not ascend to an exceptional level of gastronomical excellence. However, the venue's ambiance appeared pleasant, with ample space surrounding the bar and an outdoor seating area that presumably offers a delightful setting during favorable weather conditions."

Quirky interior, clearly popular and possibly the best priced pot of tea in town.


 Could maybe do with opening past 18:00.

Price was right. Cool concept but I like 5 guys better. What A Burger is my favorite burger, guess you could say I'm old school. In and out was busy and had good service but as for the burger's. A lot of hype.

"It is my conviction that the preponderance of recent reviews are authored by individuals who are either employed by the establishment or are affiliated with said employees, and their familial connections thereto. 

Upon attempting to redeem my prepaid Groupon, I was met with resistance, as the eatery refused to honor said voucher. It is worth noting that the venue in question remains unchanged, both in terms of its moniker - Greek Grill & Fry Co. - and its continued operation under the same proprietorship. 
The server, though courteous and helpful in their suggestions, neglected to inform me of the restaurant's policy regarding the aforementioned Groupon prior to our culinary indulgences, opting instead to offer a reduced tariff of twenty percent. As a matter of personal protocol, I habitually allude to any applicable discounts or promotions upon arrival at an establishment. 

The fare provided by the restaurant was of satisfactory quality, albeit the options available were somewhat limited. However, the food was prepared promptly and served at an appropriate temperature. It is worth mentioning that during our visit, the only other patrons present were members of the proprietary family, one of whom - an elderly gentleman, presumably an uncle or grandfather - was situated within the dining area, engaged in the dual activities of television viewing and telephonic communication. The ambiance of the venue can be described as relaxed and informal."

There are some tables and a lot of slot machines. If you live in the area, it could be a good place to go and hang out. I would never recommend a drive from the strip to gamble here, but not bad for a locals hang out. With dollar beer and hot dogs, how can you go wrong!?

Its americanized, but pretty tasty! I love the fried rice and usually just get that. We were getting takeout once and waited at the bar, and the bartender gave us free tastes of the lychee cocktail while we waited! And that was tasty too!

Its also never crowded, its quiet and the service is consistently not bad. 

All that being said though, there isn't really anything special about this place. Its just kind of...eh... Best as take out.

"Although I cannot comment on the lounge area, as I did not have the opportunity to experience it, my culinary excursion at this establishment left me feeling somewhat indifferent. The portion sizes, in relation to the cost, were minuscule, in my opinion. Furthermore, I felt that the price point of their sake was slightly elevated. The hospitality, while certainly attentive, bordered on excessive eagerness to expedite our departure. My spouse's dish was actually removed before he had completed his meal, necessitating our request for the plates to remain until we had finished dining. Despite the captivating and romantic atmosphere, I would not consider returning to this venue in the future."

This establishment no longer possesses the identical quality and culinary prowess it formerly boasted in years past. As an ardent patron since the early 1970's, I have witnessed a gradual decline in both the standard of service and gastronomical offerings since the turn of the millennium. It is no longer a viable dining option, failing to provide an adequate value for the price. Despite the persistently cordial demeanor of the staff and an aesthetically stagnant ambiance, my recent dining experience was marred by the unfortunate preparation of my New York strip steak, which was subjected to an unsolicited butterflying process that effectively extracted the inherent flavor and rendered it unpalatable. Lamentably, this once-lauded eatery has relinquished its erstwhile prestige, precluding me from enthusiastically recommending it to acquaintances embarking upon a culinary excursion to Las Vegas.

"Although my culinary preferences do not align with the gastronomical offerings at this establishment, I do appreciate the expansive outdoor seating area, which presents an ideal setting for indulging in a mixed beverage, such as a refreshing cocktail or a glass of wine, at any time."

"Concurring with the prevailing sentiment, I must aver that this excursion does not qualify as a hike in the classical sense, owing to the presence of artificial stairs and an absence of any genuine ruggedness or challenge. Rather, it constitutes a leisurely stroll with a picturesque view of the surrounding landscape, conveniently located in close proximity to the local zoological garden. While it may serve as a charming diversion for a couple seeking a lighthearted adventure, it falls short of the rigorous criteria typically associated with hiking. Notwithstanding, I did appreciate the opportunity to showcase my stylish attire, replete with fashionable footwear, as I effortlessly ascended the hill."

I was here before the supposed end of the world, and it seemed like everyone here was having a great time.  My gf got a tip from her promoter that got us to get in for free, alongside the complimentary drinks that they offered just before midnight, so it was pretty cool to come in hang out for a bit.\n\nBlush is really small in comparison to XS and Surrender. Blush doesn't have a dance floor, just walkways in between the tables. You can try to dance in those areas, but you'll end up looking kinda awkward dancing in the limited space. The music seemed to be mainstream, with less emphasis on hip hop. We only stayed in there for about 30 minutes and ended up leaving to meet up with the others outside that couldn't get in.
Chef cooking in the open facility. Mostly noodles. Pad Thai noodles, beef. A most desirable appetite for the hungry man. Couldn't take this to heart.

I went for lunch today with friends after a hike.  We were hungry.

I had a lunch meal.  The sandwich was fresh, hot and generous.  My side salad was wilted.  I would have thrown out the lettuce in my home.

One of my friends had a traditional breakfast, and he said he was great.  Eggs cook properly, and again generous portions.

My last friend (at breakfast, not on the face of the earth)  had a breakfast burrito, and said it was very good.  I think my salad was the weakest link.

The service was good, and everyone seemed very friendly.  We were seated within 10 minutes, and being warned there would be a wait.  They left carafes of coffee, iced tea, and soda on the table for self-refilling.

The prices were fine.  I'd go back, but avoid the salad...at least at lunch time.

we ate here for our last day in vegas. everyone was hung over and we needed some soup to make us feel better. i ordered the fire chicken wings which weren't spicy at all. but it wasn't bad. the dim sum was yummy because they had a good amount of shrimp inside. the duck noodle soup thing was ok. the duck was good. hot and sour soup- a bit spicy, too much pepper. and the chrysanthemum iced tea was delish.

This particular site was in close proximity to Arizona State University. It was devoid of patrons on a festive day. Our attendant was exceptional. The culinary offerings were prepared flawlessly. Furthermore, they offered a designated area for scholastic pursuits, which I believed to be an inspired notion. The sole recommendation proffered by my dining companion was that the server should inform patrons of any supplementary charges beforehand, rather than taking them by surprise on their bill. Although the menu did contain a reference to this practice, it did not explicitly state that an additional two dollars would be added to the cost of eggs upon requesting a slice of cheese.

"The tariffs were reasonable, but unfortunately, they had exhausted their supply of stout; regrettably, this resulted in a somewhat cramped ambiance, as the personnel appeared to be stretched thin in attempting to accommodate the influx of patrons, which made it arduous to acquire the attention of the servers, who seemed to be overwhelmed by the sheer volume of customers, and thus, our culinary experience was slightly prolonged, and we were compelled to solicit our beverages and settlement with some degree of urgency, yet, considering the cost, I did not feel inclined to express any significant reservations, as the entertainment afforded by the diverse assemblage of individuals, predominantly middle-aged sales representatives from the Midwest, who had converged upon the establishment moments prior to our arrival, provided an unanticipated source of amusement."

We got a room for $35/night, a Motel-6 price for a better-than-Motel-6 room with much-better-than-Motel-6 amenities.  The pools are awesome.  You get a free drink pass.  Gym is pretty nice, too.  I approve.

Finally, someone got smart and decided to open a Metro Pizza in Henderson! I no longer have to fight UNLV students on their lunch break for a nice booth and some pizza. The new location I believe is better than the original. It has a full bar area, a party room, and regular dining room. There is also a separate wing for pick up orders so you don't have to trek all the way through the restaurant in your pj's and slippers. The pizza is great on its own, but the nuclear fries are so good, I would go just for those. They are spiced and have a bit of a kick, and make the perfect addition for a pie. They also have a variety of beers on tap, which also obviously pairs well with pizza. Avoid the weekend evenings though because the hype around the new restaurant is still prevalent. It's packed. Lunch is the best time, and things stay pretty quiet. 

Recommended pizza: The margherita.

Recommended beer: Hefeweizen with some lemons.

This is the cheapest option if you are in Paris, which isn't saying much. We'll actually there's a place two doors down that had sandwiches in a display case but for an extra dollar or two we got a much more appetizing sandwich here. \n\nI definitely would not go out of your way for this place. However, if it is 2pm, you just got in from your flight and don't want another airport refrigerated sandwich, then just maybe this is the place for you too.

First and foremost, I don't mind spending money on good coffee.  I do have to say that the ambiance has definitely changed quite a bit in the last 6 months.   I used to walk in and see my favorite baristas and we'd chit chat a little but now they all seem to be gone.  I'm going to assume that's because of the new location?  I'm not sure.  Regardless the coffee now seems to taste less satisfying :(.  It's saddening because we really adored this place but now go elsewhere.  If anything it's a testament to the difference people can make in that sort of environment.

this is a review for flaverz the buffet inside harrah's. whenever i go out to vegas i always try to eat at this place. its one of those places that is not so cheap but they have a great selection of food. they have mexican, italian, sea food, fresh foods, chinese, and deserts. everything is great and all the times that ive been there is always some new item on the list. its great. i think that it is like $20 per person. however if you do the timeshare stuff then you can get 2 for 1. however having gone this week we discovered that you have to be 28+ to do the time share :( im just 24 but a few months ago i was able to do it :) oh the time share thing is at the entrance to the casino, just walk around and they will get you specially if you are a couple or look like one.

My wife and i went for lunch last week.  The food was so so and the service was a bit slow.  We both got lunch specials that came with soup, spring roll and fried wontons.  The soup was not what I would call a traditional Thai soup, the spring roll was too greasy, and the wontons were bland.  My wife got the yellow curry and I got Panang.  I ordered mine \"Thai spicy\" but it was more like medium.  Next time we go for Thai we'll try the Thai Cafe which is just a mile or so away.

The fruit and veg from here isn't always at its best and I did once buy a bag of plums from here on the cheap just to find they'd gone off, but it was on the cheap and luckily for this review I know to slow cook them and they turned out to be delicious.  This means there is a risk if you are buying the really cheap or out of season items, but other than that you should be okay.\n\nIn general I don't want to put you off because there are some nice items on offer here, but you do want to keep your eye out for something that's simply too far gone.

"Commencing with the culinary offerings, I must say that they were quite satisfactory. My spouse thoroughly enjoyed the juiciness of the steak, while I relished the flavorful halibut. The baked potato accompanying the dish was indeed exceptional, and the 'wine of the month' promotion, available for a mere $20 or complimentary with the hotel coupon book, was an added bonus. 

However, the quality of service left something to be desired. While the staff was attentive in certain aspects, such as promptly serving our beverages and wine, they were conspicuously absent in other regards. We were forced to request our entree after an extended wait time of approximately 75 minutes, and even then, it was served with haste, necessitating our swift departure to make our scheduled show. Moreover, the server displayed an unusual defensiveness and offered explanations, which we found perplexing, given that our query was delivered in a genial manner, devoid of any trace of annoyance. 

Despite these drawbacks, the eatery's ambiance exuded an air of elegance suitable for special occasions, particularly for guests lodging at the South Point hotel. While the prices may seem a tad high, the experience, on the whole, proved satisfying."

Very brisk for Christmas lunch. I strongly recommend reservations. It is very humourous that they would turn us away when the place was empty when we walked in (see picture). But clearly a popular place and by the time we left every table in the place was full. 

Without a reservation in busy Christmas lunch season I would recommend a reservation for anything more than 2 people. We sat at the bar.

Expensive lunch:
$10 soup
Lunch special $19 soup and pasta

Food was ok.... one of my colleagues had to send the lunch special back and the meat was raw. To their their credit they did check shortly after the first bite and were quick to bring a new plate out.

I have great respect for restaurants that have staff that can recognize a problem quickly. I think this was reflected in the tip.

I really like Lavo (as a nightclub)! Have yet to have a meal here though, so this review is for the nightclub only. Space-wise it can get pretty cramped because it's a bit on the smaller side, but nowhere near as uncomfortably packed as Tao. Dance floor is pretty tiny, but honestly, I didn't notice it until the place had mostly cleared out and I got a good look around. They play hip-hop and a lot of old songs, but old in a way that makes you go "oh man, I haven't heard this song in a while, but  it's still awesome," which I think is a nice change of pace from all the clubs that play almost exclusively house music.

Lavo is probably a 3.5 in my book, though I have to admit, part of the reason for that is because we had open bar, courtesy of our wonderful promoter (who also got our guys in for free!) There's a main bar area, but we got all our drinks from the side bar, which was super crowded and only had one bartender working there. But he was a really adorable and sweet bartender, so no complaints.

tl;dr: Everyone in my group had a fairly fun time. Would definitely come back-- especially if we're staying at the Venetian/Palazzo!

It's OK.

The good:
- Nice location (glad to have something at Town & Country)
- The parking was fine
- The service was great
- Prices are cheap
- Chocolate milkshake was really good

The bad:
- The Wreck
- Sandwiches had hardly any meat and hardly any toppings
- If you like a sandwich that is mostly bread then this is for you

On the cheap, I'd rather go to Subway.  Ho hum, at least at Subway I get my lettuce and tomatoes.

I would give this a 3.5. I would expect the pizza to be a lot better just because it is a Pie place. It was good but I've had a lot better. The thing this has is great ambiance. I love how low the lighting is. Dark tables that are turned perfectly so you don't feel like you are apart of other people's dinners. Great fire from the oven and open area bar. Had a good solid wine. We got the cheese board which was good. We both got pizza but like I said it was good just nothing special.

I rarely frequent Fresh and Easy due to the lack of visual appeal of their stores, with the exception of a few select items that pique my interest, primarily snacks such as peanut butter filled salted pretzel nubs, some satisfactory salted kettle chips, and a passable trail mix suitable for hiking excursions. My brief visit to the store yesterday served as a testament to my unfamiliarity with its layout, as I aimlessly wandered the aisles in search of my desired products, not unlike a zombie driven by an unyielding determination to acquire the items on my list. Following a swift checkout process, during which I presented only two items for purchase, I proceeded to venture across the street to Albertsons, whereupon I conducted a more extensive and deliberate shopping expedition.

The gastronomical experience offered by this diminutive yet delectable salsa bar, tacos, quesadillas and burritos establishment is undoubtedly reminiscent of authentic Mexican culinary traditions, a far cry from the homogenized, commercialized fare served at Macayos. However, patrons seeking to indulge in these scrumptious delights must contend with limited seating capacity and an absence of accommodations suitable for larger gatherings or families, while the prospect of parking in adjacent streets elicits consternation and potential vitriol from local residents, who manifestly take umbrage with the notion of their domain being utilized for vehicular stationing, going so far as to threaten the towing of any recurring offenders' vehicles.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by the consumption of these burgers, at a price point that can only be described as eminently reasonable, is nothing short of exceptional, particularly when considered in conjunction with the ambiance fostered by the establishment's unique setting, which serves to facilitate convivial dialogue among patrons; however, it must be noted that certain aspects of the menu, specifically the dearth of diversity in the realm of beer offerings, as well as the rather unremarkable quality of the fries served as an accompaniment to the main course, do detract somewhat from the overall enjoyment of the dining experience."

Food is great but service is terrible. This is one of my favorite restaurants, but this location doesn't make the grade. Waited 15 minutes in an empty restaurant at 1:30 for a bean burrito to go. Seriously...
Good flavor, good service, long wait and under done pepperonis. Gotta go to Grimaldis in Brooklyn to compare the two. Nothing special.

"For those who relish the prospect of partaking in a Sunday night concert series, an event characterized by an amalgamation of familial units, canine companions, and an assortment of pedestrians meandering aimlessly throughout the vicinity of one's seating arrangement, accompanied by the cacophonous symphony generated by the confluence of blaring train horns and subpar audio equipment, and further exacerbated by the unenviable task of securing a parking space within close proximity to the venue, may find the aforementioned concert series to be an ideal addition to their schedules. My companion and I managed to secure a relatively advantageous position, removed from the central performance area yet still susceptible to the multitude of distractions mentioned previously, none of which proved particularly bothersome to our collective sensibilities. However, it is essential to note that attendance at this event may necessitate tolerance of the aforementioned factors, and potentially, the presence of numerous children and canines under the stewardship of a single individual. Furthermore, it is advisable to arrive prematurely to ensure procurement of a desirable vantage point, ideally situated across the street from the performance arena. It is plausible that the throng in attendance may have been augmented due to the coincidence of a holiday weekend, although such speculation remains uncertain in the absence of subsequent visits to the event."
Went on a night that they had a live band on the patio.....was a nice atmosphere. Drinks were good but food was just okay. May go back if other places are too busy.

Nice room.
Stayed here for 3 nights.

Early checking cost $50 extra. Better than napping in the parking lot with wife, baby and mo in law in our tiny Honda insight.

Not many places to plug in all of our chargers for cell phones so we took turns and used the restroom plugs.

Check in line was always long, with not enough staff to handle it...

Check out was a mad rush too. Vegas wasn't very busy this time of year. End of march.

Parking was free. 

The iPod dock didn't charge the iPod and it had the wrong time.

They had a fridge and safe in the room.

No coffee pot in the room.

The checkout was kind of weird.  I suggest an easy checkout.  Get the folio under your door and just walk out if there aren't any problems with the bill.  We ended up standing in a 30 minute line just to check out.

Good Job TI, but I think for the price, I might stay somewhere else.

Last evening, we opted to partake of a culinary excursion to the esteemed eatery known as Mert's, whereupon we indulged in their delectable Fried Catfish and Beef Rib Combo. Alas, our gastronomical experience was not without its drawbacks, as the whole fried catfish presented some difficulties in navigating the bony terrain, ultimately yielding a meager amount of succulent fish. Furthermore, "The Beef Rib" dish was found to be somewhat lacking in quantity, with the meat being chopped into small pieces and intermingled with an abundance of bones. However, we must commend the kitchen staff for their proficiency in preparing the sides, particularly the Mac and Cheese, which boasted a satisfying crust on its surface, and the Corn Bread, whose texture and flavor were both pleasing, although a minor quibble could be raised regarding the slightly overcooked nature of the piece my spouse received, resulting in a somewhat dry and unfortunate conclusion to an otherwise enjoyable repast. In summary, while not without its flaws, our visit to Mert's proved to be a generally satisfactory dining experience.

"My affection for cinematic endeavors directed by John Hughes notwithstanding, this particular establishment purporting to serve breakfast items under the moniker 'The Breakfast Club' fell short of my expectations, which, admittedly, were predicated on the eponymous film. The eggs, while adequate in terms of their culinary execution, unfortunately lacked that je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to the realm of true gastronomical excellence; the potatoes, referred to as 'O'Brian' in an apparent attempt at novelty, were unremarkable in both texture and flavor, with an unfortunate tendency towards oiliness and an inconsistent distribution of pepper; the jalapeno biscuits, whose conceptual appeal had initially piqued my interest, regrettably failed to deliver upon their promised premise, manifesting instead as somewhat tough and flavorless disk-shaped entities infused with jalapenos; the heuvos rancheros, while perhaps visually unappealing to some due to their resemblance to a feline hairball, were declared palatable by my dining companion. \n\nIn conclusion, my experience at this establishment was, overall, disappointing, primarily due to an excessive greasiness that permeated the menu offerings, as well as an outdoor seating area that, while pleasant in theory, proved to be a mixed blessing given its proximity to a heavily trafficked thoroughfare. However, it must be acknowledged that the quality of service provided by the waitstaff was, for the most part, satisfactory, despite certain unsettling mannerisms reminiscent of the Stepford Wives that were observable in some of the servers."

"In conclusion, it can be inferred that the venue possesses certain attributes that render it an enjoyable destination, however, various factors, such as the charges associated with parking, entry, and storage, in addition to the limited number of functional water slides, may potentially hinder its appeal, ultimately leaving the decision to visit up to individual preferences."

Fairly typical Chinese food with a Sushi menu and nice restaurant seating area.  I wasn't as wow'd as I was hoping after reading all the rave reviews here on Yelp, but it is a pretty decent offering.

I tried the egg drop soup, which was a good value, the pork dumplings, which were meh - I think the sauce was overly sweet, the kung pao chicken, which was pretty good, and the chicken lo mein noodles, which were meh (but aren't all lo mein noodles pretty meh?).

Overall I would come back and get some take out because it does lie somewhere in between your PFChangs and your strip mall cheap Chinese take out place.  However, I don't believe it's that great of a value offering.  The prices are a bit high for cheap Chinese, and the quality is only just a bit higher.  Doesn't feel like you're getting a great deal.

The decor here is adorable. It made me want to sit and stay a while. I had my first macaroon, well two, mixed berry and raspberry. People always rave about them (not necessarily from here, but in general) so I decided to indulge. I didn't love or hate them. I'll definitely be back to try other options.

"Although Footlocker may not excite one's senses, it does offer an array of prominent shoe brands, including Reebok, Nike, Adidas, and an abundance of basketball sneakers that could be deemed superfluous. Prices range from moderate to expensive, yet periodic sales provide customers with the opportunity to acquire desirable footwear at a reduced cost. However, these sales often feature aesthetically unappealing shoes that may not be in high demand. As Footlocker appears to cater primarily to male clientele, its inventory is comprised predominantly of men's shoes, leaving a limited selection for women. Thus, while I may visit the store to peruse its offerings, I frequently find myself seeking alternatives that better align with my preferences."

My fiancÃ© recommended that I compose a review, and I responded by expressing my ambivalence towards the eatery, describing it as unremarkable and lacking any distinctive qualities that would warrant a positive or negative appraisal. I assigned a rating of 2.5 stars, which I deemed appropriate given the establishment's unexceptional offerings. The service was adequate, eliciting neither praise nor criticism from me. The culinary selections available during the happy hour period featured two tacos for $3, with the chef selecting the varieties. I thoroughly enjoyed consuming the salmon taco, finding its flavors to be quite satisfying. However, my expectations for the guacamole were not met, as I had hoped for a more impressive experience. While the inclusion of dried cranberries added an intriguing element, my preference remains with the superior quality of Trader Joe's guacamole. The food at this establishment could be described as "rico," a term denoting richness or abundance in Spanish, often used as a compliment. However, in this case, the term "rico" applied more to the caloric content rather than the culinary excellence. Although I wouldn't object to returning, my desire to do so isn't particularly strong either.

"It is not a cinematic establishment that I routinely visit, given my residence in NLV, but the alterations implemented since Rave acquired ownership of the venue appear to be advantageous. They have incorporated supplementary armrests between each seat, featuring sturdier cup holders than customary, presenting both benefits and drawbacks; although facilitating the sharing of beverages and snacks, the immobility of the armrests constitutes a hindrance. 

Advantages:
Enlarged armrests
Expanded snack bar relative to others

Disadvantages:
Delayed commencement of the film (White House Down) by approximately twenty minutes, ostensibly due to the absence of an individual in the operational chamber
Insufficient quantity of M&M's within the package procured at the snack bar."

"Ja... ganz OK."
Für "Jawohl. So lob' ich mir das." fehlt noch etwas...

Eine Location mit dem Ansatz "Burger & Bratwurst" außerhalb einer Fast-Food Kette anzubieten. Eher Restaurant als Bar...

Im Prinzip gibt es keine fertigen Gerichte sondern einen Baukasten aus dem man(n) sich seine Portion/ Gericht selbst zusammen stellen kann.
Der Service war bisher immer sehr freundlich (aufmerksam aber nicht aufdringlich)

Keine schlechte Location, aber das Gesamtkonzept (Preis-Leistung) ist IMHO noch nicht ganz schlüssig umgesetzt. Im Augenblick kommt es mir so vor wie eine Kreuzung zwischen Szeneladen Berlin-Mitte und den aktuell sehr angesagten Münchner "Currywurst-Bars"...

Hohe Frauenquote ;-)

A group of us went here to eat some burgers since we heard they had good burgers. The food was good but somewhat oily and dry. I woul of given the restaurant 4 stars if it wasn't for the horrible service provided by Olivia. She had a bad attitude throughout the whole time we were there for no reason at all. We asked for a To Go box and she just threw it on the table, which we thought was so rude. We asked our waters to be filled 3 times before she actually got around to it. The restaurant is expensive, so I expected better service. Overall, it's worth going if you enjoy a good burger. Hopefully, you get a better waitress/waiter.

"I decided to indulge in an afternoon delight, opting for a frozen yogurt treat from Golden Spoon. With an array of delectable flavors to choose from, I settled on Irish creme, adorned with almond roca topping. Initially, I relished every bite, savoring the richness of the frozen confection. However, as I progressed through my treat, my thoughts became increasingly preoccupied with the unmistakable zest of Twangy Tart. The tangy, fruity essence of this flavor captivated my taste buds, leaving me in a state of utter fascination. It was as if the Ice Tango had performed a tantalizing dance on my tongue, leaving an indelible impression. From that moment forward, I found myself irreversibly enamored with the Twang, and no other frozen yogurt establishment could compare. Golden Spoon, once my go-to destination for frozen delights, had suddenly become secondary. My taste buds had been forever transformed by the magical touch of Ice Tango, and nothing would ever be the same again."

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment are undoubtedly palatable, they fail to justify the cost associated with their consumption. My recent visit afforded me the opportunity to sample their allegedly piquant poultry dish, which, I must admit, lived up to its billing in terms of its fiery demeanor. However, my gratification was somewhat tempered by the exorbitant tariff levied for the meal, specifically $11 for a midday repast that, in my estimation, did not warrant such an extravagant expenditure. Notwithstanding, I would still confer upon the victuals a rating of four stars out of five, cognizant of the fact that my reservations pertain primarily to the pricing and not necessarily the quality or flavor of the fare itself."

"Although my culinary expectations were not entirely fulfilled by the pho I had ordered at this establishment, I did observe that certain menu items consumed by fellow patrons appeared to possess a level of gastronomical quality that was ostensibly superior. This observation instilled within me a sense of curiosity regarding the potential merits of the restaurant's offerings, leading me to consider the possibility of future visits during which I might sample a broader array of dishes. It is worth noting, however, that my initial impression of the venue was that it seemed to be more heavily influenced by American culinary traditions than its counterparts in the Spring Mountain area, which may have contributed to my relative disappointment with the pho."

"This shopping center formerly enjoyed a preeminent status among its peers within the locality. However, with the advent of Arizona Mills, Chandler Fashion Center, and Tempe Marketplace, it appears that a significant proportion of patrons residing in Chandler, Tempe, and Gilbert have migrated their allegiance to these newer retail establishments. Despite this shift, a plethora of quality stores continue to operate within Fiesta, mirroring an array of identical retailers found at the aforementioned competitors. Notably, during peak sales periods and holidays, the mall's diminished foot traffic translates into a more comfortable and convenient shopping experience for patrons. Additionally, Fiesta boasts a unique covered parking area, which distinguishes it from its rivals and offers a welcome respite from the sweltering heat during the summer months."

I know I said that they were professional and all, but the other day we received a bill for what the insurance wouldn't pay.  It came in a decent envelope, but then we opened it.

Plain sheet of paper with printing.  No tear-off portion, no return envelope (not to mention return postage - I wouldn't expect that from anyone).  Just a sheet, badly folded, printed out on a cheap printer.

So much for professional.  I guess that only extends to examinations - and presumably procedures.  Definitely not to the billing department.  We get a lot of medical bills since we started buying our own insurance, and this is definitely the cheapest of the bunch.

I get that it's only a few cents for an envelope and all - but it can't cost them much more to have some reasonably pre-printed invoices with tear-off return portions, much less a return envelope.  It would just make for a nicer experience, you know?

"An extraordinary location, offering an ambiance that exudes sophistication and elegance, yet remains welcoming and approachable. The Chopped Salad, a culinary masterpiece, undoubtedly reigns supreme among its peers, boasting an unparalleled flavor profile that transcends the mundane and enters the realm of gastronomic excellence. However, its portion size, though adequate for a light repast, falls short of expectations considering its premium pricing. Perhaps, a more generous serving, tantamount to the quality of the dish, might encourage increased patronage.  

Regarding beverages, the flight, while maintaining an acceptable level of potency, unfortunately, requires an interminable waiting period, analogous to the time spent awaiting the arrival of an errant canine on one's lawn. Nonetheless, the BBQ sauce, a tangy and savory condiment, serves as a delightful accompaniment to the main course. The staff, though proficient in their duties, fails to exhibit the exceptional level of hospitality one might anticipate given the upscale nature of the establishment. A gratuity or complimentary dessert, bestowed upon patrons in acknowledgment of merely satisfactory service, could potentially redeem an otherwise unremarkable dining experience and foster customer loyalty. 

In conclusion, this venue, harmonizing seamlessly with the vibrant downtown Scottsdale atmosphere, offers a unique and enjoyable dining adventure. Nevertheless, it is advisable to avoid the buffalo meat, as it may evoke imagery associated with canine visitors and detract from the overall epicurean indulgence."

The food here was really good. It was filling and tasty. However, when compared to other taco joints or mexican food, it is just very average. I love mexican food and the food here lacks the authenticity of other places... But this should be obvious since its in a casino. \nMy problem is that they are very very pricey. For two people, it was $54. The food was good and it was discounted for gamblers, but if I had to pay over $50 for the quality I would be upset.\nDefinetly people should come here and try it out, just know the quality isn't worth the price.

Decent food for the price however I've been to better sushi places for the similar price(and sometimes its worth pay extra for better food). Their makis are often sloppy and unfinished looking and certain fish(fresh tuna or yellow tail for example) are not the freshest. I guess it's good for quick lunch once in a while but not for a fancy dinner.

Met someone here to play on the tennis courts.  Surprisingly the courts were in good shape, the nets were missing the straps, but we played through it.  Overall it's a nice complex.... my one complaint would be that the parking lot is a bit of a maze to get out with a lot of curves (which means a lot of blind spots if you are backing out).  Yes, it keeps the place looking interesting, but I would hate to be a grounds keeper here since there are no straight lines in sight.\n\nThe apartments look pretty solid, all-brink.... there is a lot of highway noise coming from 485 though.... I didn't go inside one unit, but it was fairly loud from the tennis court.

"Applebee's, a ubiquitous chain restaurant, fails to impress me with its unremarkable offerings. Despite my predilection for certain franchises, Applebee's does not rank among my favorites. The cuisine is merely adequate, neither exceptional nor deplorable, but rather mediocre. My recent visit, prompted by a group decision, proved to be an underwhelming experience, save for a few notable exceptions. The Bourbon Black and Bleu Burger, a welcome surprise, boasted a satisfying combination of flavors and spices that elicited a pleasurable response from my taste buds. However, the remaining dishes, including the 3 cheese penne and chicken entrÃ©e, did not garner much enthusiasm from either myself or my fellow diners. Notably, my 18-month-old daughter, notorious for her finicky palate, surprised me by consuming half of her grilled cheese sandwich, the bread of which was reminiscent of a sweet, eggy brioche. The service at Applebee's was commendable, as our server was attentive and proactive in addressing our needs. In summary, while the food and service were satisfactory, the establishment's overall ambiance left me uninspired. Given the choice, I would opt for Chili's over Applebee's, but this particular location managed to incrementally enhance my impression of the franchise."

This was my second trip to this location and I noticed their salad bar had fewer items from before.  It was still very good but am disappointed that they seemed to have eliminated some items. I am not a big meat eater and came for the salad bar so I noticed these things. It was still really really good however.

"My culinary experience at Spago was rather divergent, as while I relished my repast, my fellow diners appeared to be more thoroughly enthralled. The wedge salad, though unremarkable in its composition, was nevertheless palatable; conversely, the heirloom tomato and burrata salad special was truly exceptional, constituting the most delectable dish of the evening. We opted to share three pizzas among us, which, regrettably, failed to elicit the same level of enthusiasm due to their relatively lackluster crusts. Specifically: 

The Margherita pizza, with its somewhat undercooked crust and uninspired toppings, could be described as merely adequate; the Proscuitto pizza, featuring a harmonious combination of prosciutto and fromage blanc, showed promise, but was hindered by the aforementioned subpar crust; lastly, the Lamb Chorizo pizza, despite its commendable quality, did not quite ascend to the level of true excellence owing to its incongruous topping arrangement. 

Notwithstanding these criticisms, the service we received throughout our meal was indeed impressive."

Great place for the price. Not the most luxurious place on the strip but the amenities are decent, the service is good, and the location is fantastic. Very good value overall.

This is the 4th or 5th time we've stayed here. The rooms are clean and comfortable, and there is a decent selection of food downstairs ranging from McDonald's to 5 star French, and everything in between. The casino floor is a bit small and smoky, but perfect for when you're not in the mood to get dressed up and go out. The spa is small and reasonably priced. And it's only a few minutes' walk to other casinos, restaurants, and shopping at the many malls nearby.

The only things we didn't care much for were the showers (high pressure mist that's definitely not my idea of pleasant) and on our most recent trip the TV didn't work properly (but we didn't call to have it fixed because it just wasn't that important to us).

Yes, you can stay at a nicer, trendier, and/or more luxurious place on the strip but you'll pay about twice as much. We prefer to stay here, where we're always satisfied, and use the cash we saved to eat, play, and party while we're in town.

Kind of tucked away and hard to notice, especially being next to the really glammed out Ella's Deli. But worth a visit if you're looking for a good gyro or kebab. :]

The donuts are alright too. They have a wide variety! Myself, I really rather like their cookies. They also offer homemade baklava.

Really though I can reccomend their sandwiches with a side of the seasoned fries. Quite yummy! Vegetarian options also available such as potato kahbi or falafel sandwiches. And they had a lot of beverages to choose from too.

Although the location is not ideal, it's worth a stop if you're in that part of town. :]

When this establishment first inaugurated its operations, it boasted an exceptional quality, thereby warranting a perfect five-star rating. However, over time, its standards have subsided, rendering it merely satisfactory. Despite this decline, my father continues to patronize this venue, and thus, we visited it together. Our meal commenced with the grilled artichoke, customarily a delectable option. Unfortunately, this particular instance proved disappointing, as the artichoke exhibited a pronounced rigidity and lacked discernible flavor, perhaps due to the off-season availability of this ingredient. Nonetheless, the accompanying aioli sauce compensated for the artichoke's deficiencies, offering a savory delight. The prime rib, though tender and possessing a satisfactory flavor profile, failed to impress, as its portion size has diminished progressively during my visits. This consistent reduction in magnitude was coupled with a uniform selection of sides, specifically a baked potato. Ultimately, our dining experience concluded without the customary sweet treat. Despite these shortcomings, the prospect of future visits remains viable, primarily owing to my father's persistent fondness for this eatery.

Barneys is a multi layered bar that is more low key than many of the other bars in the area. If you are looking to just have fun and not overdress, pay a cover etc then this might be the place for you.

I found the second level my favorite. The bartender was friendly and was prompt with the refills. I could see the roof level being a cool place when it's a bit warmer, but the drawback would be the smoking for me.

You've got to like how the beer is poured from the bottom up! When you have a bit too much to drink, what else could be more fun than trying to catch the lobster  (think the claw game to get stuffed animals).

3.5 start

My better half indulged in a personal visit to the destination in question, opting to partake in an excursion alongside several acquaintances during a recent weekday afternoon, specifically on a Monday. Her account of the adventure conveyed a sense of underwhelming, as the actuality of the experience did not align with her preconceived notions, boasting fewer fauna than anticipated. Furthermore, the entrance fee of ten dollars for local patrons appeared somewhat exorbitant upon reflection, given the limited scope of the park's attractions. Additionally, the sweltering heat, surpassing one hundred degrees Fahrenheit, coupled with the absence of potable water, raised concerns regarding the well-being of visitors, as every water fountain my spouse encountered displayed signs indicating they were out of commission. Such circumstances pose a significant threat to tourists, emphasizing the necessity for uninterrupted access to hydration.

"As an individual enrolled at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, this eatery presents an extraordinary value, offering five tacos, two sides, and a beverage for a mere $5; the tacos, though diminutive in stature, are abundant in terms of protein, thereby obviating any concern of being shortchanged; it is an ideal venue for socializing with companions, indulging in a pail of fermented beverages, and engaging in lively conversation; the protocol involves ordering at the counter, with the staff summoning one's attention via a vocal announcement when the culinary items are prepared; reportedly, the establishment occasionally features live musical performances or a disc jockey, typically showcasing a Latin-inspired theme, which, while unsurprising given the restaurant's heritage, may strike some patrons as unexpected."

I am very torn about First Friday. I absolutely love community events. Especially art walks, and more creative culture, but this is very lacking. I want to love it because it's in my back yard, too! 

However, First Friday leaves me with a sense of empty feeling. Located in the arts district downtown should be plenty of reason why this event should boast art, but it doesn't. 

The art galleries are lacking, and the street vendors that sell art are more there to just get a buck than they are about art. 

Then there's the riff raff of downtown trying to join in, and so many kids everywhere! I guess police try to crack down on curfew, but there's always so many grungy kids that are up to no good running around. 

The food stalls are nice during summer hours, winter many vendors decide to stay home. 

I'll probably end up going back in the summer, but I'll go early before it gets dark, and the crazy kids (literally kids) come out at night.

I had a profound affection for the ambiance and the personnel who were responsible for creating it, as they exhibited an exceptional level of competence in their respective roles. However, the culinary offerings did not quite live up to my expectations, despite being satisfactory in terms of taste and presentation.
