Furthermore, the tariff charged for the meal did not seem to align with the value proposition offered by the restaurant, leading me to question the overall value for money.

Came to TMI for dinner the other night.  It was good, but nothing that special.  We started with the TMI toast which was probably my favorite part of the meal.  Yes, the bread was a bit hard, but still delicious.  I had the Mac & Cheese and was less than impressed.  It was very oily and lacked flavor.  I've never really met a Mac & Cheese that I didn't get along with...until TMI.  The other people in my party had sandwiches and salads and they seemed to like their dishes.  \n\nOverall, nice atmosphere but REALLY hot inside, a little too loud to have a decent conversation and the food was just okay.  Probably won't be back here in the near future.

I was surprised to find that had a TON of brand new irrigation supplies. As a gardener, I am always fiddling with the irrigation, and am in constant need of emitters, hose, and connectors to support my filthy habit. They have it all (at least when I went), and at a fraction of what the hardware store charges.

"It serves as an enjoyable venue for social gatherings, facilitating the relational dynamics of communal dining. My culinary inclinations lean towards familial-style sharing, which this establishment accommodates seamlessly. However, our ordered dishes displayed inconsistent quality, with a notable eggplant and goat cheese entrÃ©e featuring an excessive proportion of cheese that overpowered the subtle flavor of the eggplant. In contrast, a dish comprising eggs, potatoes, and another component (the specificity of which escapes my memory) presented an unbalanced ratio of potato to other ingredients, prompting a sense of disappointment. Nonetheless, both the filet mignon and Thai beef salad showcased remarkable taste, rendering my overall experience gratifying. Despite some reservations, I am content with having visited this restaurant, yet I harbor doubts about returning in the future."

We had not visited this establishment since its previous incarnation as Cafe Del Sol, and our recent visit was facilitated by a Groupon we had procured approximately one month prior. Upon arriving at the venue, we were struck by the somewhat unconventional layout, which featured a primary dining area and a smaller, segregated section designated for'red-headed step children' and located around the corner from the main area. This configuration seemed to create an atmosphere that was somewhat lacking in vitality. Arriving during the latter portion of happy hour, my spouse opted for a glass of Sangria, while I selected a glass of Tempranillo, which unfortunately did not meet my expectations. Subsequently, I ordered an additional glass of wine, the name of which escapes me, and found it to be relatively satisfying. My culinary selections included the cola and pineapple braised short ribs, jalapeno cream corn, and a chile corn casserole. While the sides were generally well-prepared, the corn casserole was slightly overcooked. The short ribs, on the other hand, were quite flavorful and did not possess the dubious taste often associated with lesser quality braised short ribs. Although the sauce accompanying the ribs was slightly too viscous for my liking, it did not detract substantially from the overall enjoyment of the dish. My spouse's grilled shrimp appetizer, served with avocado and mango sauce, was greatly enjoyed, as were the empanadas. However, my personal preference did not extend to the empanadas. Nonetheless, the shrimp dish was fairly impressive. Considering the totality of our experience, we would classify this eatery as a respectable local option, and while we might not elect to return, we recognize that our spouse may potentially persuade us to do so at some future date.

Cool dive bar and a nice break from the normal las vegas scene.  Went in a friday night after getting free beer coupons handed to us on fremont street.\n\nWas pretty empty for weekend night.  Bartenders are as advertised.  Extremely loud with the megaphones bordering on obnoxious.  Fun though.  Be aware though bartenders will bait you into buying shots including for them and then your bill skyrockets.  Didnt think that was cool.

I have stayed at the Hotel Monte Carlo Las Vegas numerous times, and I'm ready to move on to other hotels.  Its outdated, the food at the main cafe and buffet are so-so, however the rates were pretty fantastic.  Compared to the other hotels, especially the newest arrivals, it shows its age.  

However, I do like it that the concierge will put hotel guests on the VIP list to get into Haze, and other nightclubs in the vicinity.  That was a cool feature we appreciate, and at no cost to the concierge for to get in.  

If its deals you are looking for, and "decent" rooms, it is worth looking into.

I've only frequented the one in Henderson on Sunset and the one on South Rainbow, both have been great for breakfast, the steak and eggs especially.  The happy hour at the South Rainbow location, with $2 drafts and 1/2 price appetizers. fantastic.  For that, these two places get an "A".

But as someone noted, their reward card is now pretty much of a joke.  They changed the earning levels so dramatically, it would take me years to get a $10 credit...so on that, and for doing so without any advance notice or taking into consideration past credits earned, they get an "F".

So they have 3 stars, the average between an "A" and a "F".

It was ok.... the ordering system was a little confusing, but I am a smart girl and I figured it out. I was looking for a good burger and I found one just the way I wanted it, and the onion rings were good. Its just missing a little personality....?

This was a typical resort restaurant the food was fairly ambitious and the food was pricey. I had the chicken because almost any other entree was really pricey, and almost solidly steak. Never the less the food was pretty good and the service was great. Unfortunately the table next to us lit up and then it was pretty smokey, but we were already done, and we chose to sit outside so that I don't blame them for at all. In the end it was a little too pricey for what your gonna get, some good food but also it was the resort and I wouldn't expect anything different. I probably won't be back, our server was really nice though that's the only reason I feel bad about giving this place 3 stars. Other than that it was all around ok.

It's amazing what a few blocks can do, in this case... not much if you're heading further East. I love me some Lao Laan... never really had Lao prior to moving to Madison. But I just don't get the same attentive service, sweet menu recommendations and authentic experience I so often found on Willy. What gives? The menu is more compact but the dining room is bigger, so it's perfect if you need room to groove, but other than the size, I think Willy is probably you're best bet if you're looking for curry east of the capitol.
Good Burger but on the pricy side for what you get. I work nearby and was hoping for a lunch deal but they aren't open for lunch. Pleasant staff and service was good but no lunch no return trips.

Nice but the menu it is stil the same  for the past 6 years...we are in Montreal 

Anyways, the best dish for me is the radish oyster  cannot get enough of the stuff. 12CAD$ for 4 oysters is well worth it

the rest to my taste was quite ordinary, not worth the money

I entered the establishment with the intention of acquiring a novel laptop charger and upgrading my operating system to Lion OSX, yet my experience was tainted by an array of inconveniences and illogicalities. Firstly, although obtaining the charger was a straightforward process, I was confronted with the revelation that, due to my current operating system being Leopard rather than Snow Leopard, I would need to purchase two upgrades to attain Lion. This was not only unexpected but also perplexing, as one would assume that a linear progression within the realm of operating systems would be readily available. However, much to my dismay, the retailer did not possess the Leopard to Snow Leopard upgrade disc in stock, leaving me with limited and impractical options. I could either embark on a quest to locate a Best Buy that might potentially possess the coveted upgrade disc in their inventory, or opt to procure it through online means, thereby subjecting myself to an excruciating waiting period. It is utterly confounding that the Apple store, a purveyor of cutting-edge technology, would fail to maintain a supply of such an essential component. Notwithstanding this absurdity, the physical location of the store was acceptable, the atmosphere was clean and well-maintained, and the employee who facilitated my transaction was adequately courteous.

"Culinary experiences that are reasonably priced and of sufficient quality. Enter with the expectation of a restaurant providing typical diner fare and you shall be gratified. The hospitality is adequate, the cuisine is passable, and the cost (particularly considering its proximity to the Las Vegas Strip) is quite favorable."

"Satisfactory... I had the 'Sin City' burger, and I must say, it was quite palatable. My spouse had a classic, but I didn't particularly care for it, although I'm uncertain of the specific ingredients she had added to it. Nonetheless, she seemed to enjoy it, which, in the end, is what truly matters. The sweet potato fries were not particularly impressive, primarily due to their seasoning, which did not align with my personal preferences. However, the regular fries were adequate. In conclusion, while not exceptional, the dining experience was generally satisfying, surpassing the quality of the typical fast food burger by a noticeable margin."
Pretty good for kids, average to below average for adults.  Friendly staff, good price.  Not the best tasting, but you can tolerate a slice or 2.  Limited dessert and salad options.

If you're looking for a sweet, maybe one with some chocolate or even a big sundae - this is your place. Nice old-fashioned ice cream shop located in old town. This place still has the retro pink vibe and decoration going on inside. \n\nMy friend and I came here when we were looking to splurge with the buster brownie sundae. BOY is It sweet but worth it! Sugar Bowl also serves food, which I was unaware of but probably wouldn't order. Service is friendly.

I've had dinner here a few times including delivery, and the hype really died down.  There are so many 5 star reviews that yelpers may start thinking it's flawless, when really it's just a fresh wing with awesome sauce (lol, awesome sauce). I really enjoy the Golden BBQ & order that each time. We've also had the Citrus Chipotle, Jamaican Jerk & Sweet Chili. All had their own unique flavors.

The boneless wings still are delish & large (chicken tender size). The delivery is fast and efficient.

Service is deff hit or miss. I've had really great service somethings, but not-so-good counter service a number of times (i eat here reallllly often, so not sure of the ratio lol) 

My waffle fries that I upgraded to were completely well done. Not a taste of potato.. more like potato chips. I love waffle fries too :/

So again, great wings & and great mix of sauces, but don't let all of these fabb reviews fool you.

So, I have this weird affliction that makes me feel really uncomfortable when someone puts a HUGE plate of food in front of me. I wanted the chile rellenos, but not the supersized plate! Alas, such is the state of dining in most restaurants these days, but seriously, if I would have known the portions were this big I would have shared my dinner with my friend.\n\nStill, for Vegas we got a table on a Friday night with no wait and no reservation, the service was very attentive, and the bill was reasonable. My mojito was quite tasty also. So go, share, and enjoy!

A Charlotte staple in need of a makeover. Generally solid food but sometimes inconsistent - biggest challenge is the atmosphere which is stale and hasn't kept up with the rest of the Charlotte restaurant scene. You can't go wrong by a visit to PC - especially if the weather is nice and you get to sit on the excellent patio. Salads are great here.

Stopped by here to get a drink before eating out. The place was loud, very loud. Loud from people shouting at the big screens (not sure, something with men on ice skates!), loud from birthday parties all over the place, and loud from the loud music playing. 
It's mainly a gin bar, so don't expect anything exciting about their beer menu, but their gin and gin cocktails menu is attractive. We tried the one with the Quebec gin (Ungava) and maple syrup and even though I'm not much into gin, I really liked it (but then put maple syrup into anything and I will love it!)
It's a bit on the expensive side - 20$ for a beer and a cocktail (I will never, and I mean never, get around to having to add taxes and tips everywhere here!) - but the service was great. The waitress was obviously running between those big parties tables flagging here at every chance but still managed to take care of us in due time.
Glad I went as we've been meaning to try it since the day we moved in the area though :-)

This is easy to confuse with Central Library, but this is hwere they keep the special books - all the special books.  Central Library is just a normal library.

To come read these books you will have to apply at the registration desk for a pass (with ID) that will last for either a few days or about 3 months.

If there is a secific old book here you want to see then you should definitely come here to see it, but if not then this is a lot of fuss over reading a book and you'll be better going elsewhere.

Good sports bar/restaurant--if that's your thing.

Went here when visiting with my dad who suggested it as "one of those new fun places."

The stuffed portabella mushroom appetizer was delicious, though ridiculously decadent.  The carnitas libre pizza was also pretty good, but also extremely rich--i.e. you can taste your arteries clogging.  The pollotate pizza was bland and dry--potatos on pizza is fun in theory, but I'm not convinced.  However, the cook forgot the onions on it, which actually might make a substantial, positive difference.  We okayed the oversight (they've only been open for two months) and they comped our bill a bit, so that was nice.  The service was pretty great, actually.

There's a ton of TVs here and a well-stocked bar with loads of beers on tap.  So if that's your thing, it's probably one of the better sports bar/restaurants out there.  For me, if I'm going to waste the kinds of calories that are packed into these dishes, it had better be for something extra special, which this place just isn't.

Popped in for lunch after a little AM yoga sesh today.  Had been by after my initial trip to Union on opening day - they weren't open when I was there then.  Weirdly, at 11:45 today half the stores in Union were open, half weren't.  Anyway, TDP is super cute.  Love the tables, love the outdoor seating and the small bar.  The staff was super friendly and helpful with our orders.  I could really taste the olive oil on my sandwich and the bread was nice. 

Overall, the food was good, but not great and definitely overpriced. $9 for a Caprese sandwich is ridiculous - and the tomato on this one wasn't ripe.    The meatball sandwich needed more sauce.  The chicken salad sandwich looked great, but again, for such small sandwiches I would expect fruit or salad or something.

I think next time I'll just enjoy the free smells, and buy a bottle of delicious olive oil from their store across the way.

"Although my dining experience at Jersey Mike's did not induce feelings of debilitating infatuation, the restaurant's ambiance was undoubtedly tidy, streamlined, and hospitable. The menu's layout presented a minor challenge for a novice such as myself, prompting a sense of hastened urgency upon ordering; however, the bustling atmosphere during peak lunch hours underscored the establishment's popularity. The diminutive sub sandwich, dubbed'mini,' could easily suffice as a standard portion size, while the larger option proved sufficient for a trio of patrons. The abundance of meat in the club sandwich catered to my carnivorous inclinations, while the subtle distinction between the white and wheat sub rolls remained somewhat enigmatic. Nonetheless, the quality of the bread did not detract from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Of greater curiosity was the assortment of beverage cups, each emblazoned with narratives pertaining to diverse Jersey Mike's locations that have engaged in philanthropic endeavors for worthy causes. While the veracity of these claims warrants further investigation, the notion of supporting an altruistic enterprise undoubtedly resonates with consumers. Though mere branding may be at play, I am intrigued by the possibility of genuine charitable involvement. Sufficiently satisfied with my initial visit, I anticipate returning to sample a spicier variety of sandwich in the future."

Los 7 Compadres has a variety (20) of combination platters for about 7 bucks.  Between my wife and I we had 7 items on our combination platters, which we shared.  7 has been a recurring number for us starting with the OYE at Malee's.  Including the rice and beans, the sour cream and the guacamole this gave us an astounding number of possible combinations for each bite.  

A bite of chicken enchilada.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice.
A bite of chicken enchilada with beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice, beans and guacamole.

Play this out again with the burrito, cheese enchilada, tamale, beef enchilada, bean enchilada, etcetera.  All of the food was good.  Portions were generally large.  I found the tamales to be the least satisfying item.  They were a bit dry and the dominant flavor was just the spice of jalapeno.

Note-even the mild here has a real bite.  Overall I'd give them 3.5 stars.  Good enough for a return trip.

Well, this place is puzzling and I'm not going to save the bad news for last.  They seem to pride themselves on allowing and maybe even promoting smoking.  It's puzzling because the beer selection is extensive.  The menu is above average, as is the food.  Lots of pizzas, sandwiches, appetizers.\n   BUT, who wants to go home smelling like a filthy ashtray?  It would be great if they joined the rest us in the twenty-first century.

Well...I'm super excited that there is finally, finally some V-food in downtown Phoenix.  The more ethnic cuisine around the better.  It is in a convenient location on 1st and Adams.  The kitchen area is open to the public (a first I think I've ever seen).  I ordered take out and everything I needed was in there.  The plus, fast service.  The minus, I felt like things were not quite as tasty as some of my other standbyes.  The prices also reflect the snazzy downtown locale, a dinner for two came out to be closer to 30 bucks (which is still a bargain) but I'm used to about 15-20 at the divier joints.  I'm still going to support them when I'm in a pinch for takeout or lunch downtown, but if I'm craving the authentic and frenetic pace of a Vietnamese eatery I'll have to head out to the avenue's for some of the more established dives.\nDidn't have the bahn mi (they were out).  Had a standard buhn dice which was nice but i'm used to the nom plah a little sweeter with more garlic.  The egg rolls are good, (not filled with just veggies).  The spring rolls are missing my favorite, shrimp!  The omlette dish is an acquired taste, and I'll leave it at that :)

Chinatown in Montreal is small (1 - no matter where in the world we go, my mom ALWAYS has to have rice at least once a day 2- they have the fruits my family travels to Canada for) and this is a reliable resource for good, cheap roast pork/duck over rice. Their beef pan fried noodles are not great (as in, not something I would order again). Their wonton noodle soup is pretty good: I got it both times we came here. General Tso'c chicken was pretty good: again, something my family ordered both times we came.\n\nOverall, nothing crazy and nothing that's a must see in Montreal. The service is OK (if you get a waiter that speaks English well, then the service is good, if not, the inability to effectively communicate causes some frustration. The food comes out fast, so if you're starving, this is a good place to go. Their bubble tea is alright: stops a craving, but it's not great. They do get brownie points for giving baby bochoy with everything and for the HUGE food portions.

Dropping down to three stars ... On a recent visit, I saw TWO roaches on the main floor of the restaurant. No one seemed to care, so I got up and stepped on one.  I pointed out the other, and one of the staff killed it, but they didn't seem surprised.  I know that roaches are hard to control, but having two of them wandering about in a busy restaurant just isn't a good thing. 

Also, our waiter was an overly chatty guy who seems to think we are interested in his voice.  They had some good staff in the past, but I suspect the owner, who likes to get drunk and hang out on the patio, gives me the impression of a guy who would be difficult to work for! 

The food is still decent and better than anything else I've found, but I'm looking for alternatives ...

"Although the cost of $29.99, augmented by tax to $32.42, proved to be an excessive expenditure for this culinary indulgence, the abundance of offerings, while of commendable quality, did not justify the tariff in comparison to the more luxurious hospitality establishments. My visit transpired at 10:15am on a Saturday, and I availed myself of the complimentary mimosas, consuming two glasses, which were indeed delectable. The array of breakfast and lunch items was substantial, albeit not extensive, and I partook of a moderate quantity of each. Notably, the inclusion of lunch options denoted the presence of brunch. All items were proficiently prepared, yet none truly excelled; however, the overall quality was satisfactory. The buffet, though not of considerable proportions, remained sufficient. Under specific circumstances, such as 1) intoxication, 2) craving AYCE, 3) absence of vehicular transportation, 4) coercion, or 5) inebriation, I might consider a return visit, contingent upon a reduction in price, as the current tariff seemed somewhat exorbitant."

I like Mexican food and I like Chinese food, so why not? Interesting menu. The Jade Red Chicken is as good as any Orange or General Tso's you'll find, and I like that there is a wide variety of choices here. Good food, especially if you like spicy!

I have one beef with this restaurant, and that is the cleanliness. Walking in, you'll notice that the decor and general feel of the place is very low budget. Uncomfortable seating, very weathered ceilings, and generally messy. No big deal. But the restrooms were disgusting, the eating area was dirty, and the trash was overflowing. The place was busy, but there's no excuse for the condition of the men's restroom! It looked like something (or someone) exploded in a truck stop restroom on a state highway. I would have chalked it up to a busy night, but the door and walls were filthy (almost black) with handprints from weeks (if not months) of neglect. All but one of the trash bins were over-stuffed, and most of the tables were dirty. We didn't see anyone cleaning anything. I'm glad I didn't go into the restroom until after I ate!

If it were my business, I would put at least a few dollars toward general maintenance and upkeep. Maybe even invest in a few nicer tables & chairs. If it were close to clean, I'd give at least 4 stars.

Just quickly ran in and grabbed some stuff for dinner. Never been inside of this store until today. It's okay. I don't think the fruits and vegetables are the best but they'll do in a time crunch (because the store is located near the house) but I would prefer Safeway for fruits, vegetables and possibly meats. Prices are average - specials on some things but nothing out there that makes this store stand out.

My first visit was decent, but didn't quite live up to my expectations.

I food just wasn't that good for a steakhouse. Neither my wife and I cared for our appetizer. We got the Fire-Grilled Fresh Artichoke. They say it is a popular choice, but I didn't like it at all. My burger was very plain and lacked good taste. It made me wish I had gone to Five Guys instead. My wife got the steak and thought it was OK, but later she ended up getting sick. She ordered off the gluten-free menu as she has sensitivities, so this place may have issues with cross-contamination.

One positive was our friendly server. Cassie was excellent and we were very pleased because we rarely get good service when we go out. She kept up with refills and offered to replace anything we didn't like. I also wrote about my visit and explained how I didn't like the food. The manager said he would send us a coupon, so I can appreciate that they are reaching out to their customers.

I got good vibes from sitting at the restaurant. I like their tables and seats. I think I will give it a second chance, but the food has to be better if they want to win me over as a customer.

We were the only ones in there on a sunday afternoon which I thought was weird after my friend raved about this place. Our food came out so fast that they would not even have had time to microwave it and put it on a plate so I know everything was pre-made. Food tasted alright just tons of bones in the chicken and the fried pork was so hard I almost chipped my tooth. Is this how you cubans prefer it? 

Parking lot is around back. Absolutely ensure that you lock your car and DO NOT walk alone in this immediate area. 

I would go back but I would try to order something on the menu that they hopefully will make fresh. I gave them three stars for being very friendly, being bilingual, and for not giving me food poisoning.

"Is this venue currently closed, or merely undergoing revitalization efforts? I have visited this establishment on multiple occasions for lunch, and my culinary experiences have led me to the conclusion that the barbacoa torta is, without a doubt, the most exceptional item on the menu. While I have sampled other offerings, such as the breakfast burrito, I must admit that the balance of potato to chorizo was somewhat lacking, particularly given the cost and dimensions of the dish."

"Culinary offerings at this establishment were inventive and flavorsome, with appetizer portions being reasonable in terms of both price and quality. However, main courses fell short in terms of portion size, with prices ranging from $6-10 higher than expected. Notwithstanding, the bread provided was dry, albeit suitable as a light accompaniment to the meal. The wine selection boasted an impressive variety, catering to diverse tastes. While not exceptional compared to eateries in prominent food cities like Portland, this restaurant serves as a valuable addition to the local dining scene in Chandler and Sun Lakes. Although not particularly busy on a Friday evening, it remains uncertain whether patrons perceive the dinner options as overpriced, warranting further assessment for long-term success. Despite its unconventional strip mall location, the ambiance remained pleasant."

Some of the best cocktails in town. Only downside is some bartenders make them better than others. Love the mojitos! Reasonable prices. Nice decor. Nice crowd. Nice music. I went for brunch and had a lobster omelette.. I found it had a bit too many different flavors for my taste, but I'm sure others would love it, as I'm kind of picky. The guava mimosa wasn't too good though.

I'm upgrading to 3 stars because the service is awesome.  Of course, there was about a 1:1 ratio server to guests so....

This place is not doing very well so I do feel bad, however, there are some obvious reasons.  The prices are very high and the portions are not very big.  So for the amount of food you get, the items are very overpriced.  Burgers, skewers, sandwiches and salads are all around 10, pizzas between 10-15.  Everything is a la carte and you get about 3 appetizer size skewers for the entrees.  Appetizers are about 10 as well, and desserts are 7 even with the option to add ice cream for 1.  

I will say the burgers are better than the Grind - they actually stay together!  (the bun falls apart easily at the Grind and makes eating hard after a couple bites).  The fries were good ($5).  The pork skewers were passable but nothing special.  The Dorito potato skins were nothing special - just had a wedge of cheesy chip stuck in the middle of it.  The cupcake was good, but the chocolate was a little grainy.  Very small portion for that one..

All in all, I probably won't go back for anything but happy hour - for the burgers.

"It was indeed a culinary revelation nestled within the picturesque confines of Verdun that we had the pleasure of discovering through a personal recommendation, and given our previous exposure to delectable Persian cuisine, a certain level of skepticism was inevitable. Nonetheless, Parisa managed to surpass our expectations with their unique interpretation of traditional Persian flavors.

Their signature house soup, while containing an incongruous element in the form of noodles, proved to be a truly exceptional offering. It was followed by a delightful assortment of sauteed mushrooms, which, despite lacking the anticipated sweetness, still showcased the kitchen's proficiency in executing simple yet elegant dishes.

The main course featured two distinct protein options: tender, juicy lamb that literally fell off the bone, and succulent chicken drumsticks that, while not necessarily memorable, contributed to the overall satisfaction of our dining experience.

The hospitable demeanor of the host and the tranquil ambiance of the establishment further enhanced our enjoyment, making it an ideal venue for a BYOW excursion. In conclusion, a visit to Parisa is highly recommended, particularly for the unmissable soup, a true masterpiece of culinary artistry."

After perusing the menu at this establishment on multiple occasions, I decided to partake in their culinary offerings, primarily due to the copious amount of laudatory reviews I had encountered. Upon consuming my meal, I found the flavors to be quite satisfactory, however, my companion did not share my enthusiasm. It is worth mentioning that this restaurant does not possess an air conditioning system, which resulted in a rather uncomfortable dining experience for me, as I was perspiring profusely throughout my visit.

This place is OK, not too flashy, but OK. Our family of 12 called an hour before for reservations on a busy thursday and managed to get great seating without a wait. The waitress was phenomenal, totally on top of her game and didn't batt an eyelash when she kept being sent too and froo by various sections of the table (we tipped her really well). However, the food was slightly above mediocre. My potatoes were overly cooked, and the sausage tasted wrong. My omlette was also tasting strange and was rubbery. So service was wonderful, but the food was meh.

"An establishment offering an adequate selection of alcoholic beverages and a partially enclosed outdoor area, suitable for relaxation, yet, owing to its proximity to the heavily trafficked East Washington Avenue, susceptible to auditory disturbances. While the assortment of Belgian brews failed to meet expectations, the ambiance and location render it an appropriate addition to the array of similar establishments along Williamson Street, with the added benefit of proximity to an adult entertainment store."

"The ambiance of this establishment is truly captivating. The interior design exudes an aura of elegance and sophistication, with subtle lighting that creates an atmosphere of refined intimacy. The seating arrangements are ergonomically designed to provide maximum comfort, allowing patrons to unwind and relax in style. The musical selection presented by the disc jockey on the evening in question was diverse and engaging, albeit the volume level was slightly excessive for a venue of this nature, thereby creating a slight hindrance to effective communication between patrons seated at a distance from one another. However, the outdoor seating area provided a tranquil respite from the sonic intensity within, offering ample opportunities for observation and appreciation of the surrounding environment."

I often stop in this place when Im at Tempe Marketplace to get a drink and relax.  They usually have some decent drink specials and they have a nice big bar.  The bartenders usually take a little effort to order from, not really sure why that is, maybe I just have bad luck.

Hmmm I am American and I grew up in the NYC area, so I am fairly confident that I know good Italian food when I taste it.  I am not saying that the food isn't good, but it definitely did not blow me away.  We came here because it was listed as a Top 10 Best Restaurant in Edinburgh, according to The Guardian and I definitely would not rate this in my top 10.

However, with that being said, the service was fantastic.  Our servers were all very friendly and attentive.  The portions here are enormous and we did feel that they mislead us into ordering more food than we needed because we did ask if the starters were big enough to shared and they recommended that we order two.  Both plates were huge and we certainly could have just shared one between the two of us.  Not to mention the entrees were enough for 2-3 people to share.  So come hungry!

Ambiance has a little bit of a corny feel but also reminded me a lot of any Italian spot in suburban New York / New Jersey, in the sense that there was Frank Sinatra playing in the background the entire time and the servers were a little over the top trying to prove their Italian-ness (actual, and not the macho mobster Guido kind we see over here in the States).

So, in the last two weeks I have come here for two separate issues.

The first, being that I stupidly fractured my coccyx (tail bone). I was seen after a short wait, and taken care of promptly and thoroughly. Dr. Guy did a good job at taking care of my situation, requested an immediate x-ray and saw me right after I was done to discuss my results, options, and pain relief methods. You never know how valuable a body part is until it's battered, leaving you completely dysfunctional and in mind-blowing pain.

The second, I was having severe bursts of pain in my abdomen. I went to the clinic first because it happens to be right around the corner from where I live, and I needed to be seen immediately. I was shaking, crying, pale and obviously in extreme distress. Although I understand this is simply a clinic, the fact that I was turned away due to over capacity came as a shock. Considering the severity of my ailment, I would have appreciated it more if a doctor had seen me, even if temporarily, just to help relieve the pain I was in as I awaited my transportation to the emergency. 

I will still come here in the future when push comes to shove, but my last experience wasn't so great and has shown me that they are not willing to bend the rules in extreme cases that involve a person's wellbeing and health.

I harbor neither acrimony nor ardor towards it. My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid and noncommittal. Initially, my curiosity was piqued by the visually captivating images showcased on Instagram, which inspired me to visit this venue. My expectations were predicated on the assumption that the snow-based offerings would resemble those available at Hawaiian snow-themed eateries, such as Snow Factory or Frost City. Alas, my experience did not quite live up to my expectations.  

In collaboration with my associates, we sampled three distinct flavors - #3, #4, and #5, respectively. However, I was not particularly enamored with the "popping pearls" incorporated into my #5 selection, so I opted to substitute it with a butterfinger variant instead. While the texture of the snow was somewhat reminiscent of a creamy consistency, the flavors left much to be desired in terms of depth and complexity. I had the opportunity to taste a few other options, including taro, green tea, and the mysterious "kuma snow," but unfortunately, they failed to elicit any profound enthusiasm on my part. 

It is my sincere hope that this enterprise will strive to expand its range of flavors, emulating the diverse array offered by Snow Ono, a mobile food truck specializing in shave ice. In particular, I yearn for the return of the beloved horchata flavor. Notwithstanding my underwhelming experience, I must acknowledge that the interior design of this establishment exudes an endearing quality, replete with vibrant colors and playful accents that evoke an unmistakable air of cuteness. This aesthetic, coupled with the potential for Instagram-worthy moments, served as a significant draw for me. 

In conclusion, while my initial visit did not quite meet my expectations, I remain optimistic about the future prospects of this business. With time, I trust that they will continue to refine and enhance their offerings, thereby warranting my return. Moreover, I am eager to introduce additional acquaintances to this venue, thereby facilitating a more comprehensive assessment of their menu items.

I have heard of this place, but never made it over until now.  I was there to support a fundraiser for an elementary school.  What can I say, it looks just like the skating rinks I grew up with in the 80's.  Not sure what kind of improvements have been since.  The evening we were in there the A/C must not have been working because it was hot as heck and smelled like a gym locker room.  But the concession stand prices can't be beat, the music was current and fun, and ALL the skaters, of every age group, looked like they were having a blast!  And you can even bring in your OWN roller blades if you prefer the single row of wheels versus the four wheels.  They even knock a $1 or so off your price.  So as long as you are looking for an old school joint, and not a modern updated place, check it out!

Good place. The restaurant was clean and pleasant. The food was good too. My wife and I had the clear eggrolls with peanut sauce. We eat these whenever we have Vietnamese food. Fairly straight forward. Not bad.
We also ate the combo pho soup. Very generous portions! Good job. The soup itself is reminiscent of fish sauce/mint/and some other requirement. It seems obviously made for American taste buds. It wasn't very spicy. You can do that yourself I suppose. But still for the inducted, you also require a more robust base to start with. If you want a more authentic soup, it is not here. 

They had a small menu. Sometimes that is a good thing, as it helps from choice overload. However, there were some other Vietnamese dishes, I would have liked to see.

The service was friendly and quick. Overall they did just fine. We may return in time to see how they grow.

We held a co-worker's going away party here and I have to say that for a group of 16 people and one child-they did really well at serving us. The guac was good and I really liked their \"hot\" salsa that you have to ask for. The sangria is overly sweet but the house margarita on the rocks was better. The meals were so-so. I had some tired chicken enchilada's, but they werent horrendous, just pretty boring. My favorite thing about the whole night was hitting up the Trader Joe's in the same complex after dinner!

"The panoramic vista is utterly breathtaking, encompassing a full 360 degrees of unobstructed visual splendor. The atmosphere is decidedly relaxed, with a DJ spinning an eclectic mix of predominantly top 40 and EDM tracks through the sound system on Fridays. However, the late happy hour is restricted to culinary offerings, which serves as a significant factor in the deduction of several stars from the establishment's overall rating. Specifically, the buns accompanying the sliders were excessively firm, possessing sufficient force to shatter glass upon impact, while the calamari exhibited a regrettable lack of texture, likely due to being reheated via microwave for the duration of the happy hour period. Furthermore, the waitstaff displayed a languid approach to customer service, taking an inordinate amount of time to attend to our needs. In fact, it would have been faster to descend to ground level, purchase beverages at a nearby retailer, and then ascend once more to the 107th floor than to await the tardy arrival of our order. Despite these shortcomings, the venue possesses considerable potential, necessitating merely a superficial refurbishment in select areas to elevate its status to the next level."

The people here are super friendly and nice. Yhe reason I gave only three stars is one their liquid flavors was missing somethin.  I think if they remixed a few  flavors it would be a little better. And the second reason is that their liquid is pricey. Like 21 bucks for one bottle.

Heard A LOT of good things about this place but somehow I don't seem what all the good rants about this place where. I came with high expectations due to the fact that friends and colleagues but they have come to disappoint me in Las Vegas. We came around 1 so it was considered to be the brunch time. It was majority breakfast food with some salads, and other lunch options. \nBut what I ca say was good was their chicken wings, saian chow meain and fried rie, the alfredo pasta, and the calamari skewer. Everything else was just plain jane to my eyes and my stomach. All my friends know that i'm a huge dessert fanatic so I went big on the dessert bar, but I only find just a mere of the plates appealing and taste worthy. The chocolate dipped strawberries, cheesecake and the thai ice cream were my favorites out of my whole plate! THE THAI TEA ICE CREAM IS THE ONLY REASON WHY I GAVE THEM AN EXTRA STAR! IT is a must try for all my thai tea lovers out there! \nJust your average buffet for about $30 a person with a okay food, with an exception of a great dessert which was in fact the thai tea ice cream!
= = = = = =  CLOSED  = = = = = =\n\nSorry to see Him's JL close.  I liked the place.     :-(

Nice and clean buffet, lots of seating. Didnt mind paying $13 per person but then was alittle disapointed when i noticed they had a huge selection of pork to choose from. Not a huge pork fan, would rather take my $13 next time and eat at Buffet@asia because they have more selections to choose from, more seafood and mongolian bbq.

During our peregrination through the industrial and commercial district of Phoenix in pursuit of a delectable meal, preferably of Mexican provenance, my spouse and I encountered an assortment of approximately five eateries specializing in Mexican cuisine. Following a deliberate process of selection, we opted for Salsitas, a restaurant chain prevalent in the Valley of the Sun. It is worth noting that, despite the culinary staff's proficiency in the preparation of our repast, I couldn't help but wish that the young woman who attended to us had exhibited a greater proficiency in both the comprehension and articulation of the English language. Although the order was accurately fulfilled and the victuals were copious and reasonably priced, we were not provided with utensils, specifically forks, despite our explicit request. This necessitated my excursion to the hotel lobby, where I solicited the assistance of the desk clerk in procuring a pair of plastic forks.  
The burrito, generously proportioned and gustatorily satisfying, elicited our approbation. My own culinary exploits involved the consumption of two mini-tacos featuring grilled chicken, which, though palatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi and featured a few unpleasant fragments of gristle. My spouse, whose gastronomical inclinations leaned toward a chicken burrito, expressed gratification with her selection, describing it as both ample and delicious. Additionally, the complimentary provision of piquant carrots earned the establishment brownie points with her. In conclusion, our dining experience at Salsitas, while not without its drawbacks, proved generally satisfying, and we departed sated and content, having partaken of four distinct salsas and a dollop of sour cream, all for the reasonable sum of ten dollars.

It is an acceptable venue, albeit one that I would not have chosen to visit had we not been extended an invitation accompanied by a reserved table. The diminutive size of the establishment, while potentially charming, was unfortunately exacerbated by the presence of a substantial number of patrons, creating an atmosphere akin to that of a crowded subway car in China or New York City. Notwithstanding the cramped conditions, I must admit that the personal hygiene of the clientele was satisfactory, in contrast to the malodorous ambiance often associated with public transportation in urban centers. A plethora of ostensibly synthetic, juvenile females were conspicuously present, rendering the environment somewhat unsettling for a solitary, relatively youthful individual such as myself (being merely 27 years of age). 
  The beverages served at this establishment are quite costly; I opted to procure three shots for our group, as I felt no compulsion to emulate the behavior of certain metrosexual individuals who insist on purchasing drinks for others. Furthermore, I am financially capable of treating myself. However, upon perusing the bill, I was taken aback by the exorbitant price of $36 for a mere three shots. In light of this, I felt compelled to remark on the receipt that "I ain't no rich bitch," and I apologize for any offense caused to the bartender. Nonetheless, considering the steep prices, I believe it is essential to either consume alcoholic beverages liberally before arriving or to accompany someone possessing a platinum credit card, lest one wishes to incur financial hardship. Despite the extravagant costs, the experience remains moderately enjoyable.

This is your perfect place to bring someone after going out.
Instead of going to macdonald or some fast food joint this place is cheaper,healthier and quicker than any fast food store.
Plus you can grab something for breakfast the next day.
No matter what time i go i always see people baking fresh bagel.
I'm more of a conservative guy so i usually take sesame bagel or butter bagel.
Hope this help,

Cheers,

Eric Van Nguyen

As Demetria so astutely observed, this establishment tends to be somewhat inconsistent in the quality of its offerings, with a tendency towards both excellence and disappointment. For optimal culinary experiences, it is advisable to arrive promptly, as the most delectable items often disappear rapidly. The fried chicken, when cooked to perfection, is undoubtedly a highlight, although it occasionally suffers from overcooking or dryness. The six-cheese spaghetti is also a commendable option, but its quality can vary depending on the preparation method. The abundance of sides offers numerous choices, including mac-n-cheese, which, much like the aforementioned chicken and spaghetti, may occasionally be overcooked, resulting in a less than satisfactory dining experience. However, the blackeyed peas and cornbread consistently impress, and their lemonade, arguably the finest in Charlotte, has garnered high praise. A word of caution regarding the volunteers who handle beverage refills: they are renowned for their warmth and generosity, and a adept diner may even secure an additional portion of mac-n-cheese through skillful banter. It is essential to display gratitude via a gratuity at the register. Fare thee well, my friend.

"Cautionary statement: This evaluation is predominantly grounded on the parameters of service and informational proficiency, rather than culinary offerings. We visited this establishment during happy hour and, while intending to confer four stars, a deduction of one star was necessitated due to the absence of communication regarding seating arrangements for said happy hour. Specifically, we were not apprised of the fact that happy hour seating was exclusive to the bar and adjacent bench. Furthermore, our ignorance was not alleviated by inquiring about the protocol, as we were informed to occupy any vacant seat of our preference. Notably, by the time of our departure, a sole couple remained, and they too were oblivious to the proper seating arrangement, thereby resulting in their failure to capitalize on the discounted prices.  

Our culinary experience was satisfactory, albeit not exceptional, with a few notable exceptions. The red sangria was unremarkable, while the lamb, though flavorsome, was diminutive and overpriced. The croquettes were uninspired, whereas the Patatas Bravas, essentially roasted potatoes enrobed in a tomato-based sauce, was straightforward yet gratifying. The total cost of our repast, excluding gratuity, approximated $60, with an additional $20 expended unnecessarily due to our unawareness of the happy hour stipulations. A comprehensive examination of the menu revealed that several items we ordered were available at a reduced rate had we been seated at the bar."

This place is beautiful inside. I really enjoyed the process of watching the owners transform this great piece of historic modern architecture into something a lot of people could enjoy. 

The other location is cool too, sans the DB scene. I found this location to have scary parking, but good valet service. 

The service was good on my Friday 3pm visit. Was there to celebrate a friends birthday. We had some of the apps (The Trifecta, Double Down, and Crabmeat and Artichoke Dip) and they were good. The waitress was always coming by to check on us and even told us when happy hour started. 

You could tell it was getting close to 5pm. The place was a mad house with 40 something dudes trolling for a place to sit all sweaty from a golf outing. The place is chill and there seemed to be no pretencious DB's. Sure there is a healthy mix of an older crowd, but there was a good mix of younger groups too. 

Good amount of TVs so there is always something to watch. It was kind of noisy near the enclosed patio, but we were at a table being loud anyways. There is alot of room to move and enjoy the space, and not to be bumped into. I have only visited just once for a Friday happy hour, stay tuned for a dinner visit.

I would give The Green Owl 4-5 stars for their food, but unfortunately their service really knocks them down. I came here with my boyfriend last week. After we were seated, it took us a little while to flag down our waitress so that we could order. We split an order of crabby cakes; my boyfriend ordered a bowl of chili with sour cream and cornbread, and I ordered the "meatball" sub with kale chips as a side. The crabby cakes came out very quickly, and they were covered with a delicious creamy sauce. We instantly devoured them. My boyfriend is a meat-eating tofu hater, and even he enjoyed these. Upon bringing out the crabby cakes, our waitress told us that our entrees should be out "very soon."

Our food didn't arrive for another 40 minutes, and our waitress never stopped by to assure us that it was on its way or to explain what was causing the delay. Oh well. The food, once it did get to our table, was delicious. My sandwich was piping hot, the bread roll was crispy, and the eggplant meatballs held up well in the sandwich (they weren't mushy) and were flavorful.

I would've liked to try a dessert, but $6 for an average sized portion was a little too steep. 

I will probably come back to the Green Owl. Even though the service is lacking, there are so many more items on the menu I'd like to try!

The culinary offerings were merely satisfactory, but the prices were exorbitant, far exceeding what would be considered reasonable or appropriate. We opted for a rapid midday repast, and while the hospitality was adequate, the fare was subpar, failing to meet the elevated standards one might expect from a city renowned for its gastronomic delights. Additionally, we strongly advise against ordering the kimchi, as it was not merely unimpressive, but genuinely disappointing.

"I patronized this establishment due to the overcrowding at Oregano's on a Saturday evening. It begs the question of how many patrons share a similar predicament. My initial yearning for Mexican cuisine rendered me indifferent to the alternative dining option. 

The hospitality was exceptional, the brew was nearly frozen (a desirable attribute), and the salsa was delectable. I opted for the signature chimichanga, while my maternal figure selected rolled tacos. The portions were considerable, bordering on excessive. Moreover, I must emphasize that cream cheese enhances the flavor of chimichangas, rendering them even more scrumptious. YUM. 

While not the most exceptional Mexican restaurant I have had the pleasure of experiencing, the quality of the fare and the welcoming ambiance justify future visits for local patrons."
I went on a hip hop night and not  much hip hop was played. However, it was still a good time there.

This sushi restaurant boasts an impressive array of fresh fish selections, which, coupled with its reasonable pricing, makes it the optimal choice for sushi enthusiasts within the valley. However, it is imperative to note that the service at this establishment tends to be subpar, with prolonged waiting periods being a recurring issue. Patrons should also be prepared for a leisurely dining experience, as the duration between ordering and receiving their food can be quite lengthy. On one occasion, a request for an itemized check resulted in a 25-minute delay, and even then, the check provided was incomplete. Notwithstanding the exceptional quality of their sushi, frequent instances of rudeness and neglect by the waitstaff may make it advisable for regular patrons to seek alternative sushi options. Nevertheless, the restaurant's happy hour prices, available Sunday through Thursday, offer an attractive incentive for those willing to tolerate the aforementioned deficiencies in service.

Decent store with knowledgeable staff but the prices are a bit higher than other stores. One employee recommended a collar that really helped with our dog that was a puller.

Everyone is friendly. There is a huge selection of many things for many pets. The prices are not bad but a touch high.

But Banfield. Don't do it. Avoid them. My aunt had awful experiences with "the plan" for their old dog. She was pressured into expensive treatments, they would sometimes not do ones she wanted, and it wasn't exactly cheap. Our experience was the same. We bought 1 year to try it, and canceling took a few tries. They pressured us to do more than we normally would have. And the "savings" included hundreds of dollars in services that most people would not buy.

Come here to get your pet some exercise in the summer. Get food, litter, check sale prices, visit the partnered pet rescue people, maybe grab a treat or toy for your pet. But Banfield felt even higher pressure than our last car purchase.

-Note* Review is for casino/shops/ pool area only. 

I don't love it nor do I hate it.

Shops: They have a new renovated shops it looks great and clean.  I would probably only enter the Urban Outfitters store. 
Pool: I love the beach pool they have going on. They have the waves and sands in their pool.  I always have a great time here and it is never too packed here which I like. 
Casino: It's pretty self-explanatory. All casinos in las vegas is very similar. I do love they have these chandeliers in the ceilings, it is a very nice touch.  

Overall: The casino is clean and pretty much okay.  I don't mind coming here or passing through the casino.  They offer a lot of great restaurant and they have the house of blues. Families can have a great time here and can even check out the Shark Reef in this hotel.

"An ideal location in Las Vegas to host one's parents, offering delectable cuisine, albeit at a slightly elevated cost. However, considering the city's reputation for extravagance, it would be unwise to compromise on fiscal constraints. The menu presented an intriguing array of options, yet the dishes did not possess an exceptionally unique flavor profile. Rather, they constituted a fundamental American breakfast with subtle variations here and there. The service was efficient, and we were accommodated in a timely manner (although a notable queue began to form around the peak period for brunch)."

"While the interior may benefit from some modernization, the culinary offerings are undeniably satisfactory. However, I find it somewhat problematic to be charged for supplementary hash browns and an English muffin, particularly when the portion size has diminished, resulting in a higher cost for a relatively reduced quantity of sustenance. Notwithstanding, US Egg remains a reliable establishment, albeit one that may not necessarily warrant being showcased to others as a prime dining destination."

The Chilenita they have the best empanada in town. It's a great place to take out or sit down for lunch. The staff is friendly. The food is so good. The price is affordable. There no other place that has 13 different empanada's to choose from. I love the Chilenita.

Food is average with sandwiches being $8-$10.  Had a burger with Pork Barbecue on it and onion straws and an iced tea for about $14.  Little pricey at lunch.  Surprised there was only 1 bartender/waitress for the whole bar area, but she did a good job managing it.  There were probably 20 people at the bar.  The restaurant has a bunch of TV's on sports or trivia.  The restaurant was crowded which is probably due to its location in the USX building.

We visited Red Lobster for lunch at approximately 2:00 PM, and although the establishment was moderately occupied, we were promptly accommodated with a table.  All three of us opted for the Endless Shrimp promotion, which offered an assortment of diverse flavors.  While the dishes were undoubtedly palatable, they failed to elicit any extraordinary praise or excitement.  The service, though not characterized by excessive haste, did not hinder our dining experience.  The staff members exhibited unwavering politeness and cordiality throughout our visit.  At a cost of $57.00 for three lunch specials, the total surpassed my customary expenditure in a locality renowned for its affordable cuisine.  Nonetheless, the charge was not entirely unexpected given the restaurant's reputation for quality seafood.  Ultimately, our dining experience merited a rating of "A-OK," denoting a satisfactory and enjoyable meal.

It could have all 5 stars if the service was better... Food is very good most of the times, but yesterday my pork kebob had way to many bones! They made me wait for my drink and then for my sauce, so if you like your food without soda and ketchup go for this place:))
The locations in phoenix have chicken we can add to our meal. This location does not. We drove an extra 10 minutes to get here  to find out they don't have chicken was not a pleasant surprise.

"Culinary delights are palatable, yet the quality of service is subpar. We have had the misfortune of dining at this establishment on two separate occasions, and both experiences have been marred by errors in our orders. Specifically, our meals were prepared incorrectly, and upon our second visit, we did not receive a suitable apology or any semblance of empathy from the waitstaff. It appears that the team is more reactive than proactive in addressing patrons' concerns. While the food is passable, it does not justify the exorbitant prices charged. Unfortunately, my initial enthusiasm for this restaurant has been significantly diminished due to the aforementioned factors, compelling me to seek alternative dining options."

Food is unique and tasty. Try the ultimate grilled cheese.  Service is poor. Three employees hang around at a table in the bar area chatting while the cook is preparing my food,  lunch came out wonderful but the front of house staff needs to find something to do and pay attention to a the few customers that are in there. I stopped in today at 1 for lunch but they changed their hours they are not open until 3 o'clock weekdays. I feel this place is going to close down quite soon. Prices for pool during promo hours are great.

"The conjugal partner of my closest acquaintance arrived for a sojourn from Austin, possessing an academic background in architectural design, which rendered this location an obligatory destination for our excursion. The experience of being present at this site was undoubtedly remarkable... However, I must express my indignation regarding the exorbitant cost associated with participating in a guided tour, which fell within the price range of $30 to $80, a truly preposterous expense. Consequently, we opted to circumvent the tour and instead explored the peripheral areas of the estate, including the gift shop, which we found satisfying, yet tinged with regret due to our inability to partake in the comprehensive tour."

This is one of our favorite stops for a quick bite, particularly if we have Aria resort credit that we need to spend. I used to only get the baked goods and some chocolates to go for friends and family back home (I like the bear claw in particular), but I recently tried the crepes which I really like. We had a savory one with ham, cheese, and sauteed mushrooms that was great. It also came with a side of greens and baby tomatoes. Our favorite dessert crepe is the one that has the vanilla custard cream on the inside with the mixed berry sauce drizzled on top. The lines are always busy whenever I go but they do a good job moving the customers through quickly. It's definitely pricey though!

Can't understand why this place is always so packed. Well actually, the sound system is probably the best out of any club on mill. So that part I liked. There is room to breathe once you make it to the pool tables, but it's a battle to get there in the first place. There is a good amount of tables. Overall, so so. But I'll visit another time for further review.
Very colorful, especially if you want to smoke weed surrounded by a bunch of weirdos playing African drums...other than that it is rather boring

After perusing an array of favorable critiques, my spouse and I elected to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, primarily due to her inclination towards consumng Indian cuisine.  This eatery does not boast an extensive capacity, and its format is predicated upon a buffet-style service.  The Mother's Day special included a delectable mango lassi and a dolsa, which consists of a rolled-up pancake containing a lentil filling. 
  The chilled bar presented an assortment of various chutneys, a salad, some fruit, and additional sauces.  Additionally, there were three distinct types of soup available: a tomato soup with a tangy flavor profile, a lentil-based soup, and a piquant soup. 
  This restaurant showcases a diverse array of traditional Indian dishes.  The goat curry particularly stood out to my taste buds, as the meat was tender and easily detached from the bone, complemented by a richly flavored curry sauce.  Furthermore, the tandoori chicken was cooked to perfection, retaining its natural moisture and avoiding the common pitfall of dryness often associated with this dish at other establishments.  The paneer sag (a spinach and cheese dish) also demonstrated notable quality. 
  Although vegetarian options were present, my carnivorous inclinations led me to ignore them.  Ultimately, this dining experience provided me with a satisfying introduction to Indian cuisine without overwhelming my palate with excessively spicy fare, thereby solidifying this restaurant's standing as a respectable venue in my opinion.

A lot of these reviews made me laugh because I'm not quite sure what people were expecting - it's FAST FOOD, (albeit pricy fast food)lol! I had a Groupon so my friends and I went all out so that we could get a variety of things.  I thought the staff here was really friendly, even bringing food to our table.  The shakes are amazing and I love all the topping options!  The veggie burger is tasty and my friends devoured their beef burgers.  Although the curly fries are the most popular, we decided the skinny fries are the best. Thumbs up!

UltraStar is new to the Phoenix area. It has a spacious lobby with all the warmth of a airplane hanger. Its corporate vibe is immediately apparent in every aspect of the consumer experience. One can almost sense the calculated, committee-approved decision making that dominates the theatre. \nThe concession stand and gourmet coffee bar must seem amusing to Europeans. The seating area has little ambiance and is certainly not a place I'd spend any time hanging out. Boring.\nThe theatre I viewed the film in was serviceable, but nothing outstanding comes to mind. The film started on time. The UltraStar management really would benefit from a visit to a Harkins theatre to get this whole thing 'figured out.'

"Satisfactory victuals and the customary servers are occupied but vigilant.  The greenery-based dishes are palatable, yet caution is advised regarding their preparation time, as they tend to require an equally prolonged duration, if not more, compared to other menu items to arrive at your table.  The poultry strips are delectable, and reports suggest that the wraps are exceptional. 

Beyond that, the remaining options are passable but not remarkable.  The potato-based soup is quite tasty, but avoid ordering it with excessive frequency, as it is featured as the daily special approximately 90% of the time. 

A suitable alternative when seeking a respite from fast food in the central business district or desiring something beyond a simple sandwich."

While the restaurant itself was nice and the staff was also very nice the food was nothing that I can say was truly amazing. We were expecting a very 5 star experience when it came to the food and we were surprised when the food came out just a few minutes after we ordered. Most everyone in our party thought the food was average, nothing to right home about. We have a restaurant near us called Frida Mexican Restaurant in Glendale,CA and there food is much much better. On the bright side I did order the Nachos and this seem to be the hit on the table So much so that everyone started munching away at my food \n\nSo heres the deal for me, I am always looking for amazing Mexican Food, something above and beyond what I can expect living in Los Angeles. Diego was not it for me, Great looking place, Friendly Staff, with So-So Food.

Let me start by saying that I LOVE the food and flavor combinations at Layers. Also on the fabulous list is that it's organic :). I have been a fan since this new location opened. However, (and this is why I rated only 3 stars, they used to be 5 in my book) I have been disappointed the last few visits. The baked goods remain awesome, but the \"kitchen\" food isn't as amazing these days. Last time, the pasta has far too much oil which knocked off the entire dish. This time I went for the meatloaf sandwich, The Conservative, and while the flavor combo of yummy meatloaf and carmelized onions snuggled together in a panini were a hit - the presentation was a mess. The bread was so broken and soggy that it really had no business being called a sandwich because I could not pick it up. Had to eat with a fork and knife. I've had this sandwich, or a similar one in the past (when the store opened) and had much more success in getting it from the plate to my mouth in a ladylike fashion.  Maybe the bread was different?  Possibly the chef was different?  Something has changed....\nTo clarify, I would not discourage anyone from ordering anything off the menu, but I just know that Layers can do better than I have recently experienced.  I hope that they will strive for their best because they are one of my favorites!

Make sure they know if u r in a hurry.  Was disappointed bc I called ahead and gave very specific directions (Please make sure the 3 dozen bialy's are in plastic bags bc I need to pack them in my suitcase.  Unfortunately, they were not and I had to make the taxi wait...  costing me more money.  UGH!  In the long run, it ended up costing $72 for 39 bialys (including taxi)

"Have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on two separate occasions, and upon conducting a cursory examination of the menu, it appeared that the options available remained relatively consistent between visits, although, I must admit, my culinary explorations were temporarily suspended due to a fleeting sense of uncertainty regarding the quality of the dishes, which, in hindsight, proved to be an unfounded concern, as the staff, who displayed an unwavering commitment to ensuring our satisfaction, greeted us with warm smiles and offered their assistance in Tagalog, regardless of our proficiency in the language, thereby creating a welcoming ambiance reminiscent of a familial gathering, and, furthermore, the delectable aroma of the pork gisantes and the flavorsome pancit left me in a state of gastronomical delight, all for the reasonable price of $7.99 per individual, and, as an added convenience, an assortment of tantalizing treats and snacks were available for purchase at the register, thus, making it an ideal destination for future family outings, with honorable mentions extending to the savory pusit and diniguan (dinardaraan), and, while the parking situation may appear somewhat peculiar, owing to the one-way entrance, I found that securing a parking spot was a straightforward process, albeit requiring a modicum of vigilance to ensure entry through the appropriate entrance."

Stopped in here after looking on Yelp for something different. I was pleasantly surprised at the wide selection of fresh authentic Poke. I like that I was able to sample before I bought. I finally chose the spicy avocado ahi. It was good, and mildly spicy. Not over spicy. I really enjoyed this as it was all I had for lunch that day. I know this doesn't look like the place to get amazing Poke(NLV), but you will be happy you did stop in.

After an afternoon of recreation at the nearby park, I returned home feeling famished and disinclined towards consuming the customary cuisine offered on East Boulevard; thus, I opted to venture forth to Thai Taste, a local eatery renowned for its authentic Thai culinary delights. Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the traditional Thai decor that permeated the interior space, fostering a warm and welcoming ambiance that, albeit quaint, did not feel overly cramped or congested, even during a presumably off-peak dining period. 
  The menu presented itself in a straightforward fashion, allowing patrons to select their preferred entrÃ©e and combine it with a choice of meat, thereby tailoring their dining experience according to individual preferences. In my case, I opted for the green curry, which, when prepared with chicken, promised to deliver a flavor profile characterized by a harmonious balance between the pungency of fresh green chilies and the richness of coconut milk. Unfortunately, the execution of this particular dish fell short of my expectations, as the green curry, while boasting an undeniably aromatic quality, lacked the requisite level of piquancy typically associated with such a preparation. However, in light of favorable reviews pertaining to the establishment's culinary offerings, I am inclined to attribute this shortcoming to a momentary lapse in the kitchen and intend to revisit Thai Taste in the near future, during which time I shall insist upon an extra-hot rendition of the green curry, thereby affording me the opportunity to sample the dish in its optimal form. 
  The prices charged by Thai Taste are eminently reasonable, and the attentive nature of the service afforded me a constant supply of replenished water, a considerate touch that did not go unappreciated. In a timely fashion, my meal arrived, and I relished every bite, ultimately departing the premises satiated and content. Based on my positive experience, I would unhesitatingly recommend Thai Taste to aficionados of Thai cuisine seeking a satisfying dining experience in Charlotte, and, indeed, I look forward to returning in order to sample their Pad Thai, in addition to a more fiery green curry.

"While it may appear unremarkable at first glance, a closer inspection of The House of Blues reveals a multifaceted venue that offers an immersive experience for music enthusiasts. Although primarily characterized by a predominantly standing-room layout, astute patrons can opt for the indulgence of bottle service or, alternatively, ascend to the balcony to enjoy a more exclusive vantage point. Sonically, the establishment boasts an impressive auditory infrastructure that effectively showcases the performances of both emerging and established artists, thereby ensuring an aural satisfaction that precludes any potential grievances."

Normally I wouldn't bother to write a review for a Pizza Hut. Or even check in on Yelp. Some secrets are best kept in the family. It's Pizza Hut after all. Everyone knows what they're going to get. 

So what's the motivation this time? I noticed some really bad recent reviews for the carry out location I occasionally use. The workers there, however, are consistently nice and really seem to be trying to do a good job given the limitations that Pizza Hut presents. I just wanted to give them a little "thumbs up". 

Three stars, the maximum rating allowed by law for a Pizza Hut.

"I have had the pleasure of utilizing this culinary establishment on multiple occasions for grandiose dinner parties in their exclusive private dining area, and each experience has been utterly exceptional. On this particular visit, I reserved a table for two in the main dining area to celebrate a joyous birthday occasion. Upon arrival, the restaurant was bustling with activity and our presence was acknowledged forthwith. Our beverage preferences were solicited with alacrity, but unfortunately, our server seemed to prioritize other tables, leaving us in a state of neglect for an extended period. Our salads arrived in a timely manner, yet the entrÃ©e orders took an unacceptable amount of time to materialize. Furthermore, we were compelled to seek assistance from the busperson to replenish our water glasses and request additional bread. The latter portion of our meal was marked by repeated attempts to hail the attention of our server, who appeared to be preoccupied with a large party hosted by the chef and proprietor. Ultimately, we received our check after persistent requests, and the quality of the cuisine was satisfactory, with my angel hair pasta and my companion's gnocchi dishes being generously portioned and served at an optimal temperature."

D'abord, le bouquet d'\u00e9pices fait acte de pr\u00e9sence. On se souvient de son bouillon, adroitement appr\u00e9ci\u00e9 de clous de girofle, de badianes, de graines de coriandre et de cardamomes. Diverses variantes sur le m\u00eame th\u00e8me. Les Classiques sont plut\u00f4t impersonnelles avec des coupes de viande plus propres et immacul\u00e9es. Les Aventuriers  se prononcent d'une anatomie bovine moins pr\u00e9venante, flancs gras et tripes croustillantes. Si le d\u00e9faut d'asepsie vous emmerde, s'abstenir de la toilette. Je soustrais  une \u00e9toile pour cette raison.

"The culinary experience afforded by the consumption of pasta at this establishment was satisfactory, however, the use of Hershey's syrup as a topping for the tiramisu dessert raised concerns regarding the authenticity and credibility of the restaurant's claims to be an Italian eatery, thereby eliciting a sense of skepticism and incredulity in this patron."

I was impelled to visit this establishment due to the fact that I was the fortunate recipient of a complimentary voucher, courtesy of a radio station contest, and I must admit that I would not have opted to partake in this culinary experience had it not been offered gratis.

Upon perusing the menu, I noticed that there was a sampler entrÃ©e/mix grill option available for a mere $70, which included an assortment of delectable cuts, specifically filet, kobe shirt, and a New York cut. Although the Kobe shirt was undoubtedly palatable, it is worth mentioning that I have yet to encounter a less-than-satisfactory cut of Kobe beef, thus rendering its quality somewhat predictable.

Furthermore, I opted to sample their trio of mashed potatoes, which featured an array of distinct flavors, including the tantalizing truffle and lobster variety. While these potatoes were indeed quite delectable, I cannot help but feel that they fell short of exceptional.

In conclusion, taking into account the multitude of superior dining options available, I fear that I would not consider returning to this particular restaurant, despite the occasional availability of complimentary vouchers.

I love their sandwiches but they are VERY over priced AND.... they do not have whole wheat bread.  They were definitely behind the times by not having a whole wheat bread instead of WHITE bread.  Every other sandwich place I know has whole wheat..  Fire House Subs, subway, port of subs, quiznos. etc..\n\nCome on Capriotti's get some damm whole wheat french bread.

MTD is a great way to get to class when the weather is nasty.  However, the buses are often late, so be sure to choose a bus that arrives to your destination a few minutes early.  At least the MTD buses are free to students.

Not too bad!  Been to this location several times, still have not loved it yet.  

The antipasta platter was ok.  The mozzarella was good; the brushette had too much pesto; and calamari was not crispy enough.  The chicken marsala was ok too.  I tasted more of the grill of the chicken than the marsala sauce.  The mash potatoes were good.    I should have stuck to my usual pasta carrabba.  

The service is always excellent!

"WU DINNAE NEED THEM INGLISH! WU CUN LOOK EFTER WURSEL BUCOZ  WUR A NATION!!!!"

"FFFFRRREEEEEDDDOOOOOOMMMMMMM!!!!!!!!!!!!"

The cultural cringe is alive and well.

We opted to patronize Einstein for our morning repast, despite the considerable queue that had formed outside, stretching beyond the entrance and into the street, owing to the popularity of this establishment among the local denizens. It being just shy of 9 am on a tranquil Sunday morning, we pondered the feasibility of seeking sustenance elsewhere, but ultimately elected to endure the delay, which, much to our relief, proved to be relatively brief. Following a mere thirteen minute interval, during which we placed our order and tendered payment, we were able to secure a table in the spacious dining area, whereupon our culinary selections were promptly prepared and presented to us, requiring but a scant four additional minutes of waiting. My personal preference was for the flavorful applewood bacon and cheddar cheese-adorned egg sandwich, served upon a plain bagel, which, while perhaps a tad overpriced in relation to its constituent elements, was nonetheless thoroughly enjoyable and satisfying.
