A plaque boasts it as being the Pub of The Year in 1985.\n\nI popped in for lunch here and ordered a goats cheese salad - very unlike me as I'm a huge carnivore, however it sounded light and refreshing on the menu, and light and refreshing it was. It came with two huge chunks of goats cheese on a bed of mix salad leaves and seasonal veg with a light dressing. With a nice Guinness this it hit the spot perfectly. Staff could have been a bit more attentive, though I doubt they get much training. Nevertheless it is a boozer, so expect nothing more! Kudos Rose St Brewery, and don't ever change!

"Appears to harbor an inclination towards an 'O'-like experience, boasting an array of melodious compositions and gifted performers. Nonetheless, the narrative itself suffers from a dearth of coherence and lacks the seamlessness typically associated with a Cirque production."

It's hard to evaluate the merits of a coffee shop based on a french soda, but this place seems pretty good. It cost about $3 which is a bit pricey, but tasted good, and the syrups they use are good quality.\n\nI'd have to keep going here and grab a coffee to see how the place is on the whole.
Small, quiet casino - check. Clean, spaced out machines - check. Drink options followed by food - check. Low traffic = little smoke - checkity check!
Grabbed a couple of dozen bagels and took to work.  Man they don't last long.  Bagels are good and the service is friendly.  They were real busy but make time to chat will working.

Cute little spot! Nice ambiance, ok food. The BF & I ate here for our birthday dinner over the summer. Honestly the only reason why I wanted to come here was because I was curious about the Matilda Wong.. it was even better than I imagined.. seriously drop what you're doing & get. it. NOW

We started off with the Sweet Potato Ravioli with the Gorgonzola Cream sauce. Four pieces of delicious ravioli, but I didn't really care for the creamy sauce- it was a little too rich & salty for my taste. LOVED the ravioli itself though. It was topped with walnuts & served with some bread. 

For entrees, BF got the Hanger Steak & I tried the Muffuletta Pizza without meat. BF liked the steak, but my pizza, while it looked good, was so damn salty! Must be because of the olive spread but jeez.. Nothing that another Matilda Wong couldn't remedy though :)

We split a dessert, but I don't remember what it was.. it had been a few months since we ate here. Guess that means it wasn't horrible, but also wasn't memorable :(

I would come here again & try a different entree.. perhaps the Farro Saute? I found the prices to be pretty reasonable: $12 for ravioli, $12 for the pizza, & I think around $20 for the steak, probably under $10 for the dessert .. & $11 for each mini pitcher of the Wong.. hell yeah

24/7 Local video poker sports bar, everything you'd expect. It seems like I'm always just stopping in for a cheap breakfast, the Pt's Platter is way better than its Ihop and Denny's counterparts and the waitresses are much friendlier. Unfortunately, I always get sucked into the video poker machines and end up leaving with a full tummy and an empty wallet.

I went there to celebrate my wife's completion of second year dental school from UNLV. Interior design is nice and upscale and hostess was very friendly. We ordered Steak Special for two and we had to wait about 20 min to get our plate. It was ok. However, The waiter was really busy so he did not take care of us. He did not even refill my water so I had to take my wife's water and drank. compare to the price and atmosphere, service was not that great.

A quick update after my first business trip in more than 8 months:

As a nursing mom, I now have more to worry about when going through security.  At 5am on a Friday (which is actually quite busy because of all the business travelers returning home to the East Coast).  TSA had to place each of my clear bags into the bomb-matter-detecting machine, but the agent was more than courteous, explaining the process and what would happen if the machine alarmed.  Luckily it didn't.  Even though I had over a dozen bags that had to be scanned, I was done in 5 minutes.

There's not much in the Delta portion of Terminal 3, but Starbucks and Wendy's are usually open for breakfast, though the lines are quite long.

Now that the construction is done, it's much easier to find the rental car shuttle.  And I was pleasantly surprised at how short the wait was at 12:30am, despite the multitude of people who'd arrived late like me.   The rental car shuttles always smell quite strongly of soapy air freshener, almost to the point of making me sick.  I guess that's better than smelling dirty, but it is quite overpowering. 

#Yelp365 - 169/365

If you are drunk.... as in silly drunk, loud drunk, agitated drunk, confused drunk, mellow drunk, giggly drunk, lost drunk, or still-have-$5-in-your-pocket drunk... this is where you want to eat. \n\nYou're likely to have amusing memories here as you sort of sober up with other hungry drunk people who are all lured in by the aroma of pizza. Note: the pizza tastes like a slice-of-heart-attack during the daytime, however there is something oh so good about it when eaten at 1:45 am.

"Pros: The eatery boasts a relaxed and convivial atmosphere, which is further enhanced by its prime location within the luxurious Cosmopolitan complex. The interior design is a unique blend of lucha libre and Las Vegas elements, featuring striking red lamps suspended from the ceiling and video screens displaying images of renowned Mexican artist Frida Kahlo and influential Chinese leader Mao, among others. \n\nCons: While the menu offers an extensive array of options, the dishes themselves are somewhat disappointing. Particularly considering the restaurant's laid-back setting, the prices are slightly elevated for what essentially amounts to a selection of fried rice and tacos. Employing a tapas-style service model, multiple orders are necessary for sharing, which may not necessarily constitute a cohesive fusion of Chinese and Mexican cuisine, but rather a menu showcasing unremarkable renditions of each."

What to do on Christmas Eve eve... oh, Carolina Place Mall is open 'til 11pm? Let's go wander around there and watch the masses scramble for gifts.

When I need to make a mall trip, this is not at the top of the list for me. I rank Northlake, SouthPark and Concord all above it. One: anything that involves 485 does not make me pleasant. Two: The store selection here is just kind of meh. Three: it's a pain to get in and out of this place.

Now I will say this, there is an H&M on the way which could be a game changer for this place. It will be great for people on the south side of town since currently there is just the one location up at Northlake. Until SouthPark gets one, this one will do for our side of town.

Typical anchor stores here. I don't want to say that it feels outdated... I don't think that's the right description. Maybe old school vibe is more accurate.

If I'm near this area and need a mall, I'll venture here. But with so many better options in the Charlotte area, it's definitely not a must-go shopping destination on my list.

Came here for brunch before a Cardinals' game. Food was good and drinks very generous. Love that they have the bus to the games. Very nice that everyone could enjoy their time and nobody had to worry about driving.

Food was absolutely delicious,  but pricey. We were dressed in comfortable clothing (jeans/shorts/sweatshirts) and clearly did not fit in; this is a dressy crowd. We were also the youngest people there... it was mostly older adults 65+. Great views and good service.

This club represents the pinnacle of contemporary nightlife in Las Vegas, boasting an impressive magnitude that has captured the attention of revelers and enthusiasts alike; however, my personal experience did not live up to the lofty expectations generated by its grand reputation. The layout of the club presents a formidable challenge for individuals, particularly women who must navigate numerous flights of stairs while donning high heels, which proved to be a considerable encumbrance throughout the evening. The central hub of activity within the club, located at the summit of the stairwell, hosts prominent performances and DJ sets, yet the configuration of the space itself proved unsatisfactory due to the presence of rows of tables positioned along the perimeter, thereby obstructing the view for the majority of patrons. Moreover, the balcony area, replete with tables, failed to provide an optimal vantage point for observing the featured entertainment. It appears that the club's design places a premium on coercing clientele into procuring tables, which may not align with the preferences or financial means of all potential visitors. In contrast, Lights emerges as a superior alternative for live events, earning my unwavering endorsement.

I'd really wanted to like this place, but it just isn't happening. Family has eaten here several time and we've had excellent meals (burgers in particular), but not consistently. There is always something wrong: burger over cooked, cold food, orders not correct. If a restaurant is going to charge the higher prices, I expect consistently good food and service - not hit and miss.

"I thoroughly enjoy the ambiance of this establishment, it possesses a distinctly quaint and charming 'little main street' quality that is reminiscent of a bygone era. The culinary offerings are quite satisfactory, with prices that are eminently reasonable and affordable. However, I must caution that the pace of service is somewhat leisurely, so it may not be the optimal choice for individuals who are pressed for time or have a particularly tight schedule to adhere to."

I got great service and they totally set me up with the right bike after receiving wrong sizing from another Landis store. They definitely spent some time with me on my shoe choice. My sizing appointment went well and they answered a lot of my new road bike questions though I thought some of their techniques a bit questionable. \nHaven't used for repairs yet but have a mountain bike in rough shape to bring in so will review after that.

"The performance was ostensibly satisfactory, as the comedic individual executed merely four daredevil feats to substantiate his proficiency, while expending the majority of the time engaging in banter. The spectacle prompted curiosity regarding the methodology behind his cognizance of such information. Upon culmination of the production, he divulged the winning lottery numbers to the entire assemblage, evoking amusement and intrigue. Notwithstanding, I wouldn't attend another presentation, as I possess a predilection for novel experiences and endeavors, and thus, it is imperative for me to progress forthwith."

I absolutely love this place for breakfast.  I have never seen so many selections for breakfast.  I'm definitely coming here again when I'm out in Vegas.\n\nDinner:  its 108 for 2 people and I don't really think its all that.  Yes, they have crab and a seafood selection but I was disappointed.  I thought dinner was going to be better than breakfast.  For that amount of money you can get a nice meal at Mesa Grill located in Caesar Palace.
Not a huge fan. It was okay at best. I've been to a few of these types of places around town and this one was average.

I was excited when this breakfast restaurant opened up in my neighborhood as I love to go out for breakfast almost everyday.

I have eaten there 3 times now but I only order 1 thing on the menu which I do enjoy quite a bit because their other items are a little unusual for me.

I went to eat there again yesterday and I was very sorry to see they have removed all side items off their menu. So I cannot order an omelet or 2 scrambles eggs with bacon, or a side of toast. Its one of the nine items or nothing. That does not work for me so that is why i have given this restaurant 3 stars. I hope they reconsider offering the basic breakfast items or I will probably not be back.

This was my second tapas place to visit in Las Vegas. 

The food was ok, nothing really stood out other than the paella. It was a 40 minute wait, but worth it to try at least once!

The service was top notch, from the moment you walk thru the entrance to the wait staff, manager, everyone made you feel welcome. 

The price, OH THE PRICE!   Only complaint I would say.  The entire menu is seriously over priced, even by Las Vegas Strip standards. It's the reason it will not be coming back. There are far better places to go for tapas on the Vegas strip for a better price & value. And important a better selection.

The atmosphere is great!  Plenty of light, open, not stuff. It has a bar area as well. The noise level is on the average. And the place is clean, they did a pretty good job clearing the table as you was done.  

All in all, I thought this place was OK at best.  But there are much much better places to visit.

This place is hit or miss. The service is usually subpar. Food as mentioned above is different each time. The chicken fried rice is either oily or dry. The orange chicken is very chewy which I do not enjoy. Prices are average I'd say. Overall not bad, but certainly not the best place for Chinese food in North Phoenix

A luncheon in commemoration of a colleague's departure led me to this establishment, whereupon I was less than enthused by the precursory popover bread, possessing an unmistakable ovum flavor that nearly satiated my gastronomical inclinations, yet thankfully, my fungi and gruyere panini proved to be delectable and of generous proportions, accompanied by an abundance of fries, and ultimately, all patrons relished their culinary selections, furthermore benefiting from a minor rebate extended to financial institution staff members, constituting an added advantage.

I was happy to find this restaurant in my hotel.  It was late and I didn't want to venture out.  The bar had more people than I expected for a Monday night.  I ordered the gnocchi, which I believe was misspelled on the menu (\"gnocci\").  I planned on pointing this out to the waitress until I heard the way she pronounced gnocchi (\"knock-y\").  (I wonder if she told people she worked at \"Bigelow Grill-e.\")  Somehow this made my dining experience seem a little less upscale.  Overall, I was pleasantly surprised with the ambiance - aside from the thick cigarette smoke at the bar.  \n\nThis sentence had me scratching my head for a while, \"Bigelow is serving innovative and imaginative interpretations of ethnic Pittsburgh classics.\"  Maybe some Pittsburghers will fill me in sometime.

The early bird doesn't catches the worm at Marche Atwater, especially on a cold winter Sunday morning....

Only handful of stores are opened... but luckily we able to get some pastries at Boulangerie Première Moisson as breakfast, a great start for the morning.

By 8:30 am then some of the fresh products stands and stores starts opening up.

Marche Atwater is a lot smaller than I expect, maybe it is winter so none of the outdoor vendors are open??

Next time I will skip Atwater and go to Jean-Talon instead.

Since I'm a lover for lobster rolls, I decided to come here for lunch.  My husband and I decided to split a combo.  The lobster roll was ok.  I didn't like that the meat was chopped in tiny pieces (reminds me of canned tuna).  I also didn't like how the slit of the bun was just barely half way through the bread.  It makes me feel like they're trying to save on lobster meat.  With each bite we made, the meat fell out of the bun.  The chowder fries were ok.  Nothing to rave about.  For over $20, I was pretty dissatisfied with the portions I was given.

"My predilection for fastidious gastronomical indulgences precipitated my visitation to this establishment, as the lyrical allusion had piqued my curiosity. Alas, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the culinary offering, while not necessarily deplorable, did not quite meet the lofty standards I had envisioned. In fact, my palate found the patty to be somewhat akin to those proffered by Freddy's Frozen Custard, Culver's, and Steak and Shake, which, in my opinion, are superior. My initial inclination was to sample the burger in its standard configuration, which unfortunately included an excess of saccharine relish that proved to be an unfortunate choice. Consequently, I shall exercise greater discernment in my condimentary selections during future visits."

Good & decent lunch specials! However, I had to knock a couple stars because waitress came to our table at least 3 times & did not bother to fill water glasses. And we had to remind her for our roll that comes with lunch entre\u00e8! Fish was ok, not that fresh!

One of the stops on the Light Rail Bar Crawl, I felt that the Gin Mill was the most \"dive-y\" with a lot of dented chrome and scarred wood a bathroom that needed a flamethrower and some seriously loud music. I sat at the bar with my beer and watched the young-uns dancing to the DJ's tunes on the \"stage\". This vantage point gave me a great opportunity to see the bartenders in operation. Fast, efficient and friendly. Picking up abandoned empties and serving out drinks quickly. Impressive.\n\nBouncer at the door checking ID's. Taxi stand outside ready to take the wobbly folks home, but I was good. It's a very short walk to the Light Rail station that gave me time to sober up (I only had four drinks over five hours) while riding back to my parked car.

I have really enjoyed Dos Chandler for a few years now, I used to just drink their Negra Modelo and Dos X, but recently started eating the super ewey gooey chimi, which I would recommend to anyone.  Their quesadillas are awesome, they don't get much better than that.  (And I work in a New Mexican style kitchen). I feel they should offer more Mexican beers on tap, and definitely need more tequila options.  The frozen margaritas aren't anything to brag about, however.  The tables are usually sticky now whenever I sit down..and I haven't had a consistent server or bartender in a long time, there is always someone new, but they do a decent job taking care of me, but I can tell they don't have much support management-wise on the floor.  I give three stars due to dirty tables, poor beer selection on tap, and the usual generic tequila selection.  Being a Mexican restaurant they need to step up their game and clean the place up.

Ok I guess...Ate there this morning about 8:45. Sat down, was acknowledged with a nod and be with you in a minute...but was closer to 7 or 8. Ordered \"the handful\" which has 2 eggs, 2 pancakes, potatoes, and 2 bacon. Wanted to trade bacon for veggies but was told it would be $1 more even though on side items, the bacon cost more than the veggies...go figure.  Make the customer happy and he'll come back tomorrow, don't and he won't.\nIt was decent, can't complain too much, but can't give thumbs up either.

August trip: Arrived here by taxi (cheaper than using a shuttle!) from the airport. The Bell-Man took our luggage so we did not need to wait in line for the luggage area. Check-in took about 30-45 minutes on a Sunday. We stayed in the newly renovated Grand Tower. Amenities included king bed, expensive mini fridge, awesome upgraded view for our anniversary. The spa was terrific except for the nude woman inside the women's hot tub. Germs - EW! Beware of the pool. I came back with an unwanted bacterial infection on my legs that took 4 weeks to clear up with antibiotics.

This is the Grand Lux Cafe situated within the premises of the esteemed Venetian resort. It is worth mentioning that there exists an alternative location of the same establishment in the Palazzo, however, according to local patrons, the quality of service and culinary offerings at this particular branch are deemed superior. For the sake of comparison, it is pertinent to note that the author has had the pleasure of visiting another Grand Lux Cafe situated in the Beverly Center of Beverly Hills; and while both establishments share certain commonalities in terms of their ambiance and gastronomical offerings, this specific location boasts the unique distinction of being open for business on a twenty-four hour basis.

Upon arriving with a sizable contingent of approximately fifteen individuals, the group was able to secure seating arrangements without incident, despite the fact that it was peak dining time and no prior reservations had been made (it is customary to reserve tables at least two hours in advance).

The author and a companion opted to share a pizza pie adorned with sausage, pepperoni, and mushrooms. While the dough was somewhat overly soft and difficult to handle without the toppings breaking apart, the flavor of the crust itself was quite satisfying. As a result, the author and her companion found themselves consuming the crust of each slice, leaving behind the toppings.

It is important to note that the menu at Grand Lux Cafe features an extensive array of culinary options, which bears a striking similarity to that of Cheesecake Factory, given that the two establishments share a common affiliation. Nonetheless, it is recommended that patrons exercise caution when selecting items from the Asian-inspired section of the menu, as the authenticity of such dishes may be subject to debate.

I was somewhat skeptical regarding a cafe that publicizes coffee that lacks the characteristic flavor profile associated with coffee, yet my reservations were partially alleviated upon sampling their espresso, which demonstrated a level of quality that surpassed my expectations, although it failed to elicit an exceptional degree of enthusiasm within me, and its overall quality was inferior to that of Starbucks' offerings.

good food. consistently slow and lousy service.  I had forgotten that it was nearly exactly a year since I'd been here,  and had the exact same experience (and my companions remembered too).  Very attentive manager,  but indifferent servers ... unbelievably slow.   It took an hour and a half since we arrived to go from order to meal.   Twice I had to get up and ask the manager about the status (oh and we ordered sushi, which doesn't need to be cooked!). \n\nFood was very good though.  So if you want great food without caring about the wait,  or attitude of the staff then Kona Grill is the place for you!

My Partner and I flew into Phoenix last week for the Christmas Holiday and we stopped here for lunch before heading out to the family.    I was fairly impressed with the cuisine and the ambiance.

I had a burger with all the trimmings and it was prepared perfectly.  I would have liked a few more fries with the burger, but I probably didn't need them.

I have to say the 80's hair band music videos playing were a little weird though.

If I find myself back in Phoenix, I will eat here again.

This is exactly what I was looking for in a hotel during my one night stay in Pittsburgh. Close to the city, but far enough out to get free parking and a reasonable rate (under $100).

The room was fairly small, but I was only planning on sleeping in it. It was clean so I couldn't ask for much more. The people at the front desk were very friendly too.

If I go back to Pittsburgh, I will absolutely stay here again.

Went to Rigatonys tonight with my sister and niece. Niece and I shared manicotti. It was decent enough, not super fabulous but not the worst I've ever had. My sister had the Mahi special with asparagus and quinoa pasta. She loved it. There was a creamy dill sauce on the fish. The salad was also awesome- nice portion of salami, cheeses, olives, pepperocini etc.. We tried spumoni for dessert and that was legit and a nice portion as well. Bryce was our server and was very nice, knowledgeable and had everything out in a timely manner. He told us about the extra charge for split plate. The meal came with bread as well. It was an overall great experience and we will be back.

I came here on a Saturday for lunch and it was packed so we took our food to go. By the time I was able to eat my torta ahogada, it had already soaked up all the spicy sauce it was swimming in and was soggy and quickly disintegrating. Normally I'm pretty tolerant to spicy foods but all I could taste was spicy. My friend got 3 fish tacos, which were super tiny. He was still hungry afterwards so he had san other full meal. Overall, it did not live up to all the good reviews I kept reading about on Yelp.

"Culinary experiences can be gratifying on occasion, albeit briefly, when the ambiance is revamped to create an atmosphere of sophistication. However, during our recent visit, the service was subpar, specifically with regard to the eggs, which were overcooked and lacked the desired doneness. Furthermore, the demeanor of certain servers bordered on impertinence, epitomized by their reluctance to acknowledge our presence, let alone address our concerns. Notwithstanding, the management's indifference towards our grievances was palpable, as they prioritized the interests of unremunerated patrons partaking in recreational activities over those of paying customers. Perhaps the establishment could benefit from the introduction of a poker club, whereupon we, as patronizers, might be inclined to voice our dissatisfaction and effectuate improvements in the quality of service."

I've made plenty of bad decisions here.\n\nHave you ever been somewhere where it means nothing, but somehow, means everything? I like coming to Maz. They don't have a good selection of beer. Or drinks. They don't have good pool tables. There are plenty of shady things that go on here. But still I find myself here every once in a while; generally I'm in a really crappy mood, or I'm feeling to good to go home and too mashed up to go anywhere else.

The service was a bit slow but the food made up for it. The sushi was delicious and the burger was unique and flavorful. We also got the mixed delux fries basket which was phenomenal. I would definitely come back.

"A moderate lodging facility, offering a comfortable respite in a prime location, proximal to an array of amenities, including a shopping mall, cinema, and various dining establishments, while remaining accessible to primary tourist attractions within a mere 10-15 minute distance. Additionally, this accommodation boasts a tranquil atmosphere, nestled amidst a picturesque neighborhood, replete with charming cafes and boutiques, mere steps away. Guests may enjoy the inviting ambiance of the hotel's lounge area, complete with a fireplace, ideal for relaxing with a refreshing beverage, whether alcoholic or non-alcoholic in nature. Furthermore, a comprehensive dining experience is available on-site, catering to guests' culinary needs, should they opt to forego venturing out into the city. However, it is worth noting that the rooms themselves suffer from somewhat diminutive soundproofing, resulting in an increased auditory awareness of fellow patrons' comings and goings. Moreover, the complimentary wireless internet connection, while appreciated, exhibits sluggish speeds, hindering productivity and efficiency. In summary, this establishment offers a suitable temporary abode for travelers seeking convenience and accessibility, without necessarily serving as a prolonged haven for leisurely activities."
Came in. Waiter was alright. Gave me a stair like I didn't know what I was doing. He gave mediocre service. I'm full

Qdoba is ok. Same idea as Chipotle Grill, but, in my opinion, the food just doesn't taste as good. The burritos don't have that magic ingredient that makes me want to return. And I did not dig the decorating scheme - especially the concrete floors and metal tables. It feels cold and dark, even in the summer.

I recently had the pleasure of dining at this esteemed establishment to commemorate the birthday of one of my colleagues. Prior to this experience, I had never encountered any issues with this specific chain of restaurants; however, on this particular occasion, upon ordering the shrimp and spinach salad, I discovered an unidentified synthetic substance intermingled within my culinary masterpiece. The manager and waitstaff promptly expressed their sincerest apologies for the unforeseen occurrence and demonstrated an expeditious willingness to rectify the situation. I was presented with a novel salad, which I opted to consume off-premises due to my associates having already completed their meals, and upon the food being delivered to me, the manager once again extended his deepest regret. My repast was also complimentary. Despite the fact that I do not attribute blame to either the manager or waitstaff, I cannot help but surmise that the culinary artisans responsible for preparing the victuals may have been remiss in their duties. Notwithstanding, my salad was indeed quite delectable!

I customarily visit this establishment every Sunday during the football season; however, today's visit was an impromptu decision. Upon entering, I sat down at the bar and was greeted by my preferred Asian bartender in the United States. She enthusiastically recommended their delectable chicken wings, which I ordered along with the Kobe burger. Upon arriving home, I opened the box and was utterly dismayed to discover two putrid tomatoes that not only had an unpleasant appearance but also emitted a foul odor reminiscent of organic fertilizer. I promptly returned to the restaurant to request a replacement, only to be informed by the assistant manager that the tomatoes' condition was allegedly "normal." It became evident that this individual lacked a fundamental understanding of culinary quality and customer satisfaction. Fortunately, the general manager was present to mediate the situation and prevent any further dissatisfaction on my part. Notwithstanding, I must express my gratitude towards my bartender, whose exceptional service was the sole redeeming factor of this unfortunate experience, and the primary reason I might consider returning to this establishment in the future.
Horchata is delish! Familiar faces is nice. Pretty good veggie burrito, bomb breakfast burrito, seriously good. Decent prices, but their guacamole could use some work.

I go to this facility usually 3 nights per week at about 2am and love it. Its jot crowded at all, usually having about 3-5 people in it. I can have the basketball court to myself I wanted and move freely through workout stations.

At first glance, this store looks like a tourist trap as it is in old town and they are selling Mexican trinkets. However, I can't say with absolute certainty, the prices seemed to be pretty decent.  I bought a colorful straw sombrero for 5 dollars.  I saw some other items that seemed to be priced right.

You can find all your Mexican things to make for a fantastic fiesta.  Or you can find pieces to decorate your home with in this store -- from the colorful Dia de Muertos Masks to the plates and cups to the garden pieces.  

I did not find the ladies in the store to be friendly at all.  But the store is neat and you will be happy, I am sure, with the HUGE selection of trinkets.

We have been going to PP for over 17 years. Dr Chiles and Dr Salek have been my children's doctors from the beginning. We have seen a lot of faces come and go. Now that PP has merged with  another very large group, it just isn't the same. I still love our doctors and that is why we stay as my children are older now and need less frequent visits. This office just doesn't have the same family friendly feel it once used to.

Patience is required as they take their sweet time and it isn't even busy. It's been 30 minutes and I don't know that they'll be done soon. I would come back because it's cheap but definitely not during 'rush' hour.

"This establishment is truly a behemoth; its gargantuan proportions are simply staggering. Attempting to navigate the vast expanse of the casino from the sidewalk entrance on the strip is an exercise in futility, as the labyrinthine layout and contradictory signage will inevitably lead to disorientation and confusion. Despite its impressive grandeur, the hotel's age is beginning to show in various aspects, with remnants of its former Wizard of Oz/Hollywood motif now conspicuous only by their absence. A pervasive verdant hue envelops everything, creating an ambiance that is both surreal and overwhelming."

Just wanted to update. Manager contacted us. Was willing to give full refund or have the top installed for free. Seems there was a communication issue. Issue was resolved, even kept the truck box cover. Did have an issue, but company did resolve in a timely manner and apologized for the miscommunication

I'd give Dolce 3.5 stars (if it were possible).  I really like the location and the atmosphere is cozy.  I've never eaten at this location other than some hummus and pita chips.  Based on other reviews, I might increase my rating once I sample the fare.  As a wine bar, I'm always happy to stop in to get a glass of red and talk with friends.  At times, I haven't found the servers to be friendly or warm; however, I haven't had any particular problems.  It's just a vibe.  I also wish they would extend their wine list.  As another reviewer commented, there just isn't a lot to choose from.  If you're in the area, I'd definitely stop in, although I wouldn't drive into NoDa just for this venue.

We stopped here for happy hour as I was lazy and it is close to work. Turns out they have a decent happy hour with assorted drink specials, half off selected apps and a pick 2 food special that runs open to close for $6.99. I selected the Tortilla soup and cheese enchiladas. The soup was good and enchiladas was also good and came with rice and beans. Our server was great and I wish I remembered her name but after a couple of the happy hour Margaritas names escape me.

I can here solely based off a recommendation from a friend who told me this was "the best pizza in Vegas". I consider that something of a dubious distinction since Vegas, to my knowledge, is not known for any pizza places. And if CA can barely get pizza right, I had a hard time believing Vegas could do any better. 

For the record, I live and die by NYC pizza. There is nothing on this planet that even compares. Yes, Chicago, that includes you. 

They were having a special deal where all pies were half off, so we got a large topped with pepperoni, sausage, and black olives. The quality just wasn't there for me. The pizza wasn't crispy enough, for one thing. Every time I folded a slice in half the front would start to droop like it was going flaccid. The sausage and pepperoni didn't help things since both were so greasy the pie was getting soggy. I'm cool with pepperoni, but those little blobs of meat called sausage do nothing for me. I should have vetoed that topping suggestion when it came up. Pretty good crust, though. Nothing that saved the dish but it worked all the same. 

Is this the best Vegas can do? Decent doesn't cut it for me. I can't grade on a relative scale.

"On multiple occasions, I have partaken in culinary indulgences within the confines of both the dining room and hibachi grill at this eatery, and I must say that my experiences have been nothing short of exceptional, particularly when it comes to the quality of the fare and the captivating performances put on by the chefs manning the grill. However, my encounters in the dining room have been somewhat less than satisfactory, marred by prolonged waits for my meals, which have consistently exceeded thirty minutes, despite the staff's acknowledgment of these delays and their attempts at compensation, such as offering complimentary edamame to waiting patrons. It appears that there is a dearth of sushi chefs and/or wait staff, resulting in an inadequate level of service that falls short of my expectations. While I would greatly desire to bestow upon this restaurant a more favorable rating, I fear that I cannot do so in good conscience until such time as I witness a marked improvement in the overall quality of service provided throughout the establishment."

The modified text is: "Commuted my vehicle to the servicing facility for a routine oil alteration, and I must say, I was thoroughly impressed by the efficiency and affordability of the process. The proximity of the establishment to a popular wholesale retailer also afforded me the opportunity to concurrently indulge in some recreational shopping and dining experiences while awaiting the completion of the maintenance work. Of relevance, it is advisable to peruse the business's online presence, specifically their review page, in order to potentially exploit any available financial incentives, as I did, resulting in a gratifying reduction in the overall cost."

This was supposed to be Las Vegas' latest and greatest club... I thoroughly enjoyed the sound and the vibe of the House floor, but it was so crowded that you couldn't dance let alone stand anywhere without it being shoulder to shoulder. We opt to say in the Hip Hop area that was equally as crowded, but luckily we found a small corner to dance in. After a while, we got even luckier as a girl invited us to dance in her table reserve area and Warren G performed. Being West Coast girls my group knew all the songs and had a great time watching his show. We left immediately after because it was just too packed for us.\n\nDon't buy bottled water b/c the small bottle costs $9 talk about rip off.

"My initial experience at this establishment was enjoyable, and I intended to bestow a perfect rating, as the culinary offerings were satisfactory and I consumed them on consecutive days. However, upon my return, I perceived a decline in quality regarding the sandwich I ordered. Specifically, the absence of lettuce in all four Earl's club sandwiches was glaring, and an excess of bacon resulted in an overpowering saltiness. Consequently, my enthusiasm for this venue has waned, and I shall not experience cravings for its fare in the future."

A viable alternative to Pita Jungle, albeit with a tad elevated price point relative to the quantity and quality of the fare in comparison to its competitor. My personal experience has been limited to the Togo option, which, while satisfactory, may not always provide the most pleasant dining experience, particularly when taking into account the ambient atmosphere. Notwithstanding, they accommodate Hooka smoking on the patio, a feature that, although potentially bothersome to some, does not detract from the culinary enjoyment. Upon collection of my Togo order, I must steel myself against the pungent Hooka odor that permeates the outdoor seating area. Despite these minor drawbacks, the cuisine generally meets expectations, leaving room for only slight adjustments to enhance the overall dining experience.
The tacos were greasy and unflavorful. I was quite disappointed with my order. There was also dirt on the floors and the people making the food didn't speak much English

Kitty's cafe, nestled within the esteemed El Cortez Hotel and Casino, offers a dining experience reminiscent of a bygone era, replete with the warm, personalized service that has become synonymous with this venerable establishment. Patrons can indulge in traditional counter service or occupy cozy booths, all while being addressed with endearments such as "honey" or, for regulars, by their given names, courtesy of the affable servers. The menu, though unpretentious, boasts generous portions; case in point, the grilled sourdough melt, featuring turkey and ham, which, albeit unremarkable, proved satisfying. However, a novice culinary artisan helming the kitchen on the day of our visit resulted in a tardy turnaround time for dishes. Notwithstanding, Kitty's remains an optimal destination for a late-night repast, catering to those seeking sustenance following an evening of revelry within the hotel's confines or, alternatively, for individuals yearning for a modest, nocturnal dining experience. It is worth noting that the once ubiquitous "$1.99 specials" have, regrettably, become a distant memory.

This particular Starbucks establishment, which is presumably owned and operated by the NY NY Hotel, has opted not to utilize the brand's mobile application for transactions, much to the dismay of patrons who frequently rely on said platform for convenience. It is unfortunate that this store does not offer an alternative payment method for customers who do not possess physical currency, especially considering the prevalence of digital transactions in today's society. However, on this particular visit, I was fortunate enough to have sufficient funds to procure my desired items without relying on the app. 

The bustling atmosphere within this Starbucks location is quite pronounced, with a steady stream of customers frequenting the establishment throughout the day. Despite the high volume of patrons, the service remains relatively efficient, with baristas expertly crafting an array of coffee beverages that cater to diverse tastes and preferences. While I will undoubtedly return to this Starbucks in the future due to its proximity to our hotel, I implore management to reconsider their stance on the app payment system, thereby enabling customers to accrue rewards and fostering a more seamless transaction experience.

"Upon arriving at this establishment, we were immediately greeted by Melissa, our effervescent server, who extended a cheerful salutation, thereby setting the tone for a pleasant dining experience. Following the standard ten-minute delay, which serves as an indicator of quality, we were presented with our beverages; specifically, a robust coffee possessing a full-bodied flavor profile and a diet cola characterized by an optimal level of carbonation. Notably, the expedient delivery of our egg dishes allowed me to complete merely three sentences of this review prior to their arrival, underscoring the efficiency of the kitchen staff. Additionally, our glasses were consistently replenished, ensuring that our hydration needs were met throughout the meal. Overall, this venue offers a satisfying breakfast experience."

"We traversed the distance between the FireSky hotel and the restaurant with ease, commencing our culinary excursion with the green pork chili, which, while possessing an appreciable degree of flavor, lacked the fiery zest we had anticipated. Our order also included the lamb fondue, comprising succulent lamb racks accompanied by a savory squash sauce for dipping. The fondue component of the dish boasted a rich, velvety texture and a subtle sweetness that complemented the lamb nicely. However, upon sampling the braised short ribs as our primary course, we were somewhat disappointed by their relative lack of flavor depth. Despite its generous portion size, the dish failed to impress due to its absence of salt, pepper, and other essential seasonings. While the meat itself was undeniably tender and juicy, the overall taste experience fell short of our expectations. Although the cuisine generally satisfied our palates, we couldn't help but feel that each dish could benefit from a more robust seasoning profile, thereby elevating the gastronomic experience to a higher level of satisfaction. Consequently, we have decided to award this establishment three stars for their efforts."

"The gastronomical experience at this establishment was rather dichotomous, as the tapas were delectable, particularly the fungi-based risotto, while the paella exhibited an excessive sodium content. Notwithstanding, the oxtail was tender, the potatoes were delightful, and the poultry dish was savory, although I accidentally ingested a clove of garlic, which may have been problematic for vampiric individuals. Furthermore, the quality of service within the eatery was unremarkable, in contrast to the superior hospitality offered at the adjacent cafÃ©."

"Prior to attending the performance at the Luxor, our dining possibilities were restricted, and the recommendation provided by the youthful ticket agent, who was only 20 years of age, did not align with our culinary preferences. Despite his assurance that T&T was exceptional, we should have been aware that our tastes would differ. We initiated our meal with a round of mojitos, which our server claimed were of superior quality. Although I have had the opportunity to indulge in mojitos on numerous occasions and have developed a fondness for them, the ones presented to us were excessively sweet. In an attempt to counteract the sugary flavor, I requested club soda twice, but unfortunately, it failed to enhance the beverage. The mojitos were unpleasant, and we could only consume half of them. The complimentary chips and salsa were also subpar, which was unexpected since they are typically straightforward to prepare adequately. My companion and I opted for distinct dishes, with mine being tacos and hers consisting of a shrimp-based dish. Unfortunately, both were merely average in taste. Our server exhibited friendly behavior and displayed generosity by offering us free admission to the show. However, we had already procured our tickets, rendering their kind gesture unnecessary. Considering the unsatisfactory dining experience, I would not consider returning to this establishment. Instead, I would have preferred to dine at the Asian restaurant had I known their menu was impressive."

Easily the best meal I enjoyed in Vegas this past week. I was on a vacation with my sisters. Knowing we would be eating out for 6 days we tried to keep the budget in check. This restaurant was recommended by a friend of my sister did not disappoint as far as the food was concerned. It is tucked away in the back of the food court. Location isn't great...I suppose that is how they keep the prices down. \"Outdoor tables\" are actually inside. Lighting in the interior of the restaurant is way too bright.\nService was very average...our waiter was a hyper-macho Italiano who kept himself busy fawning over the young girls eating next to us, and chatting with his buddies out in the food court plaza. At the end of our meal he was so carried away with his buddies that he had totally forgotten about us, and need to be retrieved by a bus boy. \nThe Caeser Salad that we shared was good. Filet mignon meatballs with spaghetti and red sauce were delicious, as was the wood-fired Quatro Stagioni pizza. I highly recommend the food...the service not so much.

"I thoroughly enjoyed recognizing The Dog empire during my prolonged weekend excursion to Edinburgh, as it boasted an exceptional and stylish design, accompanied by remarkable eatery concepts, including The Dog, UnderDog, SeaDog, and Amore Dog. I sincerely wished I had ample time to sample all of their delectable offerings! My flank steak salad was merely satisfactory, possessing a somewhat tough texture, yet the sweet balsamic reduction complemented the bitter arugula with precision. In contrast, my companion's mushroom risotto was exquisitely prepared and indulgent, earning it a well-deserved four stars. Unfortunately, our culinary journey concluded with a less than impressive tiramisu, which lacked the potency of espresso and featured a chilling temperature that I personally prefer for the dessert. Moreover, the dark chocolate cocoa powder overwhelmed the delicate flavor of the dish when consumed in substantial amounts, prompting us to discard the upper layer of the dessert."
Food was great and reasonably priced with restaurant.com coupon. I would've gave five stars if the waiter wasn't so cocky and direct.

"An extensive array of artisanal brews graces the taps at this establishment, yet, if predictability is a patron's preference, they might be dismayed by the constantly shifting roster of craft beverages available. However, the culinary offerings proved to be a pleasant surprise, surpassing expectations typically associated with tavern fare. A convivial ambiance permeated our gathering of numerous companions, facilitated by the provision of entertainment in the form of board games and trivia queries. Unfortunately, the hospitality and ambiance left much to be desired, as an overwhelming crush of clientele necessitated an inordinate wait for a solitary server's attention, resulting in prolonged periods of neglect. Despite these shortcomings, the eatery's redeeming qualities, including its diverse beer selection and delectable victuals, may warrant future visits, albeit sans any gastronomical inclinations."

I have been a patron of this establishment for a considerable duration, and my satisfaction has been contingent upon the attendance of Dr. Finch, whose proficiency in veterinary medicine and bedside manner have engendered a sense of confidence and tranquility in me, as a concerned pet owner. It is worth mentioning that he has executed a relatively minor surgical procedure on my canine companion, Dozer, which involved the employment of a laser to excise a small growth from her eyelid, and his performance was exemplary, characterized by a commendable level of composure, erudition, and a propitious demeanor towards our cherished animal. Furthermore, it has come to my attention that he will likely be undertaking a second, considerably more complex operation on her, specifically an ACL repair, and I am entirely at ease with entrusting her care to him. Notwithstanding, I have chosen to revise my evaluation downward by a marginal extent, motivated by two primary factors. Firstly, my initial assessment may have been somewhat generous, as I was still in the process of formulating my criteria for evaluating veterinary facilities; and secondly, certain acquaintances have expressed unwavering devotion to their respective veterinarians, whereas my relationship with this establishment, although satisfactory, does not quite rise to that level of enthusiasm. Additionally, I must admit that I have periodically sought alternatives, but procrastination has led me to rely on Dr. Finch's services when Dozer has required urgent medical attention.

"Thus far, my culinary experiences at this establishment have been limited to the breakfast menu, specifically the corned beef and farmer's omlette. While the fare has been satisfactory, it fails to elicit any exceptional praise. However, I do appreciate the option to substitute a blueberry muffin for toast. The server has demonstrated politeness and accommodating behavior, exemplified by their willingness to provide ranch dressing with my hash browns, an unconventional yet personal preference. Additionally, this venue enjoys the distinction of being the sole dining option beyond 10 p.m. in close proximity, excluding those situated within gaming establishments, and boasts reasonable pricing. Consequently, it presents itself as a suitable setting for a relaxed meal in the company of a friend. Nonetheless, I must express my disappointment regarding the absence of dark chicken meat on the menu, as the lighter variety tends to possess an undesirable dryness."

"Although the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the prices charged for said edibles were utterly exorbitant, bordering on the outrageous. Eighteen dollars for a serving of enchiladas? Such an amount would be better suited to purchasing a meal at a high-end eatery, not a run-of-the-mill Mexican establishment. Furthermore, the cost of the accompanying chips and guacamole was equally egregious, amounting to nine dollars. While the quality of the fare was undeniable, it by no means warranted such an extravagant price tag. In light of these considerations, it is my belief that this particular dining establishment harbors an inflated sense of self-importance, as evidenced by the presence of cloth napkins and ornate paper menus, which do little to justify the excessive expense. In conclusion, due to the aforementioned factors, I shall not be inclined to return to this restaurant, as there are numerous other options available that provide comparable cuisine at a significantly lower cost."

Mert's is one of those places you would see on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. The decor has a quintessential southern comfort feel and will make any out of towner feel welcome. \n\nI don't suggest eating lunch here though; if it happens, it's a wrap. You'll be knocked out like a newborn after boobie feeding. Service is good, food is decent and overall an okay spot to grab a meal.

Harrah's has a smart business module when it comes to Carnaval Court. It is situation on a pathway that sucks tourist in. With all the kiosks around, it has useless souvenirs within drunken reach. Even though my friends and I were not inebriated, we still bought those shirts that light up to the music. Thinking they were the epitome of cheesy tourist, we all bought matching shirts to signify our unity. 

Entering the party scene with our newly acquired garments garnered so much attention and compliments. The dance floor is large and provides enough room to get down. Being outside helps alleviate the overheating that sometimes occurs when the dance floor gets too crowded. 

The flare bartenders are fun to watch and make a decent cocktail. If you want to alternate between partying and gambling, this is the perfect venue because they have table games set aside as well. It has everything someone coming to Vegas is looking for.

"It was gratifying to indulge in a tranquil dining experience this week, and if you seek respite from the rigors of daily life, this establishment is an ideal setting in which to do so. The panoramic view from the restaurant's vantage point is truly breathtaking, and the hospitality of the staff is warm and inviting. I opted for the Rib eye steak, which was cooked to perfection, and the accompanying Blue cheese potatoes were delectable, although the potency of the Blue Cheese slightly overshadowed the natural flavor of the potatoes. Additionally, I sampled a slice of cake for dessert, but unfortunately, the ice cream had begun to thaw, rendering it somewhat soggy, and the cake itself was slightly dry. Considering the cost, I anticipated a more fastidious attention to detail in regards to the presentation of the dessert course. Nonetheless, the ambiance and culinary offerings made for a satisfying excursion."

Dim sum, a culinary delight recommended by a friend, aroused my curiosity due to its exclusivity, as it was only available twice a year. However, upon indulging in the delectable offerings, I couldn't help but feel that the quality of the dim sum style food would have been superior if the establishment had concentrated solely on that aspect, instead of incorporating a seafood buffet. Although the dishes were savory, some were unfortunately served at room temperature. Furthermore, the absence of chili oil, a staple condiment in most Chinese eateries I frequent in San Diego, was conspicuous, yet tolerable given the sodium-rich nature of the items we consumed. Nonetheless, the non-dim sum options proved impressive, boasting fresh raw oysters, succulent crab legs, decadent lobster, and expertly crafted nigiri. My request for sushi pieces without rice was accommodated by the gracious sushi chef, albeit the generous slice thickness slightly diminished my enjoyment. A craving for octopus prompted me to explore the buffet line, whereupon I discovered a tantalizing octopus and cucumber salad, undoubtedly the highlight of the spread. An abundance of fresh fruit, including juicy mandarin oranges, tart cherries, and exotic rambutan, beckoned, but the desire to partake in a more leisurely dining experience prevailed. While the dessert bar showcased an admirable selection, it fell short of exceptional. My preference for dim sum, second only to sushi, has piqued my interest in revisiting this establishment during my forthcoming trip to San Diego.

It's like gambling. Sometimes, you win big...and other times...not so much.

The show started off great. Our MC was engaging and very funny. He was very comfortable in his own skin and using his life as material for his comedy, but he was still socially aware to not go too far. The same cannot be said about the first two comedians that came after who were crude, swore way too much, and shoved their distasteful humor down your throat irregardless of people being notably disgusted. At one point, a lady stood up after the joke went too far and asked the comedian to move on. Instead, he used this as fodder to continue at it. I get using someone as the butt of all jokes, but when LITERALLY no one else is laughing with you...it is time to move on. Luckily, the MC was able to put a bandaid over each of these two flops.

The headliner Jay Reid did make up for the entire night though...otherwise it would have been a complete dud at $20/ticket. Jay Reid made excellent use of the stage going as far as using the stool and mic stand as props. He had jokes about current events as well as of normal controversial/taboo subjects. The jokes were tasteful and he even stuck around to meet the audience after. Very classy and cool.

I came here for my 18th birthday with a few friends. They have a happy hour from 2-6 PM Monday-Friday (unfortunately, we came at 7.) I had the grilled chicken sandwich, and the chicken was kind of pink, but it took about 45 minutes to get and I was hungry so I didn't send it back. We also shared a frozen hot chocolate, which had potential, but I was literally chewing on ice the whole time. The service was pretty slow and it's a little pricier than Cheesecake Factory, but not by much. I'll give it another try soon and hope it's better!

This isn't your Grandpa's Flamingo anymore. I would even venture to say this isn't your overweight Chain smoking uncle Larry's Flamingo we all knew and didn't love from 5-10 years ago!

Before My recent trip to The Flamingo, the thought of staying there would immediately trigger thoughts of Depressing 1980's decor, overweight fanny pack wearing gamblers & The over exuberant expressions of Donnie & Marie as they stared longingly into each others eyes trying to forget about that one night back in 77' when things went a little to far. But to the contrary I must say the Flamingo has really cleaned up its act. The new decor is nice and the casino floor is clean and 80% fanny pack clear. 

Now saying that I have yet to stay in a room, but I will say that , where as before I would've only taken a side chick I was slightly ashamed of. Now I would be ok with taking a side chick I was not ashamed of, as well as possibly a girl that I have been dating awhile, all the while  insisting "Why do we have to put labels on what we are" here without hesitation!

All in all The Flamingo is an OK place with a GREAT location that I would recommend anyone walking the strip to try out. Hey, who knows you may finally be the first person to see Donnie and Marie finally consummate 35 years of tension and frustration!

"On two separate occasions during my sojourn at Treasure Island, I have partaken of sustenance at this establishment, and while the Pho has been merely adequate, it has possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that has rendered it marginally palatable in a pinch. Furthermore, I have sampled their vegetarian spring rolls, which, while not devoid of culinary merit, have been somewhat overshadowed by the ambivalent quality of the accompanying peanut sauce, which has struck me as vaguely coconut-flavored. On one visit, I opted for the Pho Tai, while my companion selected the Veggie Pho; unfortunately, my soup proved to be somewhat lacking in gastronomic appeal, containing as it did an abundance of beef but a dearth of noodles, whereas my friend's soup, replete with bak choy, mushrooms, and corn, was more enjoyable. It is worth noting, however, that the pricing of the Pho here strikes me as somewhat elevated in comparison to similar establishments in Los Angeles, where a superior-tasting bowl may be obtained for a mere $7. Notwithstanding these reservations, I must commend the waitstaff for their congeniality and the premises for their cleanliness."

"Although I possess a certain degree of ambivalence towards this particular Target establishment, I do acknowledge that its proximity to my residence renders it a convenient option for me to procure the items I require. However, I must confess that the vast dimensions of the store and the considerable number of patrons it attracts tend to create an atmosphere that is somewhat chaotic and overwhelming, particularly when it comes to awaiting my turn at the checkout line. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, I do appreciate the numerous benefits this retail location offers, including ample parking space, a friendly and competent staff, and an impressive array of merchandise that enables me to fulfill all my shopping needs under a single roof."
The employees spend too\nMuch time with there backs to the customers talking amongst themselves instead of focusing on providing better service!

I just happened to be in Vegas this new year and since I saw this place in the past i decided to try it. Salad bar is ok, the meats a bit too salty and really raw (bloody) but I was surely disappointed with the service. Waitress show up only 3 times, when we first sat at the table, when she brought us the drinks and when she gave us the check!, I have to literally ask the servers to bring the meats to our table since the seem to just pas us by, I guess the just want you to eat from the salad bar :( \nIn other words, the price service/quality ratio is not good at all

We chanced upon this eatery subsequent to our inability to gain admittance to the Bacchanal due to an extensive queue. At the time of our arrival, we were experiencing considerable hunger! This cozy establishment boasts contemporary embellishments throughout its interior, creating a hip ambiance. Top 20 hits are played at a high volume, making it unsuitable for those seeking a tranquil setting conducive to conversation. \n\nThe servings here are generous, but unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not leave a lasting impression. Nothing remarkable or extraordinary was present in the dishes. I opted for a pastrami-based breakfast sandwich, which lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Had they included additional condiments or a unique sauce, it might have elevated the dish to a higher level of satisfaction. Unfortunately, the combination of pastrami, eggs, and other components did not harmonize effectively. However, it did satiate our hunger. Notwithstanding, I must admit that the tater tots were quite delectable - possessing a satisfying crunch and delightful flavor.

"This location possesses an intriguing ambiance and offers a plethora of knowledge. My enthusiasm for the establishment was amplified by the thoughtful division of the exhibits into four distinct ecosystems. However, I lamented the lack of comprehensive representation in the polar/arctic sector. In my opinion, the entrance fee is exorbitant relative to the value offered. Nonetheless, the gift store boasts an array of unique items, including innovative bags crafted from recycled juice containers, delectable insect-based treats, and minuscule crystalline formations, among other fascinating novelties. It is not advisable to squander your resources on the elevator ride to the summit of the metropolis, as the same panoramic perspective can be obtained gratis from the pinnacle of Mount Royal."

"It is imperative that one does not make a hasty judgment based on external appearances, as this establishment offers an array of exceptional bargains for those who are willing to invest time in their pursuit. A diverse medley of items, including apparel, artwork, and various domestic ornaments, are available for perusal and purchase. During my recent visit, it appeared that the proprietors were in the process of expanding their inventory to include an increased assortment of floor coverings and visual art pieces, which will undoubtedly be a boon for individuals seeking to revamp their domiciles. My excursion was enjoyable, and I would unhesitatingly revisit this location in quest of additional hidden gems."
Well they no longer have the Chicken Strip Cheese sandwich and what they replaced it with pretty much sucks. Other than that its like a normal hooters with some new wing flavors and steak fries.

This lodging establishment caters to individuals who seek fundamental accommodations and are financially constrained, thereby providing a suitable venue for those seeking basic amenities at an economical price point. During our sojourn, we found that it fulfilled its intended function admirably and would unhesitatingly suggest it to others who do not prioritize luxurious appointments or an extensive array of services. Within close proximity, we noticed the presence of eateries such as Pizza Hut, Subway, and Fatburger, as well as a cinema, watering holes, and numerous slot machines. Our stay was primarily characterized by slumber, and we did not partake in any notable activities within the hotel's premises themselves. Furthermore, our culinary experience at Fatburger proved to be disappointing, both in terms of taste and the prolonged duration required for its preparation.

I was motivated to go here because I saw it featured on the Food Network, and I was hoping it could hold a candle to the Boiling Crab.  While to seafood was pretty good, it wasn't as spicy & flavorful as I had hoped for.  Go early as it tends to get crowded.  We went at 11am on a weekend and by the time we finished our meal, there was a line for tables.
Solid 3 star red curry tofu.\n\nNot 5 star, not 4 star...but hey!  They did great with the one classic dish I ordered...

The hubby and I stopped by around 8:30 at night. Upon pulling up, we seen that the line was almost out the door. Determined to get some ice cream, I insisted on going in and waiting in line. It took about 15 minutes to get our order, but the place was jam packed so the wait was to be expected.  All the employees were doing their best to keep the line down. I ordered the smallest size, "like it", and the employee actually gave me the next size up at no charge because she said she grabbed too much ice cream. 

There's very little seating at this location,  and the available tables were dirty. But to be fair,  if all hands were on deck making orders, whose left to clean up? We chose to get our order to-go. 

I'm a fan of Cold Stone's ice cream.  I'm accustomed to the long lines. But to me, it's worth waiting to get me some "All lovin' no oven".

This place reminded me of Whiskey River without the shit kickers on the beach side and more of the laid back people. There were dance offs on the floor it seemed people were having fun. 99 cent Jaeger bombers and I heard 99 cent tacos or something. There was a wet t contest with only 3 contestants it was kinda sad but entertaining nonetheless. I'd probably go again.

The Grandview Saloon has one of the best views of Pittsburgh from Mt. Washington from its patio. The views from the interior of the restaurant are not bad either.  To go with your view, you can choose from a good selection of drinks and more mediocre Pittsburghesque (i.e., comfort) food. The design of the patio is fine, but the interior of the restaurant is very plain. This is a shame, because with a little work on the interior design and menu, the view could make this one of the city's most interesting restaurants. \n\nIn short, I would not go here to celebrate an anniversary, but it's a good place to take first-time visitors to see the city while enjoying a tasty beverage.

"Excellent, amicable, and assiduous service was proffered to us, complemented by a delectable Caesar salad, succulent duck, and a mediocre serving of scallops. Although the salad was scrumptious, the duck was somewhat rich and filling, while the scallops were merely average and not particularly memorable. In conclusion, our dining experience was passable but not particularly remarkable, thereby rendering it unworthy of future repetition."

"I have been frequenting this establishment on a regular basis during the week, and it can be challenging to determine whether it is open for business during inclement weather conditions. Despite this, there are certain aspects of the market that I thoroughly enjoy, while others leave something to be desired. The floral arrangements, for instance, are not only breathtakingly beautiful but also remarkably affordable; however, their longevity leaves much to be desired, typically lasting no more than a few days. Additionally, there are some exceptional deals on fresh produce, with some truly outstanding tomatoes and peaches available during their respective seasons. Nonetheless, it is somewhat disconcerting to note that nearly half of the merchandise on offer is not locally sourced. In fact, I found it quite vexing to locate a locally grown apple, and many of the fruits and vegetables sport SKU stickers indicating their origins in distant states such as California or Washington. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the presence of several local farmers scattered throughout the market renders it a worthwhile venture. Consequently, I shall continue to patronize this establishment with some degree of regularity."

I usually love The Coffee Bean.
Something's wrong with this one, though....  something's wrong with all the coffee inside the Venetian!!?!?!

I love a good, strong cup of coffee but it's either the water at the Venetian, or a plot to drive me insane, but all the coffee in the Venetian Hotel drives me nuts.  

But, it beats the room service coffee, and every morning. I had a cup of Joe from this place.

For the coffee -  1 star.
The way I had it brought to me every morning while in Vegas by a wonderfully  considerate hunk of a man  - - I throw in an additional 2 stars... hence, the 3-star rating.  :-)

"Adequate retail establishment offering an extensive array of merchandise that I would indeed utilize. Notably advantageous reductions on comestibles. Well-organized physical space, albeit susceptible to disarray due to the presence of numerous patrons. The sole drawback I have encountered during my visits is the considerable delay incurred while waiting to complete my purchases. A protracted queue at the checkout counter is a minor inconvenience given the substantial economies realized. Prepare to devote approximately 15 minutes or more to conclude your transaction."

It is a clean place and they have good service. The Koi pond is pretty cool. The sandwich I ordered was pretty awful, don't get the turkey because it is like packaged meat you can buy at a supermarket. The prices were on par with other delis, but you can get a much better sandwich for the same price elsewhere.

I must admit that my expectations were not entirely met by this establishment, despite the favorable reviews and endorsements featured on its website. Specifically, I had envisioned a more engaging and flavorful encounter with a grill master who would not only possess a distinctive Philadelphia accent but also demonstrate a certain level of culinary expertise. However, my experience fell short of these expectations, as the individual responsible for preparing my order appeared to be somewhat hearing-impaired and neglected to include the onions that I had specifically requested.

The cheese steak itself was not particularly impressive, lacking the rich, savory flavors that I have come to associate with this dish. Although the meat was lean and not excessively oily, it was somewhat bland and failed to leave a lasting impression on my palate. The cheese whiz and bread were satisfactory, yet the absence of onions proved to be a significant detriment to my overall enjoyment of the dish. It is worth noting that, in the aftermath of consuming the cheese steak, I experienced some gastrointestinal discomfort, which may serve as an indicator of the quality of the ingredients used in its preparation. Nevertheless, I remain open to the possibility of revisiting this establishment in the future and comparing its offerings to those of its competitors in the area.

Cabo is a very busy place- even on a Tuesday night! Luckily we were a party of 2 and were seated pretty quick. The food tasted good and fresh, but I had very high expectations based on the reputation they have in Charlotte. I was hoping for a little more flavor.

Contrary to some of the other reviews, I didn't feel rushed even though they were jammin'. I went with a friend and we were catching up for quite a while, but our waitress was friendly and didn't rush us, which I appreciated. Parking can be difficult, like most places in NoDa, so plan to cruise around a little. 

Overall I think Cabo has a fun atmosphere for grabbing drinks and something to eat, but it isn't a "go out of your way" establishment.

We were on our way back from a trip to Mexico and Cuba* when we arrived here for a short layover. This airport is easy to navigate, especially when you are coming through immigration -- there are lots of signs telling you exactly where to go. 

There was a long line at immigration but it moved fairly quickly. My honey and I had all of our research license paperwork in order for the Cuba portion of our travels in case we were asked for it** but the not-even-a-hello immigration officer guy just scanned our passports, looked at us with his best stern face, and stamped us on our way. We then picked up our checked suitcases, zoomed right through customs (after handing over our customs form) and rechecked our bags. 

The part that ended up taking the longest amount of time was going back through security, thanks to long lines. I do have to say that the security personnel were working very hard to move everyone along and were really nice as well.

If we had more than 5 minutes to spare, I would have picked up some local BBQ to eat on our San Francisco bound flight. Thanks a lot, security line. 

*You won't hear much more about our trip to Mexico and Cuba since they don't have Yelp. (At least not yet.) I'll just summarize to say that almost everywhere we slept, ate, drank, visited, etc. were unquestionably five star. 

** Apparently Beyonce and Jay Z did as well. http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/09/entertainment-us-usa-cuba-beyonce-idUSBRE93600V20130409

This lodging establishment's external appearance exhibits visible signs of wear and tear, suggesting the need for a comprehensive renovation. The overall aesthetic of the hotel's facade and surrounding areas appears dated and fatigued. In contrast, the guest rooms have undergone updates, albeit inconsistent with the rest of the hotel's aspects, and feature cleanliness issues regarding tile grout in certain quarters. Despite this, the quality of the culinary offerings is surprisingly satisfactory, particularly for a hotel of this caliber. Additionally, the hotel boasts a well-stocked bar featuring an assortment of regional brews, complemented by personable and attentive service. While the hotel's location is reasonably convenient, it remains a considerable distance from the central attractions of the city, necessitating either a leisurely stroll or utilization of the complimentary shuttle service, courtesy of the accommodating and knowledgeable driver, Christian. Notwithstanding, accessibility via I-277 is relatively straightforward. Considering the cost, the experience proved to be adequate.

The restaurant is cozy and somewhat dark with a separate bar area and dining area. Service was quick and attentive. They have some different beers to experiment with and even let you sample some you're not familiar with before you commit. 


Food was OK but not great. I had half a turkey sandwich and salad. My turkey sandwich was a bit dry and bland and the salad was forgettable. As bars go and as bar food goes you could do much worse.

I have been eager to experience this establishment for an extended period of time, subsequent to hearing numerous favorable comments regarding its culinary offerings and perusing its menu. Upon further investigation, it has become apparent that the prices listed on the website are intentionally omitted, as the eatery in question charges exorbitant fees for its dishes.

Upon arriving at the restaurant, we opted to be seated on the patio, as the primary dining area was not yet open for seating at the time of our arrival (6:30 pm). Our server was quite attentive and hospitable, replacing my water glass promptly upon noticing that it contained an unidentifiable substance floating within. Additionally, my spouse's water glass was observed to be unclean, and she expediently provided a fresh glass for him as well.

She presented us with two minuscule sample-sized frozen peach and strawberry margaritas, which we found to be quite delectable. However, we did notice that the rocks margarita was not as impressive as the aforementioned samples. It is worth mentioning that no complementary chips and salsa were offered, which would have been acceptable had the restaurant provided some other form of appetizer or promotion, similar to that of Barrio. Furthermore, there was no happy hour available, much to our dismay.

The street corn served at this establishment was satisfactory, although I have certainly encountered superior renditions elsewhere. The butternut squash tacos, on the other hand, were truly exceptional. My spouse preferred them significantly over his mahi tacos. Nevertheless, I cannot fathom how this restaurant has managed to remain in operation given the exorbitant pricing of their dishes, including three miniature tacos (measuring only three inches in diameter) for the sum of $12. Moreover, they have the audacity to charge $12 for guacamole prepared from a mere two avocados. It is evident that this establishment relies heavily on the tourist trade, as I cannot imagine how they could possibly sustain themselves during the off-season.

"The positive aspects of this establishment include the provision of a magna doodle for young patrons to engage in creative expression, a courteous and attentive wait staff, a pristine dining environment owing to its recent opening, a diverse array of pasta options including whole wheat and rose sauce, the opportunity for patrons to personalize their pasta dishes with various toppings, karaoke amenities available on Friday and Saturday evenings, culinary offerings that are palatable, reasonable prices for those who refrain from adding supplementary toppings, and a distinctive dessert menu."
"However, there are several drawbacks to consider, such as the limited visibility of the children's menu, which is printed on the reverse side of the magna doodle, and the fact that kids' beverages are served in adult-sized to-go cups. Additionally, the cleanup process after a spill was quite sluggish, taking nearly 10 minutes to address my daughter's spilled milk. Furthermore, the menu selections are somewhat restricted, primarily consisting of pasta, pizza, and paninis, with limited variety in terms of entrees. Moreover, the cost of individual pasta toppings is $1.50 each, and my cannelloni dessert was disappointingly unremarkable."

We encountered an unwelcoming reception upon arriving at the entrance, whereupon the security personnel exhibited a discourteous demeanor, rendering it improbable that we would proceed any further had our celebratory companion not persistently advocated for our admittance.
Fun store if you are looking for Korean. To the poster that identified this store as Japanese, was wrong. Korean and Japanese foods are similar but not the same.

Red 8 is a pretty good americanized chinese food. I love the Oxtail soup along with their mongolian beef and rice.. The ambiance is really nice and the service is wonderful.
